Mark 15:0 <chapter osisID="Mark.15" sID="gen1727"/>
Mark 15:1 And as soon as ever it was light the chief priests holding a consultation with the elders and scribes, <transChange>they</transChange> and the whole sanhedrim, bound Jesus, and carried <transChange>Him</transChange> away, and delivered <transChange>Him</transChange> to Pilate.
Mark 15:2 And Pilate asked Him, Art thou the king of the Jews? and He answered <q marker="" who="Jesus"><transChange>It is as</transChange> thou sayst.</q>
Mark 15:3 And the chief priests accused Him of many <transChange>things:</transChange> but he answered nothing.
Mark 15:4 So Pilate asked Him again, saying, Dost thou answer nothing? See how many <transChange>things</transChange> they witness against thee:
Mark 15:5 but Jesus still answered nothing, so that Pilate was amazed.
Mark 15:6 Now at the feast he used to release to them one prisoner, whomsoever they desired:
Mark 15:7 and there was <transChange>one</transChange> Barabbas under confinement with <transChange>some of his</transChange> accomplices in sedition, who had committed murder in the insurrection.
Mark 15:8 And the people clamoured and desired <transChange>him to do</transChange> as he always used to do for them.
Mark 15:9 But Pilate answered them, saying, Would ye have me release to you the king of the Jews?
Mark 15:10 (for he knew that the chief priests had delivered Him up <transChange>to him</transChange> out of envy:)
Mark 15:11 but the chief priests incited the people <transChange>to desire</transChange> that he would rather release Barabbas to them.
Mark 15:12 And Pilate answered, and said to them again, What then would you have me do <transChange>with Him,</transChange> whom ye call king of the Jews?
Mark 15:13 And they cried out again, Crucify Him.
Mark 15:14 But Pilate said unto them, Why, what ill has He done? And they cried out the more vehemently, Crucify Him.
Mark 15:15 So Pilate being willing to ingratiate with the multitude, released Barabbas to them, and having scourged Jesus, delivered <transChange>Him</transChange> up to be crucified.
Mark 15:16 And the soldiers led Him away into the hall, which is <transChange>called</transChange> the Pretorium; and gathered their whole company together:
Mark 15:17 and they clad Him in purple, and platted a crown of thorns and put it on his head,
Mark 15:18 and saluted Him, <transChange>saying,</transChange> Hail king of the Jews;
Mark 15:19 and struck Him on the head with a reed, and spit upon Him, and bowed their knees, and did Him homage.
Mark 15:20 And when they had <transChange>thus</transChange> abused Him, they took off the purple from Him, and put his own clothes on Him, and brought Him out to crucify Him.
Mark 15:21 And they compel one Simon a Cyrenian, the father of Alexander and Rufus, <transChange>as he was</transChange> passing by, coming out of the country, to carry his cross:
Mark 15:22 and they brought Him to a place <transChange>called</transChange> Golgotha, which is, being interpreted, the place of a scull.
Mark 15:23 And they offered Him wine mingled with myrrh to drink, but He would not take <transChange>it.</transChange>
Mark 15:24 And when they had fastened Him to the cross, they parted his garments, casting lots upon them, what each <transChange>of them</transChange> should take.
Mark 15:25 And it was the third hour, when they fixed Him on the cross:
Mark 15:26 and the title of his charge was written over <transChange>Him,</transChange> THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Mark 15:27 And they crucified two thieves with Him, one on his right <transChange>hand</transChange> and one on his left:
Mark 15:28 so that the scripture was fulfilled, which saith, "And He was numbered with the transgressors."
Mark 15:29 And they that passed by reviled Him, shaking their heads and saying, Ah, thou that destroyest, the temple,
Mark 15:30 and buildest <transChange>it</transChange> in three days, save thyself and come down from the cross.
Mark 15:31 And the chief priests likewise scoffing <transChange>at Him</transChange> among themselves, with the scribes, said, He saved others, Himself He cannot save: let Christ,
Mark 15:32 the king of Israel, come down now from the cross, that we may see and believe <transChange>in Him.</transChange> And <transChange>even</transChange> they that were crucified with Him, reviled Him.
Mark 15:33 Now at the sixth hour there was darkness over the whole land, until the ninth hour.
Mark 15:34 And at the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, <q marker="" who="Jesus">"Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani,"</q> which is being interpreted, <q marker="" who="Jesus">My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?</q>
Mark 15:35 And some of them that stood by hearing <transChange>it,</transChange> said, Behold He calleth upon Elias.
Mark 15:36 And there ran one, and filled a spunge with vinegar, and putting <transChange>it</transChange> on a reed offered it Him to drink, saying, Let <transChange>Him</transChange> alone, let us see whether Elias will come to take Him down.
Mark 15:37 But Jesus cried with a loud voice and expired.
Mark 15:38 And the veil of the temple was rent in two from the top to the bottom.
Mark 15:39 And when the centurion, that stood over against Him, saw that He expired with such a cry, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God.
Mark 15:40 There were also women at a distance looking on: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James the less and of Joses, and Salome;
Mark 15:41 who also when He was in Galilee, followed Him and waited on Him: and several others who came up to Jerusalem with Him.
Mark 15:42 And the evening being now come, (because it was the preparation,
Mark 15:43 or the day before the sabbath,) Joseph of Arimathea, an honorable counsellor, who also was expecting the kingdom of God, came and went in boldly to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus.
Mark 15:44 But Pilate wondered that He was dead already, and <transChange>therefore</transChange> calling for the centurion he asked him if He had been dead any time:
Mark 15:45 and when he heard <transChange>it</transChange> from the centurion, he granted the body to Joseph.
Mark 15:46 And he bought fine linen, and took Him down, and wrapped Him in the linen, and laid Him in a sepulchre which was hewn out of a rock; and rolled a stone to the door of the sepulchre.
Mark 15:47 And Mary Magdalene, and Mary <transChange>the mother</transChange> of Joses observed where He was laid. <chapter eID="gen1727" osisID="Mark.15"/>
Mark 16:0 <chapter osisID="Mark.16" sID="gen1775"/>
Mark 16:1 And when the sabbath was past Mary Magdalene, and Mary <transChange>the mother</transChange> of James, and Salome, bought spices in order to come and embalm Him:
Mark 16:2 and very early in the morning of the first <transChange>day</transChange> of the week they come to the sepulchre at sun-rising.
Mark 16:3 And they said to one another, Who will roll away the stone for us from the door of the sepulchre?
Mark 16:4 (but when they looked up, they saw that the stone was rolled away,) for it was <transChange>a</transChange> very great <transChange>one.</transChange>
Mark 16:5 And they went into the sepulchre and saw a young man sitting on the right side, clothed in a long white robe; and they were affrighted:
Mark 16:6 but he said to them, Be not affrighted, ye seek Jesus of Nazareth, who was crucified, He is risen, He is not here, see the place where they laid Him.
Mark 16:7 But go, tell his disciples, and Peter <transChange>particularly,</transChange> that He is going before you into Galilee: there ye will see Him, as He told you.
Mark 16:8 And they hasted out and fled from the sepulchre; for they were seized with trembling and amazement: neither said they any thing to any one; for they were afraid.
Mark 16:9 Now <transChange>Jesus</transChange> being risen early on the first day of the week appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom He had cast out seven devils:
Mark 16:10 <transChange>and</transChange> she went and told those that used to be with Him, who were mourning and weeping;
Mark 16:11 but they, though they heard that He was <transChange>indeed</transChange> alive, and <transChange>had been</transChange> seen by her, did not believe <transChange>it.</transChange>
Mark 16:12 After this He appeared in another form to two of them <transChange>as they were</transChange> walking, going into the country:
Mark 16:13 and they went and told the rest; <transChange>but</transChange> they did not believe them neither.
Mark 16:14 At last he appeared to the eleven as they were sitting at table, and upbraided them with their unbelief, and hardness of heart; because they did not believe those who had seen Him after He was risen.

Luke 0:0 <div osisID="Luke" sID="gen1796" type="book"/>
Luke 1:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.1" sID="gen1797"/>
Luke 1:1 <hi type="bold">Whereas</hi> many have undertaken to compose a narrative of the things, which have been fully certified among us;
Luke 1:2 as they delivered them to us, who were from the beginning eye-witnesses <transChange>of them,</transChange> and ministers of the word;
Luke 1:3 it seemed good to me also, having thoroughly traced <transChange>them</transChange> all from the <transChange>very</transChange> first, to write <transChange>an account of them</transChange> in order to thee,
Luke 1:4 most excellent Theophilus, that thou mayst know the certainty of the things wherein thou hast been instructed.
Luke 1:5 There was in the days of Herod king of Judea, a certain priest named Zacharias, of the course of Abia; and his wife <transChange>was</transChange> of the family of Aaron, and her name <transChange>was</transChange> Elisabeth.
Luke 1:6 And they were both righteous in the sight of God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless.
Luke 1:7 And they had no child, for Elisabeth was barren; and they were both far advanced in years.
Luke 1:8 And it came to pass, while he was in the order of his course performing the priest's office before God,
Luke 1:9 according to the custom of <transChange>dividing</transChange> the office of the priests, <transChange>that</transChange> it fell to his lot to burn incense, entring into the temple of the Lord:
Luke 1:10 and all the people were praying without at the time of offering incense.
Luke 1:11 And there appeared to him an angel of the Lord standing on the right <transChange>hand</transChange> of the altar of incense.
Luke 1:12 And when Zacharias saw <transChange>him,</transChange> he was startled and struck with fear:
Luke 1:13 but the angel said unto him, Fear not, Zacharias; for thy prayer is heard, and thy wife Elisabeth shall bear thee a son, and thou shalt call his name John:
Luke 1:14 and he shall be a joy and transport to thee, yea, many shall rejoice on account of his birth; for he shall be great in the sight of the Lord,
Luke 1:15 and he shall drink neither wine nor <transChange>any other</transChange> strong liquor; and he shall be filled with the holy Spirit even from his birth;
Luke 1:16 and many of the children of Israel shall he convert unto the Lord their God.
Luke 1:17 And he shall go before Him in the spirit and power of Elias, to turn the hearts of the fathers unto the children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just, to prepare for the Lord a people <transChange>well</transChange>-disposed.
Luke 1:18 And Zacharias said unto the angel, Whereby shall I know this? for I am an old man, and my wife far advanced in years.
Luke 1:19 And the angel answering said to him, I am Gabriel, that stand in the presence of God, and <transChange>I</transChange> am sent to speak to thee, and to tell thee this good news:
Luke 1:20 and now shalt thou be dumb, and not able to speak, until the day that these things shall come to pass; because thou believedst not my words, which shall be fulfilled at their season.
Luke 1:21 And the people were waiting for Zacharias, and wondered at his staying <transChange>so</transChange> long in the temple:
Luke 1:22 but when he came out he could not speak to them, and they perceived that he had seen a vision in the temple; and he made signs to them, and continued speechless:
Luke 1:23 and as soon as the days of his ministration were accomplished, he departed to his own house.
Luke 1:24 And after these days his wife Elisabeth conceived, and retired five months,
Luke 1:25 saying, the Lord hath thus dealt with me in the days wherein he looked upon <transChange>me</transChange> to take away my reproach among men.
Luke 1:26 But in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent by God to a city of Galilee called Nazareth,
Luke 1:27 to a virgin <transChange>who was</transChange> betrothed to a man, whose name <transChange>was</transChange> Joseph, of the house of David; and the name of the virgin <transChange>was</transChange> Mary.
Luke 1:28 And when the angel came in <transChange>to the room</transChange> to her, he said, Hail, <transChange>thou that art</transChange> highly favoured; the Lord <transChange>is</transChange> with thee;
Luke 1:29 blessed <transChange>art</transChange> thou among women! and when she saw <transChange>him,</transChange> she was confused at what he said, and pondered in her mind what sort of salutation this could be.
Luke 1:30 And the angel said unto her, Fear not, Mary; for thou hast found favor with God:
Luke 1:31 and behold thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and shalt bring forth a son, and shalt call his name JESUS:
Luke 1:32 He shall be great, and shall be called the Son of the Most High, and the Lord God shall give Him the throne of David his father,
Luke 1:33 and He shall reign over the house of Jacob for ever, and of his kingdom there shall be no end.
Luke 1:34 Then said Mary to the angel, How can this be, since I am a virgin?
Luke 1:35 And the angel answered and said unto her, The holy Spirit shall come upon thee, and the power of the Most High shall overshadow thee, and therefore <transChange>thine</transChange> holy offspring shall be called the Son of God: and lo,
Luke 1:36 thy cousin Elisabeth also hath conceived a son in her old age, and this is the sixth month with her that was called barren;
Luke 1:37 for nothing is impossible with God.
Luke 1:38 Then Mary said, Behold the servant of the Lord, may it be unto me according to thy word. So the angel departed from her.
Luke 1:39 Then Mary arose and went with speed into the hill-<transChange>country,</transChange> to a city of Juda,
Luke 1:40 and came into the house of Zacharias, and saluted Elisabeth.
Luke 1:41 And as soon as Elisabeth heard the salutation of Mary, the child leaped in her womb, and Elisabeth was filled with the holy Spirit:
Luke 1:42 and she cried out with a loud voice, and said, Blessed <transChange>art</transChange> thou among women, and blessed <transChange>is</transChange> the fruit of thy womb:
Luke 1:43 and whence <transChange>is</transChange> this <transChange>honor</transChange> to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?

Luke 1:46 And Mary said, "My soul doth magnify the Lord, and my spirit hath rejoiced in God my Saviour;
Luke 1:47 for He hath regarded the low estate of his handmaid:
Luke 1:48 for behold, from henceforth shall all generations call me blessed:
Luke 1:49 for He that is mighty hath done great things for me,
Luke 1:50 and his name <transChange>is</transChange> holy, and his mercy <transChange>is</transChange> on them that fear Him, unto all generations.
Luke 1:51 He hath wrought powerfully with his arm; He hath confounded <transChange>those that were</transChange> proud in the imagination of their heart.
Luke 1:52 He hath cast down the mighty from <transChange>their</transChange> thrones, and exalted the humble.
Luke 1:53 He hath filled the hungry with good <transChange>things,</transChange> and the rich He hath sent away empty.
Luke 1:54 He hath supported Israel his servant,

Luke 1:56 And Mary stayed with her about three months, and <transChange>then</transChange> returned to her own house.
Luke 1:57 Now when Elisabeth's time for her delivery was fully come, she brought forth a son:
Luke 1:58 and her neighbours and kindred heard that the Lord had magnified his mercy towards her, and they congratulated her;
Luke 1:59 and on the eighth day they came to circumcise the child: and they <transChange>would have</transChange> called him Zacharias, after the name of his father:
Luke 1:60 but his mother said, No, but he shall be called John:
Luke 1:61 and they said to her, There is none of thy relations of this name.

Luke 1:64 And his mouth was opened immediately, and his tongue <transChange>loosed,</transChange> and he spake and praised God.

Luke 2:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.2" sID="gen1878"/>
Luke 2:1 Now in those days an edict was published by Augustus Cesar, that all the world should be enrolled <transChange>or taxed,</transChange>
Luke 2:2 (this tax was first levied when Cyrenius was governor of Syria) and they all went to be enrolled,
Luke 2:3 every one to his own city:
Luke 2:4 so Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judea to the city of David, which is called Bethlehem (because he
Luke 2:5 was of the house and line of David) to be enrolled with Mary his espoused wife, who was big with child.
Luke 2:6 And while they were there, the days of her delivery were fulfilled,
Luke 2:7 and she brought forth her son, the first-born, and wrapped him in swaddling cloths, and laid him in a manger; because there was no room for them in the inn.
Luke 2:8 And there were in the same country shepherds out in the fields, keeping watch over their flock by night: and lo,
Luke 2:9 an angel of the Lord stood over them, and the glory of the Lord shone round them, and they were greatly terrified:
Luke 2:10 and the angel said to them, Be not affrighted; for behold I bring you good tidings of great joy which shall be to all people,
Luke 2:11 that this day is born, in the city of David, your Saviour Christ the Lord.
Luke 2:12 And this <transChange>shall be</transChange> a sign to you, Ye shall find the child wrapped in swaddling bands lying in a manger.
Luke 2:13 And on a sudden there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host,
Luke 2:14 praising God, and saying, Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good-will towards men.
Luke 2:15 And when the angels went from them into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, Let us go to Bethlehem, and see this which hath been told <transChange>us,</transChange> which the Lord hath made known unto us.
Luke 2:16 And they came with speed, and found both Mary and Joseph, and the child lying in the manger:
Luke 2:17 and when they had seen <transChange>it,</transChange> they divulged what had been told them concerning this child:
Luke 2:18 and all that heard <transChange>it,</transChange> were amazed at the things which were related to them by the shepherds.
Luke 2:19 But Mary treasured up all these words, pondering <transChange>them</transChange> in her heart.
Luke 2:20 And the shepherds returned glorifying and praising God for all <transChange>the things</transChange> which they had heard and seen, according as <transChange>it</transChange> had been told unto them.
Luke 2:21 And when eight days were fulfilled for the circumcising of the child, his name was called JESUS, having been <transChange>so</transChange> called by the angel before He was conceived in the womb.
Luke 2:22 And when the days of her purification according to the law of Moses were fulfilled, they brought Him to Jerusalem to present <transChange>Him</transChange> before the Lord:
Luke 2:23 (as it is written in the law of the Lord, That every male that openeth the womb shall be called holy to the Lord:) and to offer a sacrifice,
Luke 2:24 according to what is required in the law of the Lord, a pair of turtle-doves or two young pigeons.
Luke 2:25 And there was a man at Jerusalem, whose name <transChange>was</transChange> Simeon, and he <transChange>was</transChange> a just and a religious man, who expected the consolation of Israel; and the holy Spirit was upon him.
Luke 2:26 And it was revealed to him by the holy Spirit, that he should not die before he had seen the Anointed of the Lord.
Luke 2:27 And he came by <transChange>the influence of</transChange> the Spirit into the temple, as <transChange>his</transChange> parents brought in the child Jesus to do concerning Him according to the custom of the law:
Luke 2:28 and he took Him into his arms,
Luke 2:29 and blessed God, and said, "Now, Lord, thou dismissest thy servant in peace, according to thy word;
Luke 2:30 for mine eyes have seen thy salvation, which thou hast provided in the sight of all people,
Luke 2:31 a light for the enlightening of the Gentiles,
Luke 2:32 and the glory of thy people Israel."
Luke 2:33 And Joseph and his mother were amazed at the things that were spoken concerning Him.
Luke 2:34 And Simeon blessed them, and said to Mary his mother, Behold, this <transChange>child</transChange> is appointed for the fall and rising again of many in Israel, and for a sign <transChange>which shall be</transChange> spoken against,
Luke 2:35 (and a sword shall pierce through thy own soul also) that the thoughts of many hearts may be discovered.
Luke 2:36 And there was <transChange>one</transChange> Anna, a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aser; who was of a great age, having lived with a husband seven years from her first marrying,
Luke 2:37 and <transChange>had been</transChange> a widow about eighty four years; who departed not from the temple; serving <transChange>God</transChange> with fastings and prayers night and day.
Luke 2:38 And coming in at the very same time, gave thanks unto the Lord, and spake of Him to all that were looking for redemption in Jerusalem.
Luke 2:39 And when they had performed all things according to the law of the Lord, they returned into Galilee, to their own city Nazareth.
Luke 2:40 And the child grew, and became strong in spirit, being filled with wisdom; and the grace of God was upon Him.
Luke 2:41 Now his parents went every year to Jerusalem at the feast of the passover:
Luke 2:42 and when He was twelve years old, going up to Jerusalem, as usual at the feast, and having finished the time,
Luke 2:43 when they returned, the child Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem: and Joseph and his mother did not know <transChange>it;</transChange>
Luke 2:44 but supposing Him to be in the company, went a day's journey, and <transChange>then</transChange> sought for Him among their kindred and acquaintance:
Luke 2:45 and not finding Him they returned to Jerusalem seeking for Him:
Luke 2:46 and after three days they found Him in the temple, sitting in the midst of the doctors, attending to them and asking them questions.
Luke 2:47 And all that heard Him were astonished at his understanding and <transChange>his</transChange> answers.
Luke 2:48 And when they saw Him, they were amazed. And his mother said to Him, Son, why didst thou deal thus with us? behold, thy father and I with grief have been seeking for thee.
Luke 2:49 And He said to them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Why did ye <transChange>so</transChange> seek me? Did not ye know that I ought to be in my Father's <transChange>house?</transChange></q>
Luke 2:50 but they did not understand the word which He spake to them.
Luke 2:51 Then He went down with them, and came to Nazareth, and was subject to them. And his mother kept all these sayings in her heart.

Luke 3:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.3" sID="gen1931"/>
Luke 3:1 Now in the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Cesar, when Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, and Herod tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip tetrarch of Iturea and Trachonitis,
Luke 3:2 and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene, Annas and Caiaphas being high priests, the word of God came unto John the Son of Zacharias in the wilderness:
Luke 3:3 and he went into all the country about Jordan, preaching the baptism of repentance in order to the remission of sins;
Luke 3:4 as it is written in the book of Esaias the prophet, saying, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare <transChange>ye</transChange> the way of the Lord, make his paths straight:
Luke 3:5 every valley shall be raised, and every mountain and hill shall be lowered, and the crooked <transChange>ways</transChange> shall be made straight, and the rough ways smooth:
Luke 3:6 and all men shall see the salvation of God."
Luke 3:7 Therefore said he to the multitudes that came to be baptised by him, <transChange>O</transChange> generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
Luke 3:8 Bring forth therefore fruits becoming penitents, and do not say within yourselves, "We have Abraham for our father," for I tell you that God can of these stones raise up children to Abraham.
Luke 3:9 And now the ax is laid to the root of the trees: every tree therefore which doth not yield good fruit, is cut down and cast into the fire.
Luke 3:10 And the people asked him, saying, What shall we do then?
Luke 3:11 And he saith unto them, Let him that hath two coats, give <transChange>one</transChange> to him that hath none, and let him that hath food do the like.
Luke 3:12 And there came publicans to be baptized, and said unto him, Master, what shall we do?
Luke 3:13 And He said unto them, Exact no more than <transChange>what</transChange> is appointed you.
Luke 3:14 And the soldiers also asked him, saying, And what shall we do? and He said unto them, Do violence to no man, neither accuse <transChange>any</transChange> falsely, and be content with your pay.
Luke 3:15 Now as the people were in suspense, and were all thinking in their hearts concerning John, whether he were the Christ <transChange>or not,</transChange>

Luke 3:17 whose fan is in his hand, and He will thoroughly cleanse his floor, and will gather the wheat into his granary, but will burn up the chaff in unquenchable fire.

Luke 4:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.4" sID="gen1970"/>
Luke 4:1 Now Jesus being full of the holy Spirit, returned from Jordan, and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness, being forty days tempted by the devil;
Luke 4:2 and He did eat nothing in <transChange>all</transChange> those days: and when they were ended, at last He was hungry.
Luke 4:3 And the devil said to Him, If thou art the Son of God, command this stone to become bread.
Luke 4:4 And Jesus answered him, saying, <q marker="" who="Jesus">It is written, that man shall not live by bread only, but on every word of God.</q>
Luke 4:5 And the devil taking Him up into an high mountain, shewed Him all the kingdoms of the world in an instant,
Luke 4:6 and said to Him, All this power will I give thee, and the glory of them: for it is committed to me, and I give it to whomsoever I will.
Luke 4:7 Therefore, if thou wilt <transChange>but</transChange> worship me, <transChange>they</transChange> all shall be thine.
Luke 4:8 And Jesus answering him said <transChange>with indignation,</transChange> <q marker="" who="Jesus">Get thee behind me, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve.</q>
Luke 4:9 And he brought Him to Jerusalem, and set him on a battlement of the temple, and said to Him, If thou art the Son of God, cast thyself down from hence;
Luke 4:10 for it is written, He shall give his angels charge concerning thee,
Luke 4:11 to keep thee, and they shall bear thee up in <transChange>their</transChange> hands, least thou dash thy foot against a stone.
Luke 4:12 And Jesus answered him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">it is said, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.</q>
Luke 4:13 And when the devil had ended all the temptation, he departed from Him for a time.
Luke 4:14 And Jesus returned by the influence of the Spirit into Galilee: and a fame was spread through all the country round about concerning Him:
Luke 4:15 and He taught in their synagogues with universal applause.
Luke 4:16 And He came to Nazareth, where He had been brought up: and according to his custom He went into the synagogue on the sabbath-day, and stood up to read.
Luke 4:17 And there was delivered to Him the book of the prophet Esaias; and opening the book, He found the place where it was written,
Luke 4:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">"The spirit of the Lord <transChange>is</transChange> upon me <transChange>to the end,</transChange> for which He hath anointed me: He hath sent me to publish good tidings to the poor, to heal the broken-hearted, to proclaim deliverance to the captives, and recovery of sight to the blind, to release them that are bruised,</q>
Luke 4:19 <q marker="" who="Jesus"><transChange>and</transChange> to preach the acceptable year of the Lord."</q>
Luke 4:20 And He folded up the book, and gave <transChange>it</transChange> again to the minister, and sat down: and the eyes of all in the synagogue were fixed upon Him.
Luke 4:21 And He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">this day is this scripture fulfilled in your ears.</q>
Luke 4:22 And they all bare witness to Him, and wondered at the gracefulness of the words, which proceeded from his mouth, and said, Is not this the son of Joseph?
Luke 4:23 And He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">No doubt ye will apply to me this proverb, "Physician, cure thyself, and do here in thy own country what we have heard <transChange>were</transChange> done at Capernaum."</q>
Luke 4:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But,</q> said He, <q marker="" who="Jesus">indeed I <transChange>must</transChange> tell you, that no prophet is <transChange>well</transChange> received in his own country.</q>
Luke 4:25 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And I assure you, there were many widows in Israel, in the days of Elias, when the heaven was shut up for three years and six months, and there was a great famine through all the land;</q>
Luke 4:26 <q marker="" who="Jesus">but Elias was sent to none of those <transChange>widows,</transChange> but to a widow-woman at Sarepta <transChange>in the territory</transChange> of Sidon.</q>
Luke 4:27 <q marker="" who="Jesus">There were also many lepers in Israel, in the time of Elisha the prophet, and none of them was cleansed; but Naaman the Syrian <transChange>was.</transChange></q>
Luke 4:28 And all the synagogue were filled with rage, when they heard these <transChange>things,</transChange>
Luke 4:29 and they rose up and drove Him out of the city, and dragged Him to the brow of the hill, on which their city was built, in order to throw Him down the precipice.
Luke 4:30 But He passed through the midst of them, and went away.
Luke 4:31 And He came down to Capernaum a city of Galilee, and taught them on the sabbath-days,
Luke 4:32 and they were astonished at his doctrine; for He spake with authority.
Luke 4:33 And there was a man in the synagogue possessed by the spirit of an impure demon, and he cried out with a loud voice,
Luke 4:34 saying, Let us alone, what hast thou to do with us, Jesus of Nazareth? art thou come to destroy us? I know who thou art, the holy <transChange>one</transChange> of God:
Luke 4:35 but Jesus rebuked him, saying, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Be silent, and come out of him.</q> And the demon threw him <transChange>down</transChange> in the midst <transChange>of the assembly,</transChange> and came out of him, having done him no hurt.
Luke 4:36 And they were all amazed, and said one to another, What a speech is this? for with authority and power He commandeth the impure spirits, and they come out!
Luke 4:37 And his fame spread all over the country round about.
Luke 4:38 And He rose up <transChange>and went</transChange> out of the synagogue, and came into the house of Simon: now Simon's wife's mother had a violent fever, and they intreated Him on her behalf.
Luke 4:39 And he stood over her, and rebuked the fever, and <transChange>it</transChange> left her: and immediately she arose and waited upon them.
Luke 4:40 And at sun-set all that had <transChange>any persons</transChange> sick of any diseases, brought them to Him: and He laid his hands on every one of them and healed them.
Luke 4:41 And demons also came out from many, crying out, Thou art the Messiah the Son of God. And He rebuked <transChange>them,</transChange> and suffered them not to say, that they knew Him to be the Christ.
Luke 4:42 And when the day was coming on, He went out and retired into a solitary place; and the people sought for Him, and came to Him, and <transChange>would fain have</transChange> detained Him, that He might not go from them.
Luke 4:43 But He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I must preach the kingdom of God to other cities also: for therefore am I sent.</q>

Luke 5:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.5" sID="gen2015"/>
Luke 5:1 And when the people were pressing on Him to hear the word of God, as He stood by the lake of Gennesareth, seeing two vessels at <transChange>the edge of</transChange> the lake,
Luke 5:2 (but the fishermen were gone out of them, and were washing <transChange>their</transChange> nets:)
Luke 5:3 He went into one of them, which was Simon's, and desired him to put off a little <transChange>way</transChange> from the shore: and He sat down and taught the multitudes from the ship.
Luke 5:4 And when He had done speaking, He said to Simon, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Put out into the deep, and let down your nets for a draught.</q>
Luke 5:5 And Simon answered and said unto Him, Master, we have been toiling all the night, and have caught nothing; however at thy word I will cast the net.
Luke 5:6 And when they had done this, they inclosed a multitude of fishes; and their net was breaking.
Luke 5:7 And they beckoned to <transChange>their</transChange> partners <transChange>that were</transChange> in the other ship, to come and help them; and they came, and filled both the ships, so that they were <transChange>even</transChange> sinking: and when Simon Peter saw <transChange>it,</transChange>
Luke 5:8 he fell at the knees of Jesus, saying, Lord, depart from me, for I am a sinful man;
Luke 5:9 for he was astonished, and all <transChange>that were</transChange> with him, at the draught of fishes which they had taken;
Luke 5:10 as were also James and John, the sons of Zebedee, who were partners with Simon. And Jesus said to Simon, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Be not afraid, from henceforth thou shalt be a captor of men.</q>
Luke 5:11 And when they had brought their ships to land, they left all and followed Him.
Luke 5:12 And when He was in one of the cities <transChange>of that country,</transChange> behold a man full of leprosy: who seeing Jesus, fell prostrate <transChange>to Him,</transChange> and besought Him, saying, Lord, if thou wilt, thou canst cleanse me.
Luke 5:13 And <transChange>Jesus</transChange> stretched out his hand and touched him, saying, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I will; be thou cleansed:</q> and immediately the leprosy departed from him.
Luke 5:14 And He charged him to tell no one: <q marker="" who="Jesus">but go,</q> <transChange>said He,</transChange> <q marker="" who="Jesus">and shew thyself to the priest, and offer for thy cleansing according as Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.</q>
Luke 5:15 But the fame of Him spread more <transChange>and more,</transChange> and great multitudes came together to hear, and to be healed by Him of their infirmities.
Luke 5:16 But He <transChange>frequently</transChange> retired into solitary places, and prayed.
Luke 5:17 And one day, as He was teaching, there were pharisees and doctors of the law sitting by, who were come out of every town of Galilee, and Judea, and <transChange>from</transChange> Jerusalem; and the power of the Lord was <transChange>present</transChange> to heal the people:
Luke 5:18 and behold, <transChange>some</transChange> men bringing on a couch a man that was paralytic; and they endeavoured to bring him in, and lay <transChange>him</transChange> before Him:
Luke 5:19 but when they could not find what <transChange>way</transChange> to bring him in because of the croud, they went up on <transChange>the battlements of</transChange> the house, and let him down from the roof with <transChange>his</transChange> couch, into the midst before Jesus,
Luke 5:20 who seeing their faith said unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Man, thy sins are forgiven thee.</q>
Luke 5:21 And the scribes and pharisees began to cavil, saying, Who is this that talketh blasphemies? Who can forgive sins but God?
Luke 5:22 but Jesus knowing their thoughts, answered and said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">What are ye disputing in your hearts?</q>
Luke 5:23 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Which is easier, to say, Thy sins are forgiven thee, or to say, Rise up and walk?</q>
Luke 5:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">but that ye may know, that the Son of man hath power <transChange>even</transChange> on earth to forgive sins,</q> (He spake to the paralytic) <q marker="" who="Jesus">I say unto thee, Arise, and take up thy couch, and go to thine house.</q>
Luke 5:25 And immediately he rose up before them, took up <transChange>the bed</transChange> on which he lay, and went away to his house, glorifying God.
Luke 5:26 And they were all amazed and glorified God, and were filled with awe, saying, we have seen wonderful <transChange>things</transChange> to-day.
Luke 5:27 After these <transChange>things</transChange> He went out and saw a publican named Levi, sitting at the custom-<transChange>house,</transChange> and said to him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Follow me:</q>
Luke 5:28 and he left all, rose up, and followed Him.
Luke 5:29 And Levi made Him a great feast in his own house: and there was a great number of publicans, and others at table with them.
Luke 5:30 And their scribes and pharisees murmured at his disciples, saying, Why do ye eat and drink with publicans and sinners?
Luke 5:31 And Jesus answered and said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">They that are in health have no need of a physician, but they that are sick: I am not come to call the righteous,</q>
Luke 5:32 <q marker="" who="Jesus">but sinners to repentance.</q>
Luke 5:33 And they said unto Him, Why do the disciples of John frequently fast and pray, and likewise those of the pharisees; but thine eat and drink?
Luke 5:34 And He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Can ye make those of the bride-chamber fast, while the bridegroom is with them?</q>
Luke 5:35 <q marker="" who="Jesus">but the days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken from them, then they will fast.</q>
Luke 5:36 Then He spake a parable to them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">That no one putteth a piece of new cloth upon an old garment: otherwise, the new maketh a rent, and doth not match the old:</q>
Luke 5:37 <q marker="" who="Jesus">nor doth any one put new wine in to old vessels; otherwise, the new wine will burst the casks, and be spilled, and the vessels will be destroyed:</q>
Luke 5:38 <q marker="" who="Jesus">but new wine must be put into new vessels, and <transChange>then</transChange> both are saved.</q>
Luke 5:39 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And no one that has been drinking old <transChange>wine,</transChange> immediately desireth new; for he saith, the old is better.</q> <chapter eID="gen2015" osisID="Luke.5"/>

Luke 6:3 And Jesus answering them said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Have ye not read what David did, when <transChange>he</transChange> himself was hungry and those that were with him? how he went into the house of God,</q>

Luke 7:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.7" sID="gen2105"/>
Luke 7:1 Now when He had finished his discourse in the audience of the people, He entered into Capernaum: and a certain centurion's servant,
Luke 7:2 whom he had a great value for, was ill and ready to die;
Luke 7:3 and having heard of Jesus, he sent unto Him the elders of the Jews, beseeching him that He would come and heal his servant.
Luke 7:4 And when they came to Jesus, they intreated Him earnestly, saying, he is worthy of this favor:
Luke 7:5 for he loveth our nation, and hath built us a synagogue.
Luke 7:6 So Jesus went with them. And when He was now not far from the house, the centurion sent <transChange>some of his</transChange> friends to Him, saying Lord, trouble not thyself, for I am not worthy that thou shouldst enter under my roof:
Luke 7:7 neither did I think myself worthy to come unto thee. But speak the word, and my servant will be recovered.
Luke 7:8 For I also am a man placed under <transChange>the</transChange> authority <transChange>of others,</transChange> and have soldiers under me; and I say to one, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doth <transChange>it.</transChange>

Luke 8:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.8" sID="gen2156"/>
Luke 8:1 And it came to pass afterwards that He went through every city and village, preaching and declaring the good tidings of the kingdom of God: and the twelve <transChange>were</transChange> with Him;
Luke 8:2 and some women that had been cured of evil spirits and <transChange>other</transChange> infirmities, <transChange>as</transChange> Mary Magdalene, out of whom were cast seven demons,
Luke 8:3 and Joanna the wife of Chuza Herod's steward, and Susanna, and many others, who assisted Him with their substance.
Luke 8:4 And when a great multitude was gathered together, of those that came to Him out of every city, He spake a parable <transChange>saying,</transChange>
Luke 8:5 <q marker="" who="Jesus">A sower went out to sow his seed, and as he was sowing, some fell by the way-<transChange>side,</transChange> and was trodden down, and the birds of the air devoured it.</q>
Luke 8:6 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And some fell upon stony ground, and as soon as it sprung up, it withered away, because it had no moisture.</q>
Luke 8:7 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And some fell among thorns, and the thorns sprang up with <transChange>it</transChange> and choked it.</q>
Luke 8:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But some fell on good ground, and sprang up and yielded fruit an hundred-fold.</q> And as He said these things He cried out, <q marker="" who="Jesus">"He that hath ears to hear, let him hear."</q>
Luke 8:9 And his disciples asked Him, what might be <transChange>the meaning of</transChange> this parable.
Luke 8:10 And He said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">To you it is granted to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God: but <transChange>I</transChange> <transChange>speak</transChange> to others in parables, that <transChange>in</transChange> seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand.</q>
Luke 8:11 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Now this is <transChange>the meaning of</transChange> the parable, The seed is the word of God:</q>
Luke 8:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and those by the way-<transChange>side,</transChange> are such as hear <transChange>indeed; but</transChange> then the devil cometh and taketh away the word from their hearts, least they should believe and be saved.</q>
Luke 8:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And those on stony-ground <transChange>are</transChange> such as when they hear, receive the word with joy; but have no root, and <transChange>so</transChange> believe <transChange>only</transChange> for a while, and in <transChange>the</transChange> time of trial fall away.</q>
Luke 8:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And that which fell among thorns, are those who when they have heard <transChange>the word</transChange> go away and are choked with <transChange>the</transChange> cares and riches, and pleasures of life, and bring no fruit to perfection.</q>
Luke 8:15 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But that on the good ground, are those who having heard the word, retain <transChange>it</transChange> in a good and honest heart, and bring forth fruit with patience.</q>
Luke 8:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">No man when he hath lighted a candle covereth it with a vessel, or putteth it under a couch; but setteth it on a candlestick, that they who come in may see the light.</q>

Luke 9:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.9" sID="gen2213"/>
Luke 9:1 And He called his twelve disciples together, and gave them power and authority over all demons, and to cure diseases:
Luke 9:2 and He sent them forth to preach the kingdom of God, and to heal the sick.
Luke 9:3 And He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Take nothing for <transChange>your</transChange> journey, neither staves, nor bag, nor bread, nor money; nor two coats a piece.</q>
Luke 9:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And into whatever house ye enter, continue there, till ye leave that place.</q>

Luke 9:6 And they went from town to town, preaching the gospel and healing every where.
Luke 9:7 Now Herod the tetrarch heard of all <transChange>the things</transChange> that were done by Him; and was perplexed, because it was said by some that John was risen from the dead;
Luke 9:8 and by some that Elias had appeared; and by others, that one of the ancient prophets was risen again.
Luke 9:9 And Herod said, John have I beheaded: but who is this, of whom I hear such <transChange>things?</transChange> and he wanted to see Him.

Luke 9:11 But when the people knew it they followed Him; and He received them, and spake to them concerning the kingdom of God, and healed those that had need of a cure.
Luke 9:12 And when the day began to decline, the twelve came and said to Him, Dismiss the people, that they may go into the villages and country-places round about, and bait, and get food: for here we are in a desert place.
Luke 9:13 But He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Do ye give them food.</q> And they said, We have but five loaves and two fishes: unless we should go and buy provisions for all this people:
Luke 9:14 for they were about five thousand men. And He said to his disciples, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Make them sit down <transChange>in</transChange> companies by fifty.</q>
Luke 9:15 And they did so, and caused them all to sit down.

Luke 9:17 And they did eat, and were all satisfied: and there was taken up what remained <transChange>even</transChange> of fragments twelve baskets.

Luke 12:3 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Therefore whatsoever ye have said in darkness shall be heard in the light: and what ye have spoken in the ear in closets shall be proclaimed on the house-tops.</q>
Luke 12:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Now I say unto you, my friends, Be not afraid of them, that <transChange>can only</transChange> kill the body, and after that have nothing more that they can do.</q>
Luke 12:5 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But I will shew you whom ye should fear,---Fear Him, who after He hath killed, hath power to cast into hell; yea, I say unto you, fear Him.</q>
Luke 12:6 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Are not five sparrows sold for two assaries, and not one of them is forgotten before God.</q>
Luke 12:7 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Nay the very hairs of your head are all numbered. Be not therefore afraid; ye are of more worth than many sparrows.</q>

Luke 13:1 There were present at the same time, some that told Him of the Galileans, whose blood Pilate <transChange>had</transChange> mingled with their sacrifices.

Luke 14:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.14" sID="gen2470"/>
Luke 14:1 And as He went into the house of one of the chief of the pharisees to eat on the sabbath-<transChange>day,</transChange> and they were watching Him,
Luke 14:2 behold, there was a certain man before Him that had a dropsy.
Luke 14:3 And Jesus spake to the expounders of the law and <transChange>to the</transChange> pharisees, saying, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Is it lawful to heal on the sabbath-<transChange>day?</transChange></q>
Luke 14:4 but they made no answer. And He took <transChange>him</transChange> and healed him, and sent <transChange>him</transChange> away:
Luke 14:5 and said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Which of you shall have an ass or an ox fall into a pit, and will not immediately draw him out <transChange>even</transChange> on the sabbath-day?</q>
Luke 14:6 and they were not able to answer Him again to these <transChange>things.</transChange>
Luke 14:7 And He spake a parable to those that were invited, observing how they chose the chief seats, saying unto them,
Luke 14:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">When thou art invited by any <transChange>one</transChange> to a wedding, do not sit down in the uppermost place, least <transChange>one</transChange> more honorable than thou be invited by him;</q>
Luke 14:9 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and he who invited thee and him, should come and say to thee, Give place to this <transChange>person,</transChange> and then thou begin with shame to take the lowest place.</q>
Luke 14:10 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But when thou art invited, go and sit down at the lowest place, that, when he who invited thee cometh, he may say to thee, Friend, go up higher: then wilt thou have honor before them that sit at table with thee:</q>
Luke 14:11 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for whosoever exalteth himself shall be humbled, and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted.</q>
Luke 14:12 He said also to him that had invited Him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">When thou makest a dinner or a supper, do not invite thy friends, nor thy brethren, nor thy kindred, nor <transChange>thy</transChange> rich neighbors; least they invite thee again, and <transChange>so</transChange> a return be made thee.</q>
Luke 14:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But when thou makest a feast, invite the poor, the maimed, the lame, the blind; and thou shalt be happy;</q>
Luke 14:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">because they have not <transChange>wherewith</transChange> to requite thee: for a recompense shall be given thee at the resurrection of the just.</q>
Luke 14:15 And one of those; who sat at table with <transChange>Him,</transChange> hearing these <transChange>things,</transChange> said unto Him, Happy <transChange>is</transChange> he that shall eat bread in the kingdom of God.
Luke 14:16 Upon which He said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">A certain man made a great supper and invited many;</q>

Luke 14:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And they all with one <transChange>consent</transChange> began to make excuses; the first said, I have bought a field, and I must go and see it, pray have me excused.</q>
Luke 14:19 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And another said, I have bought five yoke of oxen, and am going to try them, pray have me excused.</q>
Luke 14:20 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And another said, I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.</q>
Luke 14:21 <q marker="" who="Jesus">So the servant came and told his lord these <transChange>things.</transChange> Then the master of the house being angry said to his servant, Go directly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in hither the poor, and the maimed, and the lame, and the blind.</q>
Luke 14:22 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And the servant said, Sir, it is done according to thine order, and still there is room.</q>

Luke 14:25 Now there were great multitudes going along with Him:

Luke 14:32 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and if not, while he is yet far off, he sendeth an embassy, and desireth <transChange>conditions of</transChange> peace.</q>

Luke 15:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.15" sID="gen2506"/>
Luke 15:1 Then drew near unto Him all the publicans and <transChange>other notorious</transChange> sinners, to hear Him.
Luke 15:2 And the pharisees and scribes murmured, saying, This man entertaineth wicked <transChange>persons,</transChange> and eateth with them.
Luke 15:3 But He spake to them this parable,
Luke 15:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">saying, What man of you that hath an hundred sheep, and loseth one of them, doth not leave the ninety-nine in the field, and go after that which was lost, till he find it?</q>
Luke 15:5 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And when he hath found <transChange>it,</transChange> he layeth <transChange>it</transChange> on his shoulders rejoicing:</q>
Luke 15:6 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and coming home, he calleth <transChange>his</transChange> friends and neighbors together and saith unto them, Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep which was lost.</q>
Luke 15:7 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thus, I tell you, there shall be joy in heaven over one repenting sinner, more than over ninety-nine righteous <transChange>persons,</transChange> that have no need of repentance.</q>
Luke 15:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Or what woman having ten pieces of silver, if she lose one, doth not light a candle, and sweep the house, and search carefully till she find <transChange>it?</transChange></q>
Luke 15:9 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and when she hath found <transChange>it,</transChange> she calleth <transChange>her</transChange> friends and neighbors together; saying, Rejoice with me, for I have found the piece which I had lost.</q>
Luke 15:10 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thus, I tell you, there is joy among the angels of God over one repenting sinner.</q>
Luke 15:11 And He said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">a certain man had two sons: and the younger of them said to his father,</q>
Luke 15:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Father, give me the portion that falleth <transChange>to my share.</transChange> And he divided his substance between them.</q>
Luke 15:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And not many days after the younger son gathered all together and went abroad into a distant country, and there squandered away his substance <transChange>by</transChange> living luxuriously.</q>
Luke 15:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And when he had spent all, there happen'd a grievous famine in that country, and he began to be in want.</q>
Luke 15:15 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he went and let himself to one of the people of that country, who sent him into his fields to feed swine.</q>
Luke 15:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he would gladly have filled his belly with the husks which the swine did eat: and no man relieved him.</q>
Luke 15:17 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But coming to himself, he said, How many hired servants of my father have bread enough and to spare, and I am perishing with hunger?</q>
Luke 15:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I will rise and go to my father, and will say to him, Father, I have sinned against heaven and before thee,</q>
Luke 15:19 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and am no longer worthy to be called thy son; make me as one of thy hired servants.</q>
Luke 15:20 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he rose and came to his father. But when he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, and was moved with compassion; and he ran and fell on his neck and kissed him.</q>
Luke 15:21 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And <transChange>his</transChange> son said unto him, Father, I have sinned against heaven and before thee, and am no longer worthy to be called thy son.</q>
Luke 15:22 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But the father said to his servants, bring out the best robe, and put <transChange>it</transChange> on him, and put a ring on his hand, and shoes on his feet:</q>
Luke 15:23 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and bring hither the fatted calf and kill <transChange>it,</transChange> and let us eat and be merry:</q>
Luke 15:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for this my son was dead, and is alive again, and was lost and is found. And they began to be merry.</q>
Luke 15:25 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But his elder son was <transChange>out</transChange> in the field: and as he came and drew nigh to the house, he heard music and dancing:</q>

Luke 15:27 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he said to him, Thy brother is come, and thy father hath killed the fatted calf, because he hath received him <transChange>safe and</transChange> well: but he was angry, and would not go in.</q>
Luke 15:28 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Therefore his father came out and desired him.</q>
Luke 15:29 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But he answered and said to his father, Behold so many years <transChange>as</transChange> I serve thee, nor have I ever transgressed thy command, and <transChange>yet</transChange> thou hast never given me a kid, to be merry with my friends:</q>

Luke 16:1 And He said also to his disciples, <q marker="" who="Jesus">There was a certain rich man, who had a steward; and he was accused to him of wasting his goods.</q>
Luke 16:2 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he called him, and said unto him, What <transChange>is</transChange> this I hear of thee? give up the accounts of thy stewardship, for thou canst be no longer steward.</q>
Luke 16:3 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And the steward said in himself, What shall I do? now my master takes away the stewardship from me; I am not able to work, <transChange>and</transChange> I am ashamed to beg.</q>
Luke 16:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I know what I will do, that when I am turned out of my place, they may receive me into their houses.</q>
Luke 16:5 <q marker="" who="Jesus">So he called his master's debtors to <transChange>him,</transChange> and said to the first, How much owest thou to my master? and he said, an hundred baths of oil.</q>
Luke 16:6 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he said to him, Take thy bill, and sit down and write <transChange>but</transChange> fifty.</q>
Luke 16:7 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Then he said to another, And how much owest thou? and he said, an hundred measures of wheat: and he said to him, Take thy bill, and write fourscore.</q>
Luke 16:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And <transChange>his</transChange> master commended the dishonest steward as having acted prudently: for the men of this world are as to their affairs wiser than the children of light.</q>
Luke 16:9 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And I say unto you, Make to yourselves friends with <transChange>these</transChange> unrighteous treasures, that when they fail, ye may be received into everlasting habitations.</q>

Luke 16:11 <q marker="" who="Jesus">If therefore ye have not been faithful in the false riches, who will intrust you with the true?</q>
Luke 16:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and if ye have not been faithful in <transChange>that which was</transChange> another's, who will give you <transChange>that which is</transChange> your own?</q>
Luke 16:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">No servant can serve two masters; for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or <transChange>at lest</transChange> he will be attached to the one, and neglect the other. Ye cannot serve God and Mammon.</q>
Luke 16:14 And the pharisees also, who were covetous, heard all these <transChange>things;</transChange> and derided Him.
Luke 16:15 And He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Ye justify yourselves before men, but God knoweth your hearts: for that which is highly esteemed among men is abomination in the sight of God.</q>
Luke 16:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">The law and the prophets <transChange>continued</transChange> until John: from that time the kingdom of God is preached, and every one presseth into it.</q>
Luke 16:17 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Though it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away, than one tittle of the law to fail.</q>
Luke 16:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Whosoever putteth away his wife, and marrieth another, committeth adultery; and whosoever marrieth her that is put away from <transChange>her</transChange> husband committeth adultery.</q>

Luke 16:20 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And there was a poor man named Lazarus,</q>
Luke 16:21 <q marker="" who="Jesus">who was laid at his gate full of sores, and desiring to be fed with the crumbs that fell from the rich man's table: and the dogs came and licked his sores. And it came to pass that the poor man died,</q>
Luke 16:22 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and was carried by angels to Abraham's bosom: the rich man also died, and was buried.</q>
Luke 16:23 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And in hell he lifted up his eyes, being in torments, and seeth Abraham from afar, and Lazarus in his bosom.</q>
Luke 16:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he cried out and said, Father Abraham, have pity on me, and send Lazarus, that he may dip the tip of his finger in water, and cool my tongue; for I am tormented in this flame.</q>
Luke 16:25 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And Abraham said, Son, remember that thou receivedst thy good things in thy life-<transChange>time,</transChange> and likewise Lazarus <transChange>his</transChange> evils: but now he is comforted, and thou art tormented.</q>

Luke 16:28 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for I have five brethren; that he may testify to them <transChange>my misery,</transChange> least they also come into this place of torment.</q>

Luke 17:1 Then said He to the disciples, <q marker="" who="Jesus">It is impossible that offences should not come: but wo <transChange>to him</transChange> by whom they come.</q>
Luke 17:2 <q marker="" who="Jesus">It were better for him that a milstone were hung about his neck, and he were thrown into the sea, than that he should cause one of these little ones to offend.</q>
Luke 17:3 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Take heed to yourselves: if thy brother trespass against thee, rebuke him; and if he repent, forgive him.</q>
Luke 17:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And if he trespass against thee seven times a day, and seven times <transChange>in</transChange> a day return to thee, saying, I repent; thou shalt forgive him.</q>
Luke 17:5 And the apostles said unto the Lord, Increase our faith.
Luke 17:6 And the Lord said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">If ye had faith <transChange>but</transChange> as a grain of mustard-seed, ye might say to this sycamine-tree, Be thou rooted up and planted in the sea; and it would obey you.</q>
Luke 17:7 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But which of you having a servant plowing, or feeding cattle, will say to him, as soon as he comes in from the field, Come hither and sit down at table?</q>
Luke 17:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But will he not <transChange>rather</transChange> say to him, Get ready my supper, and gird thyself, and wait upon me, till I have done, and afterwards thou shalt eat and drink.</q>
Luke 17:9 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Is he obliged to that servant for doing what he was ordered?</q>

Luke 17:12 and as He entered into a certain village, there met Him ten men <transChange>that were</transChange> lepers:

Luke 18:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he would not for a time: but afterwards he said within himself, Though I fear not God,</q>

Luke 19:1 And Jesus having entred Jericho passed through <transChange>the city,</transChange>
Luke 19:2 and behold, <transChange>there was</transChange> a man named Zaccheus, who was <transChange>the</transChange> chief publican, and <transChange>very</transChange> rich.
Luke 19:3 And he sought to see Jesus who He was; but he could not for the croud; for he was little of stature.
Luke 19:4 And he ran before and got up into a sycamore-tree that he might see Him; for He was to pass by that way.
Luke 19:5 And when Jesus came to the place, He looked up and saw him, and said to him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Zaccheus, make haste and come down; for to-day I must abide at thy house.</q>
Luke 19:6 And he made haste and came down, and received Him with joy.
Luke 19:7 And when they saw <transChange>it,</transChange> they all murmured, saying, He is gone to be guest with a wicked man.
Luke 19:8 But Zaccheus stood <transChange>up</transChange> and said unto Jesus, Behold, Lord, the half of my substance I give to the poor; and if I have taken any <transChange>thing</transChange> from any <transChange>one</transChange> wrongfully, I restore <transChange>him</transChange> fourfold.
Luke 19:9 Then said Jesus, <q marker="" who="Jesus">This day is salvation <transChange>come</transChange> to this house, for as much as he also is a son of Abraham.</q>
Luke 19:10 <q marker="" who="Jesus">For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost.</q>
Luke 19:11 And as they listened to these <transChange>things,</transChange> He proceeded and spake a parable; because He was nigh to Jerusalem, and they thought that the kingdom of God would immediately be manifested.
Luke 19:12 He said therefore, <q marker="" who="Jesus">A certain nobleman went into a distant country to receive <transChange>the investiture</transChange> of a kingdom and <transChange>then</transChange> to return.</q>
Luke 19:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he called ten <transChange>of</transChange> his servants, and delivered to them ten pounds, and said, Trade <transChange>with them</transChange> till I come.</q>
Luke 19:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But his citizens hated him, and sent an embassy after him, saying, We will not have this <transChange>man</transChange> to reign over us.</q>

Luke 19:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Then came the first and said, Lord, thy pound hath gained ten pounds.</q>
Luke 19:17 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he said to him, Well <transChange>done, thou</transChange> good servant, as thou hast been faithful in a very little, thou shalt be governor over ten cities.</q>
Luke 19:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And the second came, saying, Lord, thy pound hath produced five pounds:</q>

Luke 19:20 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And another came, and said, Behold, <transChange>my</transChange> Lord, thy pound, which I have kept laid up in a napkin:</q>
Luke 19:21 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for I was afraid of thee, because thou art an austere man, <transChange>who</transChange> takest up what thou didst not lay down, and reapest what thou didst not sow.</q>
Luke 19:22 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But he said to him, Out of thy own mouth will I judge thee, <transChange>thou</transChange> wicked servant, Thou knewest that I am an austere man, taking up what I laid not down, and reaping what I did not sow;</q>
Luke 19:23 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and why <transChange>then</transChange> didst thou not put my money into the bank, that when I came I might have received it with interest?</q>
Luke 19:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he said to them that stood by, Take away the pound from him, and give it to him that hath the ten pounds.</q>

Luke 19:26 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for I tell you, that to every one that hath shall be given; but from him that hath not, even what he <transChange>seemingly</transChange> hath shall be taken away.</q>
Luke 19:27 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But those mine enemies, who would not have me to reign over them, bring hither, and slay <transChange>them</transChange> before me.</q>
Luke 19:28 And when He had said these things, He went forward, going up to Jerusalem.
Luke 19:29 And when He was nigh to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount called <transChange>the mount</transChange> of Olives, He sent two of his disciples,
Luke 19:30 saying, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Go into the opposite village, in which, <transChange>at your</transChange> entring, ye will find a colt tied, on which no man ever yet sat; loose him and bring <transChange>him hither.</transChange></q>
Luke 19:31 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And if any one ask you, Why do ye loose <transChange>him?</transChange> thus shall ye say unto him, The Lord hath need of him.</q>
Luke 19:32 And they that were sent, went away and found <transChange>it</transChange> as He had told them.
Luke 19:33 But as they were untying the colt, the owners of it said to them, Why do ye untie the colt?
Luke 19:34 and they answered, The Lord hath need of him.
Luke 19:35 And they brought him to Jesus: and throwing their garments upon the colt they set Jesus thereon.
Luke 19:36 And as He went along they spread their clothes under <transChange>Him</transChange> in the way.
Luke 19:37 And when He was now come near to the foot of the mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples rejoicing began to praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works which they had seen,

Luke 19:40 And He answered them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I tell you, that if these were silent, the <transChange>very</transChange> stones would cry out.</q>
Luke 19:41 And as He drew near, beholding the city, He wept over it,

Luke 19:44 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and shall lay thee to the ground, and thy children within thee; and they shall not leave in thee one stone upon another: because thou didst not regard the time of thy visitation.</q>

Luke 19:47 And He was teaching daily in the temple: but the chief priests and the scribes and the rulers of the people sought to destroy Him;
Luke 19:48 and could not find how to effect it: for all the people were attentive to hear Him. <chapter eID="gen2653" osisID="Luke.19"/>
Luke 20:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.20" sID="gen2702"/>
Luke 20:1 And on one of those days as He was teaching the people in the temple and preaching the gospel, the chief priests and the scribes and elders came upon Him, saying,
Luke 20:2 Tell us by what authority thou dost these things? or who <transChange>it</transChange> is that gave thee this authority?
Luke 20:3 And He answered and said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I will also ask you one question, tell me,</q>
Luke 20:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Was the baptism of John from heaven or from men?</q>
Luke 20:5 And they reasoned among themselves, saying, If we say, From heaven, He will say, Why then did ye not believe him?
Luke 20:6 but if we say, Of men, the people will all stone us: for they are persuaded that John was a prophet.
Luke 20:7 And they answered, <transChange>they</transChange> did not know whence <transChange>it was.</transChange>
Luke 20:8 And Jesus said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these <transChange>things.</transChange></q>
Luke 20:9 Then He began to speak unto the people this parable, <q marker="" who="Jesus">A certain man planted a vineyard, and let it out to husbandmen and travelled abroad for a considerable time,</q>
Luke 20:10 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and at the <transChange>fruit</transChange>-season he sent a servant to the husbandmen that they should give him of the fruit of the vineyard; but the husbandmen beat him and sent <transChange>him</transChange> away empty.</q>
Luke 20:11 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he sent another servant; and they beat him also and abused <transChange>him,</transChange> and sent <transChange>him</transChange> away empty.</q>
Luke 20:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he sent a third; and they wounded him also and drove him out.</q>
Luke 20:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Then said the lord of the vineyard, What shall I do? I will send my beloved son: perhaps when they see Him they will reverence <transChange>Him.</transChange></q>
Luke 20:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But when the husbandmen saw Him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, This is the heir, come, let us kill him, that the inheritance may be ours.</q>
Luke 20:15 <q marker="" who="Jesus">So they cast him out of the vineyard and killed <transChange>him.</transChange> What therefore will the lord of the vineyard do unto them?</q>
Luke 20:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">He will come and destroy these husbandmen, and will give the vineyard to others.</q> And when they heard <transChange>this</transChange> they said, God forbid.
Luke 20:17 And He looked upon them and said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">What then is this, <transChange>which is</transChange> written, The stone which the builders refused, is become the head of the corner?</q>
Luke 20:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Whosoever falleth on that stone shall be bruised; but on whomsoever it falleth, it will crush him to pieces.</q>
Luke 20:19 And the chief priests and the scribes would have laid hands on Him at <transChange>that</transChange> very time, but were afraid of the people: for they perceived that He had spoken this parable against them.
Luke 20:20 And they watched <transChange>Him</transChange> and sent out spies, pretending to be righteous <transChange>men,</transChange> to lay hold of his words, that they might deliver Him up to the power and authority of the governor.
Luke 20:21 And they asked Him, saying, Master, we know that thou speakest and teachest rightly, and acceptest not the person <transChange>of any,</transChange> but teachest the way of God in truth:

Luke 20:23 But He perceived their craftiness, and said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Why do ye tempt me?</q>
Luke 20:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Shew me a penny: whose image and inscription hath it?</q> and they answered, Cesar's.
Luke 20:25 Then said He unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Render therefore unto Cesar the things that are Cesar's, and to God the things that are God's.</q>
Luke 20:26 And they could not take hold of his word before the people: and they marvelled at his answer and said no more.
Luke 20:27 And some of the Sadducees (who deny a resurrection) came to <transChange>Him</transChange> and asked Him,
Luke 20:28 saying, Moses enjoined us, if any man's brother die, having a wife, and he die childless, that his brother should take his wife, and raise up seed to his brother.
Luke 20:29 Now there were seven brethren: and the first took a wife, and died childless; and the second took the wife, and he died childless;
Luke 20:30 and the third took her;
Luke 20:31 and in like manner <transChange>all</transChange> the seven.
Luke 20:32 And they died and left no children. Last of all the woman also died.
Luke 20:33 Therefore at the resurrection whose wife is she? for <transChange>all</transChange> the seven had her to wife.
Luke 20:34 And Jesus answering said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">The children of this world marry and are given in marriage.</q>
Luke 20:35 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But they who are counted worthy to obtain that world, and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are given in marriage:</q>
Luke 20:36 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for they can die no more, being like the angels: and they are the children of God <transChange>as</transChange> being the children of the resurrection.</q>
Luke 20:37 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Now that the dead are raised, even Moses shewed at the bush; for he calleth the Lord, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.</q>
Luke 20:38 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And He is not the God of the dead, but of the living; for to Him <transChange>they</transChange> are all living.</q>
Luke 20:39 And some of the scribes replied, Master, thou hast <transChange>indeed</transChange> said right.
Luke 20:40 And they dared not any more to ask Him any <transChange>such</transChange> question.

Luke 22:4 And he went and conferred with the chief priests and the captains, how he might betray Him unto them.
Luke 22:5 And they were glad and agreed to give him money:
Luke 22:6 and he accepted <transChange>the terms,</transChange> and sought an opportunity to betray Him unto them in the absence of the multitude.

Luke 22:51 but Jesus said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Suffer ye thus far;</q> and He touched his ear and healed him.

Luke 22:60 Man, I know not what thou sayst. And immediately, while he was yet speaking, the cock crew.

Luke 23:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.23" sID="gen2861"/>
Luke 23:1 Then they all rose up and led Him to Pilate.
Luke 23:2 And they began to accuse Him, saying, We found this <transChange>fellow</transChange> perverting the nation, and forbiding to give tribute to Cesar; saying, that He himself is Christ <transChange>the</transChange> king.
Luke 23:3 And Pilate asked Him, saying, Art thou the king of the Jews? And He answered him and said, <q marker="" who="Jesus"><transChange>I am as</transChange> thou sayest.</q>
Luke 23:4 But Pilate said to the chief priests, and to the people, I find nothing criminal in this man.
Luke 23:5 Then they were more vehement, saying, He stirreth up the people <transChange>to sedition,</transChange> spreading his doctrine throughout all Judea: having begun at Galilee <transChange>and come</transChange> even to this place.
Luke 23:6 Now when Pilate heard of Galilee, he asked, if the man were a Galilean:
Luke 23:7 and understanding that He was of Herod's jurisdiction, he sent Him to Herod, who was also at Jerusalem at that time.
Luke 23:8 And Herod, when he saw Jesus, was very glad; for he had of a long <transChange>time</transChange> been desirous to see Him, because he had heard much of Him, and he hoped to see some miracle wrought by Him.
Luke 23:9 And he asked Him many questions; but He answered him nothing:
Luke 23:10 though the chief priests and scribes stood vehemently accusing Him.
Luke 23:11 But Herod with his soldiers set Him at nought and insulted <transChange>Him,</transChange> and put on Him a gaudy robe, and sent Him back to Pilate.
Luke 23:12 And on <transChange>that</transChange> same day Pilate and Herod became friends with each other: for before they were at enmity one with the other.
Luke 23:13 And Pilate called together the chief priests, and the rulers,
Luke 23:14 and the people, and said unto them, Ye have brought to me this man as one that perverteth the people: and behold I have examined <transChange>Him</transChange> before you, and found nothing chargeable on Him, of the things you alledge against Him:
Luke 23:15 nor Herod neither; for I sent you to him, and behold nothing worthy of death is proved upon Him.
Luke 23:16 I will therefore chastise Him, and <transChange>so</transChange> release <transChange>Him.</transChange>
Luke 23:17 Now he was obliged to release one to them at the feast.
Luke 23:18 And they all cried out, saying, Away with this <transChange>man,</transChange> and release to us Barabbas:
Luke 23:19 (who for a riot in the city, and <transChange>for</transChange> murder, was committed to prison:)
Luke 23:20 Pilate therefore spake to <transChange>them</transChange> again, being desirous to release Jesus.
Luke 23:21 But they bawled out, saying, Crucify <transChange>Him,</transChange> crucify Him.
Luke 23:22 And he said to them a third time, what evil hath He done? I have found nothing in Him deserving death: I will therefore chastise Him, and let <transChange>Him</transChange> go.
Luke 23:23 But they insisted upon <transChange>it</transChange> with loud clamours, demanding Him to be crucified: and their voices and <transChange>those</transChange> of the chief priests prevailed.
Luke 23:24 So Pilate gave sentence that what they demanded should be done.
Luke 23:25 And he released to them him that for sedition and murder had been cast into prison, whom they desired; and delivered up Jesus to their will.
Luke 23:26 And when they led Him away, they laid hold on one Simon a Cyrenean coming out of the country, and put the cross on him to bear it behind Jesus.
Luke 23:27 And there followed Him a great multitude of people, and of women, who also bewailed and lamented Him: but Jesus turning to them said,
Luke 23:28 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for me, but weep for yourselves, and for your children.</q>
Luke 23:29 <q marker="" who="Jesus">For behold the days are coming in which they shall say, happy <transChange>are</transChange> the barren, and the wombs that never bare, and the breasts that never gave suck.</q>
Luke 23:30 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Then shall they say to the mountains, Fall on us; and to the hills, Cover us:</q>
Luke 23:31 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for if they do these things to the green wood, what shall be done to the dry?</q>
Luke 23:32 And there were also two other malefactors led with Him to be put to death.
Luke 23:33 And when they were come to the place which is called Calvary, there they crucified Him and the malefactors: one on <transChange>his</transChange> right <transChange>hand</transChange> and the other on <transChange>his</transChange> left.
Luke 23:34 And Jesus said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do.</q> And they parted his garments, and cast lots <transChange>for them.</transChange>
