Luke 23:36 And the soldiers too insulted Him, coming to <transChange>Him</transChange> and offering Him vinegar, saying,
Luke 23:37 If thou art the king of the Jews, save thyself.
Luke 23:38 And there was a superscription written over Him in Greek, and Latin and Hebrew letters, THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Luke 23:39 And one of the malefactors that were executed <transChange>with Him</transChange> reviled Him, saying, If thou be the Messiah, save thyself and us.
Luke 23:40 But the other answered and rebuked him, saying, Dost <transChange>not</transChange> thou fear God neither, when thou <transChange>thyself</transChange> art in the same condemnation?
Luke 23:41 And we indeed justly; for we receive the due rewards of our deeds, but this <transChange>man</transChange> hath done nothing amiss.
Luke 23:42 And he said unto Jesus, Lord, remember me when thou comest into thy kingdom.
Luke 23:43 And Jesus answered him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I assure thee, thou shalt be with me this day in paradise.</q>
Luke 23:44 Now it was about the sixth hour, and there was darkness over the whole land till the ninth hour.
Luke 23:45 And the sun was darkened, and the veil of the temple was rent in the midst.
Luke 23:46 And Jesus cried with a loud voice and said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Father, into thy hands I commit my spirit.</q> And when He had said thus, He expired.
Luke 23:47 And when the centurion saw what was done, he glorified God, saying, Certainly this man was righteous.
Luke 23:48 And all the multitudes that came together to this <transChange>affecting</transChange> sight, seeing what happened, smote <transChange>on</transChange> their breasts and returned.

Luke 23:50 And behold <transChange>there was</transChange> a man of Arimathea, a city of the Jews, named Joseph, a counsellor, a good man and a just:
Luke 23:51 (who had not consented to <transChange>their</transChange> counsel nor their action; and who was also himself in expectation of the kingdom of God:)

Luke 23:53 and he took it down and wrapped it in linen, and laid it in a sepulchre hewn in stone, where no one had ever yet been laid.

Luke 24:0 <chapter osisID="Luke.24" sID="gen2918"/>
Luke 24:1 And on the first <transChange>day</transChange> of the week, very early in the morning, they came to the sepulchre, bringing the spices which they had prepared; (and some <transChange>others</transChange> with them:) and found the stone rolled away from the sepulchre:
Luke 24:2 so they went in,
Luke 24:3 but found not the body of the Lord Jesus.
Luke 24:4 And while they were in perplexity about it, behold, two men stood by them in shining robes.
Luke 24:5 And as they were afraid, and bowed down <transChange>their</transChange> faces to the ground, <transChange>the men</transChange> said unto them, Why do ye seek the living among the dead?
Luke 24:6 He is not here, He is risen: remember how He spake to you, when He was yet in Galilee,

Luke 24:8 And they remembered his words,

Luke 24:12 But Peter arose and ran to the sepulchre; and stooping down he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves: and he went away, wondering in himself at what had happened.
Luke 24:13 And behold two of them were going that day to a village <transChange>about</transChange> threescore furlongs from Jerusalem, called Emmaus.
Luke 24:14 And they were conversing together about all these <transChange>things</transChange> which had happened.
Luke 24:15 And while they were discoursing and reasoning together, Jesus himself drew near and went along with them.

Luke 24:21 But we hoped that it was He that would have delivered Israel: and besides all this, to-day is the third day since these <transChange>things</transChange> were done.

Luke 24:28 And they drew nigh to the village whither they were going: and He made as if He was going farther.
Luke 24:29 And they pressed Him, saying, Stay with us, for it is towards evening, and the day is far spent. And He went in to tarry with them.
Luke 24:30 And as He sat at table with them, He took bread and blessed <transChange>it,</transChange> and <transChange>then</transChange> brake <transChange>it</transChange> and gave to them.
Luke 24:31 And their eyes were opened, and they knew Him.
Luke 24:32 And He disappeared from them. And they said one to another, Did not our heart burn within us, as He was talking with us by the way, and while He was opening to us the scriptures?
Luke 24:33 And they rose up immediately and returned to Jerusalem; and sound the eleven and others with them assembled together, saying,
Luke 24:34 The Lord is risen indeed, and hath been seen by Simon.

John 1:0 <chapter osisID="John.1" sID="gen2973"/>
John 1:1 <hi type="bold">In</hi> the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
John 1:2 The same was in the beginning with God.
John 1:3 By Him were all <transChange>things</transChange> made, and without Him was not <transChange>any</transChange> one thing made that was made.
John 1:4 In Him was life, and the life was the light of men.
John 1:5 And the light shineth in darkness, and the darkness attained it not.
John 1:6 There was a man sent from God, whose name <transChange>was</transChange> John:
John 1:7 this <transChange>man</transChange> came for witness, that he might testify concerning the light, that through him all might believe.
John 1:8 He was not that light, but was sent to bear witness of the light.
John 1:9 The true light was <transChange>that</transChange> which enlightneth every man that cometh into the world.
John 1:10 He was in the world, and the world was made by Him, and <transChange>yet</transChange> the world knew Him not:
John 1:11 <transChange>yea,</transChange> He came to his own <transChange>peculiar right,</transChange> and <transChange>even</transChange> his own <transChange>people</transChange> received Him not.
John 1:12 But as many as received Him, to them granted He the privilege to become the children of God, <transChange>even</transChange> to them that believe on his name;
John 1:13 who were born not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
John 1:14 And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, <transChange>being</transChange> full of grace and truth: and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only-begotten of the Father.
John 1:15 Of Him did John bare witness, and publicly declared, saying, This was He of whom I spake, He that cometh after me is <transChange>preferred</transChange> before me; for He was before me.
John 1:16 And of his fulness have we all received, even grace for grace.
John 1:17 For the law was given by Moses, <transChange>but</transChange> grace and truth came by Jesus Christ:
John 1:18 <transChange>and though</transChange> no one hath ever seen God, <transChange>or can see Him: yet</transChange> the only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father, hath made Him known.
John 1:19 And this is the testimony of John, when the Jews sent from Jerusalem priests and Levites to ask him, Who art thou?
John 1:20 he confessed, and denied not; but declared openly, I am not the Christ.
John 1:21 And they asked him, What then? art thou Elias? And he said, I am not. Art thou a prophet? and he answered, No.
John 1:22 Therefore said they unto him, Who art thou? that we may give an answer to them that sent us: What dost thou say of thy self?
John 1:23 <transChange>and</transChange> he said, I <transChange>am</transChange> the voice of one crying in the wilderness, "Make straight the way of the Lord," according to Esaias the prophet.
John 1:24 Now they that were sent, were of the pharisees:
John 1:25 and they asked him, and said to him, Why then dost thou baptize, if thou art not the Christ, nor Elias, nor a prophet?
John 1:26 John answered them, saying, I baptize with water: but there standeth <transChange>one</transChange> among you, whom ye know not;
John 1:27 that cometh after me, <transChange>but</transChange> is preferred before me, the latchet of whose shoe I am not worthy to unloose.
John 1:28 These things passed at Bethabara beyond Jordan, where John was baptizing.
John 1:29 The next day John seeth Jesus coming towards him, and saith, Behold the Lamb of God that taketh away the sin of the world.
John 1:30 This is <transChange>He</transChange> of whom I said, After me cometh a man, who is preferred before me: for He was before me.
John 1:31 And I knew Him not: but therefore came I baptizing with water, that He might be made known to Israel.
John 1:32 And John testified saying, I saw the Spirit descending like a dove from heaven, and <transChange>it</transChange> abode upon Him.
John 1:33 And I knew Him not: but He that sent me to baptize with water, said unto me, Upon whom thou shalt see the Spirit descending and abiding on Him, the same is he that baptizeth with the Holy Spirit.
John 1:34 And I saw <transChange>it,</transChange> and <transChange>therefore</transChange> testified that this is the Son of God.
John 1:35 The day following John was standing, (and two of his disciples,)
John 1:36 and looking upon Jesus as He was walking, he saith, "Behold the lamb of God."
John 1:37 And when the two disciples heard what he said, they followed Jesus.
John 1:38 And Jesus turning, and seeing them following <transChange>Him,</transChange> saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">What do ye seek?</q> They said unto Him, Rabbi (that is to say, Master,) where is thine abode?
John 1:39 He saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Come and see.</q> <transChange>And</transChange> they came and saw where He dwelt, and abode with Him that day: and it was about the tenth hour.
John 1:40 <transChange>Now</transChange> Andrew the brother of Simon Peter, was one of the two that heard <transChange>what</transChange> John <transChange>said,</transChange> and <transChange>thereupon</transChange> followed Jesus.
John 1:41 He first meeteth with his own brother Simon, and telleth him, "We have found the Messiah, which is to say, the Christ."
John 1:42 And <transChange>Andrew</transChange> brought him to Jesus: and Jesus looking at him said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thou art Simon the son of Jonas, thou shalt be called Cephas; which is interpreted a stone.</q>
John 1:43 The day following Jesus had a mind to go out into Galilee, and meeting with Philip, saith unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Follow me.</q>
John 1:44 Now Philip was of Bethsaida the city of Andrew and Peter.
John 1:45 Philip meeting Nathaniel, saith unto him, We have found <transChange>Him,</transChange> of whom Moses in the law, and <transChange>of whom</transChange> the prophets <transChange>also</transChange> wrote, Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Jeseph.
John 1:46 And Nathaniel said unto him, Can any <transChange>thing</transChange> good come out of Nazareth? Philip replied, Come and see.

John 1:48 Nathaniel saith unto Him, Whence knowest thou me? Jesus answered him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Before Philip called thee, I saw thee, when under the fig-tree.</q>
John 1:49 Nathaniel replied, Rabbi, thou art the Son of God; thou art the king of Israel.

John 2:0 <chapter osisID="John.2" sID="gen3025"/>
John 2:1 And <transChange>on</transChange> the third day <transChange>after,</transChange> there was a marriage at Cana of Galilee: and the mother of Jesus was there.
John 2:2 And Jesus and his disciples were invited to the wedding.
John 2:3 And the wine falling short, the mother of Jesus saith unto Him, They have no wine.
John 2:4 Jesus saith unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Woman, what have I to do with thee? my time is not yet come.</q>
John 2:5 His mother saith to the servants, Whatsoever he ordereth you <transChange>to do,</transChange> do <transChange>it.</transChange>
John 2:6 And there were six stone waterpots, placed according to the custom of purifying among the Jews, containing each about two or three firkins.
John 2:7 Jesus saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Fill the water-pots with water:</q> and they filled them up to the brim.
John 2:8 And he saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Draw out now, and carry <transChange>it</transChange> to the master of the feast.</q> And they carried <transChange>it to him.</transChange>
John 2:9 And when the manager of the feast had tasted the water which was made wine, and knew not whence it was, (but the servants, that drew the water, knew,) he called the bride-groom,
John 2:10 and saith unto him, Every man sets <transChange>out</transChange> good wine at first, and when they have drank plentifully, then <transChange>that which is</transChange> worse; <transChange>but</transChange> thou hast keep the good wine till now.
John 2:11 This beginning of <transChange>his</transChange> miracles Jesus wrought at Cana of Galilee, and made manifest his glory: and his disciples believed on Him.
John 2:12 After this He went down to Capernaum, He and his mother, and his brethren, and his disciples: but they staid there not many days.
John 2:13 For the passover of the Jews was near, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem. And He found in the temple those that sold oxen,
John 2:14 and sheep, and doves, and the money changers sitting:
John 2:15 and having made a whip of small cords He drove <transChange>them</transChange> all, out of the temple; with the sheep and the oxen: and He poured out the changers money, and threw down the tables.
John 2:16 And said to them that sold doves, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Take away these <transChange>things</transChange> from hence, and make not my Father's house an house of traffick.</q>
John 2:17 And his disciples remembered that it is written, The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up.

John 2:20 Forty and six years has this temple been <transChange>in</transChange> building, and wilt thou raise it up in three days? but He spake of the temple of his body.
John 2:21 Therefore when he was risen from the dead,

John 2:23 And when he was in Jerusalem at the passover on the feast-<transChange>day,</transChange> many believed in his name, seeing his miracles, which He wrought.

John 3:0 <chapter osisID="John.3" sID="gen3051"/>
John 3:1 Now there was a man of the pharisees, whose name <transChange>was</transChange> Nicodemus, a ruler among the Jews:
John 3:2 who came to Jesus by night, and said unto Him, Rabbi, we know that thou art a teacher come from God: for none can do these miracles which thou dost, unless God be with him.
John 3:3 Jesus answered and said unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Verily verily I tell thee, Unless a man be born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God.</q>
John 3:4 Nicodemus saith unto Him, How can a man be born when he is old? can he enter a second time into his mother's womb, and be born?
John 3:5 Jesus answered, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I tell thee of a truth, Unless a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God.</q>
John 3:6 <q marker="" who="Jesus">That, which is born of the flesh, is flesh; and that, which is born of the Spirit, is spirit.</q>
John 3:7 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Do not wonder that I said unto thee, Ye must be born again.</q>
John 3:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus"><transChange>As</transChange> the wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound of it, but knowest not whence it cometh, or whither it goeth; so is every one that is born of the Spirit.</q>
John 3:9 Nicodemus answered and said unto Him, How can these <transChange>things</transChange> be?
John 3:10 Jesus answered and said unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Art thou a teacher of Israel and knowest not these <transChange>things?</transChange></q>
John 3:11 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I assure thee, that we speak what we know, and testify what we have seen; though ye receive not our testimony.</q>
John 3:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">If I have told you earthly <transChange>things</transChange> and ye believe not, how will ye believe if I should tell you heavenly <transChange>ones?</transChange></q>
John 3:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">For no one hath ascended up into heaven, but He that came down from heaven, <transChange>even</transChange> the Son of man who is in heaven.</q>
John 3:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of man be lifted up:</q>
John 3:15 <q marker="" who="Jesus">that whosoever believeth on Him may not perish, but have eternal life.</q>
John 3:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">For God so loved the world, that He gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth on Him might not perish, but have everlasting life:</q>
John 3:17 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for God sent not his son into the world to condemn the world, but that the world might be saved by Him.</q>
John 3:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">He that believeth on Him is not condemned: but he that believeth not, is already condemned; because he hath not believed on the name of the only-begotten Son of God.</q>
John 3:19 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And this is the condemnation, that light is come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil.</q>
John 3:20 <q marker="" who="Jesus">For every one that doth evil, hateth the light; and he cometh not to the light, least his deeds should be reproved.</q>
John 3:21 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But he that acts <transChange>according to</transChange> truth, cometh to the light, that his deeds may be made manifest, that they are wrought in God.</q>
John 3:22 After these <transChange>things</transChange> came Jesus, and his disciples into the land of Judea: and He stayed with them there, and baptized.
John 3:23 And John also was baptizing in Enon near Salim; because there was much water there: and <transChange>people</transChange> came to <transChange>him</transChange> and were baptized.
John 3:24 For John was not yet cast into prison.
John 3:25 Now there arose a dispute between <transChange>some</transChange> of the disciples of John, and the Jews, about purifying.
John 3:26 And they came to John, and said unto him, Rabbi, He that was with thee on the other side Jordan, to whom thou barest testimony, behold, He baptizeth and all <transChange>the people</transChange> come to Him.
John 3:27 John answered and said, A man can take nothing <transChange>upon him,</transChange> unless it be given him from heaven.

John 3:29 He that hath the bride is the bridegroom: but the friend of the bridegroom, who standeth and heareth him, rejoiceth with <transChange>great</transChange> joy at the bridegroom's voice. Therefore my joy is complete.
John 3:30 He must increase, but I must decrease.

John 4:0 <chapter osisID="John.4" sID="gen3088"/>
John 4:1 Therefore when the Lord knew, the pharisees had heard that Jesus made and baptized more disciples than John,
John 4:2 (though Jesus Himself did not baptize, but his disciples,)
John 4:3 He left Judea, and departed again into Galilee.
John 4:4 And as He must pass through <transChange>the country of</transChange> Samaria, He came to a Samaritan city called Sichar,
John 4:5 near the piece of ground which Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
John 4:6 And Jacob's well was there. Now Jesus was tired with <transChange>his</transChange> journey, and sat down at the well: <transChange>and</transChange> it was about the sixth hour <transChange>of the day,</transChange>
John 4:7 <transChange>when</transChange> a woman of Samaria coming to draw water, Jesus saith unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Give me to drink.</q>
John 4:8 (For his disciples were gone away to the city to buy food.)
John 4:9 But the Samaritan saith unto Him, How is it that thou who art a Jew askest drink of me, who am a Samaritan? for the Jews have no <transChange>friendly</transChange> intercourse with the Samaritans.
John 4:10 Jesus answered and said unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">If thou knewest the gift of God, and who it is that saith unto thee, Give me to drink; thou wouldst have asked of Him, and He would have given thee living water.</q>
John 4:11 The woman saith unto Him, Sir, thou hast nothing to draw with, and the well is deep: whence then hast thou the living water?
John 4:12 Art thou greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well, and drank of it himself, and his children, and his cattle?
John 4:13 Jesus answered and said unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Whosoever drinketh of this water, will thirst again;</q>
John 4:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">but he that drinketh of the water which I shall give him, shall never thirst: but the water, which I shall give him, will be in him a fountain of water springing up unto eternal life.</q>
John 4:15 The woman saith unto Him, Sir, give me this water, that I may not thirst, nor come hither to draw.
John 4:16 Jesus saith unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Go call thine husband, and come hither.</q>
John 4:17 The woman answered, I have no husband. Jesus saith unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thou hast said right, I have no husband:</q>
John 4:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for thou hast had five husbands; and he, whom thou now hast, is not thy husband: this thou hast said true.</q>
John 4:19 The woman saith unto Him, Sir, I perceive that thou art a prophet.
John 4:20 Our fathers worshipped on this mountain, and ye say that in Jerusalem is the place where <transChange>men</transChange> ought to worship.
John 4:21 Jesus saith unto her, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Woman, believe me, the time is coming, when ye shall worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem.</q>
John 4:22 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Ye worship ye know not what; <transChange>but</transChange> we worship what we know: for salvation is from the Jews.</q>
John 4:23 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But the time is coming, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and truth: for the Father requireth such worshippers of Him.</q>
John 4:24 <q marker="" who="Jesus">God is a spirit, and they that worship Him, must worship in spirit and truth.</q>

John 4:29 and saith to the people, Come, see a man who hath told me all that ever I did; is not this the Christ?
John 4:30 They therefore went out of the city, and came to Him.
John 4:31 In the mean time his disciples addressed Him, saying, Master, eat.
John 4:32 But He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I have food to eat, which ye know not of.</q>
John 4:33 Therefore the disciples said one to another, Hath any one brought Him <transChange>aught</transChange> to eat?
John 4:34 Jesus saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">My food is to do the will of Him that sent me, and to finish his work.</q>
John 4:35 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Do not ye say, it is yet four months, and <transChange>then</transChange> cometh harvest? Behold, lift up your eyes, and see the fields, they are already white for harvest.</q>
John 4:36 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And he that reapeth receiveth wages, and gathereth <transChange>the</transChange> fruit together unto life eternal: that both he that soweth and he that reapeth may rejoice together;</q>

John 4:40 Therefore when the Samaritans came to Him, they desired Him to stay with them: and He staid there two days.
John 4:41 And many more believed on account of his own discourse:
John 4:42 and said to the woman, Now we believe, not because of what thou hast spoken; for we ourselves have heard <transChange>Him,</transChange> and know that this is indeed the Christ, the Saviour of the world.
John 4:43 And after two days he departed thence, and went into <transChange>Cana of</transChange> Galilee.
John 4:44 For Jesus himself <transChange>had</transChange> testified that a prophet hath no honor in his own country.
John 4:45 And when He was come into Galilee, the Galileans received Him, having seen all that he did in Jerusalem at the feast: for they also went to the feast.
John 4:46 Therefore Jesus came again into Cana of Galilee, where He had made the water wine.
John 4:47 And there was a certain nobleman, whose son was sick at Capernaum: who, when he heard that Jesus was come out of Judea into Galilee, went to Him, and intreated Him, that he would come down and heal his son; for he was at the point of death.
John 4:48 Jesus therefore said unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Except ye see signs and wonders ye will not believe.</q>
John 4:49 The nobleman saith unto Him, Lord, come down before my child die.
John 4:50 Jesus saith unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Go, thy son is well.</q> And the man believed what Jesus said unto him, and went <transChange>his way.</transChange>
John 4:51 And as he was now going down, his servants met him and told <transChange>him,</transChange> saying, Thy son is well.
John 4:52 He inquired therefore of them the hour in which he grew better: and they said unto him, Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.
John 4:53 So the father knew that <transChange>it was</transChange> in that <transChange>same</transChange> hour, in which Jesus said to him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thy son is well.</q> And he and his whole family believed.

John 5:1 After these <transChange>things</transChange> there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
John 5:2 Now there is at Jerusalem near the sheep-<transChange>market</transChange> a pool, called in Hebrew Bethesda, with five porticos <transChange>about it.</transChange>
John 5:3 In these lay a great number of <transChange>people that were</transChange> infirm, blind, lame, withered, waiting for the moving of the water.
John 5:4 For an angel descended at a certain season into the pool, and moved the water; the first therefore that went in after the disturbing of the water, was cured of whatever malady he laboured under.
John 5:5 And there was a man who had been under illness thirty eight years.
John 5:6 Jesus seeing him lie <transChange>there,</transChange> and knowing that he had been now a long time <transChange>ill,</transChange> saith unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Dost thou desire to be cured?</q>
John 5:7 The infirm <transChange>man</transChange> answered Him, Sir, I have no man, when the water is moved, to put me into the pool; but while I am coming, another goes down before me.
John 5:8 Jesus saith unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Rise, take up thy bed, and walk.</q>
John 5:9 And immediately the man was cured: and he took up his bed and walked.
John 5:10 Now this was the sabbath-day, therefore the Jews said to him that was cured, It is the sabbath, it is not lawful for thee to carry <transChange>thy</transChange> bed.
John 5:11 He answered them, He, that made me well, said unto me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Take up thy bed and walk.</q>
John 5:12 Therefore they asked him, Who is the man that said to thee, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Take up thy bed and walk?</q>

John 6:0 <chapter osisID="John.6" sID="gen3191"/>

John 6:8 One of his disciples, <transChange>to wit,</transChange> Andrew the brother of Simon Peter,

John 6:10 And Jesus said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Make the men sit down:</q> (now there was much grass in the place:) so the men sat down <transChange>in</transChange> number about five thousand.

John 6:12 And when they were filled, He saith to his disciples, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Gather up the fragments that are left, that nothing may be lost.</q>

John 6:20 But He saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">It is I: be not afraid.</q>
John 6:21 They desired therefore to take Him into the ship: and immediately the vessel was at the land to which they were going.

John 7:0 <chapter osisID="John.7" sID="gen3263"/>
John 7:1 After these things Jesus resided in Galilee: for He would not appear in Judea, because the Jews sought to kill Him.
John 7:2 Now the Jews feast <transChange>called the feast</transChange> of tabernacles was near;
John 7:3 his brethren therefore said, Depart from hence, and go into Judea, that thy disciples <transChange>there</transChange> also may see the works which thou performest.
John 7:4 For no man doth any <transChange>thing</transChange> in secret, who is himself desirous to be <transChange>known</transChange> in public. As thou dost these <transChange>wonderful</transChange> things, make thyself known to the world.
John 7:5 For neither did his brethren believe in Him.

John 8:4 and setting her in the midst, they said to Him, "This woman was caught in the very act, committing adultery.

John 10:0 <chapter osisID="John.10" sID="gen3419"/>
John 10:1 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Verily, verily I say unto you, He that entreth not into the sheep-fold by the door, but climbeth up some other way, is a thief and a robber.</q>
John 10:2 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But he that cometh in by the door, is the shepherd of the sheep.</q>
John 10:3 <q marker="" who="Jesus">To him the porter openeth, and the sheep hear his voice; and He calleth his own sheep by name, and leadeth them out.</q>
John 10:4 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And when he bringeth forth his sheep, he goeth before them: and the sheep follow him; because they know his voice.</q>
John 10:5 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But they will not follow a stranger, but will flee from him; because they know not the voice of strangers.</q>
John 10:6 This parable Jesus spake unto them; but they did not understand what He said to them.
John 10:7 Jesus therefore said unto them again, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Verily, verily I tell you, that I am the door of the sheep.</q>
John 10:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">All that came before me are thieves and robbers: but the sheep did not regard them.</q>
John 10:9 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am the door: by me if any <transChange>man</transChange> enter in, he shall be saved; and shall go in and out, and find pasture.</q>
John 10:10 <q marker="" who="Jesus">The thief cometh only to steal, and to kill, and to destroy: I am come that they may have life, and may have <transChange>it</transChange> in perfection.</q>
John 10:11 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am the good shepherd: the good shepherd layeth down his life for the sheep.</q>
John 10:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But the hireling, that is not the <transChange>true</transChange> shepherd, whose own the sheep are not, seeth the wolf coming, and leaveth the sheep, and fleeth: and the wolf seizeth them, and disperseth the sheep.</q>
John 10:13 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Now the hireling fleeth, because he is an hireling, and careth not for the sheep.</q>
John 10:14 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am the good shepherd, and I know my <transChange>own sheep,</transChange> and am known by them.</q>
John 10:15 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Even as the Father knoweth me, and I know the Father: and I lay down my life for the sheep.</q>
John 10:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And I have other sheep, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring, and they will hear my voice; so there shall be one fold, and one shepherd.</q>
John 10:17 <q marker="" who="Jesus">For this doth the Father love me; because I lay down my life: that I may take it again.</q>
John 10:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">None taketh it from me, but I lay it down of myself: I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again. This commandment I have received from my Father.</q>
John 10:19 There was a division therefore again among the Jews on account of these words.
John 10:20 And many of them said, He is a demoniac, and is mad; why do ye hear Him?
John 10:21 Others said, These are not the words of a demoniac; can a demon open the eyes of the blind?
John 10:22 Now it was the feast of dedication at Jerusalem, and it was winter.
John 10:23 And Jesus was walking about the temple, in Solomon's portico.
John 10:24 Then the Jews came round Him, and said unto Him, How long dost thou hold us in suspense? If thou be the Messiah, tell us plainly.
John 10:25 Jesus answered them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I have told you, and ye do not believe <transChange>me: though</transChange> the works that I do in the name of my Father, testify of me.</q>
John 10:26 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But ye believe not; because ye are not of my sheep: <transChange>for</transChange> as I said unto you, my sheep hear my voice,</q>
John 10:27 <q marker="" who="Jesus">and I know them, and they follow me.</q>
John 10:28 <q marker="" who="Jesus">And I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish; nor shall any one force them out of my hand.</q>
John 10:29 <q marker="" who="Jesus">My Father who gave <transChange>them</transChange> to me, is greater than all: and <transChange>therefore</transChange> none is able to force <transChange>them</transChange> out of my Father's hand.</q>
John 10:30 <q marker="" who="Jesus">I and the Father are one. Then the Jews again took up stones to stone Him.</q>
John 10:31 <transChange>But</transChange> Jesus said unto them,
John 10:32 <q marker="" who="Jesus">Many good works have I shewn you from my Father; for which of those works do ye stone me?</q>
John 10:33 The Jews answered Him, saying, We do not <transChange>go about to</transChange> stone thee for a good work, but for blasphemy; and because thou being a man makest thyself God.
John 10:34 Jesus replied, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Is it not written in your law, "I have said, ye are gods?"</q>

John 18:0 <chapter osisID="John.18" sID="gen3731"/>
John 18:1 When Jesus had spoken these words, He went out with his disciples over the brook Kedron; where there was a garden, into which He entred, and his disciples. Now Judas who was <transChange>gone</transChange> to betray Him,
John 18:2 knew the place: for Jesus often met there together with his disciples: Judas therefore having got a band <transChange>of soldiers,</transChange>
John 18:3 and officers from the chief priests and pharisees, cometh thither with candles, and lamps, and arms.
John 18:4 Upon which Jesus, who knew all that was coming upon Him, went forth and said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Whom do ye seek?</q> They answered Him, Jesus the Nazarene.
John 18:5 Jesus saith unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am <transChange>He.</transChange></q> And Judas that betrayed Him, was standing with them.
John 18:6 Now as soon as He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am <transChange>He,</transChange></q> they went backwards and fell to the ground.
John 18:7 Then He asked them again, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Whom do ye seek?</q>
John 18:8 And they said, Jesus the Nazarene. Jesus answered, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I have told you that I am <transChange>He:</transChange> if therefore ye seek me, let these go their way:</q>
John 18:9 That the word might be fulfilled which He had spoken, <q marker="" who="Jesus">"Of those, whom Thou hast given me, I have lost none."</q>
John 18:10 Then Simon Peter, having a sword, drew it, and smote the high priest's servant, and cut off his right ear. The servant's name was Malchus.
John 18:11 But Jesus said to Peter, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Put up thy sword into the sheath: the cup which my Father hath given me, shall I not drink it?</q>
John 18:12 So the band with the captain, and the officers of the Jews seized Jesus, and bound Him:
John 18:13 and led Him away to Annas first: (for he was father-in-law to Caiaphas, who was high-priest that year:)
John 18:14 and Annas sent Him bound to Caiaphas the high-priest. Now Caiaphas was he who had said in council to the Jews, that it was expedient that one man should die for the people.
John 18:15 And Simon Peter and another disciple followed Jesus. And that <transChange>other</transChange> disciple being known to the high priest went in with Jesus into the high-priest's hall.
John 18:16 But Peter stood at the door without: the other disciple therefore, who was known to the high-priest, went out and spake to her that kept the door, and brought Peter in.
John 18:17 Then saith the maid, that kept the door, to Peter, Art not thou also <transChange>one</transChange> of this man's disciples? <transChange>and</transChange> he said, I am not.
John 18:18 And the servants and officers stood <transChange>there,</transChange> having made a fire of coals, for it was cold, and were warming themselves: and Peter was standing with them and warming himself.
John 18:19 The high-priest therefore asked Jesus concerning his disciples, and his doctrine.
John 18:20 Jesus answered him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I spake openly to the world, I always taught in the synagogue and in the temple, whither the Jews are continually resorting: and in secret have said nothing. Why dost thou ask me?</q>
John 18:21 <q marker="" who="Jesus">ask them that heard <transChange>me,</transChange> what I have said unto them: for they know what I have said.</q>
John 18:22 And upon his saying these <transChange>things,</transChange> one of the officers that stood by struck Jesus, saying, Dost thou answer the high-priest thus?
John 18:23 Jesus answered him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">If I have <transChange>ever</transChange> spoken evil, bear witness of the evil: but if well, why dost thou strike me?</q>
John 18:24 <transChange>[See verse 24 between verse 13 and 14.]</transChange>
John 18:25 And Simon Peter stood warming himself: and they said to him, Art not thou <transChange>one</transChange> of his disciples? <transChange>and</transChange> he denied <transChange>it,</transChange> and said, I am not.
John 18:26 <transChange>Then</transChange> said one of the servants of the high-priest, kinsman <transChange>to him</transChange> whose ear Peter cut off, Did not I see thee in the garden with Him?
John 18:27 Peter then denied <transChange>it</transChange> again, and immediately the cock crew.
John 18:28 Then they led Jesus from Caiaphas to the pretorium: (now it was morning) and they themselves went not in to the court, least they should be defiled, and <transChange>so might</transChange> not eat <transChange>of</transChange> the passover.
John 18:29 Therefore Pilate went out to them, and said, What accusation do ye bring against this man?
John 18:30 They answered him, If He were not a malefactor, we should not have delivered Him to thee.
John 18:31 Then said Pilate to them, Take Him, and judge Him according to your law. But the Jews said to him, It is not lawful for us to put any man to death:
John 18:32 that what Jesus had said might be fulfilled, signifying by what death He should die.
John 18:33 Pilate therefore went into the palace again, and called Jesus and said to Him, Art thou the king of the Jews?
John 18:34 Jesus answered him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Dost thou say this from thyself, or did others tell <transChange>it</transChange> thee of me?</q>
John 18:35 Pilate replied, Am I a Jew? thine own nation, and the chief priests, have delivered thee to me: what hast thou done?
John 18:36 Jesus answered, <q marker="" who="Jesus">My kingdom is not of this world: if my kingdom were of this world, my servants would have fought, that I might not have been delivered to the Jews: but my kingdom is not from hence.</q>
John 18:37 Pilate therefore said unto Him, Art thou then a king? Jesus answered, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thou sayest <transChange>right,</transChange> I am a king. For this <transChange>end</transChange> was I born, and for this came I into the world, <transChange>even</transChange> that I might bear witness to the truth. Every one that is of the truth, heareth my voice.</q>
John 18:38 Pilate saith unto Him, What is truth? And as soon as he had spoke, he went out again to the Jews,
John 18:39 and saith unto them, I find no fault at all in Him. But ye have a custom, that I should release to you one at the passover; will ye therefore <transChange>that</transChange> I release to you the king of the Jews?
John 18:40 Then they all cried out again, saying, Not Him, but Barabbas. Now Barabbas was a robber. <chapter eID="gen3731" osisID="John.18"/>
John 19:0 <chapter osisID="John.19" sID="gen3772"/>
John 19:1 Then Pilate therefore took Jesus and scourged <transChange>Him.</transChange>
John 19:2 And the soldiers platted a crown of thorns, and put <transChange>it</transChange> on his head,
John 19:3 and threw a purple robe about Him, and said, "Hail king of the Jews," and struck Him with their hands.
John 19:4 Pilate therefore came out again, and saith unto them, Behold I bring Him out to you, that ye may know that I find no fault in Him.
John 19:5 So Jesus came out wearing the crown of thorns, and the purple robe. And Pilate saith unto them, "Behold the man."
John 19:6 When the chief priests therefore and the officers saw Him, they cried out, saying, "Crucify <transChange>Him,</transChange> crucify <transChange>Him.</transChange>" Pilate saith unto them, Take Him yourselves, and crucify <transChange>Him:</transChange> for I find no fault in Him.
John 19:7 The Jews answered him, We have a law, and by our law He ought to die, because He made himself the Son of God.
John 19:8 Now when Pilate heard this he was the more afraid;
John 19:9 and went into the palace again, and saith to Jesus, From whence art thou? but Jesus gave him no answer.
John 19:10 Pilate therefore saith unto Him, Dost thou not speak to me? knowest thou not that I have power to crucify thee, and have power to release thee?
John 19:11 Jesus answered, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Thou couldest have no power at all against me, except it were given thee from above; wherefore he, that delivered me up to thee, hath the greater sin.</q>
John 19:12 Upon this Pilate sought to release Him; but the Jews cried out, saying, If thou release this <transChange>man,</transChange> thou art not Cesar's friend; <transChange>for</transChange> whosoever maketh himself a king, opposeth Cesar.
John 19:13 Therefore when Pilate heard this he brought Jesus forth, and sat down on the tribunal, in a place called the Pavement, but in Hebrew, Gabbatha.
John 19:14 (And it was the preparation of the passover, and about the sixth hour.) And he saith to the Jews, Behold your king. But they cried out,
John 19:15 Away with <transChange>Him,</transChange> away with <transChange>Him,</transChange> crucify Him. Pilate saith unto them, Shall I crucify your king? The chief priests answered, We have no king but Cesar.
John 19:16 Then delivered he Him therefore unto them to be crucified.
John 19:17 And they took Jesus, and led Him away. And He went out, bearing his cross, into a place called <transChange>the place</transChange> of a scull, in Hebrew Golgotha:
John 19:18 where they crucified Him, and with Him two others, <transChange>one</transChange> on each side, and Jesus in the middle.
John 19:19 And Pilate wrote a title, and put it on the cross: and there was written, JESUS OF NAZARETH THE KING OF THE JEWS.
John 19:20 Many of the Jews therefore read this inscription; for the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city, and it was written in Hebrew, Greek, <transChange>and</transChange> Latin.
John 19:21 And the chief priests of the Jews said to Pilate, Write not "The king of the Jews," but that "He said, I am king of the Jews."
John 19:22 Pilate answered, What I have written, I have written.
John 19:23 And the soldiers, when they had crucified Jesus, took his garments, (and made four parts, to each soldier a part,) and <transChange>his</transChange> coat. Now the coat had no seam <transChange>in it,</transChange> being woven from the top throughout:
John 19:24 they said therefore to one another, Let us not cut it, but let us cast lots for it, whose it shall be: that the scripture might be fulfilled, which saith, "They parted my garments among them, and upon my vesture did they cast lots." These <transChange>things</transChange> therefore the soldiers did.
John 19:25 Now there stood near the cross of Jesus his mother, and his mother's sister, Mary <transChange>the wife</transChange> of Cleopas, and Mary Magdalene.
John 19:26 Jesus therefore seeing <transChange>his</transChange> mother, and the disciple whom He loved standing by, saith to his mother, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Woman, behold thy son:</q>
John 19:27 <transChange>and</transChange> then saith to the disciple, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Behold thy mother.</q> And from that hour the <transChange>same</transChange> disciple took her to his own home.
John 19:28 After this Jesus knowing that all <transChange>things</transChange> were now finished, that the scripture might be fulfilled, saith, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I thirst.</q>
John 19:29 Now there was set a vessel <transChange>there</transChange> full of vinegar: so they filled a spunge with <transChange>the</transChange> vinegar, and putting it upon hyssop, held it up to his mouth.
John 19:30 And when Jesus had received the vinegar, He said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">It is finished.</q> And reclining his head, He yielded up the ghost.
John 19:31 The Jews therefore, that the bodies might not remain upon the cross on the sabbath-<transChange>day,</transChange> because it was <transChange>now</transChange> the preparation, (for that sabbath-day was an high-<transChange>day</transChange>) desired Pilate that their legs might be broken, and <transChange>that</transChange> they might be taken away.
John 19:32 So the soldiers came, and brake the legs of the first, and of the other that was crucified with Him. But coming to Jesus,
John 19:33 as they saw He was dead already, they did not break his legs:
John 19:34 but one of the soldiers pierced his side with a spear, and immediately there came out blood and water.
John 19:35 And he that saw <transChange>it</transChange> testifieth <transChange>it,</transChange> and his testimony is true: and he knoweth that he saith true, that ye may believe.
John 19:36 For these <transChange>things</transChange> were done, that the scripture might be fulfilled, Not a bone of Him shall be broken.
John 19:37 And again another scripture saith, They shall look on Him whom they have pierced.
John 19:38 And after these <transChange>things</transChange> Joseph of Arimathea (who was a disciple of Jesus, but <transChange>a</transChange> concealed <transChange>one</transChange> for fear of the Jews) petitioned Pilate, that he might take away the body of Jesus; and Pilate gave <transChange>him</transChange> leave: he came therefore and took away the body of Jesus.
John 19:39 And there came also Nicodemus (who at first came to Jesus by night) and brought a mixture of myrrh and aloes about an hundred pound <transChange>weight.</transChange>
John 19:40 So they took the body of Jesus, and wound it in linen cloths, with the spices, as the custom of the Jews is to bury.
John 19:41 Now there was a garden in the place where He was crucified; and in the garden a new sepulchre, in which none had ever yet been laid.
John 19:42 There therefore they laid Jesus, because of the Jews preparation-<transChange>day;</transChange> for the sepulchre was near. <chapter eID="gen3772" osisID="John.19"/>
John 20:0 <chapter osisID="John.20" sID="gen3815"/>
John 20:1 Now on the first <transChange>day</transChange> of the week Mary Magdalene cometh early in the morning, while it was yet dark, to the sepulchre, and seeth the stone taken away from the sepulchre.
John 20:2 She therefore runneth and cometh to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple whom Jesus loved, and saith unto them, They have taken away the Lord out of the sepulchre, and we know not where they have laid Him.
John 20:3 Peter therefore went out, and that other disciple, and came to the sepulchre.
John 20:4 So they both ran together, but the other disciple out-ran Peter, and came first to the sepulchre:
John 20:5 and stooping down <transChange>to look in</transChange> saw the linen cloths lying; but did not go in.
John 20:6 Then cometh Simon Peter, who followed him, and went into the sepulchre, and seeth the linen cloths lying <transChange>there;</transChange>
John 20:7 and the napkin that was upon his head, not laid with the linen cloths, but folded up by itself.
John 20:8 Then went in also the other disciple; who came first to the sepulchre, and he saw and believed.
John 20:9 For they did not before understand the scripture, that He must rise from the dead.

Acts 1:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.1" sID="gen3874"/>
Acts 1:1 <hi type="bold">The</hi> former treatise, O Theophilus, I made concerning all that Jesus undertook both to do and to teach;
Acts 1:2 till the day in which He was taken up, after He had by the holy Spirit given instructions to the apostles whom He had chosen:
Acts 1:3 to whom also He presented Himself alive, after He had suffered, by many certain proofs; being seen among them for forty days, and speaking of the things relating to the kingdom of God.
Acts 1:4 And meeting <transChange>them</transChange> together He commanded them not to depart from Jerusalem, but to wait for the promise of the Father, <q marker="" who="Jesus">which,</q> <transChange>said He,</transChange> <q marker="" who="Jesus">ye have heard from me;</q>
Acts 1:5 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for John indeed baptized with water, but ye shall within a few days be baptized with the holy Spirit.</q>
Acts 1:6 Being therefore come together they asked Him, saying, Lord, wilt thou at this time restore the kingdom to Israel?
Acts 1:7 And He said unto them, <q marker="" who="Jesus">It is not for you to know the times or seasons, which the Father hath reserved in his own power.</q>
Acts 1:8 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But ye shall receive power <transChange>from</transChange> the holy Spirit coming upon you: and ye shall be my witnesses both in Jerusalem, and in all Judea, and Samaria, and to the uttermost <transChange>part</transChange> of the earth.</q>
Acts 1:9 And having said these <transChange>things,</transChange> as they were looking <transChange>upon Him,</transChange> He was lifted up, and a cloud received Him out of their sight.
Acts 1:10 And while they were looking stedfastly toward heaven, as He went <transChange>up,</transChange> behold two men in white stood by them;
Acts 1:11 who said, Ye men of Galilee, why do ye stand gazing up to heaven? This Jesus who is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come in the manner ye have seen Him going into heaven.
Acts 1:12 Then they returned to Jerusalem from the mountain called Olivet, which is from Jerusalem a sabbath-day's journey.
Acts 1:13 And when they were come in <transChange>to the city,</transChange> they went up into an upper room, where Peter, and James, and John, and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew, and Matthew, James <transChange>the son</transChange> of Alpheus, and Simon the zealot, and Jude <transChange>the brother</transChange> of James, <transChange>usually</transChange> abode.
Acts 1:14 These all persevered with one accord in prayer and supplication with the women, and Mary the mother of Jesus, and his brethren.
Acts 1:15 And in these days Peter stood up in the midst of the disciples, (now the number of the persons <transChange>that were</transChange> together was about an hundred and twenty,)
Acts 1:16 and said, Men <transChange>and</transChange> brethren, it was necessary that this scripture should be fulfilled, which the holy Ghost spake by the mouth of David, concerning Judas, who was guide to them that apprehended Jesus:
Acts 1:17 for he was numbered with us, and had obtained a part of this ministry.
Acts 1:18 (Now this <transChange>man</transChange> purchased a field with the reward of iniquity; and falling down on his face, burst asunder in the middle, and all his bowels gushed out:
Acts 1:19 (and it was known to all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the field is called in their own dialect, Aceldama, that is, the field of blood:)
Acts 1:20 for it is written in the book of Psalms, Let his habitation be desolate, and let none dwell in it; and <transChange>again,</transChange> Let another take his office.)
Acts 1:21 Wherefore it is necessary that one of these men, who have been conversant with us all the time that the Lord Jesus came in and out among us,
Acts 1:22 from the baptism of John, till the day that He was taken up from us, should be <transChange>joined</transChange> with us <transChange>as</transChange> a witness of his resurrection.
Acts 1:23 And they proposed two, Joseph called Barsabas, who was surnamed Justus, and Matthias.
Acts 1:24 And they prayed and said, Thou, Lord, who knowest the hearts of all, shew <transChange>us,</transChange> which of these two Thou hast chosen,
Acts 1:25 to take part of this ministry and apostleship, from which Judas is fallen by his transgression, that he might go to his own place.
Acts 1:26 And they gave <transChange>out</transChange> their lots, and the lot fell upon Matthias, and he was numbered with the apostles. <chapter eID="gen3874" osisID="Acts.1"/>
Acts 2:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.2" sID="gen3901"/>
Acts 2:1 And when the day of Pentecost was fully come, they were all <transChange>met</transChange> together with one accord.
Acts 2:2 And suddenly there was a sound from heaven as of a strong rushing wind, and it filled all the house where they were sitting.
Acts 2:3 And there appeared unto them divided tongues, as it were of fire, and it sat upon each of them:
Acts 2:4 and they were all filled with the holy Spirit, and began to speak in other languages, as the Spirit gave them utterance.
Acts 2:5 Now there were at Jerusalem Jews, devout men, from every nation under heaven.
Acts 2:6 And when this rumor was spread, the multitude came together and were astonished; for every one heard them speaking in his own language.
Acts 2:7 And they were all amazed and wondered, saying to one another, Behold, are not all these, that are speaking, Galileans?
Acts 2:8 and how do we every one hear them in our own native tongue?
Acts 2:9 Parthians and Medes and Elamites, and those that dwell in Mesopotamia, and Judea, and Capadocia, Pontus and Asia, Phrygia and Pamphylia,
Acts 2:10 Egypt and the parts of Libya about Cyrene, and strangers from Rome, Jews and proselytes,
Acts 2:11 Cretans and Arabians, we hear them speaking in our <transChange>own</transChange> tongues the wonderful <transChange>works</transChange> of God.
Acts 2:12 And they were all amazed and in doubt, saying one to another, What can this mean?
Acts 2:13 but others scoffing said, they are full of sweet wine.
Acts 2:14 But Peter standing up with the eleven, raised his voice and said unto them, <transChange>Ye</transChange> men of Judea, and all <transChange>ye</transChange> that dwell at Jerusalem, be this known unto you, and listen to my words:

Acts 2:16 But this is that <transChange>which was</transChange> spoken of by the prophet Joel,

Acts 2:18 yea and on my servants and on my handmaids, in those days, I will pour out of my Spirit, and they <transChange>also</transChange> shall prophesy.
Acts 2:19 And I will give prodigies in the heaven, and signs upon the earth; blood, and fire, and smoky vapour.
Acts 2:20 The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before that great and illustrious day of the Lord come.
Acts 2:21 And whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord, shall be saved."
Acts 2:22 Ye men of Israel, hear these words; Jesus of Nazareth, a man approved of God among you, by miracles, and prodigies, and signs, which God wrought by Him in the midst of you,
Acts 2:23 (as <transChange>ye</transChange> yourselves also know,) Him being given up by the determinate counsel and fore-knowlege of God ye have taken, and by wicked hands have crucified and slain.
Acts 2:24 Whom God hath raised up again, having loosed the pains of death, because it was not possible that He should be held by it.
Acts 2:25 For David saith concerning Him, "I set the Lord always before me, for He is at my right hand, that I should not be moved: therefore my heart rejoiced, and my tongue was glad;
Acts 2:26 and my flesh shall rest in hope,
Acts 2:27 that Thou wilt not leave my soul in the invisible state, nor suffer thine holy <transChange>one</transChange> to see corruption.
Acts 2:28 Thou hast made known to me the ways of life; <transChange>and</transChange> Thou wilt fill me with joy by <transChange>the light of</transChange> thy countenance."
Acts 2:29 Men <transChange>and</transChange> brethren, allow me to speak with freedom to you concerning the patriarch David, that he is dead and buried, and his sepulchre is among us to this day.
Acts 2:30 Therefore being a prophet; and knowing that God had sworn to him with an oath, that of the fruit of his loins, according to the flesh, he would raise up the Messiah, to sit on his throne;
Acts 2:31 foreseeing <transChange>this</transChange> he spake of the resurrection of Christ, <transChange>when he said,</transChange> that his soul was not left in the invisible state, nor did his flesh see corruption.
Acts 2:32 This Jesus hath God raised up <transChange>from the dead,</transChange> of which we all are witnesses.
Acts 2:33 Therefore being exalted by the right <transChange>hand</transChange> of God, and having received of the Father the promise of the holy Spirit, He hath poured forth this <transChange>gift,</transChange> which ye now see and hear.
Acts 2:34 For David is not ascended into the heavens: but <transChange>he</transChange> himself says, "The Lord said to my Lord,
Acts 2:35 Sit <transChange>thou</transChange> at my right <transChange>hand,</transChange> till I make thine enemies thy footstool."
Acts 2:36 Therefore let all the house of Israel know assuredly, that God hath made this very Jesus, whom ye crucified, <transChange>both</transChange> Lord and Christ.
Acts 2:37 Now when they heard <transChange>this,</transChange> they were pricked to the heart, and said unto Peter, and <transChange>to</transChange> the rest of the apostles, Brethren, what shall we do?
Acts 2:38 And Peter said unto them, Repent and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ, for the remission of <transChange>your</transChange> sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the holy Spirit:
Acts 2:39 for the promise is to you and to your children, <transChange>yea</transChange> and to all that are afar off, <transChange>even</transChange> as many as the Lord our God shall call.
Acts 2:40 And with many other words did he press and exhort <transChange>them,</transChange> saying, Save yourselves from this perverse generation.
Acts 2:41 They therefore that received his word with readiness were baptized: and in that <transChange>same</transChange> day there were added unto <transChange>them</transChange> about three thousand souls.
Acts 2:42 And they continued stedfast in the apostles doctrine, and fellowship, and <transChange>in</transChange> the breaking of bread, and <transChange>in</transChange> prayers.
Acts 2:43 And fear came upon all the people: and many miracles and signs were wrought by the apostles.
Acts 2:44 And all that believed were together, and had all things common.
Acts 2:45 And they sold <transChange>their</transChange> possessions and goods, and distributed to all, according as any one had need.
Acts 2:46 And continuing daily with one accord in the temple, and breaking bread from house to house, they partook of their food with gladness and simplicity of heart,
Acts 2:47 praising God, and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to the church daily such as should be saved. <chapter eID="gen3901" osisID="Acts.2"/>
Acts 3:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.3" sID="gen3949"/>
Acts 3:1 Now Peter and John were going up to the temple together at the hour of prayer, <transChange>which is</transChange> the ninth <transChange>hour.</transChange>
Acts 3:2 And a certain man who had been lame from his birth was carried <transChange>along;</transChange> whom they laid every day at the gate of the temple, <transChange>which is</transChange> called Beautiful, to ask alms of those that were going into the temple:
Acts 3:3 who seeing Peter and John about to go into the temple, asked alms <transChange>of them.</transChange>
Acts 3:4 But Peter, and John, looking earnestly at him said, Look on us.
Acts 3:5 And he fixed <transChange>his eyes</transChange> upon them, expecting to receive something from them.
Acts 3:6 But Peter said, Silver and gold I have not; but what I have I give thee: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk.
Acts 3:7 And taking him by the right hand, he raised <transChange>him</transChange> up: and immediately his feet and ancles were strengthened:
Acts 3:8 and leaping up he stood <transChange>firm,</transChange> and walked; and entered with them into the temple, walking, and leaping, and praising God.
Acts 3:9 And all the people saw him walking and praising God:
Acts 3:10 and knew that it was he who sat <transChange>to ask</transChange> for alms at the Beautiful gate of the temple: and they were filled with astonishment and extasy at what had befallen him.
Acts 3:11 And as the lame <transChange>man</transChange> that was healed had hold of Peter and John, all the people being astonished ran together to them to the porch called Solomon's <transChange>porch.</transChange>
Acts 3:12 And Peter seeing <transChange>this</transChange> said to the people, Men of Israel, why marvel ye at this, or why look ye <transChange>so</transChange> earnestly on us, as if by our own power or piety we had made this <transChange>man able</transChange> to walk?
Acts 3:13 The God of Abraham and of Isaac and of Jacob, the God of our fathers hath glorified his son Jesus, whom ye delivered up, and denied before Pilate, when he determined to release <transChange>Him.</transChange>
Acts 3:14 But ye refused the holy and righteous <transChange>One,</transChange> and desired a murderer to be granted unto you:
Acts 3:15 and put to death the prince of life; whom God hath raised from the dead, of which we are witnesses.
Acts 3:16 And through faith in his name, hath strengthened this <transChange>man,</transChange> whom ye see and know: his name, <transChange>I say,</transChange> and saith in Him, hath wrought this perfect cure before you all.
Acts 3:17 And now, brethren, I know that ye did it through ignorance, as <transChange>did</transChange> also your rulers:
Acts 3:18 but thus hath God accomplished those things which He had foretold by the mouth of all his prophets, that Christ should suffer.
Acts 3:19 Repent therefore and be converted, that your sins may be blotted out: that seasons of refreshing may come <transChange>upon you</transChange> from the presence of the Lord;
Acts 3:20 and He may send Jesus Christ, who was before preached unto you:
Acts 3:21 whom heaven must indeed receive till the times of settling all things, of which God hath spoken by the mouth of all his holy prophets from the beginning.
Acts 3:22 For Moses said unto the fathers, the Lord your God will raise up a prophet unto you, of your brethren, <transChange>like</transChange> me, Him shall ye hear in all <transChange>things</transChange> whatever He shall say unto you;
Acts 3:23 and every soul, who will not hearken to that prophet, shall be destroyed from among the people: yea and all the prophets from Samuel,
Acts 3:24 and those that followed, as many as have prophesied, have also foretold these days.
Acts 3:25 <transChange>Now</transChange> ye are the children of the prophets, and of the covenant, which God made with our fathers, saying to Abraham, "And in thy seed shall all the families of the earth be blessed:"

Acts 4:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.4" sID="gen3976"/>
Acts 4:1 And while they were speaking to the people, the priests, and the captain of the temple, and the sadducees came upon them,
Acts 4:2 being vexed that they taught the people, and preached through Jesus the resurrection from the dead.
Acts 4:3 And they laid hands on them, and put them into custody till the next day: for it was now evening.
Acts 4:4 But many of them who heard the word, believed: and the number of the men was about five thousand.
Acts 4:5 And on the morrow their rulers, and elders, and scribes were gathered together at Jerusalem:
Acts 4:6 and <transChange>with them</transChange> Annas the high priest, and Caiaphas, and John, and Alexander, and as many as were of the kindred of the high priest.
Acts 4:7 And when they had set them in the midst, they asked <transChange>them,</transChange> By what power, or in what name have ye done this?
Acts 4:8 Then Peter filled with the holy Spirit said unto them, Ye rulers of the people,

Acts 4:10 by what <transChange>means</transChange> he is cured, be it known to you all, and to all the people of Israel, that by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom ye crucified, <transChange>but</transChange> whom God hath raised from the dead, <transChange>even</transChange> by Him doth this <transChange>man</transChange> stand <transChange>here</transChange> before you whole.
Acts 4:11 This is the stone that was set at nought by you builders, which is become the head of the corner.
Acts 4:12 And there is salvation in no other; for there is no other name under heaven given among men, by which we can be saved.
Acts 4:13 Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, and perceived that they were plain and illiterate men, they were amazed; and they knew them again that they had been with Jesus:
Acts 4:14 but seeing the man that was cured standing with them, they had nothing to say against <transChange>it.</transChange>
Acts 4:15 Therefore they ordered them to withdraw from the council,

Acts 4:17 But that it may spread no farther among the people, let us severely charge them to speak no more to any man in this name.
Acts 4:18 So they called them and commanded them not to speak at all, nor teach in the name of Jesus.
Acts 4:19 But Peter and John answered them, and said, Whether it be right in the sight of God to obey you rather than God, judge <transChange>ye:</transChange>
Acts 4:20 for we cannot but speak <transChange>the things</transChange> which we have seen and heard.
Acts 4:21 So they threatened them more <transChange>severely,</transChange> and let them go; not finding how to punish them, because of the people: for they all glorified God for that which was done.
Acts 4:22 For the man was above forty years old, on whom this miraculous cure was wrought.
Acts 4:23 Being dismissed they went to their own <transChange>company,</transChange> and reported all that the chief priests and elders had said to them.
Acts 4:24 And when they heard <transChange>it,</transChange> they lifted up their voice to God with one accord, and said, Lord, Thou <transChange>art</transChange> God, who hast made heaven and earth, and sea, and all <transChange>things</transChange> therein:

Acts 6:1 Now in those days, as the number of disciples increased, there rose a murmuring of the Grecians against the Hebrews, because their widows were neglected in the daily distribution.

Acts 6:4 but we will constantly attend to prayer, and to the ministry of the word.

Acts 7:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.7" sID="gen4073"/>
Acts 7:1 Then said the high priest, Are these things so?
Acts 7:2 And he said, "Brethren and fathers, hearken,---The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham, when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Charran,
Acts 7:3 and said to him, Depart from thy <transChange>native</transChange> country and from thy kindred, and come into the country which I shall shew thee.
Acts 7:4 Then he came out of the land of the Chaldeans, and dwelt in Charran: and from thence, after his father died, He removed him into this land in which ye now dwell:
Acts 7:5 though He gave him no inheritance in it, no not the breadth of a foot; but He promised to give it to him for a possession, even to his seed after him; though he had <transChange>then</transChange> no child."
Acts 7:6 And God spake thus <transChange>unto him,</transChange> "that his seed should sojourn in a strange country, and they shall in slave and abuse them four hundred years:"
Acts 7:7 and God said, "I will judge the nation, to which they shall be in slavery; and afterwards they shall come out, and shall worship me in this place."
Acts 7:8 And He gave him the covenant of circumcision: and he begat Isaac, and circumcised him <transChange>on</transChange> the eighth day; and Isaac Jacob, and Jacob the twelve patriarchs.
Acts 7:9 And the patriarchs, envying <transChange>him,</transChange> sold Joseph into Egypt: but God was with him,
Acts 7:10 and delivered him out of all his afflictions, and gave him favor and wisdom in the sight of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he appointed him governor over Egypt, and <transChange>over</transChange> all his houshold.
Acts 7:11 And there came a famine over all the land of Egypt and Canaan, and great affliction; and our fathers could not find sustenance.
Acts 7:12 But Jacob hearing that there was corn in Egypt, sent out our fathers first:
Acts 7:13 and at the second <transChange>time</transChange> Joseph was made known to his brethren; and Joseph's kindred was made known to Pharaoh.
Acts 7:14 Then Joseph sent for his father Jacob, and all his kindred, even seventy-five souls.
Acts 7:15 So Jacob went down into Egypt, and died <transChange>there,</transChange> he and our fathers:
Acts 7:16 and were carried to Sychem, and laid in the sepulchre which he had bought for a sum of money of the sons of Emmor <transChange>the father</transChange> of Sychem.
Acts 7:17 But as the time of the promise drew near, which God had sworn to Abraham, the people increased and multiplied in Egypt.
Acts 7:18 Till another king arose, who knew not Joseph. This <transChange>king</transChange> formed crafty schemes against our nation,
Acts 7:19 and oppressed our fathers, causing their children to be exposed, that their race might be extinguished.
Acts 7:20 In which time Moses was born, who was exceeding beautiful, and he was nourished up in his father's house three months: and when he was exposed,
Acts 7:21 Pharaoh's daughter took him up and nourished him for her own son.
Acts 7:22 And Moses was trained up in all the wisdom of the Egyptians: and he was mighty in words, and in deeds.
Acts 7:23 And when he was full forty years old, it came into his heart to visit his brethren the children of Israel.
Acts 7:24 And seeing one of them injured he defended <transChange>him,</transChange> and smiting the Egyptian he avenged him that was wronged.
Acts 7:25 Now he supposed that his brethren would have understood that God would give them deliverance by his hand: but they understood not.
Acts 7:26 And the next day he came to them, as they were <transChange>two of them</transChange> fighting, and <transChange>would have</transChange> persuaded them to agree, saying, Sirs, ye are brethren, why do ye injure one another?
Acts 7:27 But he, that injured his neighbor, thrust him away, saying, Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?
Acts 7:28 Wilt thou kill me, as thou killedst the Egyptian yesterday?
Acts 7:29 Upon this Moses fled, and became a sojourner in the land of Midian, where he begat two sons.
Acts 7:30 And when forty years were expired, there appeared to him in the wilderness of mount Sina, an angel of the Lord in a flame of fire in a bush.
Acts 7:31 Now Moses, when he saw it, was amazed at the sight; and as he came near to observe it, there was a voice of the Lord to him,

Acts 7:33 And the Lord said to him, "Take off thy shoes from thy feet: for the place on which thou standest is holy ground.
Acts 7:34 I have seen the oppression of my people <transChange>that are</transChange> in Egypt, and I have heard their groaning, and am come down to deliver them. Therefore come now, and I will send thee into Egypt."
Acts 7:35 This Moses whom they refused, saying, Who made thee a ruler and a judge? did God send, by the hand of the angel that appeared to him in the bush, <transChange>to be their</transChange> ruler and deliverer.
