Acts 8:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.8" sID="gen4134"/>
Acts 8:1 And Saul was well pleased with his execution. For at that time there was a great persecution against the church in Jerusalem, and they were all dispersed through the regions of Judea and Samaria, except the apostles.
Acts 8:2 And <transChange>some</transChange> pious men carried Stephen <transChange>to his burial,</transChange> and made great lamentation for him.
Acts 8:3 But Saul made havock of the church, entring into the houses, and dragging <transChange>out</transChange> men and women, committed <transChange>them</transChange> to prison.
Acts 8:4 Now they that were dispersed went about preaching the word.
Acts 8:5 And Philip coming to the city of Samaria, preached Christ unto them.
Acts 8:6 And the people unanimously attended to the things which were spoken by Philip, hearing and seeing the miracles which he wrought:
Acts 8:7 for impure spirits crying with a loud voice came out of many that were possessed <transChange>by them;</transChange> and many paralytic and lame <transChange>persons</transChange> were cured.
Acts 8:8 And there was great joy in that city.
Acts 8:9 But there was before in the city a man named Simon practising magic and bewitching the people of Samaria, giving out that he was some great <transChange>person.</transChange>
Acts 8:10 Whom they all <transChange>greatly</transChange> regarded, from the lest to the greatest, saying, This <transChange>man</transChange> is <transChange>as</transChange> the great power of God.
Acts 8:11 And they were attentive to him, because he had for a considerable time astonished them by <transChange>his</transChange> magic <transChange>arts.</transChange>
Acts 8:12 But as they believed Philip, preaching the <transChange>things</transChange> concerning the kingdom of God, and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women;
Acts 8:13 and Simon himself also believed, and was baptized, and kept constantly with Philip: and beholding the signs and miracles <transChange>that were</transChange> wrought, he was amazed.
Acts 8:14 Now when the apostles at Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent to them Peter and John:
Acts 8:15 who when they were come down prayed for them that they might receive the holy Spirit: (for He was not yet fallen upon any of them,
Acts 8:16 only they were baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus:) <transChange>and</transChange> then they laid <transChange>their</transChange> hands on them,
Acts 8:17 and they received the holy Spirit.
Acts 8:18 And when Simon saw that the holy Spirit was given by the imposition of the hands of the apostles, he offered them money,
Acts 8:19 saying, Give me also this power, that on whomsoever I lay hands, he may receive the holy Spirit.
Acts 8:20 But Peter said unto him, Let thy money perish with thee, since thou thoughtest to purchase the gift of God with money.
Acts 8:21 Thou hast no part nor lot in this matter: for thy heart is not right in the sight of God.
Acts 8:22 Repent therefore of this thy wickedness, and pray to God, if so be the thought of thine heart may be forgiven thee:
Acts 8:23 for I perceive that thou art in the gall of bitterness and bond of iniquity.
Acts 8:24 And Simon answered, and said, Do ye pray to the Lord for me, that none <transChange>of the things</transChange> which ye have spoken may come upon me.
Acts 8:25 And they having testified and declared the word of the Lord, returned to Jerusalem, and preached the gospel in many villages of the Samaritans.
Acts 8:26 And an angel of the Lord spake to Philip, saying, Arise and go southward to the way that leads down from Jerusalem to Gaza, which is desert.
Acts 8:27 And he arose and went; and behold a man of Ethiopia, an eunuch of great authority under Candace queen of the Ethiopians, and her high-treasurer, who had come to Jerusalem to worship,
Acts 8:28 was returning, and as he sat in his chariot, was reading the prophet Esaias:
Acts 8:29 and the Spirit said to Philip, Go near and join thyself to this chariot. And Philip running <transChange>up</transChange> to <transChange>him,</transChange>
Acts 8:30 heard him reading the prophet Esaias, and said, Dost thou understand what thou readest?
Acts 8:31 And he said, How can I, unless some one guide me? and he desired Philip to come up and sit with him.
Acts 8:32 And the portion of scripture, which he was reading, was this, "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb before it's shearer <transChange>is</transChange> dumb, so He opened not his mouth:
Acts 8:33 in his humiliation his judgement was taken away, and who shall declare his generation? for his life is taken away from the earth."
Acts 8:34 And the eunuch answered Philip, and said, I pray thee, of whom doth the prophet say this? of himself, or of some other <transChange>person?</transChange>
Acts 8:35 Then Philip opened his mouth, and beginning at this scripture, preached unto him Jesus.
Acts 8:36 And as they went on <transChange>their</transChange> way, they came to a certain water: and the eunuch said, See <transChange>here is</transChange> water, what hindereth me from being baptized?
Acts 8:37 And Philip said, If thou believest with all thine heart, thou mayest. And he said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.
Acts 8:38 And he ordered the chariot to stop: and they both went down to the water, Philip and the eunuch; and he baptized him.
Acts 8:39 And when they were come up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, and the eunuch saw him no more: but went on his way rejoicing.
Acts 8:40 But Philip was found at Azotus; and as he passed along, he preached the gospel in all the cities, till he came to Cesarea. <chapter eID="gen4134" osisID="Acts.8"/>
Acts 9:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.9" sID="gen4175"/>
Acts 9:1 But Saul still breathing <transChange>out</transChange> threatnings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord, came to the high priest, and desired of him letters to the synagogues at Damascus,
Acts 9:2 that if he should find any of this persuasion, men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.
Acts 9:3 And as he was on his journey, and came near to Damascus, suddenly there shone <transChange>round</transChange> about him a light from heaven;
Acts 9:4 and he fell to the ground, and heard a voice saying to him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?</q>
Acts 9:5 And he said, Who art Thou, Lord? And the Lord said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am Jesus <transChange>the Nazarene</transChange> whom thou art persecuting: <transChange>it is</transChange> hard for thee to kick against the goads.</q>
Acts 9:6 And he trembling and astonished said, Lord, what wilt Thou have me to do? And the Lord said unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Arise and go into the city, and it shall be told thee, what thou must do.</q>
Acts 9:7 And the men that went along with him, stood astonished, hearing the voice, but seeing no one.
Acts 9:8 And Saul rose from the earth, but when he opened his eyes he could not see: so they led him by the hand, and brought him to Damascus.
Acts 9:9 And he was three days without sight, and did neither eat nor drink.
Acts 9:10 Now there was a certain disciple at Damascus, named Ananias, and the Lord said to him in a vision, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Ananias,</q> and he said, Behold, I <transChange>am here,</transChange> Lord.
Acts 9:11 And the Lord <transChange>said</transChange> unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Arise and go into the street which is called Strait, and enquire in the house of Judas for <transChange>one</transChange> Saul, of Tarsus:</q>
Acts 9:12 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for behold he is praying, and hath seen in a vision a man named Ananias, coming in and putting <transChange>his</transChange> hand upon him, that he might recover his sight.</q>
Acts 9:13 And Ananias answered, Lord, I have heard from many of this man, how much mischief he hath done to thy saints at Jerusalem:
Acts 9:14 and here <transChange>too</transChange> he hath authority from the chief priests to apprehend all that call upon thy name.
Acts 9:15 But the Lord said unto him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Go thy way, for he is the instrument I have chosen, to bear my name before the Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel:</q>
Acts 9:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for I will shew him how great <transChange>sufferings</transChange> he must endure for my name.</q>
Acts 9:17 And Ananias went away and came into the house; and putting his hands on him, said, "Brother Saul, the Lord, <transChange>even</transChange> Jesus, who appeared to thee on the way as thou camest, hath sent me, that thou mightest receive thy sight, and be filled with the holy Spirit."
Acts 9:18 And immediately there fell from his eyes as it were scales; and he instantly recovered his sight, and arose and was baptized.
Acts 9:19 And when he had taken <transChange>some</transChange> nourishment, he was strengthened. Now Saul was with the disciples at Damascus <transChange>for</transChange> some time.
Acts 9:20 And he immediately preached Christ in the synagogues, that He is the Son of God.
Acts 9:21 But all that heard him, were amazed, and said, Is not this he that persecuted those in Jerusalem who called on this name, and came hither for this end, that he might carry them bound to the chief priests?
Acts 9:22 But Saul prevailed more <transChange>and more,</transChange> and confounded the Jews that dwelt at Damascus, fully proving that this <transChange>same Jesus</transChange> is the Christ.
Acts 9:23 And after a considerable time, the Jews conspired to kill him:
Acts 9:24 but Saul was apprised of their design. And they watched the gates day and night, to make away with him:
Acts 9:25 but the disciples took him by night, and let <transChange>him</transChange> down by the wall, in a basket.
Acts 9:26 And when Saul was come to Jerusalem, he attempted to associate with the disciples: and they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was a disciple.
Acts 9:27 But Barnabas took and brought him to the apostles, and related to them, how he had seen the Lord in the way, and that He had spoken to him; and how he had preached boldly at Damascus in the name of Jesus.
Acts 9:28 And he was with them coming in and going out at Jerusalem, and preaching openly in the name of the Lord Jesus:
Acts 9:29 and he talked and disputed with the Hellenists, who attempted to kill him:
Acts 9:30 but when the brethren knew <transChange>it,</transChange> they brought him down to Cesarea, and sent him away to Tarsus.
Acts 9:31 Then the churches throughout all Judea, and Galilee, and Samaria, had rest, being edified and walking in the fear of the Lord; and through the consolation of the holy Spirit were multiplied.
Acts 9:32 And it came to pass that as Peter was going through all <transChange>parts,</transChange> he came down also to the saints that dwelt at Lydda.
Acts 9:33 And there he found a man named Eneas, who had kept his bed eight years, with the palsy.
Acts 9:34 And Peter said unto him, Eneas, Jesus the Messiah, healeth thee. Arise, and make thy bed. And he rose up immediately.
Acts 9:35 And all that dwelt at Lydda and <transChange>in</transChange> Saron saw him, and turned to the Lord.
Acts 9:36 And there was at Joppa a certain female disciple named Tabitha, who by interpretation is called <transChange>in Greek</transChange> Dorcas: <transChange>and</transChange> she was full of good works and alms-deeds.
Acts 9:37 And it happened, about the same time, that she fell sick and died: and when they had washed her they laid her <transChange>out</transChange> in an upper chamber.
Acts 9:38 And as Lydda was near to Joppa, the disciples hearing that Peter was there sent two men to him, intreating <transChange>him</transChange> that he would not delay to come to them.
Acts 9:39 Then Peter arose, and went with them: and when he was come, they brought him into the upper chamber. And all the widows stood round him weeping, and shewing him the coats and garments which Dorcas made when she was with them.
Acts 9:40 But Peter, putting them all out, kneeled down and prayed: and <transChange>then</transChange> turning to the body he said, Tabitha, arise. And she opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter, she sat up.

Acts 9:43 And he staid many days in Joppa with one Simon a tanner. <chapter eID="gen4175" osisID="Acts.9"/>
Acts 10:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.10" sID="gen4219"/>
Acts 10:1 Now there was a certain man at Cesarea named Cornelius, a centurion of the band called the Italian <transChange>band:</transChange> a pious man,
Acts 10:2 and one that feared God, with all his house; giving also much alms to the people, and praying to God continually.
Acts 10:3 He evidently saw in a vision, about the ninth hour of the day, an angel of God coming in to him, and saying unto him, Cornelius!
Acts 10:4 and he looking earnestly at him, and being afraid, said, What is it, Lord? And he said unto him, Thy prayers and thine alms are come up as a memorial before God.
Acts 10:5 And now send men to Joppa, and fetch hither <transChange>one</transChange> Simon, whose sirname is Peter.
Acts 10:6 He lodgeth with one Simon a tanner, whose house is by the sea-<transChange>side:</transChange> he shall tell thee what thou must do.
Acts 10:7 As soon as the angel, that spake to Cornelius, was departed, he called two of his domestic servants, and a devout soldier, that constantly attended him.
Acts 10:8 And when he had related all to them, he sent them to Joppa.
Acts 10:9 On the morrow, while they were on their journey, and drawing near to the city, Peter went up on the top of the house to pray, about the sixth hour.
Acts 10:10 And he was very hungry, and desired <transChange>something</transChange> to eat: but while they were getting <transChange>it</transChange> ready, he fell into a trance; and saw heaven opened,
Acts 10:11 and some thing descending to him, like a great sheet tied at the four corners, and let down to the earth:
Acts 10:12 in which were all kinds of four-footed creatures, and wild beasts, and creeping things, and fowls of the air.
Acts 10:13 And there was a voice <transChange>which said</transChange> to him, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Rise, Peter, kill and eat.</q>
Acts 10:14 But Peter said, By no means, Lord; for I have never eaten any thing polluted or unclean.
Acts 10:15 And the voice <transChange>said</transChange> to him again the second time, <q marker="" who="Jesus">What God hath cleansed, do not thou account polluted.</q>

Acts 10:19 And as Peter was pondering upon the vision, the Spirit said unto him, Behold there are three men enquiring for thee:

Acts 10:21 Then Peter went down to the men that were sent to him from Cornelius, and said, Behold I am <transChange>the person</transChange> whom ye seek: what is the cause for which ye are come?
Acts 10:22 And they said, Cornelius the centurion, a righteous man, and one that feareth God, and of a good character among all the nation of the Jews, hath been warned from God by an holy angel, to send for thee to his house, and to hear what thou shalt say.
Acts 10:23 Then he invited them in, and entertained <transChange>them that night.</transChange> And on the morrow Peter set out with them; and some of the brethren from Joppa went with him.
Acts 10:24 And the next day they came into Cesarea; and Cornelius was waiting for them, having called together his relations and intimate friends.
Acts 10:25 And as Peter came in, Cornelius met him, and falling down at his feet did <transChange>him</transChange> reverence.
Acts 10:26 But Peter raised him up, saying, I myself also am a man.
Acts 10:27 And <transChange>as he was</transChange> conversing with him, he went in, and found many assembled together.
Acts 10:28 And he said unto them, Ye know how unlawful it is for a man that is a Jew, to associate with or go to <transChange>the house of</transChange> one of another nation: but God hath shewn me, that I should not call any man polluted or unclean.
Acts 10:29 And therefore I came <transChange>to you,</transChange> when I was sent for, without demur. I ask therefore on what account ye sent for me.
Acts 10:30 And Cornelius said, Four days ago I was fasting till this hour, and at the ninth hour I was praying in my house, when behold a man stood before me in bright raiment,
Acts 10:31 and said, Cornelius, thy prayer is heard, and thine alms are remembered before God.

Acts 10:33 Immediately therefore I sent to thee, and thou hast done well that thou art come. And now we are all here present before God, to hear all the things which God hath charged thee with <transChange>to us.</transChange>
Acts 10:34 Then Peter opened his mouth and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons:

Acts 10:39 And we are witnesses of all <transChange>things</transChange> that He did, both in the country of Judea, and in <transChange>the city of</transChange> Jerusalem: whom <transChange>notwithstanding</transChange> they put to death, hanging <transChange>Him</transChange> on a tree.

Acts 10:42 And He commanded us to preach unto the people, and to testify that it is He who is appointed by God <transChange>to be</transChange> judge of the living and of the dead.

Acts 10:44 While Peter was yet speaking these words, the holy Spirit fell upon all them that heard the word.

Acts 11:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.11" sID="gen4268"/>
Acts 11:1 Now the apostles and brethren that were in Judea heard that the Gentiles also had received the word of God.
Acts 11:2 And when Peter was come up to Jerusalem, those <transChange>that were</transChange> of the circumcision contended with him, saying,
Acts 11:3 Thou wentest in to men uncircumcised and didst eat with them.
Acts 11:4 But Peter began and laid <transChange>the matter</transChange> in order before them,
Acts 11:5 saying, I was praying in the city <transChange>of</transChange> Joppa; and in a trance I saw a vision, some thing like a large sheet descending from heaven, let down by the four corners; and it came close to me.
Acts 11:6 And looking stedfastly upon it, I observed four-footed creatures and wild beasts, and reptiles, and fowls of the air.
Acts 11:7 And I heard a voice saying to me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Rise, Peter, kill and eat.</q>
Acts 11:8 But I said, By no means, Lord: for nothing polluted or unclean hath ever entered into my mouth.
Acts 11:9 And the voice answered me a second time from heaven, <q marker="" who="Jesus">What God hath cleansed do not thou call polluted.</q>
Acts 11:10 And this was done thrice: and <transChange>then</transChange> they were all drawn up again to heaven.
Acts 11:11 And behold at that very time there came three men to the house where I was, sent from Cesarea to me.
Acts 11:12 And the Spirit ordered me to go with them, doubting nothing. And these six brethren also came with me, and we entred into the man's house;
Acts 11:13 and he told us how he had seen an angel in his house, standing and saying to him, Send men to Joppa, and fetch hither Simon,
Acts 11:14 whose sirname is Peter, who will tell thee things, by which thou shalt be saved and all thy family.
Acts 11:15 And when I began to speak, the holy Spirit fell on them, even as <transChange>it did</transChange> upon us at the beginning.
Acts 11:16 Then I remembered the word of the Lord, how He said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">John indeed baptized with water; but ye shall be baptized with the holy Spirit.</q>

Acts 11:18 And when they heard these things they acquiesced, and glorified God, saying, Then hath God given to the Gentiles also repentance unto life.
Acts 11:19 Now they that were dispersed by the trouble, which arose about Stephen, travelled as far as Phenicia, and Cyprus, and Antioch, preaching the word to none but the Jews only.
Acts 11:20 But some of them were Cyprians, and Cyrenians, who when they came to Antioch, discoursed with the Grecians <transChange>also,</transChange> preaching the Lord Jesus.
Acts 11:21 And the hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number believed, and turned unto the Lord.
Acts 11:22 And the report of these things came to the ears of the church in Jerusalem; and they sent Barnabas to Antioch.
Acts 11:23 Who, when he was come, and saw the grace of God, rejoiced, and exhorted them all with steadiness of heart to adhere to the Lord.
Acts 11:24 For he was a good man, and full of the holy Spirit, and of faith: and many were added unto the Lord.
Acts 11:25 Then Barnabas departed to Tarsus, to seek Saul: and when he found him, he brought him to Antioch.
Acts 11:26 And they assembled in the church a whole year, and taught much people: and the disciples were first called Christians at Antioch.
Acts 11:27 And in these days came down prophets from Jerusalem to Antioch.
Acts 11:28 And one of them, named Agabus, stood up and signified by the Spirit, that there would be a great famine over all the earth: which accordingly came to pass in the reign of Claudius Cesar.
Acts 11:29 And each of the disciples, according to his ability, determined to send relief to the brethren who dwelt in Judea.
Acts 11:30 Which they also did, sending <transChange>it</transChange> to the elders by the hand of Barnabas and Saul. <chapter eID="gen4268" osisID="Acts.11"/>
Acts 12:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.12" sID="gen4299"/>
Acts 12:1 About that time Herod the king exerted his power to distress some of the church.
Acts 12:2 And he cut off James, the brother of John, with the sword.
Acts 12:3 And seeing that it was pleasing to the Jews, he proceeded to apprehend Peter also, (in the days of unleavened bread:)
Acts 12:4 whom he seized and put into prison, delivering him to four quaternions of soldiers to guard him; intending, after the passover, to bring him out to the people.
Acts 12:5 Peter was therefore kept in custody: but incessant prayer was made to God for him by the church.
Acts 12:6 And when Herod was about to bring him forth, that <transChange>very</transChange> night Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains: and the guards at the door watched the prison.
Acts 12:7 And behold an angel of the Lord stood by him, and a light shone in the room; and smiting Peter on the side, he waked him, and said, Rise up quickly. And his chains fell off from <transChange>his</transChange> hands.
Acts 12:8 And the angel said unto him, Gird thyself and tie on thy sandals: and he did so. And he saith unto him, Throw thy garment round thee, and follow me.
Acts 12:9 So he went out and followed him; and he did not know, that what was done by the angel was real, but thought he saw a vision.
Acts 12:10 And passing through the first and second guard, they came to the iron gate, that leadeth into the city, which of its own accord opened to them: and they went out and passed on through one street; and then the angel departed from him.
Acts 12:11 And Peter being come to himself said, Now I know truly, that the Lord hath sent his angel and hath delivered me from the hand of Herod, and <transChange>from</transChange> all the expectation of the people of the Jews.
Acts 12:12 And considering with <transChange>himself,</transChange> he came to the house of Mary the mother of John, <transChange>who was</transChange> sirnamed Mark, where many were gathered together and praying.
Acts 12:13 And when Peter knocked at the door of the porch, a servant named Rhoda came to ask who was there.
Acts 12:14 And knowing Peter's voice, through <transChange>excess of</transChange> joy she did not open the door, but ran in and told <transChange>them,</transChange> that Peter was standing at the door.
Acts 12:15 And they said to her, Thou art mad: but she confidently affirmed that it was so. Then said they, It is his angel.
Acts 12:16 But Peter continued knocking; and when they opened <transChange>the door,</transChange> they saw him, and were astonished.
Acts 12:17 But he made a sign to them with <transChange>his</transChange> hand to be silent, and related to them, how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. And he said, Go, tell these things to James and to the <transChange>other</transChange> brethren. And he departed and went to another place.
Acts 12:18 Now as soon as it was day, there was no small disturbance among the soldiers, what was become of Peter.
Acts 12:19 And Herod searching for him, and not finding <transChange>him,</transChange> brought the keepers to a trial, and ordered them to be executed. Then he went down from Judea to Cesarea, and abode <transChange>there.</transChange>
Acts 12:20 And Herod was going to make war upon the Tyrians and Sidonians: but they came to him with one consent, and making interest with Blastus the king's chamberlain, they sued for peace; because their territory was supplied with provision by the king's <transChange>country.</transChange>
Acts 12:21 And upon a set day, Herod arrayed in <transChange>his</transChange> royal robes, and sitting upon his throne, made an oration to them.
Acts 12:22 And the people gave a shout, <transChange>saying, It is</transChange> the voice of a god, and not of a man:
Acts 12:23 but immediately an angel of the Lord smote him, because he gave not God the glory: and being devoured by worms he died.
Acts 12:24 But the word of God grew and was multiplied.
Acts 12:25 And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem, when they had fulfilled their charge, taking along with them John <transChange>who was</transChange> sirnamed Mark. <chapter eID="gen4299" osisID="Acts.12"/>
Acts 13:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.13" sID="gen4325"/>
Acts 13:1 Now there were in the church that was at Antioch certain prophets and teachers, as Barnabas, and Simeon called Niger, and Lucius the Cyrenean, and Manaen who had been educated with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul;
Acts 13:2 and as they were ministring to the Lord, and fasting, the holy Spirit said, Separate me Barnabas and Saul, for the work to which I have called them.
Acts 13:3 Then having fasted and prayed and laid their hands on them they sent <transChange>them</transChange> away.
Acts 13:4 These therefore being sent forth by the holy Spirit came down to Seleucia, and from thence they sailed away to Cyprus.
Acts 13:5 And when they arrived at Salamis, they preached the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews: and they had also John for <transChange>their</transChange> assistant.
Acts 13:6 And going <transChange>quite</transChange> through the island even to Paphos, they found <transChange>there</transChange> a certain magician, a false prophet, a Jew, whose name was Barjesus.
Acts 13:7 Who was with the proconsul Sergius Paulus, an understanding man: who calling for Barnabas and Saul, desired to hear the word of God.
Acts 13:8 But Elymas the magician (for so his name signifies) withstood them endeavouring to turn away the proconsul from the faith.
Acts 13:9 Then Saul, who also <transChange>is called</transChange> Paul, being filled with the holy Spirit, and looking earnestly at him,
Acts 13:10 said, O thou son of the devil, thou enemy of all righteousness, <transChange>who art</transChange> full of all deceit and craft, wilt thou not cease to pervert the right ways of the Lord?
Acts 13:11 And now behold, the hand of the Lord <transChange>is</transChange> upon thee, and thou shalt be blind, not seeing <transChange>even</transChange> the sun for a time. And immediately there fell upon him a mist and darkness; and groping about he sought for some<transChange>body</transChange> to lead him by the hand.
Acts 13:12 Then the proconsul, seeing what was done, believed, being struck <transChange>with admiration</transChange> at the doctrine of the Lord.
Acts 13:13 Now Paul and those that were with him loosing from Paphos, came to Perga in Pamphylia: but John departed from them and returned to Jerusalem.
Acts 13:14 And they passing on from Perga came to Antioch in Pisidia, and went into the synagogue on the sabbath-day, and sat down.
Acts 13:15 And after the reading of the law and the prophets, the rulers of the synagogue sent unto them, saying, Brethren, if ye have any word of exhortation to the people, deliver <transChange>it.</transChange>
Acts 13:16 Then Paul stood up, and made a sign with <transChange>his</transChange> hand, and said, Men of Israel, and ye that fear God, give audience.
Acts 13:17 ---The God of this people Israel chose our fathers, and raised the people, while they sojourned in the land of Egypt, and with mighty power brought them out of it.
Acts 13:18 And about forty years He bare with their behaviour in the wilderness.
Acts 13:19 And destroying seven nations in the land of Canaan, He gave them their country for an inheritance.
Acts 13:20 And after these <transChange>things,</transChange> about <transChange>the space of</transChange> four hundred and fifty years, He gave them judges till Samuel the prophet.
Acts 13:21 And then they desired a king: and God gave them Saul the Son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for <transChange>the space of</transChange> forty years.
Acts 13:22 And having removed him, He raised up David for their king, to whom also He gave testimony and said, I have found David <transChange>the son</transChange> of Jesse, a man after my own heart, who will perform all my will.
Acts 13:23 Of this man's seed, according to the promise, hath God raised up to Israel Jesus the Saviour:
Acts 13:24 John having preached before his coming the baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
Acts 13:25 And as John was fulfilling his course, he said, Whom do ye take me to be? I am not <transChange>He:</transChange> but behold there cometh <transChange>one</transChange> after me, the shoes of whose feet I am not worthy to unloose.
Acts 13:26 ---Men <transChange>and</transChange> brethren, children of the race of Abraham, and <transChange>all</transChange> those among you that fear God, to you is the word of this salvation sent.
Acts 13:27 For the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and their rulers, not knowing Him, have indeed fulfilled the words of the prophets, which are read every sabbath-day, <transChange>in</transChange> condemning <transChange>Him.</transChange>
Acts 13:28 And though they found <transChange>in Him</transChange> no capital offence, yet they desired <transChange>of</transChange> Pilate that He might be put to death.
Acts 13:29 And when they had finished all <transChange>things that were</transChange> written concerning Him, they took <transChange>Him</transChange> down from the cross and laid <transChange>Him</transChange> in a tomb.
Acts 13:30 But God raised Him from the dead:
Acts 13:31 and He was seen for many days by those that came up with Him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are his witnesses to the people.
Acts 13:32 And we bring you good tidings,
Acts 13:33 that the promise made unto the fathers God hath fulfilled unto us their children, having raised up Jesus again: as it is also written in the second psalm, "Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee."
Acts 13:34 And that He raised Him from the dead, no more to return to <transChange>the place of</transChange> corruption, He hath said thus, "I will give you the sure mercies of David."
Acts 13:35 Wherefore he saith also in another <transChange>place,</transChange> Thou wilt not suffer thine holy <transChange>One</transChange> to see corruption.
Acts 13:36 Now David having served his own generation according to the will of God, fell asleep, and was laid with his fathers, and saw corruption: but He whom God raised,
Acts 13:37 did not see corruption.
Acts 13:38 Be it known therefore unto you, brethren, that through Him is preached unto you the remission of sins:
Acts 13:39 and by Him every one that believeth is justified from all <transChange>things,</transChange> from which ye could not be justified by the law of Moses.
Acts 13:40 Beware therefore, least what is spoken in the prophets come upon you,
Acts 13:41 "Behold, ye despisers, and wonder, and vanish; for I do a work in your days, which ye will not believe, though any <transChange>one</transChange> should declare it unto you."
Acts 13:42 As they went out of the synagogue of the Jews, the Gentiles desired that these words might be spoken to them on the following sabbath.
Acts 13:43 And when the synagogue was broken up, many of the Jews and of the devout proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas; who addressing themselves to them, persuaded them to continue in the grace of God.
Acts 13:44 And on the next sabbath almost all the city came together to hear the word of God.
Acts 13:45 But when the Jews saw the multitudes, they were filled with envy, and contradicted the things which were spoken by Paul, opposing and reviling <transChange>him.</transChange>
Acts 13:46 Then Paul and Barnabas boldly said, It was necessary that the word of God should be first spoken to you; but since ye reject it, and judge not yourselves worthy of eternal life, lo, we turn to the Gentiles:
Acts 13:47 for so the Lord hath commanded us, <transChange>saying,</transChange> "I have appointed thee for a light to the Gentiles, that thou shouldest be for salvation to the utmost <transChange>part</transChange> of the earth."
Acts 13:48 And when the Gentiles heard <transChange>this,</transChange> they rejoiced and glorified the word of the Lord: and as many as were determined for eternal life believed.
Acts 13:49 And the word of the Lord was spread through the whole country:
Acts 13:50 but the Jews stirred up devout and honorable women, and the heads of the city, and raised a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and drove them out of their territories.
Acts 13:51 But they shook off the dust of their feet against them, and came to Iconium.
Acts 13:52 And the disciples were filled with joy, and with the holy Spirit. <chapter eID="gen4325" osisID="Acts.13"/>
Acts 14:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.14" sID="gen4378"/>
Acts 14:1 And at Iconium they went both together into the synagogue of the Jews, and so spake, that a great number both of the Jews and of the Greeks believed.
Acts 14:2 But the unbelieving Jews stirred up and inflamed the minds of the Gentiles against the brethren.
Acts 14:3 They therefore stayed a considerable time speaking freely of the Lord, who bare witness to the word of his grace, and gave signs and wonders to be done by their hands.
Acts 14:4 But the multitude of the city was divided: and some were for the Jews, and some for the apostles:
Acts 14:5 but when there was an effort both of the Gentiles and of the Jews, together with their rulers, to offer violence <transChange>to them,</transChange> and to stone them;
Acts 14:6 being apprised <transChange>of it</transChange> they fled to the cities of Lycaonia, Lystra and Derbe, and the adjacent country:
Acts 14:7 and there they preached the gospel.
Acts 14:8 And there was sitting at Lystra, a man disabled in his feet, who had never walked <transChange>at all,</transChange> being lame from his birth.
Acts 14:9 This <transChange>man</transChange> heard Paul speaking; who looking earnestly at him, and perceiving that he had faith to be healed,
Acts 14:10 said with a loud voice, Stand upright on thy feet. And he leaped up, and walked.
Acts 14:11 And the people, seeing what Paul had done, lifted up their voice, saying in the Lycaonian tongue, The gods are come down to us in the likeness of men.
Acts 14:12 And they called Barnabas Jupiter, and Paul Mercury; because he was the chief speaker.
Acts 14:13 And the priest of Jupiter, who<transChange>se image</transChange> was before the city, brought oxen and garlands to the gates, and with the people would have offered sacrifices <transChange>to them.</transChange>
Acts 14:14 But the apostles Barnabas and Paul, when they heard <transChange>of it,</transChange> rent their clothes, and ran in among the people,
Acts 14:15 crying out, and saying, "Sirs, why do ye these <transChange>things?</transChange> we also are men subject to the like infirmities with you, and we preach the gospel unto you, that ye may turn from these vanities to the living God, who made the heaven, and the earth, and the sea,
Acts 14:16 and all <transChange>things</transChange> therein, who in generations past suffered all the nations to walk in their own ways: though He left not Himself without witness;
Acts 14:17 for He did <transChange>us</transChange> good, <transChange>in</transChange> giving us rain from heaven, and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and gladness."
Acts 14:18 And saying these <transChange>things,</transChange> they with difficulty restrained the people from sacrificing to them.
Acts 14:19 But there came thither <transChange>some</transChange> Jews from Antioch and Iconium, and persuading the multitude, stoned Paul, and dragged <transChange>him</transChange> out of the city, supposing him to be dead.
Acts 14:20 But when the disciples were gathered round him, he rose up and came into the city: and the next day he departed with Barnabas to Derbe.
Acts 14:21 And when they had preached the gospel to that city, and made many disciples, they returned to Lystra, and Iconium, and Antioch;
Acts 14:22 confirming the souls of the disciples, exhorting <transChange>them</transChange> to continue in the faith, and <transChange>telling them</transChange> that through many afflictions we must enter into the kingdom of God.
Acts 14:23 And when they had appointed them elders in every church, praying and fasting, they recommended them to the Lord, in whom they had believed.
Acts 14:24 And passing through Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia.
Acts 14:25 And when they had preached the word at Perga, they went down to Attalia.
Acts 14:26 And from thence they sailed to Antioch, from whence they had been recommended to the grace of God, for the work which they had <transChange>now</transChange> fulfilled.
Acts 14:27 And when they were come, and had gathered the church together, they related what God had done by them, and how he had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.
Acts 14:28 And they spent a considerable time there with the disciples. <chapter eID="gen4378" osisID="Acts.14"/>
Acts 15:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.15" sID="gen4407"/>
Acts 15:1 Now some that came down from Judea, taught the brethren, <transChange>saying,</transChange> Except ye be circumcised according to the law of Moses, ye cannot be saved.
Acts 15:2 A dissension therefore arising, and Paul and Barnabas having no small dispute with them, it was resolved that Paul and Barnabas, and some others, should go up to the apostles and elders at Jerusalem about this question.
Acts 15:3 They therefore, being brought forward on their way by the church, passed through Phenicia and Samaria, relating the conversion of the Gentiles: and they gave great joy to all the brethren.
Acts 15:4 And when they came to Jerusalem, they were received by the church, and <transChange>by</transChange> the apostles and elders, and they told them all that God had done by them.
Acts 15:5 But there rose up, <transChange>said they,</transChange> some of the sect of the pharisees that believed, saying, that it was necessary to circumcise them, and enjoin <transChange>them</transChange> to keep the law of Moses.
Acts 15:6 So the apostles and elders were assembled together to consider about this matter.
Acts 15:7 And after much debate, Peter rose up, and said unto them, Brethren, ye know that a good while ago, God, <transChange>who was</transChange> among us, chose that the Gentiles should hear by my mouth the word of the gospel, and believe.
Acts 15:8 And God who knoweth the heart, bare witness to them, giving them the holy Spirit, as <transChange>He had done</transChange> also to us:
Acts 15:9 and made no difference between us and them, having purified their hearts by faith.
Acts 15:10 Now therefore why do ye tempt God, <transChange>in</transChange> imposing a yoke on the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear?
Acts 15:11 But we believe that we shall be saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, in like manner as they.
Acts 15:12 And all the multitude kept silence, and gave attention to Barnabas and Paul, relating what signs and wonders God had wrought among the Gentiles by them.
Acts 15:13 And after they had done speaking, James rose up and said, Brethren, hearken unto me.
Acts 15:14 ---Simeon hath related, how God at first condescended to take out of the Gentiles a people to his name.
Acts 15:15 And to this agree the words of the prophets,
Acts 15:16 as it is written, "After this will I return, and rebuild the tabernacle of David, which is fallen down; and I will repair its ruins, and set it up again.
Acts 15:17 That the rest of mankind may seek the Lord, even all the nations, upon whom my name is called, saith the Lord who doth all these <transChange>things.</transChange>"
Acts 15:18 <transChange>Now</transChange> all his works are known unto God from the beginning of the world:
Acts 15:19 wherefore my advice is, not to trouble those who from among the Gentiles are converted to God; but to write to them,
Acts 15:20 that they abstain from the pollutions of idols, and <transChange>from</transChange> fornication, and <transChange>from what is</transChange> strangled, and <transChange>from</transChange> blood.
Acts 15:21 For Moses hath <transChange>had</transChange> from ancient times those that preach him in every city, and is <transChange>still</transChange> read in the synagogues every sabbath-<transChange>day.</transChange>
Acts 15:22 Then it seemed good to the apostles, and elders, and the whole church, to send men chose from among themselves to Antioch <transChange>along</transChange> with Paul and Barnabas; namely, Judas sirnamed Barsabas, and Silas; leading men among the brethren:
Acts 15:23 and they wrote by their hand, as follows, The apostles and elders and brethren <transChange>here</transChange> to the Gentile brethren <transChange>which are</transChange> in Antioch, and Syria, and Cilicia, send greeting.
Acts 15:24 Forasmuch as we have heard, that some who went out from us, have troubled you by <transChange>their</transChange> discourses, unsettling your minds, saying, <transChange>ye must</transChange> be circumcised, and keep the law; to whom we gave no <transChange>such</transChange> commission;
Acts 15:25 it seemed good to us, being assembled with one accord, to send chosen men unto you, with our beloved <transChange>brethren</transChange> Barnabas and Paul,
Acts 15:26 who have exposed their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Acts 15:27 We have therefore sent <transChange>with them</transChange> Judas and Silas, to tell <transChange>you</transChange> the same things also by word <transChange>of mouth.</transChange>
Acts 15:28 For it seemed good to the holy Spirit, and <transChange>so</transChange> to us, to lay no more burthen upon you than these necessary <transChange>things.</transChange>
Acts 15:29 That ye abstain from <transChange>meats</transChange> offered to idols, and from blood, and from <transChange>what has been</transChange> strangled, and from fornication: from which ye will do well to keep yourselves. Farewel.
Acts 15:30 Being thus dispatched they came to Antioch, and when they had assembled the brethren, they delivered the epistle.
Acts 15:31 And when they had read <transChange>it,</transChange> they rejoiced at the consolation <transChange>it brought.</transChange>
Acts 15:32 And Judas and Silas being prophets also themselves, exhorted and established: the brethren by many discourses.
Acts 15:33 And after <transChange>some</transChange> time, they were dismissed with peace from the brethren to the apostles.
Acts 15:34 But it seemed good to Silas to continue there: Paul also and Barnabas stayed at Antioch,
Acts 15:35 teaching and preaching, with many others likewise, the word of the Lord.
Acts 15:36 And after some days Paul said to Barnabas, Let us return and visit our brethren in every city, where we have preached the word of the Lord, <transChange>and see</transChange> how they are.
Acts 15:37 And Barnabas proposed to take with <transChange>them</transChange> John, <transChange>who was</transChange> surnamed Mark.
Acts 15:38 But Paul did not think proper to take him with <transChange>them,</transChange> who left them in Pamphylia, and went not with them to the work.
Acts 15:39 And there was a sharp dispute, so that they separated from each other; and Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus: but Paul chose Silas and departed,
Acts 15:40 being recommended to the grace of God.
Acts 15:41 And he went through Syria and Cilicia confirming the churches. <chapter eID="gen4407" osisID="Acts.15"/>
Acts 16:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.16" sID="gen4449"/>
Acts 16:1 Then he came to Derbe and Lystra: and behold there was a certain disciple there, named Timothy, the son of a believing Jewess, but of a Grecian father.
Acts 16:2 Who was well spoken of by the brethren at Lystra and Iconium:
Acts 16:3 <transChange>wherefore</transChange> Paul was desirous that he should go forth with him, and took and circumcised him because of the Jews that were in those parts; for they all knew that his father was a Greek.
Acts 16:4 And as they passed through the cities, they delivered to them the decrees that had been made by the apostles and elders at Jerusalem.
Acts 16:5 And so the churches were established in the faith, and increased in number daily.
Acts 16:6 And when they had passed through Phrygia and Galatia, being forbidden by the holy Spirit to preach the word in Asia, they came to Mysia, and endeavoured to go to Bithynia:
Acts 16:7 but the Spirit suffered them not.
Acts 16:8 So they passed by Mysia, and came down to Troas.
Acts 16:9 And Paul saw a vision in the night, There stood a certain man of Macedonia, intreating him and saying, Come over into Macedonia and help us.
Acts 16:10 And as soon as he had seen the vision, immediately we endeavoured to depart into Macedonia, concluding that the Lord called us to preach the gospel to them.
Acts 16:11 Therefore we set sail from Troas, and came in a direct course to Samothracia, and the <transChange>day</transChange> following to Neapolis;
Acts 16:12 and from thence to Philippi, which is the chief city of <transChange>that</transChange> part of Macedonia, <transChange>and</transChange> a <transChange>Roman</transChange> colony. And we staid some time in this city.
Acts 16:13 And on the sabbath-day we went out of the city to a river-side, where there used to be prayer: and we sat down and preached to the women that resorted <transChange>thither.</transChange>
Acts 16:14 And a certain woman named Lydia, a purple-seller of the city of Thyatira, who worshipped God, heard <transChange>us:</transChange> whose heart the Lord opened to attend to the things that were spoken by Paul.
Acts 16:15 And when she was baptized and her family, she requested <transChange>us,</transChange> saying, If ye have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come into my house, and lodge <transChange>there.</transChange> And she constrained us.
Acts 16:16 Now as we were going to <transChange>the place of</transChange> prayer, there met us a young woman that had a spirit of divination, who brought her masters much gain by soothsaying.
Acts 16:17 She following Paul and us, cried out, saying, These men are the servants of the most high God, who shew us the way of salvation.
Acts 16:18 And this she did for many days. But Paul being grieved, turned and said to the spirit, I command thee in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her.
Acts 16:19 And he came out that instant. And when her masters saw, that the hope of their gain was gone, they seized on Paul and Silas, and dragged them into the court to the magistrates.
Acts 16:20 And when they brought them to the governors, they said, These men cause great disturbance in our city, for they are Jews, and teach customs,
Acts 16:21 which it is not lawful for us to receive, nor practise, who are Romans.
Acts 16:22 And the populace rose up together against them: and the officers stripped off their clothes, and ordered them to be scourged.
Acts 16:23 And when they had given them many stripes, they cast <transChange>them</transChange> into prison, charging the jailor to keep them safely.
Acts 16:24 Who having received such a charge, thrust them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.
Acts 16:25 Now in the middle of the night Paul and Silas were praying and singing praises to God, and the prisoners heard them.
Acts 16:26 And on a sudden there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken; and immediately all the doors were opened, and every one's bonds were loosed.
Acts 16:27 The jailor waking, and seeing the prison-doors open, drew his sword and was going to kill himself, thinking that the prisoners were fled.
Acts 16:28 But Paul cried with a loud voice, saying, Do thyself no harm: for we are all here.
Acts 16:29 Then he called for lights, and sprang in, and being in a tremor fell down before Paul and Silas:
Acts 16:30 and bringing them out, he said, Sirs, what must I do to be saved?
Acts 16:31 And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thine house.
Acts 16:32 And they spake unto him the word of the Lord, and to all in his family.
Acts 16:33 And he took them at that <transChange>very</transChange> time of the night, and bathed their stripes: and was baptized, he and all his immediately <transChange>after.</transChange>
Acts 16:34 And he brought them into his house, and spread a table <transChange>for them,</transChange> and rejoiced, believing in God with all his household.
Acts 16:35 And when it was the day the governors sent the serjeants, saying, Let those men go.
Acts 16:36 And the jailor told these words to Paul, <transChange>saying,</transChange> the governors have sent <transChange>orders,</transChange> that you should be discharged; now therefore depart, and go in peace.
Acts 16:37 But Paul said unto them, They have publicly beaten us, uncondemned, <transChange>and</transChange> Romans, and cast us into prison, and do they now turn us out privately? No verily, let them come themselves and fetch us out.
Acts 16:38 And the serjeants reported these words to the governors: and they were afraid when they heard that they were Romans.
Acts 16:39 And they came and intreated them, and when they had brought them out, they desired them to leave the city.
Acts 16:40 And when they were come out of the prison, they went into <transChange>the house of</transChange> Lydia: and seeing the brethren, they comforted them, and departed. <chapter eID="gen4449" osisID="Acts.16"/>
Acts 17:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.17" sID="gen4490"/>
Acts 17:1 Now when they had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.
Acts 17:2 And according to <transChange>his</transChange> custom Paul went in among them, and for three sabbath-<transChange>days</transChange> discoursed to them from the scriptures;
Acts 17:3 opening <transChange>them</transChange> and shewing, that the Messiah was to suffer and rise again from the dead: and that this is the Christ <transChange>even,</transChange> Jesus, whom, <transChange>said he,</transChange> I preach unto you.
Acts 17:4 And some of them believed and joined themselves to Paul and Silas, and a great number of the devout Greeks, and of the women of distinction not <transChange>a</transChange> few.
Acts 17:5 But the unbelieving Jews being filled with envy, collected some loose profligate fellows, and making a tumult set <transChange>all</transChange> the city in an uproar: and assaulting Jason's house, they sought for them <transChange>in order</transChange> to bring them out to the populace.
Acts 17:6 But not finding them, they dragged Jason and some <transChange>of the</transChange> brethren to the rulers of the city, crying out, these <transChange>men</transChange> that have turned the world upside down,
Acts 17:7 are come hither also, and Jason has privately received them. And they all act contrary to the decrees of Cesar, saying, there is another king, <transChange>one</transChange> Jesus.
Acts 17:8 And they alarmed the people, and the rulers of the city <transChange>upon</transChange> hearing these <transChange>things:</transChange>
Acts 17:9 but they taking security of Jason and the rest, let them go.
Acts 17:10 And the brethren immediately sent away Paul and Silas by night to Berea: who, when they were come <transChange>thither,</transChange> went into the synagogue of the Jews.
Acts 17:11 These were more ingenuous than those at Thessalonica; for they received the word with all readiness of mind, searching the scriptures daily, whether these <transChange>things</transChange> were so.
Acts 17:12 And therefore many of them believed: and of the Grecian women of quality, and of men <transChange>likewise</transChange> not <transChange>a</transChange> few.
Acts 17:13 But when the Jews of Thessalonica knew that the word of God was preached by Paul at Berea, they came thither also, to stir up the people.
Acts 17:14 Then the brethren immediately sent away Paul towards the sea: but Silas and Timothy remained there.
Acts 17:15 And they that conducted Paul attended him to Athens: and receiving an order to Silas and Timothy, to come to him as soon as possible, they departed.
Acts 17:16 Now while Paul was waiting for them at Athens, his Spirit was greatly moved, when he saw the city wholly given up to idolatry.
Acts 17:17 He therefore disputed in the synagogue with the Jews and <transChange>other</transChange> devout persons <transChange>on the sabbath-day,</transChange> and with whomsoever he met in public every day.
Acts 17:18 But some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers encountered him; and some said, What would this babler say? and others, He seemeth to be a proclaimer of foreign deities: because he preached to them Jesus and the resurrection.
Acts 17:19 And they took and brought him to the Areopagus, and said, May we know what this new doctrine is, of which thou speakest?
Acts 17:20 For thou bringest strange <transChange>things</transChange> to our ears; we would therefore know what these <transChange>things</transChange> mean.
Acts 17:21 (Now all the Athenians, and strangers sojourning <transChange>among them,</transChange> spent their time in nothing else, but to tell or to hear something new.)
Acts 17:22 Then Paul stood up in the midst of the Areopagus and said, Ye men of Athens, I perceive that you are indeed over-much religious:
Acts 17:23 for as I was passing along, and looking at what ye worshipped, I found an altar on which there was inscribed, "To the unknown God." Whom therefore ye worship unknown, Him do I declare unto you.
Acts 17:24 The God that made the world and all things therein, being lord of heaven and earth dwelleth not in temples made with hands:
Acts 17:25 nor is He served by the hands of men, <transChange>as</transChange> needing any <transChange>thing:</transChange> for He giveth to all life, and breath, and all things;
Acts 17:26 and hath made of one blood every nation of men to dwell upon all the face of the earth, having determined the seasons before-appointed <transChange>them,</transChange> and the bounds of their habitation;
Acts 17:27 that they might seek the Lord, if possibly they might trace Him, and find <transChange>Him:</transChange> though indeed He is not far from every one of us.
Acts 17:28 For in Him we live and move, and exist; as some also of your own poets have said, "For we his offspring are."
Acts 17:29 Being then the offspring of God, we ought not to imagine that the Deity is like to gold, or silver, or stone, carved by the art and device of man.
Acts 17:30 Wherefore though God overlooked the times of <transChange>this</transChange> ignorance, He now requireth all men every where to repent.
Acts 17:31 Because He hath fixed a day, in which He will judge the world in righteousness, by <transChange>that</transChange> man whom He hath appointed <transChange>thereto;</transChange> having given assurance <transChange>of it</transChange> to all <transChange>men, by</transChange> raising Him from the dead.
Acts 17:32 And when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some laughed at <transChange>it:</transChange> and others said, We will hear thee again concerning this <transChange>matter.</transChange>
Acts 17:33 So Paul went out of the assembly.
Acts 17:34 Some however adhered to him, and believed: among whom <transChange>was</transChange> Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them. <chapter eID="gen4490" osisID="Acts.17"/>
Acts 18:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.18" sID="gen4525"/>
Acts 18:1 After these things Paul departed from Athens and came to Corinth.
Acts 18:2 And finding <transChange>there</transChange> a certain Jew, named Aquila, a native of Pontus, <transChange>who was</transChange> lately come from Italy, with his wife Priscilla, (because Claudius <transChange>Cesar</transChange> had ordered all the Jews to depart from Rome,) he went to them;
Acts 18:3 and as he was of the same trade, he staid and worked with them: for they were tent-makers.
Acts 18:4 And he discoursed in the synagogue every sabbath-<transChange>day,</transChange> and persuaded both Jews and Greeks.
Acts 18:5 And when Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was <transChange>very</transChange> urgent in spirit, testifying to the Jews that Jesus <transChange>was</transChange> the Messiah.
Acts 18:6 But as they opposed and blasphemed, he shook his garment, and said unto them, Your blood <transChange>be</transChange> upon your own heads; I am clear <transChange>of it:</transChange> from henceforth I will go to the Gentiles.
Acts 18:7 And departing thence, he went to the house of one named Justus, who worshipped God, whose house was contiguous to the synagogue.
Acts 18:8 But Crispus the ruler of the synagogue believed on the Lord with all his house: and many of the Corinthians hearing <transChange>the word</transChange> believed, and were baptized.
Acts 18:9 And the Lord said to Paul by a vision in the night, <q marker="" who="Jesus">"Fear not, but speak: and be not silent:</q>
Acts 18:10 <q marker="" who="Jesus">for I am with thee, and no man shall lay <transChange>hands</transChange> on thee to hurt thee; for I have much people in this city."</q>
Acts 18:11 And he staid a year and six months, teaching among them the word of God.
Acts 18:12 But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews with one accord rose against Paul, and brought him to the seat of justice,
Acts 18:13 saying, this <transChange>fellow</transChange> persuadeth men to worship God contrary to the law.
Acts 18:14 And when Paul was going to speak, Gallio said to the Jews, If it were indeed an act of injustice, or <transChange>some</transChange> wicked crime, it would be reasonable that I should bear with you.
Acts 18:15 But if it be a question about words, and names, and your law, settle <transChange>it</transChange> yourselves; for I will be no judge of these <transChange>matters.</transChange>
Acts 18:16 And he ordered them away from the tribunal.
Acts 18:17 Then all the Greeks took Sosthenes the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him <transChange>even</transChange> before the tribunal: but Gallio did not concern himself about the matter.
Acts 18:18 And after Paul had staid <transChange>there</transChange> yet a considerable time, he took leave of the brethren, and sailed from thence to Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila, after he had shaved his head at Cenchrea; for he had a vow.
Acts 18:19 And he came to Esphesus, and left them there: but <transChange>before his departure</transChange> he himself went into the synagogue, and reasoned with the Jews.
Acts 18:20 Though when they desired him to stay longer with them, he did not consent: but took his leave of them,
Acts 18:21 saying, I must by all means keep the approaching feast at Jerusalem; but I will return to you again, God willing. So he sailed from Ephesus;
Acts 18:22 and landing at Cesarea, went up <transChange>to Jerusalem,</transChange> and after he had saluted the church, he went down to Antioch.
Acts 18:23 And when he had spent some time <transChange>there,</transChange> he departed, and went in order through the country of Galatia and Phrygia strengthening all the disciples.
Acts 18:24 Now there came to Ephesus a certain Jew named Apollos, an Alexandrian by birth, an eloquent man, <transChange>and</transChange> mighty in the scriptures.
Acts 18:25 Who had been instructed in the way of our Lord; and being fervent in spirit, he spake and taught clearly the things of the Lord, though he knew only the baptism of John.
Acts 18:26 And as he began to speak openly in the synagogue, Aquila and Priscilla heard him and took him home, and expounded to him the way of God more perfectly.
Acts 18:27 And as he was inclined to go into Achaia, the brethren wrote to the disciples exhorting <transChange>them</transChange> to receive him: who when he arrived, was very helpful to those who had believed through grace.
Acts 18:28 For he disputed vehemently with the Jews in public, proving by the scriptures, that Jesus was the Christ. <chapter eID="gen4525" osisID="Acts.18"/>
Acts 19:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.19" sID="gen4554"/>
Acts 19:1 Now it came to pass while Apollos was at Corinth, that Paul having passed through the upper parts <transChange>of Asia</transChange> came to Ephesus:
Acts 19:2 and finding some disciples <transChange>there,</transChange> he said unto them, Have ye received the holy Spirit since ye embraced the faith? And they said unto him, Nay, we had not even heard whether the holy Spirit be <transChange>yet given.</transChange>
Acts 19:3 And he said unto them, Into what then were ye baptized? And they said, Into the baptism of John.
Acts 19:4 Then said Paul, John indeed baptized with the baptism of repentance, telling the people, that they should believe in Him that was coming after him, that is, in Christ Jesus.
Acts 19:5 And when they heard <transChange>this,</transChange> they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
Acts 19:6 And as Paul laid <transChange>his</transChange> hands on them, the holy Spirit came upon them; and they spake with tongues, and prophesied. And the men were <transChange>in</transChange> all about twelve.
Acts 19:7 And he went into the synagogue,
Acts 19:8 and spake boldly, disputing <transChange>with them</transChange> for <transChange>the space of</transChange> three months, and persuading <transChange>them of</transChange> the things concerning the kingdom of God.
Acts 19:9 But as some were hardened and refractory, speaking evil of the way <transChange>of life</transChange> before the multitude, he departed from them, and took away the disciples <transChange>with him,</transChange> disputing daily in the school of one Tyrannus.
Acts 19:10 And this he did for two years; so that all the inhabitants of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord Jesus.
Acts 19:11 And God wrought extraordinary miracles by the hands of Paul:
Acts 19:12 so that even handkerchiefs or aprons were brought from his body to the sick, and the diseases lest them, and evil spirits went out of them.
Acts 19:13 Then some of the vagabond Jews, exorcists, took upon them to name the name of the Lord Jesus over those that had evil spirits, saying, "We adjure you by Jesus, whom Paul preacheth."
Acts 19:14 Now there were seven sons of <transChange>one</transChange> Sceva a Jewish priest, who did this.
Acts 19:15 But the evil spirit answered and said, Jesus I know, and Paul I know, but who are ye?
Acts 19:16 And the man in whom the evil spirit was, leapt upon them, and mastered them, and prevailed against them, so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded.
Acts 19:17 And this became known to all, both Jews and Greeks, that dwelt at Ephesus; and fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
Acts 19:18 And many of them that believed came confessing and declaring their <transChange>former</transChange> practices.
Acts 19:19 And a great number of those that had used inquisitive arts, brought the books, and burned <transChange>them</transChange> before <transChange>them</transChange> all: and they computed the price of them, and found <transChange>it to be</transChange> fifty thousand <transChange>pieces</transChange> of silver.
Acts 19:20 So mightily did the word of the Lord increase and prevail.
Acts 19:21 After these things, Paul purposed in spirit to pass through Macedonia and Achaia, and go to Jerusalem, saying, After I have been there, I must also see Rome.
Acts 19:22 So he sent into Macedonia two of those that ministred to him, Timothy and Erastus, <transChange>but he</transChange> himself stayed <transChange>some</transChange> time in Asia.
Acts 19:23 Now there happened at that time no small disturbance about the way <transChange>which he taught.</transChange>
Acts 19:24 For one Demetrius, a silver-smith, who made silver models of Diana's temple, brought no small gain to the artificers: whom he got together,
Acts 19:25 and <transChange>with them</transChange> the workmen <transChange>they employed</transChange> about such things, and said, My friends, ye know that by this employment we get our wealth.
Acts 19:26 And ye see and hear, that not only at Ephesus, but in almost all Asia, this Paul hath persuaded and perverted many people, saying, that they are no gods which are made by hands.
Acts 19:27 So that we are not only in danger of this, that the business <transChange>we follow</transChange> will come to nothing; but also that the temple of the great goddess Diana will be despised; and her magnificence destroyed, whom all Asia and the <transChange>whole</transChange> world worshippeth.
Acts 19:28 Hearing <transChange>this</transChange> and being filled with rage, they cried out, saying, Great <transChange>is</transChange> Diana of the Ephesians.
Acts 19:29 And the whole city was filled with confusion: and they rushed with one accord into the theatre, dragging with <transChange>them</transChange> Gaius and Aristarchus <transChange>two</transChange> Macedonians, fellow-travellers with Paul.
Acts 19:30 And when Paul would have gone in unto the people, the disciples would not let him.
Acts 19:31 And some also of the chief <transChange>men</transChange> of Asia, being his friends, sent to him and desired him not to venture himself into the theatre.
Acts 19:32 Some therefore cried one thing, and some another; for the assembly was confused, and the greater part did not know for what they were come together.
Acts 19:33 And they brought Alexander forward out of the multitude, the Jews urging him on. And Alexander beckoning <transChange>with</transChange> the hand, would have made a defence to the people.
Acts 19:34 But when they knew that he was a Jew, they all cried out with one voice, for near two hours, Great <transChange>is</transChange> Diana of the Ephesians.
Acts 19:35 And when the Secretary had appeased the multitude, he said, Ye men of Ephesus, what man is there who doth not know that the city of the Ephesians is devoted to the service of the great goddess Diana, and of the image which fell down from Jupiter?
Acts 19:36 Since therefore these things are incontestible, ye ought to be quiet <transChange>and composed,</transChange> and to do nothing rashly.
Acts 19:37 For ye have brought these men <transChange>hither,</transChange> who are neither robbers of temples, nor blasphemers of your goddess.
Acts 19:38 If Demetrius therefore, and the artificers that are with him, have a charge against any <transChange>one,</transChange> the law-courts are open, and there are <transChange>Roman</transChange> proconsuls <transChange>likewise:</transChange> let them implead one another.
Acts 19:39 But if ye are enquiring any thing about other matters, let it be decided in a lawful assembly:
Acts 19:40 for we are in danger of being charged with sedition for <transChange>what has happened</transChange> this day, there being no cause by which we can give a reason for this concourse.
Acts 19:41 And when he had said these things, he dismissed the assembly. <chapter eID="gen4554" osisID="Acts.19"/>
Acts 20:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.20" sID="gen4596"/>
Acts 20:1 And after the tumult was over, Paul sent for the disciples to <transChange>him,</transChange> and having embraced them, departed to go into Macedonia.
Acts 20:2 And having passed through those parts, and given them much exhortation, he came into Greece.
Acts 20:3 And when he had spent three months <transChange>there,</transChange> the Jews having laid wait for him as he was going to embark for Syria, he determined to return by Macedonia.
Acts 20:4 And there accompanied him to Asia, Sopater the Berean, and of the Thessalonians Aristarchus and Secundus, and Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy: and the Asiatics,
Acts 20:5 Tychicus and Trophimus, who went before and stayed for us at Troas.
Acts 20:6 And after the days of unleavened bread we sailed from Philippi, and came to them at Troas in five days, where we spent seven days.
Acts 20:7 And upon the first day of the week, when the disciples were assembled together to break bread, Paul being about to depart on the morrow, preached unto them, and continued his discourse till midnight.
Acts 20:8 And there were many lamps in the upper room where they were assembled.
Acts 20:9 And a young man named Eutychus, who sat in a window, falling into a deep sleep, as Paul was discoursing for a long time, sunk down and fell from the third story, and was taken up dead.
Acts 20:10 And Paul went down and leaned over him, and took him up and said, Be not disturbed; for his life is in him.
Acts 20:11 Then he went up again, and having broken bread and eaten, and conversed <transChange>with them</transChange> a considerable time, <transChange>even</transChange> till break of day, he departed.
Acts 20:12 And they brought <transChange>in</transChange> the young man alive, and were not a little comforted.
Acts 20:13 But we went before to the ship, and sailed to Assos, being there to take in Paul: for so he had appointed, designing himself to go on foot.
Acts 20:14 And as soon as he joined us at Assos, we took him in and came to Mitylene.
Acts 20:15 And sailing from thence we came the next <transChange>day</transChange> over against Chios; and the <transChange>day</transChange> following we arrived at Samos, and stopping at Trogyllium, we came the <transChange>day</transChange> after to Miletus.
Acts 20:16 For Paul had determined to sail by Ephesus, that he might not spend time in Asia: for he endeavoured, if it were possible, to be at Jerusalem <transChange>on</transChange> the day of Pentecost.
Acts 20:17 But he sent from Miletus to Ephesus, and called the elders of the church.
Acts 20:18 And when they were come to him, he said unto them, Ye know in what manner I behaved among you all the time, from the first day that I came into Asia.
Acts 20:19 Serving the Lord with all humility, and many tears, and trials which befel me by the ambushes of the Jews.
Acts 20:20 <transChange>And</transChange> how I with-held nothing <transChange>that was</transChange> useful, but have declared <transChange>it</transChange> to you, and have taught you publicly and from house to house:
Acts 20:21 testifying both to the Jews and Greeks, repentance towards God, and faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.
Acts 20:22 And now, being constrained by the spirit, behold I am going to Jerusalem, not knowing what will befal me there:
Acts 20:23 save that the holy Spirit testifieth in every city, that bonds and afflictions await me.
Acts 20:24 But none of these things move me, nor do I account my life dear, so that I may finish my course with joy, and the ministry which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God.
Acts 20:25 And now behold I know that ye all, among whom I have gone preaching the kingdom of God, shall see my face no more.
Acts 20:26 Wherefore I call you to witness this day, that I am clear from the blood of all <transChange>men.</transChange>
Acts 20:27 For I have not failed to declare unto you all the counsel of God.
Acts 20:28 Take heed therefore to yourselves, and to all the flock, in which the holy Spirit hath appointed you bishops, to feed the church of God, which He purchased with his own blood.
Acts 20:29 For I know this, that after my departure grievous wolves will enter in among you, not sparing the flock.
Acts 20:30 And from among yourselves shall men arise, speaking perverse <transChange>things</transChange> to draw away disciples after them.
Acts 20:31 Watch therefore, remembering that for the space of three years I ceased not <transChange>by</transChange> night and <transChange>by</transChange> day to warn every one with tears.
Acts 20:32 And now, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, I recommend you to God, and to the word of his grace: who is able to edify <transChange>you,</transChange> and to give you an inheritance among all that are sanctified.
Acts 20:33 I have coveted no one's silver, or gold, or apparel:
Acts 20:34 and ye yourselves know that these hands have ministred to my necessities, and to those that were with me.
Acts 20:35 I have shewed you <transChange>in</transChange> all <transChange>things,</transChange> that <transChange>by</transChange> labouring thus ye ought to support the infirm; and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, who said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">It is more blessed to give than to receive.</q>
Acts 20:36 And when he had said these <transChange>things,</transChange> he kneeled down, and prayed with them all.
Acts 20:37 And they were all much grieved, and fell on Paul's neck, and kissed him: sorrowing most <transChange>of all</transChange> at the word which he spake,
Acts 20:38 that they should see his face no more. And they accompanied him to the ship. <chapter eID="gen4596" osisID="Acts.20"/>
Acts 21:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.21" sID="gen4635"/>
Acts 21:1 Now as soon as we had parted from them, and set sail, we came in a strait course to Coos, and the <transChange>day</transChange> following to Rhodes, and from thence to Patara.
Acts 21:2 And finding a ship <transChange>there, which was</transChange> passing over to Phenicia, we went aboard <transChange>it,</transChange> and set sail.
Acts 21:3 And coming in fight of Cyprus, we left it on the left hand, and sailed to Syria, and came down to Tyre: for there the ship was to unlade.
Acts 21:4 And we stayed there seven days; having met with <transChange>some</transChange> disciples: who told Paul by the Spirit, not to go up to Jerusalem.
Acts 21:5 But when we had completed <transChange>these</transChange> days, we departed and went our way, all <transChange>of them</transChange> attending us with <transChange>their</transChange> wives and children, till <transChange>we were</transChange> out of the city: and we kneeled down on the shore and prayed.
Acts 21:6 And having taken leave of each other, we went into the ship, and they returned home.
Acts 21:7 And we finishing our voyage, came down from Tyre to Ptolemais, and saluting the brethren stayed with them one day.
Acts 21:8 On the morrow Paul and those that were with him departed <transChange>from Ptolemais,</transChange> and came to Cesarea; and entering into the house of Philip the evangelist, who was <transChange>one</transChange> of the seven <transChange>deacons,</transChange> we stayed with him.
Acts 21:9 And he had four daughters virgins, <transChange>that were</transChange> prophetesses.
Acts 21:10 And as we abode <transChange>there</transChange> several days, there came down from Judea a certain prophet named Agabus:
Acts 21:11 and he came to us, and taking up Paul's girdle, and binding his own hands and feet, he said, Thus saith the holy Spirit, So shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man whose girdle this is, and shall deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.
Acts 21:12 And when we heard these things, both we and those of the place intreated him not to go up to Jerusalem.
Acts 21:13 But Paul answered, What do ye <transChange>mean,</transChange> weeping and breaking my heart? for I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.
Acts 21:14 And as he would not be persuaded, we ceased, saying, The will of the Lord be done.
Acts 21:15 And after these days <transChange>were expired,</transChange> we packed up our things, and went to Jerusalem.
Acts 21:16 And there went also with us from Cesarea <transChange>some</transChange> of the disciples, who brought us to one Mnason a Cyprian, an old disciple, with whom we were to lodge.
Acts 21:17 And when we were come to Jerusalem, the brethren received us with joy.
Acts 21:18 And the next day Paul went in with us to James: and all the elders were present.
Acts 21:19 And when he had saluted them, he gave a particular narrative of the things which God had done among the Gentiles by his ministry.
Acts 21:20 And when they heard <transChange>it,</transChange> they glorified the Lord, and said to him, Thou seest, brother, how many myriads there are of the believing Jews, and they are all zealous for the law.
Acts 21:21 And they have heard of thee, that thou teachest all the Jews, who are among the Gentiles, to forsake <transChange>the law of</transChange> Moses, telling them not to circumcise <transChange>their</transChange> children, nor to walk after <transChange>our</transChange> customs.
Acts 21:22 What then is <transChange>to be done?</transChange> The people must necessarily meet together; for they will hear that thou art come.
Acts 21:23 Do this therefore, which we advise thee. <transChange>Here</transChange> are four men with us, that have a vow upon them: take these and be purified with them,
Acts 21:24 and join in their expences, that they may shave their head: and <transChange>that</transChange> all may know, that there is nothing in what they have heard of thee; but thou thyself walkest according to the law.
Acts 21:25 But as to the believing Gentiles, we have written and determined, that they <transChange>need</transChange> observe no such thing; only to keep themselves from what is offered to idols, and from blood, and from <transChange>any thing</transChange> strangled, and from fornication.
Acts 21:26 Then Paul took the men, and the next day being purified with them entered into the temple to signify the accomplishment of the days of purification till an offering should be offered for every one of them.
Acts 21:27 But when the seven days were near ended, the Jews <transChange>that came</transChange> from Asia seeing him in the temple, raised a tumult among the people, and laid hands on him, crying out, Men of Israel, help:
Acts 21:28 this is the man that teaches all <transChange>men</transChange> every where against the people <transChange>of the Jews,</transChange> and the law, and this <transChange>sacred</transChange> place? and besides, hath brought Greeks too into the temple, and polluted this holy place.
Acts 21:29 (For they had before seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, whom they thought Paul had brought into the temple.)
Acts 21:30 And the whole city was moved, and there was a concourse of the people: and they laid hold on Paul, and dragged him out of the temple; and immediately the gates were shut.
Acts 21:31 And as they were going to kill him, a report came to the tribune of the cohort, that all Jerusalem was in an uproar:
Acts 21:32 who immediately took soldiers and centurions, and ran down to them. And when they saw the chiliarch and the soldiers, they left off beating Paul.
Acts 21:33 Then the commanding officer came near and took him, and ordered <transChange>him</transChange> to be bound with two chains; and inquired, who he was, and what he had done.
