Acts 21:34 But some in the croud bawled out one thing and some another: and as he could not know the certainty for the tumult, he commanded him to be carried into the castle.
Acts 21:35 And when he was upon the stairs, he was <transChange>even</transChange> borne by the soldiers, because of the violence of the people.
Acts 21:36 For the multitude followed crying out, Away with him.
Acts 21:37 And as Paul was going to be led into the castle, he said to the tribune, May I be allowed to speak <transChange>a word</transChange> to thee? And he said, Canst thou speak Greek?
Acts 21:38 Art not thou that Egyptian, who before this madest a sedition, and didst lead out into the wilderness four thousand murtherers?
Acts 21:39 But Paul said, I am indeed a Jew, a man of Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no mean city: and I beg thou wouldest permit me to speak to the people.
Acts 21:40 And when he gave him leave, Paul standing on the stairs made a sign with the hand to the people: and there being a great silence made, He spake to them in the Hebrew tongue, saying, <chapter eID="gen4635" osisID="Acts.21"/>
Acts 22:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.22" sID="gen4676"/>
Acts 22:1 Brethren, and Fathers, hear now my apology to you,
Acts 22:2 ---(and when they heard that he spake to them in the Hebrew dialect, they the more <transChange>readily</transChange> kept silence, and he said,)
Acts 22:3 ---I am indeed a Jew, born at Tarsus in Cilicia, but educated in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, accurately instructed in the law of our fathers, being zealous for God, as ye all are this day.
Acts 22:4 And I persecuted <transChange>those of</transChange> this persuasion even unto death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women.
Acts 22:5 As the high priest is my witness, and all the elders: from whom I received letters to <transChange>our</transChange> brethren, and went to Damascus to bring those also, that were there, bound to Jerusalem, to be punished.
Acts 22:6 And it came to pass that as I was on my journey and drew nigh to Damascus, about mid-day, on a sudden a great light from heaven shone round about me:
Acts 22:7 and I fell to the ground, and heard a voice saying unto me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?</q>
Acts 22:8 And I answered, Who art <transChange>thou,</transChange> Lord? And He said unto me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom thou persecutest.</q>
Acts 22:9 And they that were with me saw the light indeed, and were affrighted; but they did not hear the voice of Him that spake to me.
Acts 22:10 And I said, Lord, what shall I do? And the Lord said unto me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Arise, and go <transChange>on</transChange> to Damascus, and there it shall be told thee concerning all things which are appointed for thee to do.</q>
Acts 22:11 And as I could not see by reason of the glory of that light, being led by the hand by those that were with me, I came to Damascus.
Acts 22:12 And one Ananias, a devout observer of the law, who had a good character from all the Jews that dwelt <transChange>there,</transChange>
Acts 22:13 came to me, and stood by <transChange>me,</transChange> and said, Brother Saul, look up: and I immediately looked up upon him.
Acts 22:14 And he said, The God of our Fathers hath before appointed thee to know his will, and to see the just <transChange>One,</transChange> and to hear a voice from his mouth.
Acts 22:15 For thou shalt be his witness unto all men, of what thou hast seen and heard.
Acts 22:16 And now why shouldst thou delay? Arise and be baptized, and wash away thy sins, calling upon the name of the Lord.
Acts 22:17 And when I was returned to Jerusalem, and was praying in the temple, I was in a trance.
Acts 22:18 And <transChange>I</transChange> saw Him saying unto me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Make haste and go quickly out of Jerusalem; for they will not receive thy testimony concerning me.</q>
Acts 22:19 And I said, Lord, they themselves know that I imprisoned and scourged in the synagogues them that believed on Thee.
Acts 22:20 And when the blood of thy martyr Stephen was shed, I also stood by and consented to his death, and kept the clothes of them that slew him.
Acts 22:21 But he said unto me, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Go away; for I will send thee far hence unto the Gentiles.</q>---
Acts 22:22 And they heard him to this word, and <transChange>then</transChange> they exalted their voice, saying, Away with such <transChange>a fellow</transChange> from the earth; for it is not fit that he should live.
Acts 22:23 And as they were bawling out, and throwing <transChange>off</transChange> their clothes, and casting <transChange>up</transChange> dust into the air,
Acts 22:24 the tribune commanded him to be brought into the castle, and ordered him to be put to the question by scourging; that he might know for what reason they so cried out against him.
Acts 22:25 And as they were binding him with thongs, Paul said to the centurion that stood by, Is it lawful for you to scourge a man <transChange>who is</transChange> a Roman, uncondemned?
Acts 22:26 And the centurion hearing <transChange>this,</transChange> went and told the tribune, saying, Consider what thou art about to do; for this man is a Roman.
Acts 22:27 Then the tribune came and said to him, Tell me, art thou a Roman? And he said, Yes.
Acts 22:28 And the tribune replied, I obtained this freedom with a large sum of money. And Paul said, But I was <transChange>free</transChange>-born.
Acts 22:29 Immediately therefore those who were going to put him to the question quitted him: and the tribune also was afraid, when he knew that he was a Roman, and because he had bound him.
Acts 22:30 And on the morrow, desiring to know for certain what he was accused of by the Jews, he loosed him from his bonds, and ordered the chief priests and all their council to attend; and he brought down Paul, and set him before them: <chapter eID="gen4676" osisID="Acts.22"/>
Acts 23:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.23" sID="gen4707"/>
Acts 23:1 and Paul looking earnestly at the sanhedrim, said, "Brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God even to this day:"
Acts 23:2 but the high priest Ananias ordered those that stood next him, to smite him on the mouth.
Acts 23:3 Then said Paul to him, "God will smite thee, thou whited wall: dost thou sit to judge me according to the law, and contrary to the law commandest me to be smitten?"
Acts 23:4 But they that stood by said, Revilest thou God's high-priest?
Acts 23:5 And Paul said, I was not aware, brethren, that it was the high-priest: for it is written, Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people.
Acts 23:6 But Paul, knowing that the one part were sadducees, and the other pharisees, cried out in the sanhedrim, "Brethren, I am a pharisee, the son of a pharisee: for the hope of a resurrection of the dead I am <transChange>now</transChange> prosecuted."
Acts 23:7 Upon his saying this, there rose a contention between the pharisees and the sadducees; and the people were divided.
Acts 23:8 For the sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit; but the pharisees acknowledge both.
Acts 23:9 So there was a great clamor: and the scribes <transChange>that were</transChange> of the party of the pharisees rose up and contended, saying, We find no evil in this man; but if a spirit or an angel hath spoken to him, let us not fight against God.
Acts 23:10 But as there arose much contention, the tribune fearing least Paul should be torn in pieces by them, ordered <transChange>a party of</transChange> soldiers to go down, and take him by force out of the midst of them, and to bring him into the castle.
Acts 23:11 And the following night, the Lord standing by him said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Paul, be of good courage; for as thou hast testified concerning me at Jerusalem, so must thou also bear testimony at Rome.</q>
Acts 23:12 And when it was day, some of the Jews, having formed a conspiracy, bound themselves with a curse, saying, that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.
Acts 23:13 And they were more than forty that had made this oath:
Acts 23:14 who came to the chief priests and the elders, and said, "We have bound ourselves by a curse to eat nothing till we have killed Paul.
Acts 23:15 Now therefore do ye with <transChange>the rest of</transChange> the sanhedrim signify to the tribune, that he would bring him down to you to-morrow, as if you would examine more accurately some <transChange>things</transChange> concerning him: and we are ready to dispatch him before he come near <transChange>you.</transChange>"
Acts 23:16 But Paul's sister's son, hearing of the ambush, came and entered into the castle, and told Paul.
Acts 23:17 Then Paul called one of the centurions to <transChange>him,</transChange> and said, Introduce this young man to the tribune; for he hath something to tell him.
Acts 23:18 So he took him and brought him to the tribune, and said, Paul the prisoner called me to <transChange>him,</transChange> and desired me to introduce this young man unto thee, <transChange>as</transChange> having something to say to thee.
Acts 23:19 And the tribune took him by the hand, and retiring into a private <transChange>apartment</transChange> asked <transChange>him,</transChange> What is <transChange>it</transChange> which thou hast to tell me?
Acts 23:20 And he said, The Jews have agreed to desire thee, that thou wouldest bring down Paul to-morrow to the council, as if they would inquire something more strictly concerning him.
Acts 23:21 <transChange>But</transChange> do not thou comply with them: for there lie in wait for him more than forty men of them, who have bound themselves with a curse neither to eat nor drink till they have killed him: and they are now ready, waiting for an order from thee.
Acts 23:22 Then the tribune dismissed the young man, charging <transChange>him,</transChange> Tell no one that thou hast discovered these <transChange>things</transChange> to me.
Acts 23:23 And he called two of the centurions to <transChange>him,</transChange> and said, Get ready two hundred soldiers to go to Cesarea, and seventy horsemen, and two hundred spearmen, by the third hour of the night.
Acts 23:24 And provide beasts, that they may set Paul on and bring <transChange>him</transChange> safe to Felix the governor.
Acts 23:25 And he wrote a letter to this effect:
Acts 23:26 Claudius Lysias to the most excellent governor Felix <transChange>sendeth</transChange> greeting.
Acts 23:27 This man being seized by the Jews, and about to be killed by them, I came upon them with <transChange>some</transChange> soldiers and rescued him: for I understand that he is a Roman.
Acts 23:28 But desiring to know the cause for which they accused him, I brought him down into their council:
Acts 23:29 and I found he was accused about questions of their law, but had no charge <transChange>against him</transChange> deserving death or bonds.
Acts 23:30 But an ambush, <transChange>which was</transChange> going to be laid for the man by the Jews, being discovered to me, immediately I sent <transChange>him</transChange> to thee, telling his accusers also to say before thee what <transChange>they had</transChange> against him. Farewell.
Acts 23:31 The soldiers therefore, according to the orders given them, took up Paul, and brought him by night to Antipatris.
Acts 23:32 And the next day they returned to the castle, leaving the horsemen to go with him;
Acts 23:33 who, when they came into Cesarea, and delivered the epistle to the governor, presented Paul also before him.
Acts 23:34 And when the governor had read <transChange>the letter,</transChange> and asked of what province he was; being informed that <transChange>he was</transChange> of Cilicia, he said,
Acts 23:35 I will hear thee, when thine accusers are also come. And he ordered him to be kept in Herod's palace. <chapter eID="gen4707" osisID="Acts.23"/>
Acts 24:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.24" sID="gen4743"/>
Acts 24:1 And after five days, the high-priest Ananias came down with the elders, and one Tertulius an orator, who appeared before the governor against Paul.
Acts 24:2 And when he was called, Tertullus began to accuse <transChange>him,</transChange> saying, "As by thee we enjoy much peace, and glorious things are done to this nation by thy prudent administration,
Acts 24:3 we acknowledge <transChange>it</transChange> upon all occasions and in all places, most noble Felix, with all thankfulness.
Acts 24:4 But that I may not trespass upon thee too far, I beg thou wouldst hear us a few words with thy <transChange>wonted</transChange> goodness.
Acts 24:5 For having found this man a pestilent fellow, and a mover of sedition among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ring-leader of the sect of the Nazarenes,
Acts 24:6 and attempting to profane the temple, we apprehended him, and would have judged <transChange>him</transChange> according to our law.
Acts 24:7 But Lysias the tribune came upon us, and with great violence took <transChange>him</transChange> away out of our hands, commanding his accusers to come unto thee:
Acts 24:8 from whom thou mayst thyself <transChange>by</transChange> examining <transChange>him</transChange> come to the knowledge of all these <transChange>things</transChange> of which we accuse him."
Acts 24:9 And the Jews also assented, saying, that these <transChange>things</transChange> were so.
Acts 24:10 Then Paul, when the governor permitted him to speak, answered <transChange>in this manner,</transChange> "As I know that thou hast been many years a judge to this nation, I do the more chearfully answer for myself:
Acts 24:11 because thou mayst know, that there are not more than twelve days since I went up to worship at Jerusalem:
Acts 24:12 and they neither found me disputing with any one in the temple, or making sedition among the people, neither in the synagogues, nor in the city:
Acts 24:13 nor can they prove <transChange>the things</transChange> of which they now accuse me.
Acts 24:14 But this I confess unto thee, that after the way, which they call heresy, so do I worship the God of my fathers, believing all things <transChange>which are</transChange> written in the law, and the prophets:
Acts 24:15 having hope in God, (which they themselves also expect) that there shall be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and unjust.
Acts 24:16 And on this account do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void of offence <transChange>both</transChange> towards God and <transChange>towards</transChange> men.
Acts 24:17 Now after several years I came to bring alms to my nation, and offerings.
Acts 24:18 Upon which some Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with multitude nor with tumult:
Acts 24:19 who ought to have been here before thee, and make good their charge, if they had any thing against me.
Acts 24:20 Or let these themselves say, if they found any crime in me, when I stood before the sanhedrim;
Acts 24:21 unless for this one expression, that I cried out when I stood among them, For the resurrection of the dead I am called in question by you this day."
Acts 24:22 And when Felix heard these <transChange>things</transChange> he put them off, (for he had been more particularly informed concerning this way <transChange>of religion,</transChange>) and said, When Lysias the tribune comes down, I will thoroughly examine your matters.
Acts 24:23 And he commanded the centurion to keep Paul <transChange>secure,</transChange> and to let him have <transChange>some</transChange> liberty, and to hinder none of his friends from assisting him or coming to him.
Acts 24:24 Some days after Felix coming with his wife Drusilla, a Jewess, sent for Paul, and heard him concerning faith in Christ.
Acts 24:25 And as he was reasoning of justice, temperance, and a future judgement, Felix trembled, and said, Go thy way for this time, and I will take a proper opportunity to call for thee <transChange>again.</transChange>
Acts 24:26 And hoping also that money would be given him by Paul, that he might discharge him; he sent for him the more frequently, and conversed with him.
Acts 24:27 But after two years Felix received a successor, Porcius Festus; and being willing to gain favor with the Jews lest Paul confined. <chapter eID="gen4743" osisID="Acts.24"/>
Acts 25:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.25" sID="gen4771"/>
Acts 25:1 Festus therefore, being come into the province, after three days went up from Cesarea to Jerusalem.
Acts 25:2 And the high-priest and principal <transChange>men</transChange> among the Jews, appeared before him against Paul, and made application to him,
Acts 25:3 begging the favor of him, that he would send for him to Jerusalem; <transChange>for they were</transChange> preparing an ambush to kill him by the way.
Acts 25:4 But Festus answered, that Paul was in custody at Cesarea, and that <transChange>he</transChange> himself should go <transChange>thither</transChange> soon.
Acts 25:5 Therefore, said he, let those of you who are able, go down with <transChange>me,</transChange> and if there be any thing <transChange>bad</transChange> in this man, let them accuse him.
Acts 25:6 And when he had staid among them more than ten days, he went down to Cesarea, and the next day sitting on the tribunal, he commanded Paul to be brought <transChange>before him.</transChange>
Acts 25:7 And when he was come, the Jews that came down from Jerusalem, stood <transChange>round</transChange> about, bringing many heavy charges against Paul, which they were not able to prove:
Acts 25:8 he answering in his <transChange>own</transChange> defence, Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Cesar have I committed any offence.
Acts 25:9 But Festus, being desirous to gain favor with the Jews, answered Paul and said, Art thou willing to go up to Jerusalem, and there to be tried concerning these things before me?
Acts 25:10 Then said Paul, I stand at Cesar's tribunal, where I ought to be tried: I have done no wrong to the Jews, as thou very well knowest.
Acts 25:11 For if I am indeed doing <transChange>them</transChange> wrong, and have committed any thing worthy of death, I refuse not to die: but if there be nothing <transChange>in</transChange> what these <transChange>men</transChange> accuse me of, no one can give me up to them.
Acts 25:12 I appeal to Cesar. Then Festus, conferring with <transChange>his</transChange> council, answered, Hast thou appealed to Cesar? to Cesar thou shalt go.
Acts 25:13 And some days after king Agrippa and Bernice came to Cesarea to salute Festus.
Acts 25:14 And as they spent several days there, Festus related Paul's <transChange>case</transChange> to the king, saying, There is a man left in custody by Felix: concerning whom,
Acts 25:15 when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews appeared <transChange>in court,</transChange> desiring judgement against him.
Acts 25:16 To whom I answered, it is not the custom of the Romans to give up any man to destruction, till he that is accused have the accusers face to face, and have an opportunity of <transChange>making his</transChange> defence concerning the accusation.
Acts 25:17 Therefore when they were come hither, making no delay, I sat on the tribunal the next day, and ordered the man to be brought <transChange>before me.</transChange>
Acts 25:18 Against whom, when the accusers stood up, they brought no charge of such things as I supposed <transChange>they would:</transChange>
Acts 25:19 but had certain questions against him concerning their own religion; and of one Jesus that was dead, whom Paul affirmed to be alive.
Acts 25:20 But I being in doubt as to the dispute concerning these <transChange>matters,</transChange> asked <transChange>him,</transChange> if he would go to Jerusalem, and there be tried concerning these <transChange>things.</transChange>
Acts 25:21 But when Paul appealed, to be reserved to the hearing of <transChange>our</transChange> sovereign, I ordered him to be kept till I could send him to Cesar.
Acts 25:22 Then Agrippa said to Festus, I should be willing to hear the man myself. And he said, thou shalt hear him to-morrow.
Acts 25:23 The next day therefore, Agrippa and Bernice coming with much pomp, and entering into the court, together with the chief officers, and men of <transChange>greatest</transChange> eminence in the city, at the command of Festus Paul was brought <transChange>in.</transChange>
Acts 25:24 And Festus said, "King Agrippa and all that are here present with us, ye see this <transChange>man,</transChange> concerning whom all the Jews have applied to me, both at Jerusalem and here, crying out, that he ought not to live.
Acts 25:25 But when I found that he had done nothing worthy of death, and as he himself has appealed to the emperor, I have determined to send him.
Acts 25:26 Concerning whom I have nothing certain to write to <transChange>our</transChange> sovereign: wherefore I have brought him out before you, and especially before thee, O king Agrippa, that after examination <transChange>is</transChange> made I may have somewhat to write.
Acts 25:27 For it seems to me absurd, to send a prisoner and not to signify the crimes <transChange>laid</transChange> against him." <chapter eID="gen4771" osisID="Acts.25"/>
Acts 26:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.26" sID="gen4799"/>
Acts 26:1 Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretching forth <transChange>his</transChange> hand, <transChange>thus</transChange> made his defence,
Acts 26:2 "O king Agrippa, I think myself happy, that I am this day to make my defence before thee, concerning all <transChange>the things</transChange> which I am accused of by the Jews:
Acts 26:3 especially as thou art acquainted with all the customs and questions <transChange>which are</transChange> among the Jews; wherefore I intreat thee to hear me patiently.
Acts 26:4 My manner of life then from <transChange>my</transChange> youth, as it has been from the beginning among my own nation at Jerusalem, all the Jews are acquainted with,
Acts 26:5 knowing me before, (if they would testify <transChange>it,</transChange>) that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived a pharisee.
Acts 26:6 And now I stand arraigned for the hope of the promise <transChange>which was</transChange> made by God to our fathers:
Acts 26:7 to which <transChange>promise</transChange> our twelve tribes, worshipping continually night and day, hope to attain: concerning which hope, O king Agrippa, I am accused by the Jews.
Acts 26:8 What! is it judged incredible by you, that God <transChange>should</transChange> raise the dead?
Acts 26:9 I indeed <transChange>once</transChange> thought with myself, that I ought to do many <transChange>things</transChange> contrary to the name of Jesus the Nazarene:
Acts 26:10 which I also did in Jerusalem; and I shut up many of the saints in prison, having received authority <transChange>for it</transChange> from the chief priests; and when they were put to death I gave my voice against <transChange>them.</transChange>
Acts 26:11 And often punishing them in all the synagogues, I compelled <transChange>them</transChange> to blaspheme, and being excessively enraged against them, I persecuted them even to foreign cities.
Acts 26:12 On which <transChange>accounts</transChange> as I was going to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests---at mid-day,
Acts 26:13 O king, <transChange>as I was</transChange> on the way <transChange>thither</transChange> I saw a light from heaven exceeding the splendor of the sun, shining <transChange>round</transChange> about me and those that were going with me.
Acts 26:14 And when we were all fallen down to the earth, I heard a voice speaking to me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, <q marker="" who="Jesus">Saul, Saul, why dost thou persecute me? <transChange>It is</transChange> hard for thee to kick against the goads.</q>
Acts 26:15 And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And He said, <q marker="" who="Jesus">I am Jesus, whom thou persecutest.</q>
Acts 26:16 <q marker="" who="Jesus">But rise, and stand on thy feet: for to this <transChange>end</transChange> have I appeared unto thee, to appoint thee a minister and a witness both of the things which thou hast seen, and <transChange>of those for</transChange> which I shall <transChange>hereafter</transChange> appear unto thee:</q>
Acts 26:17 <q marker="" who="Jesus">delivering thee from the people and <transChange>from</transChange> the Gentiles, to whom I now send thee,</q>
Acts 26:18 <q marker="" who="Jesus">to open their eyes, <transChange>and</transChange> to turn <transChange>them</transChange> from darkness to light, and <transChange>from</transChange> the power of satan unto God; that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and an inheritance among them that are sanctified by faith in me.</q>
Acts 26:19 Wherefore, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision:
Acts 26:20 but declared first to those in Damascus and Jerusalem, and through all the country of Judea, and <transChange>then</transChange> to the Gentiles, that they should repent, and turn unto God, performing works suitable to repentance.
Acts 26:21 For these <transChange>things</transChange> the Jews seized me in the temple, and attempted to kill me.
Acts 26:22 But having obtained help of God, I continue until this day, testifying both to small and great, <transChange>and</transChange> saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses declared should come to pass; <transChange>even</transChange> that the Messiah should suffer,
Acts 26:23 <transChange>and</transChange> being the first of the resurrection from the dead should bring light to the people and to the Gentiles."
Acts 26:24 And as he was saying these things in his defence, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself: much learning turns thy brain.
Acts 26:25 But he replied, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but <transChange>I</transChange> speak the words of truth and of a sound mind.
Acts 26:26 For the king knoweth of these <transChange>things,</transChange> to whom also I speak with freedom; because I am persuaded that none of them are unknown to him; for this was not done in a corner.
Acts 26:27 O king Agrippa, believest thou the prophets?
Acts 26:28 I know that thou believest <transChange>them.</transChange> Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou almost persuadest me to be a Christian.
Acts 26:29 And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.
Acts 26:30 And when he had said this, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and those that sat with them.
Acts 26:31 And when they were retired, they spake to each other, saying, this man hath done nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
Acts 26:32 And Agrippa said to Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed to Cesar. <chapter eID="gen4799" osisID="Acts.26"/>
Acts 27:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.27" sID="gen4832"/>
Acts 27:1 Now as it was determined that we should sail to Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion named Julius, of the Augustan cohort.
Acts 27:2 And going on board a ship of Adramyttium, we went off, intending to sail by the coasts of Asia; Aristarchus a Macedonian of Thessalonica being with us.
Acts 27:3 And the next <transChange>day</transChange> we touched at Sidon. And Julius treating Paul with <transChange>great</transChange> humanity, permitted him to go to his friends to get <transChange>proper</transChange> supplies.
Acts 27:4 And when we departed from thence, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.
Acts 27:5 And sailing through the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra <transChange>a city</transChange> of Lycia.
Acts 27:6 And there the centurion finding a ship of Alexandria bound for Italy, he put us on board it.
Acts 27:7 And as we sailed slowly for many days, and were hardly got on to Cnidus, the wind not permitting us, we sailed under Crete by Salmone.
Acts 27:8 And passing it with difficulty, we came to a place called the Fair-havens, near to which was the city <transChange>of</transChange> Lasea.
Acts 27:9 And as much time was spent, and sailing was now dangerous, (for the fast was now past,) Paul exhorted <transChange>them,</transChange>
Acts 27:10 saying, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage is like to be prejudicial and <transChange>with</transChange> much damage, not only of the lading and of the ship, but also of our lives.
Acts 27:11 But the centurion regarded the pilot and the master of the vessel, more than the <transChange>things</transChange> that were said by Paul.
Acts 27:12 And the haven not being commodious to winter in, the greater part advised to sail from thence, if they could possibly reach to Phenice to winter <transChange>at that</transChange> haven of Crete, which looks <transChange>both</transChange> to the south-west and north-west.
Acts 27:13 And as the south wind blew gently, thinking they were secure of <transChange>their</transChange> purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed close by Crete.
Acts 27:14 But not long after there arose against it a tempestuous wind called Euroclydon.
Acts 27:15 And the ship being hurried on, and not able to face the wind, we gave it up and <transChange>so</transChange> were carried <transChange>along.</transChange>
Acts 27:16 And running under a certain island called Clauda, we were hardly able to become masters of the boat.
Acts 27:17 Which when they had hoisted up, they used helps, undergirding the ship; and fearing least they should fall into the quick-sands, they struck fail, and so were driven.
Acts 27:18 And as we were exceedingly tossed by the storm, the next <transChange>day</transChange> they lightened the ship:
Acts 27:19 and the third <transChange>day</transChange> we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship <transChange>too.</transChange>
Acts 27:20 And as neither sun nor stars appeared for several days, and no small tempest lay on <transChange>us,</transChange> all hope of our being saved was now taken away.
Acts 27:21 But after long abstinence from food, Paul stood <transChange>up</transChange> in the midst of them and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me, and not loosed from Crete, and so have saved this damage and loss.
Acts 27:22 However, I now exhort you to be of good courage: for there shall be no loss of <transChange>any</transChange> life among you, but only of the ship:
Acts 27:23 for there stood by me this night an angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve, saying,
Acts 27:24 Fear not, Paul, thou must be brought before Cesar, and behold God hath given thee all <transChange>that are</transChange> sailing with thee.
Acts 27:25 Wherefore, Sirs, be of good courage; for I trust in God, that it shall be so, according as it was told me.
Acts 27:26 But we must be cast upon some island.
Acts 27:27 And when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven up and down in the Adriatic sea, about the middle of the night the mariners thought they drew near to some land:
Acts 27:28 and sounding they found <transChange>it</transChange> twenty fathoms; and when they had gone a little farther, and sounded again, they found <transChange>it</transChange> fifteen fathoms.
Acts 27:29 Then fearing least they should fall upon <transChange>some</transChange> rocky places, they cast four anchors out of the stern and wished for day.
Acts 27:30 But the mariners endeavouring to flee out of the ship, and having let down the boat into the sea, under pretence that they were going to stretch out anchors from the head of the ship,
Acts 27:31 Paul said to the centurion, and to the soldiers, Unless these <transChange>men</transChange> stay in the ship ye cannot be saved.
Acts 27:32 Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let it fall off.
Acts 27:33 And while the day was coming on, Paul exhorted <transChange>them</transChange> all to take <transChange>some</transChange> food, saying, Fourteen days this day ye continue waiting without <transChange>proper</transChange> food, having taken nothing:
Acts 27:34 wherefore I exhort you to take <transChange>some</transChange> nourishment, for this is <transChange>necessary</transChange> for your safety: for there shall not a hair fall from the head of any of you.
Acts 27:35 And having spoken thus, he took bread and gave thanks to God in presence of <transChange>them</transChange> all, and when he had broken <transChange>it</transChange> he began to eat.
Acts 27:36 And being all encouraged they also took <transChange>some</transChange> food.
Acts 27:37 And we were <transChange>in</transChange> all in the ship two hundred <transChange>and</transChange> seventy-six souls.
Acts 27:38 And when they were satisfied with food, they lightened the ship and cast out the corn into the sea.
Acts 27:39 And when it was day, they did not know the land <transChange>near them:</transChange> but they perceived a certain creek with a shore, into which they were desirous, if they could, to have thrust the ship.
Acts 27:40 And when they had taken up the anchors, they trusted <transChange>the ship</transChange> to the sea, at the same time, loosing the rudder-bands; and hoisting up the main-sail to the wind, they made to the shore.
Acts 27:41 But falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship a-ground; and the fore-part stuck fast, and remained immoveable, but the hinder part was dashed in pieces by the violence of the waves.
Acts 27:42 And the counsel of the soldiers was to kill the prisoners, least any <transChange>of them</transChange> should swim out and escape.
Acts 27:43 But the centurion, desirous to save Paul, hindered them from <transChange>their</transChange> purpose, and ordered those that could swim to throw <transChange>themselves</transChange> out first, and get off to land:
Acts 27:44 and the rest, some on planks, and others on some <transChange>other things</transChange> out of the ship. And so it came to pass that <transChange>they</transChange> all got safe to land. <chapter eID="gen4832" osisID="Acts.27"/>
Acts 28:0 <chapter osisID="Acts.28" sID="gen4877"/>
Acts 28:1 And when they were safe <transChange>on shore,</transChange> they understood, that the island was called Melita.
Acts 28:2 And the barbarians shewed us uncommon humanity: for they kindled a fire and took us all in, because of the present rain, and of the cold.
Acts 28:3 And Paul having gathered together a bundle of sticks, and laid them on the fire, there came out a viper from the heat, and fastened on his hand.
Acts 28:4 And when the barbarians saw the <transChange>venomous</transChange> creature hanging on his hand, they said to one another, This man is certainly a murderer, whom, though he hath been saved from the sea, yet justice suffereth not to live.
Acts 28:5 But he shook off the creature into the fire, and suffered no hurt.
Acts 28:6 They however were expecting that he would swell, or suddenly fall down dead: but when they had waited a good while, and saw no hurt come to him, they changed <transChange>their opinion</transChange> and said that he was a god.
Acts 28:7 Now in the parts adjacent to <transChange>this</transChange> place was the seat of the chief <transChange>man</transChange> of the island, whose name was Publius, who took us into <transChange>his house,</transChange> and entertained us three days courteously.
Acts 28:8 And it happened that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and dysentery: to whom Paul went in, and prayed, and laid his hands on him, and healed him.
Acts 28:9 Upon this, others also in the island, who had diseases came to <transChange>him</transChange> and were cured:
Acts 28:10 who also honoured us with many honors, and furnished <transChange>us,</transChange> when we departed, with such things as were necessary.
Acts 28:11 And after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, that had wintered in the island, whose sign was Castor and Pollux.
Acts 28:12 And being arrived at Syracuse, we staid <transChange>there</transChange> three days.
Acts 28:13 From whence coasting round we came to Rhegium, and after one day a south-wind rising, we came the second day to Puteoli:
Acts 28:14 where finding <transChange>some</transChange> brethren, we were desired to stay with them seven days: and so we went <transChange>on</transChange> to Rome.
Acts 28:15 And when the brethren heard of us, they came from thence to meet us, <transChange>some</transChange> as far as Appii-forum, and <transChange>others to</transChange> the Three-taverns: whom when Paul saw, he thanked God and took courage.
Acts 28:16 And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but Paul was permitted to live by himself with the soldier that had him in custody.
Acts 28:17 And after three days Paul called together the chief of the Jews. And when they were come together, he said unto them, Brethren, though I have done nothing against the people <transChange>of the Jews,</transChange> or the customs of <transChange>our</transChange> fathers, <transChange>yet</transChange> was I delivered a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans:
Acts 28:18 who when they had examined me, would have set <transChange>me</transChange> at liberty, because there was no crime <transChange>worthy</transChange> of death <transChange>found</transChange> in me:
Acts 28:19 but the Jews opposing <transChange>it,</transChange> I was obliged to appeal to Cesar; <transChange>though</transChange> not as having any thing to accuse my nation of.
Acts 28:20 For this reason therefore I desired to see and to speak to you: because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
Acts 28:21 And they said to him, We have neither received letters concerning thee from Judea, nor has any of the brethren, that is come hither, related or spoken any ill of thee.
Acts 28:22 But we would willingly hear from thee what thou thinkest: for as to this sect, we know that it is every where spoken against.
Acts 28:23 And having appointed him a day, many came to him at his lodging; to whom he discoursed and testified the kingdom of God, persuading them of the things concerning Jesus, both from the law of Moses, and <transChange>from</transChange> the prophets, from morning till evening.
Acts 28:24 And some regarded the things that were spoken, but others did not believe.
Acts 28:25 And <transChange>so</transChange> disagreeing one with another they separated, when Paul had said one word, <transChange>to wit,</transChange> that the holy Spirit spake rightly by Esaias the prophet to our fathers,
Acts 28:26 saying, Go to this people and say, Ye shall hear by <transChange>the</transChange> hearing <transChange>of the ear,</transChange> and not understand; and <transChange>in</transChange> seeing ye shall see, and not perceive: for the heart of this people is stupified,
Acts 28:27 and they hear heavily with <transChange>their</transChange> ears, and have closed their eyes; least they should see at all with <transChange>their</transChange> eyes, and hear with <transChange>their</transChange> ears, and understand with <transChange>their</transChange> heart, and be converted, and I should heal them.
Acts 28:28 Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent to the Gentiles, and they will hear <transChange>it.</transChange>
Acts 28:29 And when he had said these <transChange>things,</transChange> the Jews departed, having much debate among themselves.
Acts 28:30 And Paul abode two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came to him:

Romans 1:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.1" sID="gen4910"/>
Romans 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> a servant of Jesus Christ, called <transChange>to be</transChange> an apostle,
Romans 1:2 separated unto the gospel of God, (which He had promised before by his prophets in the holy scriptures) concerning his Son,
Romans 1:3 who was of the seed of David according to the flesh,
Romans 1:4 <transChange>but</transChange> powerfully declared <transChange>to be</transChange> the Son of God, according to the spirit of holiness, by <transChange>his</transChange> resurrection from the dead, even Jesus Christ our Lord;
Romans 1:5 by whom we have received grace and apostleship to <transChange>preach</transChange> the obedience of faith for his name's sake, to all nations;
Romans 1:6 among whom are ye also the called of Jesus Christ;
Romans 1:7 to all that are in Rome beloved of God, called <transChange>and</transChange> holy: grace <transChange>be</transChange> to you, and peace from God our Father, and <transChange>from</transChange> the Lord Jesus Christ.
Romans 1:8 And first I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is celebrated through the whole world:
Romans 1:9 for God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of his Son, how incessantly I make mention of you always in my prayers,
Romans 1:10 intreating if I may now at length have a prosperous journey by the will of God, to come unto you.
Romans 1:11 For I long to see you, that I may impart to you some spiritual gift, that you may be established:
Romans 1:12 that is <transChange>to say,</transChange> that <transChange>being</transChange> among you we may be comforted together by the faith of each, both yours and mine.
Romans 1:13 And I would not have you ignorant, brethren, that I often purposed to come unto you, (but have been hindered hitherto) that I might have some fruit among you also, even as among the other Gentiles.
Romans 1:14 <transChange>For</transChange> I am a debtor both to Greeks and barbarians, both to <transChange>the</transChange> learned and <transChange>the</transChange> unlearned:
Romans 1:15 therefore am I ready, as much as in me <transChange>lies,</transChange> to preach the gospel to you also that are at Rome.
Romans 1:16 For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ; for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth, both Jew and Greek:
Romans 1:17 for the righteousness of God is therein revealed from faith to faith; as it is written, "The just shall live by faith."
Romans 1:18 For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who withhold the truth in unrighteousness;
Romans 1:19 for what is to be known of God is manifest among them, for God hath manifested it to them.
Romans 1:20 <transChange>Inasmuch</transChange> as from the <transChange>first</transChange> creation of the world, the invisible things of Him, <transChange>even</transChange> his eternal power and Godhead, are, if attended to, clearly seen in <transChange>his</transChange> works:
Romans 1:21 so that they are inexcusable; because having <transChange>thus</transChange> known God they glorified Him not as God, neither were they thankful; but were infatuated by their <transChange>own</transChange> reasonings, and their heart <transChange>being</transChange> void of understanding was darkened.
Romans 1:22 Pretending to be wise they Became fools:
Romans 1:23 and changed the glory of the incorruptible God for an image like to corruptible man, and birds, and <transChange>beasts,</transChange> and reptiles.
Romans 1:24 Wherefore God also gave them up to impurity, in the lusts of their own hearts, to dishonour their own bodies among themselves;
Romans 1:25 who changed the truth of God into a lie, and worshipped and served the creature instead of the Creator, who is blessed for ever. Amen.
Romans 1:26 Therefore God gave them up to infamous passions: for even their women changed the natural use into that which is unnatural,
Romans 1:27 and the men likewise, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust to one another, men with men committing shame, and receiving in themselves the recompence of their error which they deserved.
Romans 1:28 And as they were not careful to acknowledge God, God gave them up to an undiscerning mind to do things <transChange>that were</transChange> not fit <transChange>to be done:</transChange>
Romans 1:29 being filled with all injustice, lewdness, wickedness, covetousness, malignity; full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, <transChange>and every</transChange> evil habit; whisperers,
Romans 1:30 slanderers, haters of God, injurious, haughty, proud, inventers of mischief, undutiful to parents, void of understanding,
Romans 1:31 covenant-breakers, without natural affection, implacable, <transChange>and</transChange> unmerciful:
Romans 1:32 who though they knew the just judgement of God, (that they who commit such practises are worthy of death) <transChange>yet</transChange> not only do these very things, but also countenance <transChange>and encourage others</transChange> in the practice <transChange>of them.</transChange> <chapter eID="gen4910" osisID="Rom.1"/>
Romans 2:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.2" sID="gen4943"/>
Romans 2:1 Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whoever thou art, that judgest: for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself; for thou that judgest dost the same <transChange>things.</transChange>
Romans 2:2 But we know that the judgement of God is according to truth against those that do such <transChange>things.</transChange>
Romans 2:3 And thinkest thou, O man, who judgest those that do such <transChange>things,</transChange> and dost the same, that thou shalt escape the judgement of God?
Romans 2:4 Or despisest thou the riches of his goodness, and forbearance, and long-suffering, not knowing that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?
Romans 2:5 But by thy hardness and impenitence of heart thou art treasuring up to thyself wrath against the day of wrath and revelation of the just judgement of God,
Romans 2:6 who will render to every <transChange>one</transChange> according to his works:
Romans 2:7 to them, who by perseverance in well-doing seek for glory, and honor, and immortality, eternal life:
Romans 2:8 but to those who are contentious, and obey not the truth, but obey unrighteousness, indignation and wrath.
Romans 2:9 Tribulation and anguish <transChange>shall be</transChange> upon every soul of man that worketh evil, both of the Jew, and of the Gentile:
Romans 2:10 but glory, and honor, and peace to every <transChange>one</transChange> that worketh good, both to the Jew, and to the Greek:
Romans 2:11 for there is no respect of persons with God.
Romans 2:12 For as many as have sinned without the law shall also perish without the law; and as many as have sinned under the law shall be judged by the law;
Romans 2:13 (for not the hearers of the law are just before God, but the doers of the law shall be justified:
Romans 2:14 for when the Gentiles, who have not the law, do by nature <transChange>the</transChange> <transChange>duties</transChange> of the law, these though they have not the law, are a law to themselves,
Romans 2:15 and shew the work of the law written on their hearts, their conscience witnessing together with <transChange>it,</transChange> and their <transChange>own</transChange> thoughts either accusing, or excusing <transChange>them,</transChange>)
Romans 2:16 in the day when God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my gospel.
Romans 2:17 Behold thou art called a Jew, and restest on the law, and boastest in God,
Romans 2:18 and knowest <transChange>his</transChange> will, and approvest things that are excellent, being instructed out of the law,
Romans 2:19 and art persuaded that thou art a guide of the blind,
Romans 2:20 a light to them that are in the darkness, an instructor of the simple, a teacher of babes, having the form of the knowledge and of the truth <transChange>which is</transChange> in the law.
Romans 2:21 Thou then, who teachest another, teachest thou not thyself? <transChange>Thou,</transChange> that preachest <transChange>a man should</transChange> not steal, dost thou steal?
Romans 2:22 <transChange>Thou,</transChange> that sayest <transChange>a man should</transChange> not commit adultery, dost thou commit adultery? <transChange>Thou,</transChange> that abhorrest idols, dost thou commit sacrilege?
Romans 2:23 <transChange>Thou,</transChange> that boastest in the law, dost thou by transgression of the law dishonour God?
Romans 2:24 for through you the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles, as it is written.
Romans 2:25 For circumcision indeed is profitable, if thou keep the law: but if thou be a transgressor of the law, thy circumcision is become uncircumcision.
Romans 2:26 Therefore if the uncircumcised keep the righteous precepts of the law, shall not his uncircumcision be accounted to him for circumcision?
Romans 2:27 and shall not the uncircumcision that is by nature, if it fulfil the law, judge thee, who by the letter and circumcision art a transgressor of the law? for he is not a Jew, who is <transChange>only</transChange> so in appearance;
Romans 2:28 nor is <transChange>that</transChange> circumcision, which is <transChange>only</transChange> in appearance, in the flesh;
Romans 2:29 but he <transChange>is</transChange> a Jew who is one inwardly, and circumcision <transChange>is that</transChange> of the heart in the spirit, not in the letter: whose praise is not from men, but from God. <chapter eID="gen4943" osisID="Rom.2"/>
Romans 3:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.3" sID="gen4973"/>
Romans 3:1 What then <transChange>is</transChange> the advantage of the Jew, or what <transChange>is</transChange> the profit of circumcision?
Romans 3:2 Much, every way: chiefly, because they were intrusted with the oracles of God.
Romans 3:3 For what if some did not believe? shall their incredulity make the faithfulness of God of no effect?
Romans 3:4 God forbid: yea, let God be <transChange>acknowledged</transChange> true, though every man <transChange>be</transChange> a liar; as it is written, That thou mightest be justified in thy words, and mightest overcome, when thou judgest.
Romans 3:5 "But if our unrighteousness confirm the righteousness of God, what shall we say? <transChange>Is</transChange> not God unrighteous, who inflicteth <transChange>his</transChange> wrath?" (I speak as a man) God forbid:
Romans 3:6 for then how shall God judge the world?
Romans 3:7 "But, <transChange>say you,</transChange> if the truth of God hath abounded unto his glory through my falshood, why yet am I also judged as a sinner?
Romans 3:8 and <transChange>why</transChange> may we not do evil that good may come?"---as we are injuriously charged, and as some affirm that we say; whose condemnation is just.
Romans 3:9 "What then are we the better?" Not at all, <transChange>in point of justification;</transChange> for we have before proved that both Jews and Gentiles are all under sin: as it is written,
Romans 3:10 "There is none righteous, no not one;
Romans 3:11 there is none that understandeth; there is none that seeketh after God.
Romans 3:12 They are all gone out of the way, they are become unprofitable, there is none that practiseth goodness, no not one.
Romans 3:13 Their throat <transChange>is</transChange> an open sepulchre: with their tongues they have used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips:
Romans 3:14 whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness:
Romans 3:15 their feet <transChange>are</transChange> swift to shed blood:
Romans 3:16 destruction and misery <transChange>are</transChange> in their ways:
Romans 3:17 and the way of peace they have not known; <transChange>and</transChange> the fear of God is not before their eyes."
Romans 3:18 Now we know that whatsoever the law saith,
Romans 3:19 it saith to those under the law: that every mouth may be stopped, and all the world obnoxious to the justice of God.
Romans 3:20 Wherefore by the works of the law no flesh shall be justified before Him: for by the law <transChange>is</transChange> the knowledge of sin.
Romans 3:21 But now, without <transChange>the</transChange> law, righteousness before God is manifested, being attested by the law and the prophets;
Romans 3:22 and <transChange>this</transChange> righteousness of God <transChange>is</transChange> by faith in Jesus Christ unto all and upon all believers; for there is no difference;
Romans 3:23 for all have sinned and come short of the glory of God;
Romans 3:24 being justified freely by his grace, because of the redemption <transChange>that is</transChange> in Christ Jesus:
Romans 3:25 whom God hath appointed <transChange>to be</transChange> a propitiation, through faith in his blood, for a demonstration of his righteousness, in the remission of past sins, according to the forbearance of God;
Romans 3:26 for a demonstration, <transChange>I say,</transChange> of his righteousness at this time: that He might be just, and the justifier of him, that believeth in Jesus.
Romans 3:27 Where then <transChange>is</transChange> boasting? it is excluded: by what law? of works? no: but by the law of faith.
Romans 3:28 Therefore we conclude, that a man is justified by faith, without the works of the law:
Romans 3:29 or is He the God of the Jews only, and not also of the Gentiles?
Romans 3:30 surely of the Gentiles also: seeing <transChange>it is</transChange> one God who will justify the circumcision by faith, and uncircumcision <transChange>also</transChange> through faith.
Romans 3:31 Do we then make the law of none effect through faith? God forbid: yea we establish the law. <chapter eID="gen4973" osisID="Rom.3"/>
Romans 4:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.4" sID="gen5005"/>
Romans 4:1 What shall we say then that Abraham our father obtained according to the flesh?
Romans 4:2 for if Abraham were justified by works, he hath something to boast of; but <transChange>this he hath</transChange> not before God:
Romans 4:3 for what saith the scripture? "Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him for righteousness."
Romans 4:4 Now to him that worketh the reward is not reckoned as a favor, but as a debt:
Romans 4:5 but to him that worketh not, but believeth on Him who justifieth the ungodly, his faith is accounted for righteousness.
Romans 4:6 As David also describeth the blessedness of the man to whom: God imputeth righteousness without works, <transChange>saying,</transChange>
Romans 4:7 "Blessed <transChange>are</transChange> they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered:
Romans 4:8 blessed <transChange>is</transChange> the man to whom the Lord imputeth not sin."
Romans 4:9 Now <transChange>is</transChange> this blessedness upon the circumcised <transChange>only,</transChange> or upon the uncircumcised also? for we say that faith was accounted to Abraham for righteousness.
Romans 4:10 How then was it accounted <transChange>to him?</transChange> when he was in circumcision, or in uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.
Romans 4:11 And he received the sign of circumcision <transChange>as</transChange> a seal of the righteousness of the faith <transChange>which he had</transChange> in uncircumcision: that he might be the father of all that believe though not circumcised, that righteousness may be imputed to them also:
Romans 4:12 and the father of circumcision to those, who not only are of the circumcision, but also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had in uncircumcision.
Romans 4:13 For the promise <transChange>made</transChange> to Abraham, or to his seed, that he should be heir of the world, <transChange>was</transChange> not by the law, but by the righteousness of faith:
Romans 4:14 for if they <transChange>only</transChange> that are of the law be heirs, faith is made useless, and the promise is become of no effect.
Romans 4:15 Now the law worketh wrath; for where there is no law, <transChange>there is</transChange> no transgression.
Romans 4:16 <transChange>And</transChange> therefore <transChange>it is</transChange> of faith, that <transChange>it might be</transChange> by grace, that <transChange>so</transChange> the promise might be sure to all the seed; not to that only <transChange>which is</transChange> of the law, but also to that <transChange>which is</transChange> of the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all,
Romans 4:17 (as it is written, "I have made thee a father of many nations,") in the sight of <transChange>Him</transChange> whom he believed, <transChange>even</transChange> God, who giveth life to the dead, and calleth the things that are not as if they were:
Romans 4:18 who against hope believed, with hope, that he should be the father of many nations, according to that which was said <transChange>unto him,</transChange> "So shall thy seed be."
Romans 4:19 And not being weak in faith, he considered not his own body now dead, being about an hundred years old; nor the deadness of Sarah's womb.
Romans 4:20 He hesitated not at the promise of God through unbelief: but was strong in faith, giving glory to God,
Romans 4:21 and being fully persuaded, that what was promised He was able to perform:
Romans 4:22 and therefore it was imputed to him for righteousness.
Romans 4:23 Now it was not written on his account only, that it was imputed to him:
Romans 4:24 but for our sakes also, to him it will be imputed, as we believe on Him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead:
Romans 4:25 who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification. <chapter eID="gen5005" osisID="Rom.4"/>
Romans 5:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.5" sID="gen5031"/>
Romans 5:1 Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ:
Romans 5:2 through whom also we have admission by faith into this grace in which we stand, and boast in hope of the glory of God.
Romans 5:3 And not only <transChange>so,</transChange> but we also glory in tribulations, knowing that tribulation worketh patience,
Romans 5:4 and patience experience,
Romans 5:5 and experience hope, and <transChange>this</transChange> hope maketh <transChange>us</transChange> not ashamed; because the love of God is diffused in our hearts by the holy Spirit that is given to us.
Romans 5:6 For when we were yet without strength, Christ died in <transChange>due</transChange> season for the ungodly.
Romans 5:7 Whereas one would hardly die for a just <transChange>man,</transChange> though perhaps for a good <transChange>man</transChange> one might dare even to die.
Romans 5:8 But God recommendeth his love towards us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
Romans 5:9 Much more then, being now justified by his blood, shall we be saved from wrath through Him.
Romans 5:10 For if when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son; much more being reconciled shall we be saved by his life.
Romans 5:11 And not only <transChange>so,</transChange> but we also boast in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom we have now received reconciliation.
Romans 5:12 Wherefore as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin, so death passed upon all men, for to that all have sinned:
Romans 5:13 for sin was in the world before the law. Now sin is not imputed where there is no law;
Romans 5:14 <transChange>and</transChange> yet death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned after the likeness of Adam's transgression, who is the type of Him that was to come.
Romans 5:15 But not as the offence, so also <transChange>is</transChange> the free gift: for if through the offence of one many died, much more hath the grace of God, and the gift <transChange>bestowed</transChange> by the grace of one man, Jesus Christ, abounded to many.
Romans 5:16 For the gift is not as <transChange>the sentence was</transChange> by one that sinned; for the sentence <transChange>is passed</transChange> from one <transChange>offence</transChange> to condemnation, but the free gift <transChange>is</transChange> of many offences to justification.
Romans 5:17 For if, by the offence of one, death reigned through one, much more they who receive the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness, shall reign in life through one, <transChange>even</transChange> Jesus Christ.
Romans 5:18 Therefore as by the offence of one <transChange>the effect of it was</transChange> upon all men to condemnation: so also by the righteousness of one, <transChange>the effect was</transChange> upon all men to justification of life.
Romans 5:19 For as by the disobedience of one man many were made sinners; so by the obedience of One shall many be made righteous.
Romans 5:20 Now the law made some entrance, that the offence might <transChange>appear to</transChange> abound; but where sin abounded, grace hath superabounded; that as sin had reigned in death,
Romans 5:21 so grace might reign through righteousness, unto eternal life, by Jesus Christ our Lord. <chapter eID="gen5031" osisID="Rom.5"/>
Romans 6:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.6" sID="gen5053"/>
Romans 6:1 What shall we say then? Shall we continue in sin, that grace may abound?
Romans 6:2 God forbid! how shall we, who are dead to sin, live any longer therein?
Romans 6:3 Know ye not, that as many of us as were baptized into Jesus Christ, were baptized into his death?
Romans 6:4 Therefore we are buried with Him by baptism into death: that as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so we also should walk in newness of life:
Romans 6:5 for if we have been planted together in the resemblance of his death, so shall we be also of <transChange>his</transChange> resurrection.
Romans 6:6 Knowing this, that our old man is crucified with <transChange>Him,</transChange> that the body of sin might be destroyed, that we might no longer be inslaved to sin:
Romans 6:7 for he that is <transChange>thus</transChange> dead <transChange>with Christ,</transChange> is delivered from sin.
Romans 6:8 Now if we be dead with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with Him:
Romans 6:9 knowing that Christ being raised from the dead dieth no more; death hath no more power over Him: for as He died, He died once for all on account of sin;
Romans 6:10 but as He liveth, He liveth unto God.
Romans 6:11 So also do ye reckon yourselves to be dead indeed unto sin, but alive unto God in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Romans 6:12 Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body, to obey it in the lusts thereof.
Romans 6:13 Neither yield your bodies <transChange>as</transChange> instruments of unrighteousness unto sin: but present yourselves to God as alive from the dead, and your bodies as instruments of righteousness to God.
Romans 6:14 For sin shall have no power over you, inasmuch as ye are not under the law, but under grace.
Romans 6:15 What then? shall we sin, because we are not under the law, but under grace?
Romans 6:16 God forbid! Know ye not, that to whom ye present yourselves servants to obedience, <transChange>his</transChange> servants ye are whom ye obey? either of sin unto death, or of obedience unto righteousness?
Romans 6:17 But thanks <transChange>be</transChange> to God, that ye <transChange>who</transChange> were servants of sin, have obeyed from the heart <transChange>that</transChange> form of doctrine which was delivered to you:
Romans 6:18 and being set free from sin, ye are become the servants of righteousness.
Romans 6:19 I speak after the manner of men, because of the infirmity of your flesh: as ye have yielded your bodies servants to impurity and iniquity to <transChange>work</transChange> iniquity; so now present your bodies servants to righteousness, unto holiness.
Romans 6:20 For when ye were servants of sin, ye were free from righteousness.
Romans 6:21 What fruit therefore had ye then <transChange>in the things,</transChange> which ye are now ashamed of? for the end of those things <transChange>is</transChange> death.
Romans 6:22 But now being set free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life.
Romans 6:23 For the wages of sin <transChange>is</transChange> death: but the gift of God <transChange>is</transChange> eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord. <chapter eID="gen5053" osisID="Rom.6"/>
Romans 7:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.7" sID="gen5077"/>
Romans 7:1 Are ye ignorant, brethren, (for I speak to them that know the law) that the law hath power over a man, <transChange>only</transChange> so long as it liveth?
Romans 7:2 For a married woman is bound by the law to <transChange>her</transChange> husband <transChange>while he is</transChange> living; but if <transChange>her</transChange> husband die, she is discharged from the law of <transChange>her</transChange> husband.
Romans 7:3 Therefore while <transChange>her</transChange> husband is living, she shall be called an adulteress if she become another man's: but if <transChange>her</transChange> husband be dead, she is free from the law; so that she is not an adulteress, though she become another man's.
Romans 7:4 And thus, my brethren, ye also are dead to the law by the body of Christ; that ye might become another's, <transChange>even his</transChange> who is raised from the dead, that we might bring forth fruit unto God.
Romans 7:5 For when we were in the flesh, the sinful passions <transChange>while we were</transChange> under the law operated in our bodies <transChange>so</transChange> as to bring forth fruit unto death.
Romans 7:6 But now we are delivered from the law, <transChange>that</transChange> being dead by which we were bound, that we might serve <transChange>God</transChange> in newness of spirit, and not <transChange>in the</transChange> oldness of <transChange>the</transChange> letter.
Romans 7:7 What shall we say then? <transChange>is</transChange> the law sin? God forbid! Nay, I had not known sin, but by the law: for I had not known lust <transChange>to be sinful,</transChange> if the law had not said, "Thou shalt not covet."
Romans 7:8 But sin taking occasion by the commandment wrought in me all manner of concupiscence: for without the law sin <transChange>was</transChange> dead.
Romans 7:9 And I was heretofore alive without the law: but when the commandment came, sin revived, and I died:
Romans 7:10 and the commandment <transChange>which was intended</transChange> to life, I found <transChange>to be</transChange> unto death.
Romans 7:11 For sin taking occasion by the commandment deceived me, and by it slew me.
Romans 7:12 So that the law is holy; and the commandment holy, and just, and good.
Romans 7:13 Was then that which is good made death unto me? God forbid! But sin, that it might appear sin, working death in me by that which is good: that sin might be <transChange>shewn</transChange> by the commandment <transChange>to be</transChange> exceeding sinful.
Romans 7:14 For we know that the law is spiritual: but I am carnal, sold under sin.
Romans 7:15 For that which I do, I allow not: for I do not that which I would; but what I hate, this I do.
Romans 7:16 And if I do that which I would not, I consent to the law that it is good:
Romans 7:17 but now I am no more the doer of it, but sin that dwelleth in me.
Romans 7:18 For I know that in me (that is in my flesh) dwelleth no good: for to will is present with me, but <transChange>how</transChange> to perform <transChange>that which is</transChange> good, I find not.
Romans 7:19 For I do not the good that I would; but the evil which I would not, this I do.
Romans 7:20 Now if I do that which I would not, I am no more the doer of it, but sin that dwelleth in me.
Romans 7:21 I find then a <transChange>kind of</transChange> law, that when I would do good, evil besets me.
Romans 7:22 For I delight in the law of God, as to the inward man:
Romans 7:23 but I perceive another law in my body warring against the law of my mind, and captivating me to the law of sin, which is in my body.
Romans 7:24 Wretched man <transChange>that</transChange> I <transChange>am!</transChange> who shall deliver me from this body of death?
Romans 7:25 The grace of God through Jesus Christ our Lord. So then with my mind I serve the law of God, but with the flesh the law of sin. <chapter eID="gen5077" osisID="Rom.7"/>
Romans 8:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.8" sID="gen5103"/>
Romans 8:1 <transChange>There is</transChange> therefore now no condemnation to them that are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh but after the spirit.
Romans 8:2 For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath set me free from the law of sin and death.
Romans 8:3 For that which was impossible for the law <transChange>to do, and</transChange> in which it was weak through <transChange>the corruption of</transChange> the flesh, God <transChange>by</transChange> sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh <transChange>to be a sacrifice</transChange> for sin, hath <transChange>done; that is,</transChange> hath condemned sin in the flesh:
Romans 8:4 that the righteousness of the law may be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh but after the spirit.
Romans 8:5 For they who are after the flesh, mind the things of the flesh; but they who are led by the Spirit, <transChange>do mind</transChange> spiritual <transChange>things.</transChange>
Romans 8:6 Now to be carnally minded <transChange>is</transChange> death; but to be spiritually minded <transChange>is</transChange> life and peace:
Romans 8:7 because the carnal mind is an enemy to God; for it is not subject to the law of God, nor indeed can be:
Romans 8:8 and they who are carnal, cannot please God.
Romans 8:9 But ye are not in the flesh, but in the spirit, if the Spirit of God dwelleth in you: but if any <transChange>one</transChange> hath not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.
Romans 8:10 And if Christ <transChange>be</transChange> in you, the body indeed <transChange>is</transChange> dead because of sin, but the spirit <transChange>is</transChange> alive because of righteousness.
Romans 8:11 And if the Spirit of Him that raised up Jesus from the dead, dwelleth in you, He that raised up Christ from the dead, will also restore your mortal bodies to life, by his Spirit that <transChange>now</transChange> dwelleth in you.
Romans 8:12 Therefore, brethren, we are debtors not to the flesh, to live after the flesh:
Romans 8:13 for if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die; but if by the Spirit ye mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.
Romans 8:14 For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, these are the sons of God.
Romans 8:15 For ye have not received the spirit of bondage again to fear; but ye have received the spirit of adoption, whereby we cry, Abba, Father.
Romans 8:16 <transChange>So that</transChange> the Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
Romans 8:17 And if children, then heirs; heirs of God, and co-heirs with Christ: if so be we suffer with <transChange>Him,</transChange> that we may be also glorified with <transChange>Him.</transChange>
Romans 8:18 And I account the sufferings of this present time not worthy <transChange>to be set</transChange> against the glory that shall be revealed to us.
Romans 8:19 For the earnest expectation of the world is waiting for the revelation of the sons of God:
Romans 8:20 (for the world was subjected to vanity, not willingly, but through him who made it subject:)
Romans 8:21 in hope that they also shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption into the glorious liberty of the children of God.
Romans 8:22 For we know that the whole world groaneth, and doth <transChange>as it were</transChange> travail in pain together even to this day.
Romans 8:23 And not only <transChange>others,</transChange> but those also who have the first-fruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, waiting for the adoption, <transChange>to wit</transChange> the redemption of our body.
Romans 8:24 For we are saved by hope: but hope that is seen, is not hope; for what any <transChange>one</transChange> sees, how doth he yet hope for?
Romans 8:25 but if we hope for what we see not, <transChange>then</transChange> we wait for it with patience.
Romans 8:26 And the Spirit likewise helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for, as we ought: but the Spirit itself intercedes for us with unutterable groans.
Romans 8:27 And He that searcheth the hearts, knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit; for he intercedeth for the saints according to <transChange>the will of</transChange> God.
Romans 8:28 And we know that all <transChange>things</transChange> co-operate for good to them that love God, to them that are called according to his purpose;
Romans 8:29 for those whom he foreknew, He also predetermined <transChange>to be</transChange> conformed to the image of his Son, that He might be <transChange>as</transChange> the first-born among many brethren: and whom He before ordained, these He also called;
Romans 8:30 and whom He called, these he also justified; and whom He justified, these He also glorified.
Romans 8:31 What shall we say then to these <transChange>things?</transChange> if God <transChange>be</transChange> for us, who <transChange>can be</transChange> against us?
Romans 8:32 He that spared not his own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how shall He not with Him freely give us all <transChange>things?</transChange>
Romans 8:33 Who shall lay <transChange>any</transChange> accusation against the elect of God? <transChange>will</transChange> God, who justifieth <transChange>us?</transChange>

Romans 9:1 I say the truth in Christ, I lye not, (my conscience bearing me witness in the holy Ghost,)
Romans 9:2 that I have great grief and continual sorrow in my heart:
Romans 9:3 for I could wish that I myself were made a curse after the manner of Christ, for my brethren, my kindred according to the flesh;
Romans 9:4 who are Israelites, whose <transChange>is</transChange> the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the <transChange>form of</transChange> divine worship, and the promises:
Romans 9:5 whose <transChange>are</transChange> the fathers, and of whom, as to the flesh, Christ <transChange>came,</transChange> who is over all God blessed for ever. Amen.
Romans 9:6 Not that the word of God hath failed. For they <transChange>are</transChange> not all Israel, who are <transChange>descended</transChange> from Israel.
Romans 9:7 Nor because they are the seed of Abraham, <transChange>are they</transChange> all children <transChange>of promise:</transChange> but "in Isaac shall thy seed be called."
Romans 9:8 That is, not the children of the flesh <transChange>are</transChange> the children of God, but the children of the promise are accounted for the seed.
Romans 9:9 For this <transChange>is</transChange> the word of <transChange>the</transChange> promise, "According to this time will I come, and Sarah shall have a son:"
Romans 9:10 and not <transChange>to her</transChange> only; but Rebecca also being with child by our father Isaac,

Romans 9:16 So then <transChange>it is</transChange> not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy.
Romans 9:17 And the scripture saith unto Pharaoh, for this very purpose have I raised thee up, that I may shew forth my power in thee, and that my name may be declared through all the earth.
Romans 9:18 So then He hath mercy on whom He pleaseth, and whom He will, He hardeneth.
Romans 9:19 Thou wilt say then, Why doth he yet blame <transChange>us?</transChange> who hath resisted his will?
Romans 9:20 Nay but, O man, who art thou, that disputest against God? Shall the thing formed say to him that formed <transChange>it,</transChange> Why didst thou make me thus?
Romans 9:21 Hath not the potter power over the clay, out of the same mass to make one vessel to honor and another to dishonor?
Romans 9:22 And <transChange>what</transChange> if God, <transChange>though</transChange> resolved to shew his displeasure <transChange>at last,</transChange> and to make known his power, <transChange>yet</transChange> bore with much long-suffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction?
Romans 9:23 and that He might make known the riches of his glory in the vessels of mercy, which He hath prepared for glory?

Romans 9:26 And in the place where it was said to them, Ye are not my people, there shall they be called the children of the living God.

Romans 10:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.10" sID="gen5177"/>
Romans 10:1 Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is that they may be saved.
Romans 10:2 For I bear them witness that they have a zeal for God, but not according to knowledge.
Romans 10:3 For being ignorant of the righteousness of God, and seeking to establish their own righteousness, they have not submitted themselves to the righteousness <transChange>which is</transChange> of God.
Romans 10:4 For Christ is the end of the law, for righteousness to every believer.
Romans 10:5 For Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, "That the man who doth those <transChange>things</transChange> shall live by them."
Romans 10:6 But the righteousness <transChange>which is</transChange> of faith speaketh thus, "Say not in thine heart, Who shall ascend into heaven, (that is, to bring Christ down) or,
Romans 10:7 who shall descend into the deep, (that is, to
Romans 10:8 bring up Christ from the dead)" but what saith <transChange>it?</transChange> "The word is nigh thee, in thy mouth and in thy heart." This is the word of faith which we preach: that if thou confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus,
Romans 10:9 and believe in thine heart, that God hath raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
Romans 10:10 For with the heart <transChange>man</transChange> believeth unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.
Romans 10:11 For the scripture saith, Whosoever believeth on Him, shall not be ashamed.
Romans 10:12 For there is no difference of Jew and Greek: for He <transChange>being</transChange> Lord of all is bountiful to all that call upon Him.
Romans 10:13 For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
Romans 10:14 But how shall they call upon <transChange>him</transChange> in whom they have not believed? and how shall they believe <transChange>on him</transChange> of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher?
Romans 10:15 and how shall they preach unless they be sent? as it is written, How beautiful are the feet of those who bring the good tidings of peace, who bring the good tidings of good <transChange>things?</transChange>
Romans 10:16 But all have not obeyed the gospel: for Esaias saith, "Lord, who hath believed our report?"
Romans 10:17 So that faith <transChange>cometh</transChange> by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
Romans 10:18 But I say, Have they not heard? Verily their sound is gone out into all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.
Romans 10:19 But I say <transChange>again,</transChange> Did not Israel know <transChange>this? when</transChange> first Moses saith, "I will move you to jealousy by <transChange>those who are</transChange> not a people, I will provoke you to anger by a foolish nation:"
