Romans 11:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.11" sID="gen5199"/>
Romans 11:1 I say then, Hath God cast off his people? God forbid! for I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
Romans 11:2 God hath not cast off his people, whom He foreknew. Do ye not know what the scripture saith of Elias? how he complains to God against Israel,
Romans 11:3 saying, "Lord, they have slain thy prophets, and digged down thine altars; and I am left alone, and they seek my life."
Romans 11:4 But what saith the oracle of God to him? "I have reserved to myself seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knee to Baal."
Romans 11:5 And so in the present time also there is a remnant according to the election of grace.
Romans 11:6 And if by grace, <transChange>it is</transChange> no more of works: for <transChange>then</transChange> grace is no longer grace. But if of works, it is no more grace: for <transChange>then</transChange> work is no longer work.
Romans 11:7 What then? Israel hath not obtained that which he sought: but the elect have obtained <transChange>it,</transChange> and the rest were blinded,
Romans 11:8 (according as it is written, God hath given them a spirit of slumber, that their eyes could not see and their ears could not hear,) <transChange>even</transChange> unto this day.
Romans 11:9 And David saith, Let their table become a snare, and a trap, and a stumbling-block, and a recompence unto them.
Romans 11:10 Let their eyes be darkened that they may not see, and always bow down their back.
Romans 11:11 Say I then, Have they stumbled, that they should fall <transChange>irrecoverably?</transChange> God forbid! but <transChange>this I say, that</transChange> by their fall salvation <transChange>is come</transChange> to the Gentiles to excite them to emulation.
Romans 11:12 Now if their fall <transChange>be</transChange> the riches of the world, and their diminution <transChange>be</transChange> the riches of the Gentiles, how much more <transChange>will</transChange> their fulness <transChange>be?</transChange>
Romans 11:13 For I speak to you Gentiles: inasmuch indeed as I am the apostle of the Gentiles,
Romans 11:14 I extol my office, that if possible I may excite to emulation my <transChange>brethren according to the</transChange> flesh, and may save some of them:
Romans 11:15 for if the rejecting of them <transChange>be</transChange> the reconciling of the world, what <transChange>will</transChange> the receiving <transChange>them again be</transChange> but life from the dead?
Romans 11:16 Now if the first-fruits <transChange>be</transChange> holy, so <transChange>is</transChange> the <transChange>whole</transChange> heap: and if the root <transChange>be</transChange> holy, so <transChange>are</transChange> the branches.
Romans 11:17 But if some of the branches were broken off, and thou a wild-olive wert grafted in among them, and art made a partaker together <transChange>with them</transChange> of the root and fatness of the olive; boast not against the branches:
Romans 11:18 and if thou boastest, <transChange>remember</transChange> thou bearest not the root, but the root thee.
Romans 11:19 Wilt thou say then, The branches were broken off, that I might be grafted in?
Romans 11:20 Well; they were broken off for <transChange>their</transChange> infidelity, and thou standest by faith: <transChange>therefore</transChange> be not high-minded but fear.
Romans 11:21 For if God spared not the natural branches, neither would He spare thee.
Romans 11:22 Behold therefore the goodness and severity of God: towards them that fell, severity; but towards thee, goodness; if thou continue in <transChange>his</transChange> goodness: for <transChange>else</transChange> thou also shalt be cut off.
Romans 11:23 And they, if they do not continue in unbelief, shall be grafted in: for God is able again to graft them in.
Romans 11:24 For if thou wert cut out of the wild olive, which was natural <transChange>to thee,</transChange> and contrary to nature were grafted into a good olive; how much more shall these <transChange>who are</transChange> the natural <transChange>branches,</transChange> be grafted into their own olive-tree?
Romans 11:25 For I would not have you, brethren, to be ignorant of this mystery, (least ye should be wise in your own eyes) that blindness in part is befallen Israel, till the fulness of the Gentiles be come in.
Romans 11:26 And so all Israel shall be saved, as it is written, "The deliverer shall come out of Sion, and shall turn away impiety from Jacob:
Romans 11:27 and this <transChange>is</transChange> my covenant with them, when I take away their sins."
Romans 11:28 As to the gospel indeed they are enemies on your account, but as to the election they are beloved on account of the fathers.
Romans 11:29 For the gifts and calling of God <transChange>are</transChange> without repentance.
Romans 11:30 For as ye were heretofore disobedient to God, but have now obtained mercy in their disobedience:
Romans 11:31 so these also in your mercy have now been disobedient, that they themselves might be the objects of mercy.
Romans 11:32 For God hath included them all in <transChange>the charge of</transChange> disobedience, that He might have mercy upon all.
Romans 11:33 O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable <transChange>are</transChange> his judgements, and his ways not to be traced out!
Romans 11:34 For who hath known the mind of the Lord, or who hath been his counsellor?

Romans 12:1 I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, <transChange>and</transChange> well-pleasing to God, <transChange>as</transChange> your rational service.
Romans 12:2 And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may experience what is the good, and acceptable, and perfect will of God.
Romans 12:3 For by the grace conferred on me I charge every one among you, not to think <transChange>of himself</transChange> above what he ought to think: but to think with sobriety, according as God hath divided to every man the measure of faith.
Romans 12:4 For as in one body we have many members, and all the members have not the same office:
Romans 12:5 so we <transChange>who are</transChange> many, are one body in Christ, and every one members of each other.
Romans 12:6 But having different gifts, according to the grace conferred upon us, whether prophecy, <transChange>let us prophesy</transChange> according to the proportion of <transChange>our</transChange> faith:
Romans 12:7 or ministry, <transChange>let us attend</transChange> to the ministry: or he that teacheth, on teaching: or he that exhorteth, on exhortation:
Romans 12:8 he that distributeth, let him do it with integrity: he that presideth, with diligence: he that sheweth mercy, with chearfulness.
Romans 12:9 <transChange>Let</transChange> love <transChange>be</transChange> unfeigned. Abhor <transChange>that which is</transChange> evil, cleave to that which is good;
Romans 12:10 <transChange>be</transChange> tenderly affected with brotherly love to each other, in honor preferring one another:
Romans 12:11 not slothful in business: fervent in spirit: serving the Lord.
Romans 12:12 Rejoicing in hope, patient under affliction, persevering in prayer,
Romans 12:13 communicating to the necessities of the saints, given to hospitality.
Romans 12:14 Bless them that persecute you: bless <transChange>them, I say,</transChange> and do not curse <transChange>them.</transChange>
Romans 12:15 Rejoice with those that rejoice, and weep with those that weep.
Romans 12:16 <transChange>Be</transChange> alike affected to each other: not aiming at high things, but accommodating <transChange>yourselves</transChange> to persons of low rank. Be not wise in your own conceit.
Romans 12:17 Render to no one evil for evil: behaving honorably in the sight of all men.
Romans 12:18 If <transChange>it be</transChange> possible, as much as ye can, live peaceably with all men.
Romans 12:19 Avenge not yourselves, <transChange>my</transChange> beloved; but <transChange>rather</transChange> give place to the wrath <transChange>of others:</transChange> for it is written, "Vengeance <transChange>belongeth</transChange> to me, I will recompence, saith the Lord."

Romans 13:1 Let every soul be subject to the powers <transChange>that are</transChange> over <transChange>them:</transChange> for there is no <transChange>such</transChange> power but from God: the powers that are <transChange>over men,</transChange> are appointed by God.
Romans 13:2 So that he who resisteth the power, resisteth the ordinance of God: and they that resist shall receive condemnation.
Romans 13:3 For rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil. Wouldest thou then not be afraid of the <transChange>civil</transChange> power? do <transChange>what is</transChange> good, and thou shalt have praise from it:
Romans 13:4 for he is the minister of God to thee for good. But if thou dost evil, be afraid; for he beareth not the sword in vain: for he is <transChange>also</transChange> the minister of God, <transChange>as</transChange> an avenger to <transChange>execute his</transChange> wrath upon the malefactor.
Romans 13:5 Wherefore it is necessary to submit, not only on account of punishment, but also of conscience.
Romans 13:6 For you pay <transChange>them</transChange> tribute also for this <transChange>reason;</transChange> because they are God's ministers, continually attending hereunto.
Romans 13:7 Render therefore to all <transChange>what is</transChange> their due: tribute to whom tribute <transChange>is due,</transChange> custom to whom custom, reverence to whom reverence, honor to whom honor.
Romans 13:8 Owe no one any thing, but to love one another; for he that loveth others hath fulfilled the law:
Romans 13:9 for this <transChange>command,</transChange> Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness, Thou shalt not covet, and every other <transChange>social</transChange> precept, is summed up in this, namely, "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself."
Romans 13:10 Love worketh no evil to <transChange>our</transChange> neighbour: therefore love <transChange>is</transChange> the fulfilling of the law.
Romans 13:11 And this <transChange>let us observe,</transChange> knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep; for now is our salvation nearer than when we <transChange>first</transChange> believed.
Romans 13:12 The night is far spent, the day is at hand: let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armour of light.
Romans 13:13 Let us behave decently as <transChange>being</transChange> in the day; not in rioting and drunkenness, not in lewdness and lasciviousness, not in strife and envying.

Romans 14:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.14" sID="gen5273"/>
Romans 14:1 Receive him that is weak in the faith, <transChange>but</transChange> not to disputes about doubtful matters:
Romans 14:2 for one believeth that he may eat any <transChange>food;</transChange> another, who is weak, liveth upon herbs.
Romans 14:3 Let not him, that eateth, despise him that eateth not; and let not him, that eateth not, censure him that eateth: for God hath received him.
Romans 14:4 Who art thou that judgest the servant of another? To his own master he standeth or falleth: yea, he shall be established; for God is able to establish him.
Romans 14:5 One preferreth some days to others; another esteemeth every day <transChange>alike.</transChange> Let every <transChange>one</transChange> be fully satisfied in his own mind.
Romans 14:6 He that regardeth a day regardeth <transChange>it</transChange> to the Lord; and he that regardeth not the day, <transChange>in deference</transChange> to the Lord he doth not regard <transChange>it</transChange>. <transChange>So</transChange> he, that eateth <transChange>all sorts of food,</transChange> eateth to the Lord; for he giveth God thanks <transChange>for it;</transChange> and he that eateth not <transChange>of some kinds of food, in deference</transChange> to the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks <transChange>for the rest.</transChange>
Romans 14:7 For none of us liveth to himself, and no one dieth to himself:
Romans 14:8 but if we live, we live to the Lord; and if we die, we die unto the Lord: whether we live therefore, or die, we are the Lord's.
Romans 14:9 For to this <transChange>end</transChange> Christ both died, and rose, and lives again, that He might be Lord both of the dead and of the living.
Romans 14:10 But why dost thou censure thy brother? or why dost thou set at nought thy brother? since we shall all stand before the tribunal of Christ;
Romans 14:11 for it is written, <transChange>As</transChange> I live, saith the Lord, every knee shall bow to me, and every tongue shall confess to God.
Romans 14:12 So that every one of us shall give an account of himself to God.
Romans 14:13 Let us not therefore judge one another any more: but judge this rather, not to lay a stumbling-block or scandal before a brother.
Romans 14:14 I know and have been taught by the Lord Jesus, that nothing <transChange>is</transChange> unclean of itself: only to him that thinketh any <transChange>thing</transChange> unclean, to him <transChange>it is</transChange> unclean.
Romans 14:15 But if thy brother be grieved by <transChange>thy</transChange> food, thou dost not herein walk in love. Do not by thy food destroy him, for whom Christ died.
Romans 14:16 Let not your liberty then be evil-spoken of: for the kingdom of God consists not in meat and drink;
Romans 14:17 but <transChange>in</transChange> righteousness and peace, and joy in the holy Ghost: for he,
Romans 14:18 that in these serveth Christ, is acceptable to God, and approved by men.
Romans 14:19 Let us then pursue peace, and mutual edification.

Romans 15:0 <chapter osisID="Rom.15" sID="gen5297"/>
Romans 15:1 Now we that are strong, ought to bear the infirmities of the weak, and not to please ourselves:
Romans 15:2 but let every one of us please <transChange>our</transChange> neighbor for <transChange>his</transChange> good, to <transChange>his</transChange> edification.
Romans 15:3 For Christ also pleased not himself; but as it is written, "The reproaches of them that reproached thee, fell upon me."
Romans 15:4 For whatever <transChange>things</transChange> were written heretofore, were written for our instruction; that we through patience and the consolation of the scriptures might have hope.
Romans 15:5 And may the God of patience and consolation grant you the like <transChange>mutual</transChange> affection to each other, according to <transChange>the example of</transChange> Christ Jesus:
Romans 15:6 that with one mind <transChange>and</transChange> one mouth ye may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Romans 15:7 Wherefore receive ye one another, as Christ hath received us, to the glory of God.
Romans 15:8 Now Jesus Christ was a minister of the circumcision for <transChange>the manifestation of</transChange> the truth of God, to confirm the promises <transChange>made</transChange> to the fathers:

Romans 15:10 And again he saith, "Rejoice, ye Gentiles, with his people."
Romans 15:11 And again, "Praise the Lord, all ye nations, praise Him, all ye people."
Romans 15:12 And again Esaias saith, "There shall be a root of Jesse, and one that shall rise to rule over the Gentiles: in Him shall the Gentiles trust."
Romans 15:13 Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope through the power of the holy Spirit.
Romans 15:14 And I myself am indeed persuaded concerning you, my brethren, that ye are full of goodness, being filled with all knowledge, and able to admonish one another.
Romans 15:15 However, I have written to you, brethren, somewhat the more freely, in reminding you <transChange>of your duty;</transChange> because of the favor bestowed upon me by God,
Romans 15:16 that I should be the minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, administring the gospel of God, that the offering of the Gentiles might be acceptable, being sanctified by the holy Spirit.
Romans 15:17 I have therefore <transChange>matter of</transChange> glorying in Christ Jesus, as to the <transChange>things</transChange> of God.
Romans 15:18 For I shall not go about to speak of any <transChange>thing,</transChange> but what Christ hath wrought by me, (to <transChange>gain</transChange> the obedience of the Gentiles,) <transChange>both</transChange> in word and deed:
Romans 15:19 through the efficacy of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God; so that from Jerusalem, and round as far as to Illyricum, I have fully declared the gospel of Christ:
Romans 15:20 being studious however so to preach the gospel, not where Christ had been named, least I should build upon another <transChange>man's</transChange> foundation;
Romans 15:21 but as it is written, They, to whom nothing was said concerning Him, shall see, and they who have not heard, shall understand.
Romans 15:22 And thus I have been much hindered from coming to you:
Romans 15:23 but now having no more to detain me in these parts, and having <transChange>had</transChange> a great desire for many years to come to you, when I take my journey into Spain, I will come to you:
Romans 15:24 for I hope to see you as I pass by, and to be brought forward by you <transChange>on my way</transChange> thither, after I have first had some enjoyment of you.
Romans 15:25 But now I am going to Jerusalem to minister unto the saints.
Romans 15:26 For the Macedonians and Achaians have been pleased to make a contribution for the poor saints at Jerusalem.
Romans 15:27 It pleased them, <transChange>I say,</transChange> and they are <transChange>indeed</transChange> their debtors; for if the Gentiles have partook of their spiritual <transChange>things,</transChange> they ought also to be helpful to them in carnal <transChange>ones.</transChange>
Romans 15:28 Therefore when I have dispatched this, and sealed this fruit <transChange>of love</transChange> to them, I will come by you into Spain.
Romans 15:29 And I know that when I come unto you, I shall come in the fulness of the blessing of the gospel of Christ.
Romans 15:30 Now I beseech you, brethren, by our Lord Jesus Christ, and by the love of the Spirit, that ye earnestly strive together with me in prayers to God for me;
Romans 15:31 that I may be delivered from the unbelievers in Judea; and that this my service at Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints:
Romans 15:32 that I may come to you with joy, by the will of God, and may be refreshed with you.
Romans 15:33 Now the God of peace be with you all. Amen. <chapter eID="gen5297" osisID="Rom.15"/>

I Corinthians 1:6 (even as the testimony of Christ was confirmed among you;)
I Corinthians 1:7 so that ye are deficient in no gift, expecting the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ:

I Corinthians 1:10 Now I beseech you, brethren, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that ye would all say alike, and <transChange>that</transChange> there may be no schisms among you, but <transChange>that</transChange> ye be perfectly united in the same mind and in the same judgement.
I Corinthians 1:11 For I have been informed concerning you, my brethren, by some of Chloe's <transChange>family,</transChange> that there are contentions among you.

I Corinthians 1:15 <transChange>so</transChange> that no one can say I baptized in my own name.
I Corinthians 1:16 I also baptized indeed the family of Stephanas: <transChange>but</transChange> I know not whether I baptized any other.
I Corinthians 1:17 For Christ sent me not to baptize, but to preach the gospel: not in fine speech, least the cross of Christ should be made of no effect.
I Corinthians 1:18 For the doctrine of the cross is to them, that perish, foolishness: but to us, who are saved, it is the power of God.
I Corinthians 1:19 For it is written, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and will bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent."

I Corinthians 1:22 And whereas the Jews require a sign, and the Greeks look for wisdom, we preach Christ crucified;
I Corinthians 1:23 to the Jews indeed a stumbling-block, and to the Greeks foolishness; but to them that are called,
I Corinthians 1:24 both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God.
I Corinthians 1:25 Because the foolishness of God, <transChange>as they call it,</transChange> is wiser than men; and the weakness of God is stronger than men.

I Corinthians 2:1 And I, when I came among you, brethren, came not with excellency of language, or of <transChange>human</transChange> wisdom, declaring unto you the testimony of God:
I Corinthians 2:2 for I did not think <transChange>it meet</transChange> to know any thing among you, but Jesus Christ, and Him crucified.
I Corinthians 2:3 And I was with you in weakness, and in fear, and in much trembling.
I Corinthians 2:4 And my discourse, and my preaching <transChange>was</transChange> not with the persuasive words of human wisdom, but in the demonstration of the Spirit and of power;
I Corinthians 2:5 that your faith might not be in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God.
I Corinthians 2:6 Yet we speak <transChange>true</transChange> wisdom among the perfect: though not the wisdom of this world, nor of the rulers of this world, who come to nought.
I Corinthians 2:7 But we speak the wisdom of God in a mystery, <transChange>that</transChange> hidden <transChange>wisdom</transChange> which God ordained before the worlds for our glory:
I Corinthians 2:8 which none of the rulers of this age knew; for if they had known <transChange>it,</transChange> they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.

I Corinthians 5:1 It is commonly reported <transChange>that there is</transChange> lewdness among you, and such lewdness as is not named even amongst the heathens, that one should have his father's wife.

I Corinthians 6:1 Dare any of you, having a matter <transChange>of complaint</transChange> against another, try <transChange>it</transChange> before the unjust, and not before the saints?

I Corinthians 6:3 Know ye not that we shall judge angels? what! and not <transChange>worthy of judging</transChange> the affairs of <transChange>this</transChange> life?
I Corinthians 6:4 Therefore if ye have controversies about the things of <transChange>this</transChange> life, do ye set them to judge, who are despised by the church?

I Corinthians 12:8 For to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge by the same Spirit;
I Corinthians 12:9 to another faith by the same Spirit; to another the gifts of healing by the same Spirit;
I Corinthians 12:10 to another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another the discerning of spirits; to another <transChange>various</transChange> kinds of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues:
I Corinthians 12:11 but all these worketh that one and the same Spirit distributing to every <transChange>one</transChange> in particular as He sees fit.
I Corinthians 12:12 For as the body is one, and hath many members; but all the parts of this one body, though many, are <transChange>but</transChange> one body:
I Corinthians 12:13 so also is <transChange>the mystical body of</transChange> Christ; for by one Spirit we are all baptized into one body, (whether Jews or Greeks, slaves or free) and are all made to drink into one Spirit:
I Corinthians 12:14 for the body is not one member, but many.
I Corinthians 12:15 If the foot should say, "Because I am not the hand, I am not of the body," is it therefore not of the body?
I Corinthians 12:16 And if the ear should say, "Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body," is it therefore not of the body?
I Corinthians 12:17 If the whole body <transChange>were an</transChange> eye, where <transChange>were</transChange> the hearing? <transChange>and</transChange> if the whole <transChange>were</transChange> hearing, where <transChange>were</transChange> the smelling?
I Corinthians 12:18 But now God hath placed the members, every one of them in the body, as He pleased.
I Corinthians 12:19 And if they were all one member, where <transChange>were</transChange> the body?
I Corinthians 12:20 whereas now <transChange>there are</transChange> many members, yet <transChange>but</transChange> one body.
I Corinthians 12:21 And the eye cannot say to the hand, I have no need of thee: or again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.
I Corinthians 12:22 But <transChange>those</transChange> parts of the body, which seem to be weaker, are much more necessary:
I Corinthians 12:23 and <transChange>those</transChange> which we judge the less honorable <transChange>parts</transChange> we clothe with more abundant honor; and <transChange>so</transChange> our less comely <transChange>parts</transChange> have more comeliness <transChange>added to them,</transChange> of which our comely <transChange>ones</transChange> have no need.
I Corinthians 12:24 But God hath <transChange>so</transChange> blended <transChange>the several parts of</transChange> the body, giving greater honor to that which was deficient,
I Corinthians 12:25 that there might be no schism in the body; but that <transChange>all</transChange> the members might have the same care one for another.
I Corinthians 12:26 And so if one member suffer all the members suffer with <transChange>it;</transChange> and if one member be honoured, all the members rejoice with <transChange>it.</transChange>
I Corinthians 12:27 Now ye are the body of Christ, and <transChange>his</transChange> members <transChange>each of you</transChange> in particular.
I Corinthians 12:28 And God hath placed <transChange>you</transChange> accordingly in the church, first apostles, secondly prophets, thirdly teachers, after that <transChange>miraculous</transChange> powers, then gifts of healing, helps, governments, <transChange>and various</transChange> kinds of tongues.

I Corinthians 13:1 <transChange>For</transChange> if I speak with the tongues of men and angels, and have not charity, I am but as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal.
I Corinthians 13:2 And though I have <transChange>the gift of</transChange> prophecy, and am acquainted with all mysteries, and all knowledge: yea if I have faith, <transChange>even.</transChange> to remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing.
I Corinthians 13:3 And though I give all my substance to feed the poor, and my body to be burnt, and have not charity, I am nothing profited.
I Corinthians 13:4 Charity beareth long, <transChange>and</transChange> is kind; charity envieth not; charity is not insolent, is not puffed up,
I Corinthians 13:5 doth not behave indecently, is not selfish, is not easily provoked,
I Corinthians 13:6 suspecteth no evil, rejoiceth not at injustice, but rejoiceth in the truth:

I Corinthians 14:0 <chapter osisID="1Cor.14" sID="gen5688"/>
I Corinthians 14:1 Labour after charity, and be desirous of spiritual <transChange>gifts:</transChange> but especially that ye may prophesy.
I Corinthians 14:2 For he, that speaketh in an <transChange>unknown</transChange> tongue, speaketh not to men, but to God: for no one understandeth, though in spirit he speaketh mysteries.
I Corinthians 14:3 But he, that prophesieth, speaketh edification, and exhortation, and comfort to men.
I Corinthians 14:4 He, that speaketh in an <transChange>unknown</transChange> tongue, edifieth himself: but he, that prophesieth, edifieth the church.
I Corinthians 14:5 I <transChange>could</transChange> wish that ye all spake with tongues, but rather that ye prophesied: for greater <transChange>is</transChange> he that prophesieth than he that speaketh with tongues, except he interpret, that the church may receive edification.
I Corinthians 14:6 Now, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, if I come to you speaking with <transChange>many</transChange> tongues, what shall I profit you, unless I speak <transChange>intelligibly</transChange> to you of revelation, or knowledge, or prophecy, or doctrine?
I Corinthians 14:7 As inanimate <transChange>things</transChange> which give a found, whether pipe or harp, unless they give a distinction in the sounds, how shall what is piped or harped be understood?
I Corinthians 14:8 For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who will prepare himself for the battle?
I Corinthians 14:9 So also unless ye utter by the tongue intelligible words, how shall what is spoken be understood? for <transChange>thus</transChange> ye will be <transChange>only</transChange> talking to the wind.
I Corinthians 14:10 There are, it may be, as many kinds of voices in the world <transChange>as people,</transChange> and none of them insignificant.
I Corinthians 14:11 But if I know not the force of the words, I shall be to him that speaketh a barbarian, and he that speaketh <transChange>will be</transChange> a barbarian to me.
I Corinthians 14:12 So ye also, since ye are <transChange>so</transChange> desirous of spiritual gifts, seek to abound <transChange>in them</transChange> to the edification of the church.
I Corinthians 14:13 Wherefore let him, that speaketh in an <transChange>unknown</transChange> tongue, pray that he may interpret.
I Corinthians 14:14 For if I pray in an <transChange>unknown</transChange> tongue, my spirit <transChange>indeed</transChange> prayeth, but my meaning is fruitless.
I Corinthians 14:15 What is then <transChange>to be done?</transChange> I will pray with the Spirit, but I will pray to be understood: I will sing with the spirit, but I will sing to be understood.
I Corinthians 14:16 For if thou bless in the spirit, how shall the unlearned say Amen to thy thanksgiving, when he knoweth not what thou sayst?
I Corinthians 14:17 thou indeed givest thanks well, but the other is not edified.
I Corinthians 14:18 I thank God, I speak with tongues more than you all.
I Corinthians 14:19 But in a <transChange>public</transChange> assembly I had rather speak five words to be understood, that I may instruct others also, than ten thousand words in an <transChange>unknown</transChange> tongue.

I Corinthians 14:22 So that tongues are for a sign, not to believers but to unbelievers: but prophecy not to unbelievers but to those that believe.
I Corinthians 14:23 If then the whole church be come together and all speak in <transChange>unknown</transChange> tongues, and there come in illiterate <transChange>persons,</transChange> or infidels, will they not say that ye are mad?
I Corinthians 14:24 But if all prophesy, and there come in an unbeliever, or <transChange>one</transChange> unlearned, he is convinced by all, he is judged by all.
I Corinthians 14:25 And thus the secrets of his heart are made manifest; so that falling down upon <transChange>his</transChange> face he will worship God, declaring that God is indeed among you.

I Corinthians 15:13 for if there be no resurrection of the dead, then Christ is not risen.
I Corinthians 15:14 And if Christ be not risen, then <transChange>is</transChange> our preaching vain, and your faith is also vain.

I Corinthians 16:6 And perhaps I shall stay <transChange>a while,</transChange> or even pass the winter with you; that ye may forward me on my journey, whithersoever I go.

II Corinthians 1:0 <chapter osisID="2Cor.1" sID="gen5814"/>
II Corinthians 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Timothy <transChange>our</transChange> brother, to the church of God which is at Corinth, and all the saints that are in Achaia:
II Corinthians 1:2 grace <transChange>be</transChange> to you, and peace from God our Father, and <transChange>from</transChange> the Lord Jesus Christ.
II Corinthians 1:3 Blessed <transChange>be</transChange> the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies, and God of all consolation; who comforteth us in all our affliction,
II Corinthians 1:4 that we may be able to comfort those, <transChange>that are</transChange> in any trouble, by the consolation wherewith we ourselves are comforted by God.
II Corinthians 1:5 For as the sufferings <transChange>for the sake</transChange> of Christ abound on us, so our consolation by Christ doth also abound.
II Corinthians 1:6 And whether we be afflicted, <transChange>it is</transChange> for your consolation and salvation, which is wrought out by the patient enduring of the same sufferings which we also suffer: or if we be comforted, <transChange>it is</transChange> for your consolation and salvation.
II Corinthians 1:7 And our hope <transChange>is</transChange> firm concerning you, knowing that as ye are partakers of the sufferings, so also of the consolation.
II Corinthians 1:8 For we would not have you ignorant, brethren, concerning our affliction which befel us in Asia, that we were exceedingly pressed above <transChange>our</transChange> strength, so that we despaired even of life:
II Corinthians 1:9 but we had the sentence of death within ourselves, that we might not trust in ourselves, but in God who raiseth the dead:
II Corinthians 1:10 who delivered us from so great a death, and doth deliver, in whom we trust that He will yet deliver <transChange>us:</transChange>
II Corinthians 1:11 you also assisting by prayer for us, that the favor <transChange>obtained</transChange> for us by <transChange>the prayers of</transChange> many might be thankfully acknowledged by many on our account.
II Corinthians 1:12 For this is our rejoicing, the testimony of our conscience, that in simplicity and pious sincerity, not with carnal wisdom, but by the grace of God, we have had our conversation in the world, and especially towards you.
II Corinthians 1:13 For we write no other <transChange>things</transChange> to you, but what ye own and acknowledge, and I hope ye will always acknowledge.
II Corinthians 1:14 As ye have acknowledged us in part, that we are your boasting, as ye also <transChange>are</transChange> ours, in the day of the Lord Jesus.
II Corinthians 1:15 And in this confidence I had a mind to come to you first, (that ye might have a second benefit,) and to pass by you into Macedonia;
II Corinthians 1:16 and <transChange>then</transChange> to come to you again from Macedonia, and by you to be forwarded <transChange>on my way</transChange> to Judea.
II Corinthians 1:17 Now when I intended this, was I chargeable with levity? or what I purpose, do I purpose from carnal motives, that with me there should be yea, yea, and <transChange>then</transChange> no, no?
II Corinthians 1:18 But the faithful God, <transChange>He knows,</transChange> that our word to you was not yes and no.

II Corinthians 10:0 <chapter osisID="2Cor.10" sID="gen5994"/>
II Corinthians 10:1 Now I Paul myself exhort you, by the meekness and lenity of Christ, who in presence am lowly among you,
II Corinthians 10:2 but being absent am bold towards you, yea I intreat you, that I may not be bold, when I am present, with <transChange>that</transChange> confidence, wherewith I think to proceed against some, who censure us as walking after the flesh.
II Corinthians 10:3 For though we are in the flesh, we do not carry on our war according to the flesh:
II Corinthians 10:4 (for the weapons of our warfare <transChange>are</transChange> not carnal, but mighty through God to the demolishing of bulwarks:)

II Corinthians 10:6 And being prepared to avenge all disobedience, since your obedience is fulfilled.

II Corinthians 10:10 for <transChange>his</transChange> letters, say they, <transChange>are</transChange> weighty and powerful, but <transChange>his</transChange> bodily presence <transChange>is</transChange> weak, and <transChange>his</transChange> speech contemptible.
II Corinthians 10:11 <transChange>But</transChange> let such a one know this, that as we are in word by letters, when absent, such also <transChange>shall we be</transChange> in fact when present.
II Corinthians 10:12 For we presume not to number, or compare ourselves with some who recommend themselves: but they measuring themselves by themselves, and comparing themselves with themselves, are void of understanding.
II Corinthians 10:13 But we will not glory of things beyond <transChange>our</transChange> bounds, but according to the measure of the rule which God hath given to us, a measure to come even unto you.
II Corinthians 10:14 For we do not stretch ourselves beyond <transChange>measure,</transChange> as though we were not <transChange>commissioned</transChange> to come unto you; for we have reached even to you also in <transChange>preaching</transChange> the gospel of Christ.

II Corinthians 11:1 I wish ye would bear with me a little in <transChange>my</transChange> folly; and indeed bear with me.
II Corinthians 11:2 For I am jealous over you with a godly jealousy, having espoused you to one husband, that I may present <transChange>you as</transChange> a chaste virgin to Christ.
II Corinthians 11:3 But I fear least as the serpent seduced Eve by his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted from the purity that is in Christ.
II Corinthians 11:4 For if he, that cometh <transChange>to you,</transChange> preacheth another Jesus, whom we have not preached; or <transChange>if</transChange> ye receive another Spirit which ye have not received, or another gospel which ye have not embraced, ye might indeed bear with <transChange>him.</transChange>

II Corinthians 12:0 <chapter osisID="2Cor.12" sID="gen6047"/>
II Corinthians 12:1 To boast indeed does not become me: but I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.
II Corinthians 12:2 I knew a man in Christ above fourteen years ago (whether in the body, or out of the body, I know not, God knoweth) such a one caught up to the third heaven.
II Corinthians 12:3 And I know such a man (whether <transChange>then</transChange> in the body, or out of the body,
II Corinthians 12:4 I know not, God knoweth) that he was caught up into paradise, and heard unutterable words, which it is not permitted unto man to speak.
II Corinthians 12:5 Of such a one I will boast; but of myself I will not boast, unless in my infirmities.
II Corinthians 12:6 For though I should incline to boast, I shall not be a fool; for I should speak truth. But I forbear least any <transChange>one</transChange> should think of me above what he seeth me <transChange>to be,</transChange> or heareth from me.
II Corinthians 12:7 And least I should be too much lifted up with the abundance of the revelations, there was given me a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to buffet me, least I should be too much elevated.
II Corinthians 12:8 For this I besought the Lord thrice, that it might depart from me.

II Corinthians 13:3 since ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me, who is not weak toward you, but is powerful among you.

Galatians 1:0 <chapter osisID="Gal.1" sID="gen6085"/>
Galatians 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> an apostle (not from men, nor by man, but by Jesus Christ, and God the Father, who raised Him from the dead),
Galatians 1:2 and all the brethren <transChange>that are</transChange> with me, to the churches of Galatia:
Galatians 1:3 grace <transChange>be</transChange> to you and peace from God the Father, and <transChange>from</transChange> our Lord Jesus Christ,
Galatians 1:4 who gave himself for our sins, that He might deliver us from the present evil world, according to the will of our God and Father:
Galatians 1:5 to whom <transChange>be</transChange> glory for ever and ever. Amen.
Galatians 1:6 I wonder that ye are so soon removed from him who called you by the grace of Christ to another gospel: which is not another;
Galatians 1:7 but there be some that disturb you, and would subvert the gospel of Christ.
Galatians 1:8 But tho' we or an angel from heaven should preach to you <transChange>any</transChange> other <transChange>gospel</transChange> than what we have preached to you; let him be accursed.
Galatians 1:9 I say <transChange>it</transChange> again, if any <transChange>one</transChange> preach to you <transChange>any</transChange> other <transChange>gospel</transChange> than what ye have received, let him be accursed.
Galatians 1:10 For do I now persuade <transChange>you to obey</transChange> men or God? Or do I seek to please men? if I yet pleased men, I should not be the servant of Christ.
Galatians 1:11 But I assure you, brethren, that the gospel preached by me is not <transChange>of</transChange> human <transChange>invention.</transChange>
Galatians 1:12 For I neither received it, nor was taught it by man, but by the revelation of Jesus Christ.
Galatians 1:13 For ye have heard of my conversation formerly in Judaism, that I outragiously persecuted the church of God, and laid it waste:
Galatians 1:14 and I made a proficiency in Judaism above many of the same age <transChange>with me</transChange> in my own nation, being excessively zealous for the traditions of my fathers.
Galatians 1:15 But when it pleased God, (who separated me from my mother's womb, and called <transChange>me</transChange> by his grace,)
Galatians 1:16 to reveal his Son in me, that I might preach Him among the gentiles; immediately I conferred not with flesh and blood,
Galatians 1:17 nor went I up to Jerusalem to those that were apostles before me, but I departed into Arabia, and <transChange>afterwards</transChange> returned again to Damascus.
Galatians 1:18 Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to visit Peter, and I staid with him fifteen days.
Galatians 1:19 But I saw no other of the apostles, except James the brother of <transChange>our</transChange> Lord.
Galatians 1:20 (Now <transChange>in</transChange> what I write to you, behold, before God, I do not lie.)
Galatians 1:21 Afterwards I came into the regions of Syria and Cilicia,
Galatians 1:22 and was not known in person to the churches of Judea, <transChange>which were</transChange> in Christ.
Galatians 1:23 But only they had heard that he who persecuted us before, now preacheth the faith which he formerly <transChange>would have</transChange> destroyed.
Galatians 1:24 And they glorified God on my account. <chapter eID="gen6085" osisID="Gal.1"/>
Galatians 2:0 <chapter osisID="Gal.2" sID="gen6110"/>
Galatians 2:1 Fourteen years after, I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, and took Titus also with <transChange>me.</transChange>
Galatians 2:2 But I went up according to <transChange>a divine</transChange> revelation, and laid before them the gospel which I preach among the gentiles: though privately to those of note, least I should run, or had run in vain.
Galatians 2:3 But even Titus, who was with me, being a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised;
Galatians 2:4 and <transChange>that</transChange> because of the false brethren clandestinely introduced, who had crept in as spies upon our liberty, which we have in Christ Jesus, that they might bring us into bondage:
Galatians 2:5 to whom we yielded no submission, <transChange>not</transChange> even for an hour; that the truth of the gospel might continue with you.
Galatians 2:6 And as to those who seemed to be <transChange>men</transChange> of note, whatever they were, it is all one to me, (God accepteth no man's person) for <transChange>even</transChange> these eminent <transChange>persons</transChange> added nothing more to me.
Galatians 2:7 But on the contrary, seeing that I was intrusted with the gospel of uncircumcision, as Peter <transChange>was with that</transChange> of the circumcision;
Galatians 2:8 (for He who wrought effectually in Peter as to the apostleship of the circumcision, wrought effectually also in me as to the gentiles:)
Galatians 2:9 and knowing the grace <transChange>which was</transChange> given to me; James, and Cephas, and John, who seemed to be pillars <transChange>of the church,</transChange> gave to me and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship; that we <transChange>should go</transChange> to the gentiles, and they to the circumcision.
Galatians 2:10 Only <transChange>desiring</transChange> that we would remember the poor: which I also was forward to do.
Galatians 2:11 But when Peter came to Antioch, I withstood him to the face, because he was <transChange>indeed</transChange> to be blamed.
Galatians 2:12 For before certain <transChange>men</transChange> came from James, he did eat with the gentiles; but when they were come, he withdrew and separated himself, fearing those of the circumcision.
Galatians 2:13 And the rest of the Jews dissembled also with him; so that Barnabas too was carried away with their dissimulation.
Galatians 2:14 But when I saw that they walked not uprightly according to the truth of the gospel, I said to Peter before <transChange>them</transChange> all,---If thou, who art a Jew, livest <transChange>sometimes</transChange> after the manner of the gentiles, and not like the Jews, why dost thou <transChange>now in a manner</transChange> compel the gentiles to judaize?
Galatians 2:15 We, <transChange>who are</transChange> Jews by birth, and not sinners of the gentiles,
Galatians 2:16 knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by faith in Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Christ Jesus, that we might be justified by faith in Christ, and not by <transChange>the</transChange> works of <transChange>the</transChange> law: for by <transChange>the</transChange> works of <transChange>the</transChange> law shall no flesh be justified.
Galatians 2:17 But if while we seek to be justified by Christ, we ourselves also are found sinners, <transChange>is</transChange> Christ therefore the minister of sin?
Galatians 2:18 God forbid. And if I build again the same <transChange>things</transChange> which I demolished, I shew myself a transgressor: for I through the law am dead to the law,
Galatians 2:19 that I might live unto God.
Galatians 2:20 I am crucified with Christ; yet I live, <transChange>though</transChange> no longer I, but Christ liveth in me: and <transChange>the life</transChange> which I now live in the flesh, I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me, and gave up himself for me.
Galatians 2:21 I do not frustate the grace of God: for if righteousness <transChange>be</transChange> by the law, then Christ died in vain. <chapter eID="gen6110" osisID="Gal.2"/>
Galatians 3:0 <chapter osisID="Gal.3" sID="gen6132"/>
Galatians 3:1 O senseless Galatians, who hath <transChange>so</transChange> bewitched you, that <transChange>ye</transChange> should not obey the truth? <transChange>you,</transChange> before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth <transChange>as</transChange> crucified.
Galatians 3:2 This only would I learn of you, Did ye receive the Spirit by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith?
Galatians 3:3 Are ye so void of understanding? having begun in the Spirit, are ye now made perfect by the flesh?
Galatians 3:4 have ye suffered so many <transChange>things</transChange> in vain? if indeed in vain.
Galatians 3:5 He therefore that imparteth to you the Spirit, and worketh miracles among you, <transChange>doth he it</transChange> by the works of the law, or by the doctrine of faith?
Galatians 3:6 As Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness:
Galatians 3:7 so ye know that they who believe, are the children of Abraham.
Galatians 3:8 And the scripture foreseeing that God would justify the gentiles through faith, preached the gospel to Abraham long ago, <transChange>saying,</transChange> "In thee shall all nations be blessed."
Galatians 3:9 So then they that believe, are blessed with believing Abraham.
Galatians 3:10 For as many as are of the works of the law, are under the curse; for it is written, Cursed <transChange>be</transChange> every one that continueth not in all <transChange>things which are</transChange> written in the book of the law, to do them.
Galatians 3:11 And that by the law no one is justified before God <transChange>is</transChange> evident; for <transChange>it is</transChange> <transChange>written</transChange> "The just shall live by faith:"
Galatians 3:12 now the law is not of faith, but <transChange>saith,</transChange> "The man that doth them, shall live in them."
Galatians 3:13 Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, having been made a curse for us: for it is written, "Cursed <transChange>is</transChange> every one that hangeth on a tree:"
Galatians 3:14 that the blessing of Abraham might come on the gentiles by Christ Jesus; that we through faith might receive the promise of the Spirit.
Galatians 3:15 Brethren, (I speak after the manner of men,) no one cancelleth or addeth to a covenant <transChange>which hath been</transChange> ratified, though <transChange>it be but the covenant</transChange> of a man.
Galatians 3:16 Now the promises were made to Abraham, and to his seed. He doth not say, "and to seeds," as of many; but as of one, "and to thy seed," which is Christ.
Galatians 3:17 This then I say, <transChange>that</transChange> the law, which was <transChange>given</transChange> four hundred and thirty years after, cannot disannul the covenant, which was <transChange>so long</transChange> before confirmed by God unto Christ, to make void the promise.
Galatians 3:18 For if the inheritance be from the law, <transChange>it is</transChange> no more from <transChange>the</transChange> promise: whereas God gave <transChange>it</transChange> to Abraham by promise.
Galatians 3:19 What then <transChange>availeth</transChange> the law? It was added because of transgressions, till the seed should come, to whom the promise was made; <transChange>and it was</transChange> delivered by angels in the hand of a mediator.
Galatians 3:20 Now a mediator is not <transChange>the mediator</transChange> of one <transChange>only;</transChange> and God is <transChange>but</transChange> one.
Galatians 3:21 <transChange>Is</transChange> the law then contrary to the promises of God? not at all: for if a law had been given, which could have confered life, certainly righteousness would have been by the law.
Galatians 3:22 But the scripture hath shut up all under sin, that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to them that believe.
Galatians 3:23 But before faith came, we were kept shut up under the law, till the faith <transChange>appeared</transChange> which was to be revealed.
Galatians 3:24 So that the law was our guide <transChange>to lead us</transChange> to Christ, that we might be justified by faith.
Galatians 3:25 But now faith is come we are no longer under a pedagogue.
Galatians 3:26 For ye are all the children of God by faith in Christ Jesus.
Galatians 3:27 For as many of you as have been baptized into Christ, have put on Christ:
Galatians 3:28 <transChange>and</transChange> there is neither Jew nor Greek, those is neither bond nor free, there is neither male nor female; for ye are all one in Christ Jesus.
Galatians 3:29 And if ye <transChange>be</transChange> Christ's, then are ye Abraham's seed, and heirs according to the promise. <chapter eID="gen6132" osisID="Gal.3"/>
Galatians 4:0 <chapter osisID="Gal.4" sID="gen6162"/>
Galatians 4:1 Now as long as the heir is a child, he differeth nothing from a servant, though he <transChange>is to</transChange> be lord of all:
Galatians 4:2 but is under guardians and managers till the time appointed by the father.
Galatians 4:3 So we when we were children, were in servitude under the elements of the world:
Galatians 4:4 but when the fulness of the time came, God sent forth his Son born of a woman made under the law,
Galatians 4:5 that He might redeem those <transChange>that were</transChange> under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons.
Galatians 4:6 And because ye are sons, God hath sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father.
Galatians 4:7 So that thou art no longer a servant, but a son; and if a son, an heir also of God through Christ.
Galatians 4:8 But then indeed, when ye knew not God, ye served those which in reality are no gods.
Galatians 4:9 But now that ye know God, or rather are known by God, how <transChange>is it that</transChange> ye turn again to the poor weak elements, to which ye desire again to be in bondage as before?
Galatians 4:10 Ye observe days, and months, and times, and years:
Galatians 4:11 <transChange>so that</transChange> I am afraid for you, least I have indeed bestowed upon you labour in vain.
Galatians 4:12 Brethren, I beseech you, be as I <transChange>am;</transChange> for I also <transChange>was</transChange> as ye <transChange>are: and</transChange> ye have not injured me at all.
Galatians 4:13 But ye know that in the infirmity of the flesh I preached the gospel to you at first:
Galatians 4:14 and my temptation which was in my flesh ye despised not, nor rejected <transChange>me for it;</transChange> but received me as an angel of God, <transChange>even</transChange> as Christ Jesus.
Galatians 4:15 What then was your blessedness? for I bear you witness that, if <transChange>it had been</transChange> possible, ye would have plucked out your own eyes, and have given them to me.

Galatians 5:0 <chapter osisID="Gal.5" sID="gen6194"/>
Galatians 5:1 Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and be not entangled again in the yoke of bondage.
Galatians 5:2 Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ will profit you nothing.
Galatians 5:3 And I testify again to every man that is circumcised, that he is a debtor to the whole law.
Galatians 5:4 Christ is become nothing to you, whosoever <transChange>of you</transChange> are <transChange>seeking to be</transChange> justified by the law: ye are fallen from the grace <transChange>of the gospel.</transChange>
Galatians 5:5 For we through the Spirit wait for the hope of righteousness by faith.
Galatians 5:6 For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but faith which worketh by love.
Galatians 5:7 Ye did run well: who hindered you from obeying the truth?
Galatians 5:8 This persuasion <transChange>came</transChange> not from him that called you: <transChange>but</transChange> a little leaven leaveneth the whole mass.
Galatians 5:9 I have confidence in you <transChange>however</transChange> through the Lord,

Galatians 5:11 And I, brethren, if I still preach circumcision, why am I still persecuted <transChange>by the Jews? for</transChange> then the offence of the cross is ceased.
Galatians 5:12 I wish they were even cut off <transChange>from your communion,</transChange> that make <transChange>such</transChange> disturbance amongst you.
Galatians 5:13 For, brethren, ye have been called unto liberty; only <transChange>abuse</transChange> not this liberty for an occasion to <transChange>indulge</transChange> the flesh, but by <transChange>mutual</transChange> love serve one another.
Galatians 5:14 For all the law is fulfilled in one precept, <transChange>even</transChange> in this, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.
Galatians 5:15 But if ye bite and devour one another, take heed that ye be not destroyed by one another.
Galatians 5:16 I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye will not fulfil the desire of the flesh:

Galatians 5:18 But if ye be led by the Spirit, ye are not under the law.

Galatians 5:20 lasciviousness, idolatry, witchcraft, enmities, strifes, emulations, animosities, contentions, divisions,

Galatians 5:23 gentleness, goodness, fidelity, meekness, temperance: against such <transChange>things</transChange> there is no law.

Galatians 6:0 <chapter osisID="Gal.6" sID="gen6221"/>
Galatians 6:1 Brethren, if a man be overtaken in any fault, do ye, who are spiritual, restore such a one in the spirit of meekness; considering thyself, least thou also shouldst be tempted.
Galatians 6:2 Bear one another's burdens, and so fulfil the law of Christ.
Galatians 6:3 For if any one thinketh <transChange>that</transChange> he is something, when he is nothing, he deceiveth himself.
Galatians 6:4 But let every one try his own work, and then he will have <transChange>matter of</transChange> glorying in himself alone, and not in another.
Galatians 6:5 For every one shall bear his own burthen.
Galatians 6:6 And let him, that is instructed in the word, communicate in all good things to him that instructeth.
Galatians 6:7 Be not deceived, God is not <transChange>to be</transChange> mocked: for whatever a man soweth, that shall he also reap.
Galatians 6:8 He then, who soweth to his flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he, that soweth to the Spirit, shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting.
Galatians 6:9 And let us not be weary <transChange>in</transChange> doing good: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not.
Galatians 6:10 And therefore as we have opportunity, let us do good to all <transChange>men,</transChange> but especially to those who are of the houshold of faith.
Galatians 6:11 Ye see in how large letters I have written to you with my own hand.
Galatians 6:12 They, who want to make a fair appearance in the flesh, <transChange>would</transChange> constrain you to be circumcised; only that they may not be persecuted for the cross of Christ.
Galatians 6:13 For they, who are circumcised, do not themselves keep the law: but they would have you circumcised, that they may glory in your flesh.
Galatians 6:14 But God forbid that I should glory, unless in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world is crucified to me, and I to the world.
Galatians 6:15 For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but being created anew.

Ephesians 4:1 I therefore, a prisoner for <transChange>the sake of</transChange> the Lord, exhort you to walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called, with all humility and meekness;
Ephesians 4:2 <transChange>and</transChange> with long-suffering forbear one another in love,
Ephesians 4:3 endeavouring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace: <transChange>for there is but</transChange> one body and one Spirit,
Ephesians 4:4 even as ye are called in one hope of your calling;
Ephesians 4:5 one Lord, one faith, one baptism,
Ephesians 4:6 one God and Father of all, who <transChange>is</transChange> above all, and through all, and in all.
Ephesians 4:7 But grace is given to each of us, according to the measure of the gift of Christ.
Ephesians 4:8 Wherefore it is said, "When he ascended on high, He led captivity captive, and gave gifts to men."
Ephesians 4:9 Now this <transChange>expression</transChange> "He ascended" what does it mean, but that He descended first into the lower parts of the earth?

Ephesians 4:16 from whom the whole body being fitly joined together and compacted by the aid of every joint, according to the operation proportioned to every part, maketh an increase to the edification of itself in love.

Ephesians 5:1 Be ye therefore imitators of God as <transChange>his</transChange> dear children; and walk in love,
Ephesians 5:2 even as Christ hath loved us, and given Himself up for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for an odor of sweet perfume.
Ephesians 5:3 But fornication, and all uncleanness, or inordinate desire, let it not be even named among you; for so it becometh saints:
Ephesians 5:4 nor ribaldry, nor buffoonery, nor <transChange>wanton</transChange> jesting, which are not meet: but rather giving of thanks.

Ephesians 5:6 Let no one deceive you with vain words: for because of these <transChange>things</transChange> cometh the wrath of God upon the children of disobedience.
Ephesians 5:7 Therefore be not partners with them.
Ephesians 5:8 For ye were heretofore darkness, but now <transChange>ye are</transChange> light in the Lord:
Ephesians 5:9 walk <transChange>therefore</transChange> as children of light, (for the fruit of the Spirit <transChange>is</transChange> in all goodness and righteousness and truth,)
Ephesians 5:10 approving what is well-pleasing to the Lord.
Ephesians 5:11 And have no communion with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather reprove them.
Ephesians 5:12 For it is a shame even to relate the things <transChange>that are</transChange> done by them in secret.

Ephesians 5:14 Wherefore He saith, Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light.

Ephesians 5:17 Wherefore be not thoughtless, but consider what <transChange>is</transChange> the will of the Lord.

Ephesians 5:23 for the husband is the head of the wife, even as Christ is the head of the church: and the saviour of <transChange>that</transChange> body.
Ephesians 5:24 As the church then is subject to Christ, so also <transChange>should</transChange> wives <transChange>be</transChange> to their own husbands in every thing.

Ephesians 5:26 to sanctify and cleanse it with the washing of water by the word,
Ephesians 5:27 that He might prepare it for Himself a glorious church, not having spot or wrinkle, or any such thing: but that it should be holy and unblameable.
Ephesians 5:28 Men ought so to love their wives, as their own bodies: he that loveth his wife, loveth himself.
Ephesians 5:29 For no one ever hated his own flesh, but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as the Lord also <transChange>doth</transChange> the church:
Ephesians 5:30 for we are members of his body, <transChange>as if taken</transChange> out of his flesh, and of his bones, <transChange>as Eve was out of Adam's.</transChange>

Ephesians 6:0 <chapter osisID="Eph.6" sID="gen6377"/>
Ephesians 6:1 Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right.
Ephesians 6:2 Honour thy father and thy mother, (which is the first commandment with promise,)
Ephesians 6:3 that it may be well with thee, and thou shalt be long-lived upon the earth.
Ephesians 6:4 And ye fathers, do not exasperate your children: but educate them in the nurture and admonition of the Lord.
Ephesians 6:5 Servants, obey <transChange>them that are your</transChange> masters according to the flesh, with reverential fear, in the simplicity of your heart, as unto Christ:
Ephesians 6:6 not with eye-service as men-pleasers, but as servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart;
Ephesians 6:7 with good-will, <transChange>as</transChange> serving the Lord rather than men:
Ephesians 6:8 knowing that whatever good any one doth, he shall receive <transChange>the reward of</transChange> it from the Lord, whether He be a slave or free.
Ephesians 6:9 And <transChange>ye</transChange> masters, do the same to them, forbearing threatening: knowing that ye yourselves also have a Master in heaven, and there is no respect of persons with Him.
Ephesians 6:10 Moreover, my brethren, strengthen yourselves in the Lord, and in his mighty power.
Ephesians 6:11 Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the Devil.
Ephesians 6:12 For our conflict is not with flesh and blood <transChange>only,</transChange> but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the world <transChange>and</transChange> of the darkness of this age, against wicked spirits in heavenly <transChange>places.</transChange>
Ephesians 6:13 Take therefore the complete armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all to stand.
Ephesians 6:14 Stand therefore having your loins girt about with truth, and putting on the breast-plate of righteousness:
Ephesians 6:15 and having your feet shod with the preparation of the gospel of peace:

Ephesians 6:17 take also the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God:

Philippians 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> and Timothy, servants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus, which are at Philippi, with the bishops and deacons:
Philippians 1:2 grace <transChange>be</transChange> unto you, and peace from God our father, and <transChange>from</transChange> the Lord Jesus Christ.
Philippians 1:3 I give thanks unto my God upon every mention of you,
Philippians 1:4 (always making supplication for you all with joy
Philippians 1:5 in every prayer of mine) for your attachment to the gospel, from the first day even till now;
Philippians 1:6 being confident of this, that He who hath begun a good work in you will <transChange>continue to</transChange> perfect <transChange>it</transChange> till the day of Jesus Christ.
Philippians 1:7 As it is just for me to think this of you all, because ye have me in <transChange>your</transChange> heart, both in my bonds, and in the defence and confirmation of the gospel, being all of you partakers of the <transChange>same</transChange> grace with me.
Philippians 1:8 For God is my witness, how much I long for you all, <transChange>as</transChange> with the bowels of Jesus Christ.
Philippians 1:9 And this I pray, that your love may abound yet more and more in knowledge and <transChange>in</transChange> all discernment;
Philippians 1:10 that ye may try things that differ, that ye may be sincere and without offence until the day of Christ;
Philippians 1:11 being full of the fruits of righteousness <transChange>which are</transChange> through Jesus Christ unto the glory and praise of God.
Philippians 1:12 But I would have you know, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, that the things, which have befallen me, have proved rather to the advancement of the gospel:
Philippians 1:13 so that my bonds are manifest in all the palace, and all other <transChange>places, to be</transChange> for the sake of Christ;
Philippians 1:14 and many of the brethren in the Lord, encouraged by my bonds, are much more bold to publish the word without fear.
Philippians 1:15 Some indeed through envy and strife, and some also through good-will:
Philippians 1:16 the former preach Christ out of contention, not sincerely, thinking to add affliction to my bonds;
Philippians 1:17 the others out of love, knowing that I am set for the defence of the gospel.
Philippians 1:18 What then? yet every way, whether in pretence or in truth, Christ is preached: and in this I rejoice, yea and I will rejoice;
Philippians 1:19 for I know that this shall turn to my safety through your prayer, and the aid of the Spirit of Jesus Christ.
Philippians 1:20 According to my earnest expectation and hope, that I shall be put to shame in nothing; but <transChange>that</transChange> with all freedom of speech, as always, <transChange>so</transChange> now also Christ shall be magnified in my body, whether by life or by death.
Philippians 1:21 For to me to live <transChange>is</transChange> Christ, and to die <transChange>is</transChange> gain: and if I live in the flesh, this <transChange>is</transChange> the fruit of my labor:
Philippians 1:22 so that I know not what to chuse;
Philippians 1:23 for I am in a strait betwixt two, having a desire to depart, and to be with Christ, which <transChange>is</transChange> much preferable:
Philippians 1:24 but to abide in the flesh is more necessary for you.
Philippians 1:25 And as I am confident of this, I know that I shall abide and shall continue with you all, for your improvement and the joy of <transChange>your</transChange> faith:
Philippians 1:26 that your rejoicing in Christ Jesus may abound through me, by my coming to you again.
Philippians 1:27 Only behave worthy of the gospel of Christ, that whether I come and see you, or be absent, I may hear of you, that ye stand firm in one Spirit, striving together <transChange>as</transChange> with one soul for the saith of the gospel;
Philippians 1:28 and <transChange>are</transChange> in nothing terrified by your adversaries: which is a demonstration of ruin to them, but to you of salvation, and this from God.
Philippians 1:29 For to you it is granted as a favor from Christ, not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer for his sake:
Philippians 1:30 having the same conflict as ye saw in me, and now hear <transChange>to be</transChange> in me. <chapter eID="gen6403" osisID="Phil.1"/>
Philippians 2:0 <chapter osisID="Phil.2" sID="gen6434"/>
Philippians 2:1 If therefore there be any consolation in Christ, if any comfort of love, if any participation of the Spirit,
Philippians 2:2 if any bowels of compassion, compleat ye my joy, be like-minded, maintaining the same love, with your souls united, <transChange>in</transChange> attending to the one <transChange>thing needful.</transChange>
Philippians 2:3 <transChange>Do</transChange> nothing through strife or vain-glory, but in lowliness of mind each esteeming others better than themselves.
Philippians 2:4 Look not every one to his own <transChange>interests only,</transChange> but every one also to <transChange>the concerns</transChange> of others.
Philippians 2:5 Let the same mind be in you, which <transChange>was</transChange> also in Christ Jesus:
Philippians 2:6 who being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be as God.
Philippians 2:7 Yet He emptied himself, assuming the form of a servant, when made in the likeness of men:
Philippians 2:8 and being in the human state, He humbled himself, and was obedient even unto death, and <transChange>that</transChange> the death of the cross.
Philippians 2:9 Wherefore God hath highly exalted Him, and given Him a name above every name:
Philippians 2:10 that in the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of celestial <transChange>beings,</transChange> as well as of those on earth, and of those under the earth;
Philippians 2:11 and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ <transChange>is</transChange> Lord, to the glory of God the Father.
Philippians 2:12 Wherefore, my beloved, as ye have always obeyed <transChange>the gospel,</transChange> not only in my presence, but now much more in my absence; be <transChange>still</transChange> working out your own salvation <transChange>though</transChange> with fear and trembling:
Philippians 2:13 for it is God that worketh in you both to will, and to work, out of <transChange>his own</transChange> good-pleasure.
Philippians 2:14 Do all <transChange>things</transChange> without murmurings and disputings:
Philippians 2:15 that ye may be blameless and inoffensive, the children of God without reproof, in the midst of a crooked and perverse generation; among whom ye shine as lights in the world,
Philippians 2:16 exhibiting the word of life; to my rejoicing in the day of Christ, that I have not run in vain, nor laboured in vain.
Philippians 2:17 But if I be even poured forth as a libation on the sacrifice and service of your faith, I rejoice and congratulate with you all.
Philippians 2:18 And <transChange>for</transChange> the same <transChange>cause</transChange> do ye also rejoice, and congratulate with me.
Philippians 2:19 But I hope in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you shortly, that I also may be refreshed, <transChange>by</transChange> knowing <transChange>the state of</transChange> your affairs.
Philippians 2:20 For I have no one of a like spirit, who will with a <transChange>kind of</transChange> natural affection take care of your affairs.
Philippians 2:21 For all seek their own <transChange>interests,</transChange> not those of Christ Jesus.

Philippians 2:23 I hope therefore to send him as soon as I see <transChange>the issue of</transChange> my own affairs.
Philippians 2:24 But I trust in the Lord, that I shall soon come myself too.
Philippians 2:25 However, I thought it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus my brother, and fellow-laborer, and fellow-soldier, but your messenger, who ministred to my wants:
Philippians 2:26 for he much longed after you all, and was greatly concerned because ye had heard that he was sick.
Philippians 2:27 For indeed he was sick <transChange>and</transChange> nigh unto death: but God had mercy on him, and not on him only, but on me also, that I might not have sorrow upon sorrow.
Philippians 2:28 I have sent him therefore the more desirously, that when ye see him again ye may rejoice, and I may be the less sorrowful.
Philippians 2:29 Receive him therefore in the Lord with all joy, and have such in high esteem:

Colossians 1:4 (having heard of your faith in Christ Jesus, and <transChange>your</transChange> love to all the saints:)

Colossians 1:6 which is come unto you, even as in all the world, and is fruitful; as <transChange>it hath been</transChange> also among you, from the day in which ye heard and knew the grace of God in truth.

Colossians 2:1 For I would have you know what a great conflict I have for you, and for those in Laodicea, and as many as have not seen me in person:
Colossians 2:2 that their hearts may be comforted, being knit together in love, and to all the riches of a full assurance of understanding <transChange>in these things,</transChange> to the acknowledgment of the mystery of <transChange>our</transChange> God and Father, and of Christ:
Colossians 2:3 in whom are all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.
Colossians 2:4 And this I say, least any one should deceive you with fine speeches.
Colossians 2:5 For though I be absent in body, yet am I with you in spirit, rejoicing and beholding your regularity, and the stedfastness of your faith in Christ.
Colossians 2:6 Therefore as ye have received Christ Jesus the Lord, walk in Him;
Colossians 2:7 rooted and built up in Him, and established in the faith, as ye have been taught <transChange>it,</transChange> abounding therein with thanksgiving.
Colossians 2:8 Take heed least any one make a prey of you by philosophy and vain deceit, according to the tradition of men, after the elements of the world, and not after Christ:
Colossians 2:9 for all the fulness of the deity dwelleth personally in Him.
Colossians 2:10 And ye are complete in Him, who is the head of all principality and power.
Colossians 2:11 In whom also ye are circumcised with the circumcision not performed by hands, in putting off the body of the sins of the flesh, by the circumcision <transChange>which is</transChange> of Christ:
Colossians 2:12 being buried with Him in baptism, wherein also ye are raised together with <transChange>Him,</transChange> through faith in the power of God, who raised Him from the dead.
Colossians 2:13 And when ye were dead in trespasses, and <transChange>in</transChange> the uncircumcision of your flesh, He made you alive together with Him, having forgiven you all trespasses,
Colossians 2:14 and cancelled the obligation we were under by <transChange>ritual</transChange> decrees, which was grievous to us, and hath taken it quite away, <transChange>even</transChange> nailing it to <transChange>his</transChange> cross.
Colossians 2:15 And having spoiled principalities and powers, He made them an open spectacle, triumphing over them by it.
Colossians 2:16 Let no one therefore judge you on account of meat, or drink, or in respect of a feast, or a new-moon, or sabbaths;
Colossians 2:17 which are a shadow of <transChange>good</transChange> things to come, but the body <transChange>is</transChange> of Christ.
Colossians 2:18 Let no one deprive you of your reward by an affected humility and worshipping of angels, intruding into what he hath not seen, vainly puffed up by his carnal mind;
Colossians 2:19 and not adhering to the head, from which all the body, being supplied and held together <transChange>as</transChange> by joints and bands, increaseth with the increase of God.
Colossians 2:20 If therefore ye be dead with Christ from the elements of the world; why, as if living in the world, are ye subject to <transChange>ceremonial</transChange> ordinances,
Colossians 2:21 (<transChange>such as</transChange> "touch not, taste not,
Colossians 2:22 handle not," which all tend to corruption in the using,) according to the commandments and doctrines of men?

Colossians 3:1 If ye then be risen with Christ, seek the things <transChange>that are</transChange> above, where Christ sitteth at the right hand of God.
Colossians 3:2 Mind the things above, not those on the earth.
Colossians 3:3 For ye are dead <transChange>as to the world,</transChange> and your life is hid with Christ in God.
Colossians 3:4 When Christ, <transChange>who is</transChange> your life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with Him in glory.
Colossians 3:5 Mortify therefore your members <transChange>that are</transChange> upon the earth; fornication, uncleanness, <transChange>disorderly</transChange> passion, evil concupiscence, and insatiable desire, which is <transChange>indeed</transChange> idolatry:
Colossians 3:6 for which <transChange>things</transChange> the wrath of God cometh on the children of disobedience.
Colossians 3:7 In which ye also formerly walked, when ye lived among them.
Colossians 3:8 But now put away all <transChange>these</transChange> also, wrath, animosity, malice, calumny, <transChange>and</transChange> filthy discourse out of your mouth.

I Thessalonians 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> and Silvanus and Timothy to the church of the Thessalonians in God the Father, and <transChange>in</transChange> the Lord Jesus Christ. I Thessalonians 1:2 We give thanks to God always for you all, making mention of you in our prayers.
I Thessalonians 1:3 Incessantly remembering your work of faith, and labor of love, and patience of hope in our Lord Jesus Christ, before our God and Father:
I Thessalonians 1:4 knowing, beloved brethren, your election by God.
I Thessalonians 1:5 For our gospel came not to you in word only, but also in power, and in the holy Ghost, and in much certainty; as ye know what sort of persons we were among you for your sakes.
I Thessalonians 1:6 And ye became imitators of us and of the Lord, having received the word <transChange>tho'</transChange> in much affliction, <transChange>yet</transChange> with joy of the holy Ghost.

I Thessalonians 2:1 For ye yourselves, brethren, know our entrance among you, that it was not <transChange>in</transChange> vain.
I Thessalonians 2:2 But though we had suffered before and been injuriously treated, as ye know, at Philippi, we spake boldly in <transChange>the name of</transChange> our God to declare unto you the gospel of God with much conflict.
I Thessalonians 2:3 For our exhortation <transChange>was</transChange> not of deceit, nor of impurity, nor in guile:
I Thessalonians 2:4 but as we have been approved by God to be entrusted with the gospel, so we speak, not as pleasing men, but God, who trieth our hearts.
I Thessalonians 2:5 For neither at any time used we flattering speech, as ye know, nor covetous pretence, God <transChange>is</transChange> witness:
I Thessalonians 2:6 nor sought we glory of men, neither of you, nor of others: though we might have expected maintenance, as the apostles of Christ.
I Thessalonians 2:7 But we were gentle among you, even as a nurse cherisheth her children:
I Thessalonians 2:8 so we, being affectionately desirous of you, were willing to impart to you, not only the gospel of God, but even our own souls, because ye were dear unto us.
I Thessalonians 2:9 For ye remember, brethren, our labor and toil; for working night and day, that we might not be burthensome to any of you, we preached among you the gospel of God.

I Thessalonians 3:3 that no one might be shaken by these afflictions: for ye yourselves know that we are appointed hereunto.
I Thessalonians 3:4 For when we were with you, we told you before that we should be afflicted, as it came to pass, and ye know.
