II Thessalonians 2:2 we beseech you, brethren, that ye be not soon moved from your <transChange>steadiness of</transChange> mind, or troubled, neither by Spirit, nor by word, nor by letter, as from us, that the day of Christ is at hand.
II Thessalonians 2:3 Let not any <transChange>one</transChange> deceive you by any means; for <transChange>it shall not come</transChange> till there come an apostasy first, and the man of sin be revealed,
II Thessalonians 2:4 the son of perdition, who opposeth and exalteth himself above all that is called God, or the object of worship; so that he sits as God in the temple of God, shewing himself that he is God.
II Thessalonians 2:5 Do ye not remember, that when I was with you, I told you these things?
II Thessalonians 2:6 And ye know what now hindereth him from being revealed in his own time.
II Thessalonians 2:7 For the mystery of iniquity is already working, only there is one that hindreth till he be taken out of the way.
II Thessalonians 2:8 And then the wicked <transChange>one</transChange> shall be detected, whom the Lord will destroy by the breath of his mouth, and abolish by the brightness of his coming:
II Thessalonians 2:9 who comes, through the efficacy of Satan, with all <transChange>kind of</transChange> lying power, and signs,
II Thessalonians 2:10 and wonders, and with all iniquitous fraud, among those that <transChange>shall</transChange> perish; because they received not the love of the truth, by which they might be saved.
II Thessalonians 2:11 And for this <transChange>cause</transChange> God will send <transChange>upon</transChange> them the efficacy of error, so that they shall <transChange>themselves</transChange> believe the lie:
II Thessalonians 2:12 that they may all be condemned, who believed not the truth, but had pleasure in iniquity.
II Thessalonians 2:13 But we ought always to give thanks to God for you, brethren beloved of the Lord; because God hath from the beginning chosen you to salvation, through sanctification of the Spirit, and belief of the truth:
II Thessalonians 2:14 to which He hath called you by our gospel, to the obtaining of the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ.
II Thessalonians 2:15 Therefore, brethren, be steady, and hold fast the traditions, which ye have been taught, whether by word or by our letter.

II Thessalonians 3:7 For ye know how <transChange>ye</transChange> ought to imitate us: for we were not disorderly among you;

I Timothy 1:0 <chapter osisID="1Tim.1" sID="gen6758"/>
I Timothy 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> an apostle of Jesus Christ by the appointment of God our Saviour, and the Lord Jesus Christ our hope,
I Timothy 1:2 to Timothy <transChange>my</transChange> true son in the faith, <transChange>be</transChange> grace, mercy, <transChange>and</transChange> peace from God our Father, and Christ Jesus our Lord.
I Timothy 1:3 As I exhorted thee to stay at Ephesus, when I went into Macedonia, that thou mightest charge certain <transChange>persons</transChange> not to teach other doctrine,
I Timothy 1:4 nor attend to fables and endless genealogies, which occasion debates, rather than pious edification in the faith:
I Timothy 1:5 <transChange>so do,</transChange> and <transChange>acquaint them that</transChange> the end of <transChange>that</transChange> charge is charity, out of a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned:
I Timothy 1:6 from which some having swerved are turned aside to vain discourses;
I Timothy 1:7 desiring to be teachers of the law, though they neither understand what they say, nor what <transChange>things</transChange> they assert.
I Timothy 1:8 But we know that the law is good, if a man use it lawfully;
I Timothy 1:9 knowing this, that a law does not lie against a righteous <transChange>person,</transChange> but <transChange>against</transChange> the lawless and unruly, the impious and wicked, the unholy and profane,
I Timothy 1:10 parricides, murderers, whoremongers, sodomites, kidnappers, liars, false-swearers, and if there be any thing else contrary to <transChange>that</transChange> sound doctrine,
I Timothy 1:11 <transChange>which is</transChange> according to the glorious gospel of the blessed God, with which I was intrusted.
I Timothy 1:12 And I give thanks to Christ Jesus our Lord, who gave me ability <transChange>for the work,</transChange> that He accounted me faithful, having put <transChange>me</transChange> into the ministry,
I Timothy 1:13 who before was a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and an oppressor. But I obtained mercy, because I did <transChange>it</transChange> ignorantly in unbelief: and the grace of our Lord superabounded,
I Timothy 1:14 with faith and love in Christ Jesus.
I Timothy 1:15 <transChange>It</transChange> is a truth <transChange>highly</transChange> to be believed, and worthy to be received by all, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners:---of whom I am <transChange>one of the</transChange> chief.
I Timothy 1:16 But for this <transChange>end</transChange> I obtained mercy, that in me a chief <transChange>sinner</transChange> Jesus Christ might display <transChange>his</transChange> long-suffering, for an example to those who should afterwards believe on Him to eternal life.
I Timothy 1:17 Now to the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God, <transChange>be</transChange> honor and glory for ever and ever. Amen.
I Timothy 1:18 This charge I commit to thee, son Timothy, according to the prophecies which before came on thee, that by them thou mightest war a good warfare,
I Timothy 1:19 having faith and a good conscience, which some putting away have made shipwreck concerning the faith:
I Timothy 1:20 of whom is Hymeneus and Alexander, whom I have delivered unto Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme. <chapter eID="gen6758" osisID="1Tim.1"/>
I Timothy 2:0 <chapter osisID="1Tim.2" sID="gen6779"/>
I Timothy 2:1 <transChange>This</transChange> then I exhort <transChange>thee</transChange> first of all, that supplications, prayers, intercessions, <transChange>and</transChange> thanksgivings he made for all men;
I Timothy 2:2 <transChange>particularly</transChange> for kings, and all that are in authority, that we may lead a quiet and peaceful life in all piety and virtue.
I Timothy 2:3 For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour:
I Timothy 2:4 who is willing that all men should be saved, and <transChange>therefore</transChange> come to the knowledge of the truth.
I Timothy 2:5 For <transChange>there is</transChange> one God, and one Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus:
I Timothy 2:6 who gave himself a ransom for all, a testimony <transChange>to be published</transChange> in due time,
I Timothy 2:7 for which I was appointed a herald and an apostle. I speak the truth in Christ, I lie not; <transChange>I am</transChange> a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and truth.
I Timothy 2:8 I direct therefore that men pray in every place, lifting up holy hands without wrath and debate:
I Timothy 2:9 likewise that women dress themselves in decent apparel with modesty and prudence, not in braided hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly garments;
I Timothy 2:10 but in good works, as becometh women professing godliness.
I Timothy 2:11 Let the woman learn in silence with all submission: but I permit not a woman to teach,
I Timothy 2:12 nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be silent.
I Timothy 2:13 For Adam was formed first, then Eve.
I Timothy 2:14 And Adam was not seduced <transChange>by the serpent,</transChange> but the woman being led astray was <transChange>first</transChange> in the transgression.
I Timothy 2:15 Yet shall <transChange>she</transChange> be saved through childbirth, if they continue in faith and love, <transChange>in</transChange> holiness and modesty. <chapter eID="gen6779" osisID="1Tim.2"/>
I Timothy 3:0 <chapter osisID="1Tim.3" sID="gen6795"/>
I Timothy 3:1 <transChange>It is</transChange> certain, if any one is desirous of the episcopal office, he desireth a good work.
I Timothy 3:2 A bishop then must be blameless, the husband of <transChange>but</transChange> one wife, sober, prudent, grave,
I Timothy 3:3 hospitable, able to teach, not given to wine, no striker, not greedy of sordid gain, moderate, not quarrelsome,
I Timothy 3:4 not covetous, governing his own family well, having his children in subjection with all gravity;
I Timothy 3:5 (for if any <transChange>one</transChange> know not how to govern his own house, how shall he take care of the church of God?)
I Timothy 3:6 not one newly converted, least being puffed up he fall into the condemnation of the devil.
I Timothy 3:7 He ought also to have an honorable testimony from those that are without, least he fall into reproach and the snare of the devil.
I Timothy 3:8 The deacons <transChange>should</transChange> likewise <transChange>be</transChange> grave, not double-tongued, not given to much wine, not greedy of base gain,
I Timothy 3:9 holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience.
I Timothy 3:10 (And let these also first be proved, then let them take the office of deacons, if they be <transChange>found</transChange> blameless.)
I Timothy 3:11 <transChange>And their</transChange> wives likewise grave, not slanderers, sober, <transChange>and</transChange> faithful in all <transChange>things.</transChange>
I Timothy 3:12 Let the deacons <transChange>too</transChange> be husbands of one wife <transChange>only,</transChange> governing their children and their own houses well.
I Timothy 3:13 For they, that discharge the office of a deacon well, gain to themselves a good degree <transChange>of honor,</transChange> and much freedom in <transChange>promoting</transChange> the faith that is in Christ Jesus.
I Timothy 3:14 These things I write unto thee, hoping to come to thee shortly.
I Timothy 3:15 But if I <transChange>should</transChange> be retarded, that thou mayst know how thou oughtest to behave in the house of God, the church of the living God, the pillar and support of the truth.
I Timothy 3:16 And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifested in <transChange>the</transChange> flesh, justified in <transChange>the</transChange> Spirit, seen by angels, preached among the Gentiles, believed on in the world, <transChange>and</transChange> received up into glory. <chapter eID="gen6795" osisID="1Tim.3"/>
I Timothy 4:0 <chapter osisID="1Tim.4" sID="gen6812"/>
I Timothy 4:1 Now the Spirit expressly saith, that in latter times some shall apostatize from the faith, attending to seducing spirits,
I Timothy 4:2 and doctrines of demons <transChange>founded</transChange> in the hypocrisy of liars, <transChange>who are</transChange> seared <transChange>in</transChange> their own conscience, forbidding to marry,
I Timothy 4:3 <transChange>and enjoining</transChange> abstinence from meats, which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving by those that believe and know the truth.
I Timothy 4:4 For every creature of God <transChange>is</transChange> good, and nothing to be rejected, if <transChange>it be</transChange> received with thanksgiving:
I Timothy 4:5 for it is sanctified by the word of God and <transChange>by</transChange> prayer.
I Timothy 4:6 If thou lay these things before the brethren, thou wilt be a good minister of Jesus Christ, <transChange>as one</transChange> brought up in the words of faith and of good doctrine, to which thou hast attained.
I Timothy 4:7 But profane and groundless fables reject, and exercise thyself unto godliness.
I Timothy 4:8 For bodily exercise profiteth little, but piety is profitable unto all <transChange>things,</transChange> having <transChange>the</transChange> promise of the life <transChange>that</transChange> now <transChange>is,</transChange> and of that <transChange>which is</transChange> to come:
I Timothy 4:9 <transChange>this</transChange> is a certain truth and worthy of all acceptance.
I Timothy 4:10 For to this <transChange>end</transChange> we both labour and suffer reproach, because we have hope in the living God, who is the Saviour of all men, especially of the faithful.
I Timothy 4:11 These <transChange>things</transChange> declare and teach.
I Timothy 4:12 Let no one <transChange>have cause to</transChange> despise thy youth; but he <transChange>thou</transChange> an example to believers in word, in conversation, in charity, in spirit, in faith, in purity.
I Timothy 4:13 Till I come attend to reading, to exhortation, <transChange>and</transChange> teaching.
I Timothy 4:14 Neglect not the gift that is in thee, which was given thee by prophecy, with the laying on of the hands of the presbytery.
I Timothy 4:15 Meditate on these <transChange>things,</transChange> be <transChange>wholly</transChange> in them, that thy proficiency may be manifest in all.
I Timothy 4:16 Take heed to thyself, and to <transChange>thy</transChange> doctrine; continue in them: for <transChange>in</transChange> doing this, thou wilt both save thyself and those that hear thee. <chapter eID="gen6812" osisID="1Tim.4"/>
I Timothy 5:0 <chapter osisID="1Tim.5" sID="gen6829"/>
I Timothy 5:1 Do not chide a senior, but exhort <transChange>him</transChange> as a father; and younger <transChange>men</transChange> as brethren:
I Timothy 5:2 <transChange>the</transChange> elder women as mothers, the younger as sisters, with all purity.
I Timothy 5:3 Honour widows who are widows indeed.
I Timothy 5:4 But if any widow have children or grandchildren, let <transChange>these</transChange> learn first to shew piety at home, and to make suitable returns to <transChange>their</transChange> parents: for this is becoming, and acceptable in the sight of God.
I Timothy 5:5 Now she, that is really a widow and desolate, hopeth in God, and continueth in supplications and prayers night and day.
I Timothy 5:6 But she that indulgeth to luxury, is dead while she liveth.
I Timothy 5:7 These <transChange>things</transChange> give in charge, that they may be blameless.
I Timothy 5:8 But if any provide not for his own, and especially for those of his own family, he hath renounced the faith, and is worse than an infidel.
I Timothy 5:9 Let not a widow be chosen into the number under sixty years old,
I Timothy 5:10 having been the wife of one man: in repute for good actions, if she have educated children, if she have entertained strangers, if she have washed the feet of saints, if she have relieved the afflicted, and diligently followed every good work.
I Timothy 5:11 But the younger widows refuse: for when they grow wanton against Christ, they will <transChange>needs</transChange> marry:
I Timothy 5:12 and are <transChange>therefore</transChange> to be condemned, because they violate their first faith.
I Timothy 5:13 And withal being idle they learn to go about from house to house: and <transChange>are</transChange> not only idle, but tatlers also and busy-bodies, talking of <transChange>things</transChange> unbecoming <transChange>them.</transChange>
I Timothy 5:14 I would therefore have the younger <transChange>widows</transChange> marry, bear children, manage houshold affairs, <transChange>and</transChange> give no occasion to the adversary for reproach.
I Timothy 5:15 For some are already turned aside after Satan.
I Timothy 5:16 <transChange>And</transChange> if any believer have <transChange>relations</transChange> widows, let them relieve them, and let not the church be burdened; that it may relieve those that are indeed widows <transChange>and desolate.</transChange>
I Timothy 5:17 Let the elders, who preside well, be counted worthy of double honor, especially those that labour in preaching and teaching.
I Timothy 5:18 For the scripture saith, "Thou shalt not muzzle the ox that treadeth out the corn:" and, <q marker="" who="Jesus">"The workman <transChange>is</transChange> worthy of his hire."</q>
I Timothy 5:19 Receive not an accusation against an elder, unless from two or three witnesses.
I Timothy 5:20 Those that offend reprove before all, that others also may fear.
I Timothy 5:21 I charge <transChange>thee</transChange> before God, and the Lord Jesus Christ, and the elect angels, that thou keep to these <transChange>things</transChange> without preference <transChange>of persons,</transChange> doing nothing with partiality.
I Timothy 5:22 Lay hands on no <transChange>man</transChange> precipitately, and be not <transChange>hereby</transChange> a partaker in the sins of others. Keep thyself pure.
I Timothy 5:23 Drink no longer water <transChange>only,</transChange> but use a little wine <transChange>with it,</transChange> for the sake of thy stomach and thy frequent infirmities.
I Timothy 5:24 The sins of some men are notorious, leading <transChange>as it were</transChange> to <transChange>their</transChange> condemnation; and some <transChange>more artful</transChange> they follow after.
I Timothy 5:25 So also the good works <transChange>of some</transChange> are manifest; and they that are otherwise cannot be hid. <chapter eID="gen6829" osisID="1Tim.5"/>
I Timothy 6:0 <chapter osisID="1Tim.6" sID="gen6855"/>
I Timothy 6:1 Let as many as are servants under the yoke account their own masters worthy of all honor; that the name of God and <transChange>his</transChange> doctrine may not be blasphemed:
I Timothy 6:2 and let not those who have believing masters, despise <transChange>them,</transChange> because they are brethren; but serve <transChange>them</transChange> more <transChange>readily,</transChange> because they are faithful and beloved <transChange>by God,</transChange> partakers of <transChange>his</transChange> grace.
I Timothy 6:3 These <transChange>things</transChange> teach and exhort. If any one teach otherwise, and adhere not to the sound words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the doctrine which is according to godliness;
I Timothy 6:4 he is proud, knowing nothing, but <transChange>is</transChange> delirious about questions and strifes of words: from which cometh envy, contention, calumnies, wicked suspicions, perverse debates of men corrupted in mind,
I Timothy 6:5 and void of truth, accounting gain to be godliness: from such withdraw thyself.
I Timothy 6:6 But godliness with contentment is great gain.
I Timothy 6:7 For we brought nothing into the world, <transChange>and</transChange> it is certain that we can carry nothing out:
I Timothy 6:8 having therefore food and raiment, let us be herewith content.
I Timothy 6:9 But they, that will be rich, fall into temptation and a snare, and <transChange>into</transChange> many foolish and hurtful lusts, which plunge men into ruin and perdition.
I Timothy 6:10 For the love of money is the root of all evils, which some coveting after have been led astray from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows.
I Timothy 6:11 But do thou, O man of God, flee these <transChange>things,</transChange> and follow after righteousness, piety, fidelity, love, patience, meekness.
I Timothy 6:12 Maintain the glorious combat of faith, lay hold on eternal life, to which thou hast been called, and hast made a good profession before many witnesses.
I Timothy 6:13 I charge thee before God, who giveth life to all, and <transChange>before</transChange> Christ Jesus who witnessed a good confession before Pontius Pilate,
I Timothy 6:14 that thou keep <transChange>this</transChange> commandment, unspotted and blameless, till the appearance of our Lord Jesus Christ;
I Timothy 6:15 which He will manifest in his own times, <transChange>who</transChange> is the blessed and only potentate, the King of kings, and Lord of lords,
I Timothy 6:16 who alone hath immortality, dwelling in light inaccessible, whom no man hath seen, nor can see: to whom <transChange>be</transChange> honor and power everlasting. Amen.
I Timothy 6:17 Charge them, that are rich in this world, not to be high-minded nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God, who richly affords us all <transChange>things</transChange> for enjoyment: <transChange>charge them</transChange> to do good,
I Timothy 6:18 to be rich in good works, to be ready to distribute, willing to communicate;
I Timothy 6:19 treasuring up to themselves a good foundation for the future, that they may obtain eternal life.
I Timothy 6:20 O Timothy, keep that with which thou art entrusted, avoiding profane empty babblings, and the oppositions of science falsely so called:
I Timothy 6:21 which some pretending to, have erred from the faith. Grace <transChange>be</transChange> with thee. Amen. <chapter eID="gen6855" osisID="1Tim.6"/> <div eID="gen6757" osisID="1Tim" type="book"/>

II Timothy 1:0 <chapter osisID="2Tim.1" sID="gen6878"/>
II Timothy 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, according to the promise of life in Christ Jesus,
II Timothy 1:2 to Timothy <transChange>my</transChange> beloved son, grace, mercy, <transChange>and</transChange> peace from God the Father, and <transChange>from</transChange> Christ Jesus our Lord.
II Timothy 1:3 I give thanks to God, whom I serve as <transChange>my</transChange> forefathers <transChange>did,</transChange> with a pure conscience, having remembrance of thee continually in my prayers night and day;
II Timothy 1:4 greatly desiring to see thee, (for I remember thy tears,) that I may be filled with joy:
II Timothy 1:5 keeping in memory the unfeigned faith, <transChange>that is</transChange> in thee, which dwelt first in thy grandmother Lois, and thy mother Eunice: and I am persuaded that <transChange>it dwells</transChange> in thee also;
II Timothy 1:6 for which cause I remind thee to stir up the gift of God which is in thee through the imposition of my hands.
II Timothy 1:7 For God hath not given us a spirit of fearfulness, but of vigor, and of love, and of prudence.
II Timothy 1:8 Be not therefore ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me his prisoner: but bear <transChange>thy</transChange> part in the afflictions of the gospel, according to the power of God;
II Timothy 1:9 who hath saved us, and called us with an holy calling, not according to our works, but according to his own purpose, and grace bestowed upon us through Christ Jesus, before the world was,
II Timothy 1:10 but now made manifest by the appearance of our Saviour Jesus Christ, who hath abolished death, and brought life and immortality to light by the gospel: for which I was appointed an herald,
II Timothy 1:11 and an apostle, and a teacher of the gentiles:
II Timothy 1:12 for which cause also I suffer these <transChange>things;</transChange> but I am not ashamed: for I know <transChange>in</transChange> whom I have trusted, and am persuaded that He is able to keep what I have committed to Him against that day.
II Timothy 1:13 Hold <transChange>fast</transChange> the form of sound words, which thou hast heard from me, in faith and love <transChange>which is</transChange> in Christ Jesus.
II Timothy 1:14 The good thing committed to thee keep, through the Holy Spirit which dwelleth in us.
II Timothy 1:15 Thou knowest that all those of Asia are turned from me, of whom is Phygellus and Hermogenes.
II Timothy 1:16 The Lord shew mercy to the family of Onesiphorus; for he often refreshed me, and was not ashamed of my chain: but when he was at Rome,
II Timothy 1:17 he sought for me <transChange>the</transChange> more diligently, and found <transChange>me.</transChange>
II Timothy 1:18 (The Lord grant that he may find mercy of the Lord in that day!) And how much he ministered <transChange>to me</transChange> at Ephesus <transChange>too,</transChange> thou knowest full well. <chapter eID="gen6878" osisID="2Tim.1"/>
II Timothy 2:0 <chapter osisID="2Tim.2" sID="gen6897"/>
II Timothy 2:1 Thou therefore, my son, be strong in the grace which is in Christ Jesus:
II Timothy 2:2 and <transChange>the things</transChange> which thou hast heard from me, before many witnesses, these commit to faithful men, who shall be able to teach others also.
II Timothy 2:3 Do thou therefore endure hardship, as <transChange>becomes</transChange> a good soldier of Jesus Christ.
II Timothy 2:4 No one, that enters into military service, embarrasseth himself with the affairs of <transChange>this</transChange> life, that he may please him who enlisted <transChange>him.</transChange>
II Timothy 2:5 And if any one contend <transChange>in the public games,</transChange> he gains not the crown unless he contend fairly.
II Timothy 2:6 The husbandman must labour first, <transChange>in order</transChange> to partake of the fruits.
II Timothy 2:7 Consider what I say, and the Lord give thee understanding in all <transChange>things.</transChange>
II Timothy 2:8 Remember Jesus Christ of the seed of David, <transChange>who was</transChange> raised from the dead, according to my gospel:
II Timothy 2:9 for whose sake I suffer trouble <transChange>even</transChange> unto bonds, as <transChange>if I were</transChange> a malefactor; but the word of God is not bound.
II Timothy 2:10 Therefore I submit to every <transChange>thing</transChange> for the sake of the elect, that they also may obtain the salvation which is by Christ Jesus, with eternal glory.
II Timothy 2:11 <transChange>It is</transChange> an undoubted truth, if we are dead with <transChange>Him,</transChange> we shall also live with <transChange>Him:</transChange>
II Timothy 2:12 if we suffer, we shall also reign with <transChange>Him:</transChange> if we disown <transChange>Him,</transChange> He will also disown us.
II Timothy 2:13 If we are unfaithful, He continueth faithful <transChange>notwithstanding;</transChange> He cannot renounce Himself.
II Timothy 2:14 These <transChange>things</transChange> remind <transChange>them</transChange> of, charging <transChange>them</transChange> before the Lord not to contend about words, <transChange>which is</transChange> profitable for nothing, <transChange>and tends</transChange> to the subversion of the hearers.
II Timothy 2:15 Endeavour to present thyself approved unto God, a workman that needeth not to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth.
II Timothy 2:16 But avoid prophane empty harangues; for they will proceed to more impiety,
II Timothy 2:17 and their discourse will eat like a gangrene. Of whom is Hymeneus and Philetus; who have erred from the truth,
II Timothy 2:18 saying that the resurrection is already past; and subvert the faith of some.
II Timothy 2:19 However, the foundation of God standeth firm, having this inscription, The Lord knoweth them that are his; and, Let every one that nameth the name of Christ depart from iniquity.
II Timothy 2:20 In a great house there are not only vessels of gold and silver, but also of wood and of earth; and some to honor, some for meaner uses.
II Timothy 2:21 If therefore any one purify himself from these <transChange>corruptions,</transChange> he shall be a vessel unto honor, sanctified and fitted for the Master's use, being prepared for every good work.
II Timothy 2:22 Flee youthful passions: and follow righteousness, fidelity, love, <transChange>and</transChange> peace, with <transChange>all</transChange> those that call upon the Lord out of a pure heart:
II Timothy 2:23 but foolish and unlearned questions avoid, knowing that they produce quarrels; for the servant of the Lord ought not to wrangle,
II Timothy 2:24 but to be gentle towards all <transChange>men,</transChange> ready to teach, patient under injuries,
II Timothy 2:25 with meekness instructing those of different sentiments, not <transChange>knowing</transChange> but God may give them repentance to the acknowledgement of the truth;
II Timothy 2:26 and they may awake out of the snare of the devil, who have been captivated by him to his will. <chapter eID="gen6897" osisID="2Tim.2"/>
II Timothy 3:0 <chapter osisID="2Tim.3" sID="gen6924"/>
II Timothy 3:1 But this know, that in the last days there will be difficult times;
II Timothy 3:2 for men will be selfish, covetous, arrogant, proud, blasphemers, undutiful to parents, ungrateful, unholy,
II Timothy 3:3 without natural affection, perfidious, false accusers, intemperate, savage, enemies to the good, traitors,
II Timothy 3:4 headstrong, conceited, lovers of pleasure more than lovers of God,
II Timothy 3:5 having a form of godliness, but strangers to the power of it: from such turn away.
II Timothy 3:6 For of these are they who insinuate themselves into families, and captivate weak women, that are laden with sins,
II Timothy 3:7 <transChange>and</transChange> led <transChange>away</transChange> by various lusts, always learning and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth.
II Timothy 3:8 And as Jannes and Jambres withstood Moses, so do these also withstand the truth; <transChange>being</transChange> men of corrupt minds, and of no judgement in the faith.
II Timothy 3:9 But they shall not proceed far: for their folly shall be evident to all, as theirs also was.
II Timothy 3:10 But thou art well acquainted with my doctrine, conduct, purpose, faith, long-suffering, charity, patience, persecutions,
II Timothy 3:11 sufferings, which befel me at Antioch, in Iconium, in Lystra; what persecutions I endured, and <transChange>how</transChange> the Lord delivered me out of them all.
II Timothy 3:12 And indeed all, that are desirous to live godly in Christ Jesus, shall suffer persecution.
II Timothy 3:13 But wicked men and impostors will grow worse and worse, deceiving and being deceived.
II Timothy 3:14 But continue thou in <transChange>the things</transChange> which thou hast learnt, and been assured of, knowing from whom thou hast learned <transChange>them;</transChange>
II Timothy 3:15 and that from a child thou hast known the holy scriptures, which are able to make thee wise unto salvation, through faith in Christ Jesus: <transChange>for</transChange> all scripture <transChange>is</transChange> by inspiration from God,
II Timothy 3:16 and <transChange>is</transChange> profitable for doctrine, for conviction, for correction, for instruction in righteousness;
II Timothy 3:17 that the man of God may be complete, thoroughly fitted for every good work. <chapter eID="gen6924" osisID="2Tim.3"/>
II Timothy 4:0 <chapter osisID="2Tim.4" sID="gen6942"/>
II Timothy 4:1 I charge <transChange>thee</transChange> therefore before God, and the Lord Jesus Christ, who will judge the living and the dead at his appearing, <transChange>in</transChange> his kingdom;
II Timothy 4:2 preach the word, be instant <transChange>both</transChange> in season <transChange>and</transChange> out of season; convince, rebuke, exhort with all long-suffering and instruction.
II Timothy 4:3 For the time will come, when they will not bear sound doctrine; but having itching ears, will heap up to themselves teachers after their own hearts:
II Timothy 4:4 and turn away their attention from the truth, and be turned aside to fables.
II Timothy 4:5 But be thou watchful in all <transChange>things,</transChange> endure hardship, do the work of an evangelist, give full proof of thy ministry.
II Timothy 4:6 For I am now <transChange>going to be</transChange> sacrificed, and the time of my dissolution is near.
II Timothy 4:7 I have fought the good fight, I have finished <transChange>my</transChange> race, I have kept the faith.
II Timothy 4:8 <transChange>As to</transChange> what remains, there is laid up for me a crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge, will give me in that day: and not to me only, but also to all <transChange>those</transChange> who have longed for his appearance.
II Timothy 4:9 Endeavour to come to me soon: for Demas hath forsaken me,
II Timothy 4:10 through love of this world, and is gone to Thessalonica; <transChange>as is</transChange> Crescens to Galatia, <transChange>and</transChange> Titus to Dalmatia: Luke only is with me.
II Timothy 4:11 Take Mark, and bring <transChange>him</transChange> with thee: for he is useful to me in the ministry.
II Timothy 4:12 And I have sent Tychicus to Ephesus.
II Timothy 4:13 When thou comest, bring <transChange>with thee</transChange> the cloke, that I left at Troas with Carpus; and the books, <transChange>but</transChange> especially the parchments.
II Timothy 4:14 Alexander the brazier did me many ill <transChange>turns:</transChange> the Lord <transChange>will</transChange> reward him according to his deeds.
II Timothy 4:15 Of whom do thou also beware: for he hath greatly opposed our doctrine.

II Timothy 4:17 But the Lord stood by me, and strengthened me; that by me the <transChange>gospel</transChange> might be fully spread, and <transChange>that</transChange> all the nations might hear: and <transChange>so</transChange> I was delivered out of the mouth of the lion.

Titus 1:0 <chapter osisID="Titus.1" sID="gen6966"/>
Titus 1:1 <hi type="bold">Paul</hi> a servant of God, and an apostle of Jesus Christ, for <transChange>promoting</transChange> the faith of God's chosen <transChange>people,</transChange> and the knowledge of the truth which <transChange>is</transChange> according to godliness:
Titus 1:2 in hope of eternal life, which God, who cannot lie, promised before all ages;
Titus 1:3 and hath in his own times manifested his word, by the preaching, with which I was intrusted according to the commandment of God our Saviour:
Titus 1:4 to Titus <transChange>my</transChange> son in the common faith, grace, mercy, <transChange>and</transChange> peace from God the Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ our Saviour.
Titus 1:5 For this cause I left thee in Crete, that thou mightest set in order what remained, and ordain elders in every city as I directed thee:
Titus 1:6 <transChange>to wit,</transChange> if any <transChange>one</transChange> be blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children, not accused of debauchery, or unruly.
Titus 1:7 For a bishop must be blameless as the steward of God, not self-willed, not passionate, not given to wine, no striker, not greedy of sordid gain:
Titus 1:8 but hospitable, benevolent, sober, just, holy, temperate;
Titus 1:9 holding fast the faithful word, according as he hath been taught, that he may be able both to instruct in sound doctrine, and to convince gainsayers.
Titus 1:10 For there are many disorderly <transChange>persons,</transChange> vain-talkers and deceivers, especially those of the circumcision; whose mouths must be stopped:
Titus 1:11 who subvert whole families, teaching what they ought not, for shameful gain:
Titus 1:12 <transChange>as</transChange> said one of themselves, a prophet of their own, "The Cretans <transChange>are</transChange> always liars, mischievous beasts, sluggish gluttons."
Titus 1:13 This testimony is true: for which cause rebuke them sharply, that they may be found in the faith;
Titus 1:14 not attending to Jewish fables, and the precepts of men who turn away from the truth.
Titus 1:15 To the pure indeed all things <transChange>are</transChange> pure; but to the polluted and unbelieving nothing <transChange>is</transChange> pure; even their mind and conscience is polluted.
Titus 1:16 They profess to know God, but in works deny <transChange>Him,</transChange> being abominable and disobedient, and to every thing <transChange>that is</transChange> good void of understanding. <chapter eID="gen6966" osisID="Titus.1"/>
Titus 2:0 <chapter osisID="Titus.2" sID="gen6983"/>
Titus 2:1 But do thou speak <transChange>the things</transChange> which become sound doctrine:
Titus 2:2 that aged men be sober, grave, temperate, sound in the faith, in love, in patience:
Titus 2:3 the aged women likewise in behaviour as becometh saints, not false accusers, not given to much wine, teachers of that which is good;
Titus 2:4 that they may instruct the young women to be temperate, to love their husbands, to love their children, <transChange>to be</transChange> prudent,
Titus 2:5 chaste, keepers at home, good, submissive to their husbands, that the word of God may not be evil spoken of.
Titus 2:6 Exhort the young men in like manner to be temperate:
Titus 2:7 in all <transChange>things</transChange> shewing thyself a pattern of good works, <transChange>with</transChange> uncorruptness in teaching, gravity, sound doctrine that cannot be condemned;
Titus 2:8 that he who opposeth <transChange>it</transChange> may be ashamed, having no evil to say of you.
Titus 2:9 <transChange>Exhort</transChange> servants to submit to their masters, to be obsequious in all <transChange>things,</transChange>
Titus 2:10 not answering frowardly, not purloining, but shewing all good fidelity; that they may adorn the doctrine of God our Saviour in all <transChange>things.</transChange>
Titus 2:11 For the grace of God, that bringeth salvation, hath appeared to all men;
Titus 2:12 teaching us that denying ungodliness, and worldly desires, we should live soberly, and righteously, and piously in this present world;
Titus 2:13 looking for the blessed hope, and glorious appearance of the great God, and our Saviour, Jesus Christ:
Titus 2:14 who gave Himself for us, that He might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify to Himself a peculiar people, zealous of good works.

Titus 3:2 to slander no <transChange>man,</transChange> to avoid contention, <transChange>to be</transChange> gentle, shewing all meekness unto all men.
Titus 3:3 For we also were formerly foolish, disobedient, going astray, enslaved to various <transChange>disorderly</transChange> appetites and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful, <transChange>and</transChange> hating one another.
Titus 3:4 But when the kindness and love of God our Saviour towards man appeared,
Titus 3:5 not for works of righteousness which we had done, but according to his <transChange>own</transChange> mercy He saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the holy Spirit;
Titus 3:6 which He hath plentifully shed upon us, through Jesus Christ our Saviour:
Titus 3:7 that being justified by his grace, we might become heirs according to the hope of eternal life.
Titus 3:8 <transChange>This is</transChange> a word <transChange>which ought</transChange> to believed <transChange>and observed,</transChange> and concerning these things I would have thee stedfastly affirm, that they who have believed in God be careful to excel in good works: <transChange>for</transChange> these <transChange>things</transChange> are good and profitable to men.
Titus 3:9 But avoid foolish questions, and genealogies, and strifes and contentions about the law; for they are unprofitable and vain:

Philemon 1:4 I thank my God always making mention of thee in my prayers,
Philemon 1:5 (hearing of the faith which thou hast towards the Lord Jesus, and of thy love to all the saints,)
Philemon 1:6 that the communication of thy faith may become effectual in the acknowledgement of all the good that is in you towards Christ Jesus:
Philemon 1:7 for we have much joy and comfort in thy love, because by thee, <transChange>dear</transChange> brother, the bowels of the saints are refreshed.
Philemon 1:8 Wherefore though I have sufficient authority in Christ to enjoin thee what is meet,
Philemon 1:9 I <transChange>would</transChange> rather intreat <transChange>thee</transChange> out of love <transChange>to me,</transChange> being such a one as Paul the aged, and now a prisoner too <transChange>for the sake</transChange> of Jesus Christ.
Philemon 1:10 I intreat thee <transChange>then</transChange> for my son Onesimus, whom I have begotten in my bonds,
Philemon 1:11 who was formerly unprofitable to thee, but now profitable both to thee and to me; whom I have sent back <transChange>to thee:</transChange>
Philemon 1:12 him therefore, as my own bowels, do thou receive.
Philemon 1:13 Whom I would <transChange>gladly</transChange> have kept with me, that he might have ministered unto me as thou <transChange>wouldst have done,</transChange> in the bonds of the gospel.
Philemon 1:14 But I would do nothing without thy knowledge, that thy kindness might not be as it were forced, but voluntary.
Philemon 1:15 For perhaps he was therefore parted <transChange>from thee</transChange> for a season, that thou mightest receive him for ever:
Philemon 1:16 not now as a servant, but above a servant, a dear brother, especially to me, and how much more to thee both in the flesh and in the Lord.
Philemon 1:17 If therefore thou accountest me a friend, receive him as <transChange>thou wouldst receive</transChange> me.

Philemon 1:19 I Paul have written it with my own hand, I will pay <transChange>it:</transChange> not to say that thou indeed owest even thy own self to me.
Philemon 1:20 Yea, <transChange>my</transChange> brother, let me enjoy <transChange>this</transChange> satisfaction from thee in the Lord: <transChange>and thus</transChange> refresh my bowels in the Lord.
Philemon 1:21 Being <transChange>fully</transChange> persuaded of thy compliance, I have written to thee; knowing that thou wilt indeed do more than I ask.
Philemon 1:22 But I must add, prepare me also a lodging; for I hope that through your prayers I shall be restored to you.

Hebrews 1:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.1" sID="gen7043"/>
Hebrews 1:1 <hi type="bold">God</hi>, who at sundry times, and various ways, spake of old unto the fathers by the prophets, hath in these last days spoken to us by <transChange>his</transChange> Son,
Hebrews 1:2 whom He hath appointed heir of all <transChange>things,</transChange> by whom also He made the worlds.
Hebrews 1:3 Who being the refulgence of <transChange>his</transChange> glory and the imprest image of his person, and sustaining all <transChange>things</transChange> by his powerful word, having by Himself performed the purging away of our sins, sat down at the right hand of the majesty on high.
Hebrews 1:4 Being as much superior to the angels, as He inheriteth a name more excellent than they.
Hebrews 1:5 For to which of the angels did He ever say, "Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee?" and again, "I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to me a Son?"
Hebrews 1:6 and when He again introduceth the First-born into the world, he saith, "And let all the angels of God worship Him."
Hebrews 1:7 And <transChange>as</transChange> to the angels He saith, "Who maketh his angels spirits and his ministers a flame of fire:"
Hebrews 1:8 but to the Son, "Thy throne, O God, <transChange>is</transChange> for ever and ever; the sceptre of thy kingdom <transChange>is</transChange> a sceptre of righteousness:
Hebrews 1:9 thou lovest righteousness and hatest iniquity; therefore God, <transChange>even</transChange> thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thine associates."
Hebrews 1:10 And <transChange>in another place,</transChange> "Thou, Lord, in the beginning hast founded the earth, and the heavens are the works of thy hands:
Hebrews 1:11 they <transChange>shall</transChange> perish, but thou remainest; and they shall all grow old as a garment,
Hebrews 1:12 and as a mantle wilt thou fold them <transChange>up,</transChange> and they shall be changed; but thou art the same, and thy years shall not fail."
Hebrews 1:13 But to which of the angels hath He ever said, "Sit <transChange>thou</transChange> at my right hand, till I make thine enemies <transChange>thy</transChange> footstool?"

Hebrews 2:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.2" sID="gen7058"/>
Hebrews 2:1 For this <transChange>reason</transChange> we ought the more earnestly to attend to what we have heard, least by any means we should be <transChange>found</transChange> deficient.
Hebrews 2:2 For if the word spoken by angels was stedfast, and every transgression and disobedience received <transChange>it's</transChange> just recompence;
Hebrews 2:3 how shall we escape, if we neglect so great a salvation? which began to be declared by the Lord, <transChange>and</transChange> was confirmed to us by them that heard <transChange>Him;</transChange>
Hebrews 2:4 God also testifying together with <transChange>them</transChange> by signs, and wonders, and divers miracles, and gifts of the holy Spirit, according to his own will.
Hebrews 2:5 For He hath not subjected to angels the world to come, of which we speak.
Hebrews 2:6 But one in a certain place hath testified, saying, "What is man that thou art mindful of him? or the son of man that thou visitest Him?
Hebrews 2:7 Thou madest Him <transChange>for</transChange> a little <transChange>while</transChange> inferior to <transChange>the</transChange> angels; with glory and honor hast thou crowned Him, and hast set Him over the works of thy hands; thou hast put all <transChange>things</transChange> under his feet,"
Hebrews 2:8 For in putting all things under Him, He left nothing <transChange>which was</transChange> not <transChange>to be</transChange> in subjection to Him: though we do not yet see all things subjected to Him.
Hebrews 2:9 But we see Jesus, who was made <transChange>for</transChange> a little <transChange>while</transChange> lower than the angels, in order to suffer death, that by the grace of God He might taste death for every man, crowned with glory and honor.
Hebrews 2:10 For it became Him for whom are all <transChange>things,</transChange> and by whom <transChange>are</transChange> all things, <transChange>in</transChange> bringing many sons to glory, to make the author of their salvation perfect by sufferings:
Hebrews 2:11 since He that sanctifieth, and they that are sanctified, <transChange>are</transChange> all of one. For which cause He is not ashamed to call them brethren,
Hebrews 2:12 saying, "I will declare thy name unto my brethren, in the midst of the congregation will I praise Thee."
Hebrews 2:13 And again, "I will trust in Him:" and again, "Behold, I, and the children which God hath given me."
Hebrews 2:14 Seeing then the children are partakers of flesh and blood, He also himself in like manner partook of them; that by death He might destroy him that had the empire of death, that is, the devil:
Hebrews 2:15 and deliver those who through fear of death were all their life-time subject to bondage.
Hebrews 2:16 For indeed He taketh not hold of angels <transChange>to save them,</transChange> but of the seed of Abraham.
Hebrews 2:17 Whence it behoved Him to be made in all things like unto <transChange>his</transChange> brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful high-priest in the <transChange>things</transChange> concerning God, to make atonement for the sins of the people:
Hebrews 2:18 for as He himself hath suffered, <transChange>in</transChange> being tempted, He is able to succour those that are tempted. <chapter eID="gen7058" osisID="Heb.2"/>
Hebrews 3:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.3" sID="gen7077"/>
Hebrews 3:1 Wherefore, holy brethren, partakers of the heavenly calling, consider the apostle and high-priest of our profession, Christ Jesus;
Hebrews 3:2 who was faithful to Him that appointed Him, as Moses also <transChange>was</transChange> in all his house.
Hebrews 3:3 For He was accounted worthy of more honor than Moses, as he who hath built it, hath more honor than the house.
Hebrews 3:4 For every house is built by some <transChange>one:</transChange> and He who built all <transChange>things is</transChange> God.
Hebrews 3:5 Now Moses <transChange>was</transChange> indeed faithful in all his house as a servant, for a testimony of the things which were to be spoken:
Hebrews 3:6 but Christ as a Son over his own house; whose house we are, if we maintain the free profession and exultation of hope firm unto the end.
Hebrews 3:7 Therefore, as the holy Ghost saith, "To-day if ye will hear his voice,
Hebrews 3:8 harden not your hearts, as in the provocation, in the day of temptation in the wilderness, when your fathers tempted me,
Hebrews 3:9 proved me, and saw my works forty years:
Hebrews 3:10 wherefore I was provoked with that generation, and said, They are always erring in <transChange>their</transChange> heart, and they have not known my ways:
Hebrews 3:11 so I sware in my wrath, they shall not enter into my rest."
Hebrews 3:12 Take heed, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, least there be in any of you a wicked heart of unbelief in departing from the living God:
Hebrews 3:13 but exhort one another daily, while it is called to-day; that none of you may be hardened through the deceitfulness of sin:
Hebrews 3:14 for we are made partakers of Christ, if we hold fast our first confidence firm unto the end; inasmuch as it is said,
Hebrews 3:15 "To-day if ye will hear his voice,
Hebrews 3:16 harden not your hearts, as in the provocation." For some that heard did provoke; but not all that came out of Egypt with Moses.
Hebrews 3:17 But with whom was He provoked forty years? <transChange>was it</transChange> not with those that sinned, whose carcases fell in the wilderness?
Hebrews 3:18 and to whom did He swear that they should not enter into his rest, but to those that were disobedient?
Hebrews 3:19 and <transChange>so</transChange> we see that they could not enter in because of unbelief. <chapter eID="gen7077" osisID="Heb.3"/>
Hebrews 4:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.4" sID="gen7097"/>
Hebrews 4:1 Let us therefore fear least a promise being left <transChange>us</transChange> of entering into his rest, any of us should seem to fall short of it:
Hebrews 4:2 for we are graciously offered <transChange>it,</transChange> as they also were. But the word, which they heard, did not profit them, not being mixed with faith in them that heard <transChange>it.</transChange>
Hebrews 4:3 For we who believe shall enter into rest, as He said <transChange>above,</transChange> "So I sware in my wrath, they shall not enter into my rest:" though the works <transChange>of creation</transChange> were finished from the foundation of the world:
Hebrews 4:4 for it is thus said concerning the seventh <transChange>day,</transChange> "And God rested the seventh day from all his works."
Hebrews 4:5 And yet in this <transChange>place,</transChange> "They shall not enter into my rest."
Hebrews 4:6 Seeing therefore it remaineth that some <transChange>are to</transChange> enter into it, and they to whom it was at first offered did not enter because of <transChange>their</transChange> unbelief,
Hebrews 4:7 He appoints a certain day, <transChange>called</transChange> To-day, saying by David so long after, (as it is recorded) "To-day if ye will hear his voice, harden not your hearts."
Hebrews 4:8 For if Joshua had given them <transChange>the</transChange> rest, He would not afterwards have spoken of another day.
Hebrews 4:9 There remaineth therefore a rest for the people of God:
Hebrews 4:10 for he that is entered into his rest, hath also himself ceased from his works, as God <transChange>did</transChange> from his.
Hebrews 4:11 Let us labour therefore to enter into that rest, least any one fall after the same example of unbelief.
Hebrews 4:12 For the word of God is lively and efficacious, and sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing even to the dividing of soul and spirit, and of the <transChange>very</transChange> joints and marrow, and judging the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
Hebrews 4:13 And there is no creature concealed from his sight: but all things are naked and open to the eyes of Him, to whom we are to <transChange>give an</transChange> account.

Hebrews 4:15 for we have not an high-priest who cannot sympathize with our infirmities, but was in all <transChange>respects</transChange> tempted in like manner <transChange>with us, yet</transChange> without sin.
Hebrews 4:16 Let us therefore come with freedom to the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy and find grace for <transChange>our</transChange> seasonable help. <chapter eID="gen7097" osisID="Heb.4"/>
Hebrews 5:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.5" sID="gen7114"/>
Hebrews 5:1 For every high-priest taken from among men, is appointed for <transChange>the sake of</transChange> men in things relating to God, that he may offer gifts and sacrifices for sins:
Hebrews 5:2 who can have due compassion on the ignorant and those that are going astray; seeing he himself also is surrounded with infirmity:
Hebrews 5:3 and for this <transChange>reason</transChange> he ought, as for the people, so also for himself, to offer <transChange>sacrifice</transChange> for sins.
Hebrews 5:4 And no one taketh this honor to himself, but he that is called by God, as Aaron <transChange>was.</transChange>
Hebrews 5:5 So also Christ did not glorify himself to be made an high-priest; but He that said unto Him, "Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee."
Hebrews 5:6 As He saith also in another <transChange>place,</transChange> "Thou <transChange>art</transChange> a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec."
Hebrews 5:7 Who in the days of his flesh, offered prayers and supplications with strong crying and tears, to Him that was able to save Him from death, and was heard in what He feared;
Hebrews 5:8 <transChange>but</transChange> though He was a Son, yet He learned obedience by the things which He suffered: and being <transChange>thus</transChange> perfected,
Hebrews 5:9 He became the author of eternal salvation to all that obey Him:
Hebrews 5:10 having been declared by God an high-priest after the order of Melchisedec.
Hebrews 5:11 Concerning whom we have much to say and difficult to be explained, since ye are become dull of hearing.
Hebrews 5:12 For whereas ye ought for the time to be teachers <transChange>of others,</transChange> ye have need again of some <transChange>one</transChange> to teach you the first rudiments of the oracles of God; and are become such as have need of milk and not of solid food.
Hebrews 5:13 For every one that wanteth milk, is unacquainted with the doctrine of justification; for he is an infant:
Hebrews 5:14 but firm food is for persons come to age, who by habit have <transChange>their</transChange> senses exercised to a discernment both of good and evil. <chapter eID="gen7114" osisID="Heb.5"/>
