Hebrews 6:4 who were once enlightened, and have tasted of the heavenly gift, and were made partakers of the holy Spirit,
Hebrews 6:5 and of the good word of God,
Hebrews 6:6 and the powers of the gospel-age, and <transChange>yet</transChange> fall away, should be renewed again to repentance: since they again crucify to themselves the Son of God, and make an <transChange>open</transChange> example <transChange>of Him.</transChange>
Hebrews 6:7 For <transChange>as</transChange> the earth, which imbibeth the rain that is frequently coming upon it, and produceth herbs fit for those by whom it is cultivated, receiveth a blessing from God:
Hebrews 6:8 but that which bringeth forth thorns and briars, <transChange>is</transChange> rejected and near to a curse, (whose end <transChange>is</transChange> burning) <transChange>so are they.</transChange>
Hebrews 6:9 But, beloved, we are persuaded better <transChange>things</transChange> of you, and things that accompany salvation, though we thus speak <transChange>for your caution.</transChange>
Hebrews 6:10 For God is not unjust to forget your work and labor of love, which ye have shewn to his name, <transChange>by</transChange> having ministred to the saints, and <transChange>yet</transChange> ministring.
Hebrews 6:11 And we desire that every one of you would shew the same diligence to <transChange>acquire</transChange> the full assurance of hope <transChange>even</transChange> unto the end:
Hebrews 6:12 that ye would not be sluggish, but imitators of them who through faith and patience are inheriting the promises.
Hebrews 6:13 For when God made the promise to Abraham, because He could swear by no greater, He sware by Himself, saying,
Hebrews 6:14 "Verily blessing I will bless thee, and multiplying I will multiply thee."
Hebrews 6:15 And thus waiting patiently he obtained the promise.
Hebrews 6:16 For men swear by a greater <transChange>Being,</transChange> and an oath for confirmation <transChange>is</transChange> to them an end of all controversy.
Hebrews 6:17 Wherefore God being willing more abundantly to manifest unto the heirs of the promise the immutability of his counsel, confirmed <transChange>it</transChange> with an oath:
Hebrews 6:18 that by two immutable things, in which <transChange>it is</transChange> impossible for God to fail, we might have strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to lay hold on the hope set before us;
Hebrews 6:19 which we have as an anchor of the soul safe and stedfast, and which entereth within the veil.
Hebrews 6:20 Whither Jesus <transChange>our</transChange> fore-runner is entered for us, being made an high-priest for ever, after the order of Melchisedec. <chapter eID="gen7129" osisID="Heb.6"/>
Hebrews 7:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.7" sID="gen7150"/>
Hebrews 7:1 For this Melchisedec, king of Salem, priest of the most high God, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings,
Hebrews 7:2 and blessed him, to whom also Abraham divided the tenth of all <transChange>his spoils;</transChange> being in the first place, by interpretation <transChange>of his name,</transChange> king of righteousness, and moreover king of Salem, which is king of peace;
Hebrews 7:3 without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days <transChange>recorded,</transChange> nor end of life, but resembling the Son of God, remaineth a priest continually.
Hebrews 7:4 Now consider how great a man this <transChange>was,</transChange> to whom even the patriarch Abraham gave the tenth of the spoils.
Hebrews 7:5 And those indeed of the sons of Levi, who receive the priesthood, have a commandment according to the law to take tithes of the people, that is, of their brethren, though they came out of the loins of Abraham:
Hebrews 7:6 but he, whose pedigree is not reckoned among them, took tithes of Abraham, and blessed him that had the promises.
Hebrews 7:7 Now without all contradiction the inferior is blessed by the superior:
Hebrews 7:8 besides, here men that die receive tithes; but there he of whom it is testified that he liveth.
Hebrews 7:9 And (as one may say) even Levi, who receiveth tithes, paid tithes in Abraham:
Hebrews 7:10 for he was yet in the loins of his father, when Melchisedec met him.
Hebrews 7:11 Now if perfection were by the Levitical priesthood, (for under it the people received the law) what farther need <transChange>was there</transChange> that another priest should arise after the order of Melchisedec, and not after the order of Aaron?
Hebrews 7:12 For the priesthood being changed, there is of necessity a change also of the law.
Hebrews 7:13 Now He, of whom these things are said, is of another tribe, of which none <transChange>ever</transChange> attended at the altar..
Hebrews 7:14 For <transChange>it is</transChange> evident that our Lord sprang from Judah, as to which tribe Moses spake nothing about <transChange>the</transChange> priesthood.
Hebrews 7:15 And it is yet more abundantly evident, that after the similitude of Melchisedec there ariseth another priest,
Hebrews 7:16 who is made not according to the law of a temporary command, but according to the power of an endless life.
Hebrews 7:17 For He testifieth, Thou <transChange>art</transChange> a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec.
Hebrews 7:18 For there is indeed a disannulling of the preceding command, on account of it's weakness and unprofitableness;
Hebrews 7:19 for the law made nothing perfect, but the introducing of a better hope <transChange>did,</transChange> by which we draw near to God.
Hebrews 7:20 Moreover inasmuch as <transChange>He was</transChange> not <transChange>made priest</transChange> without an oath,
Hebrews 7:21 (for they indeed are become priests without <transChange>the solemnity of</transChange> an oath; but He with an oath, by Him who said unto Him, "The Lord hath sworn, and will not repent, Thou <transChange>art</transChange> a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec:")
Hebrews 7:22 by so much is Jesus become the surety of a better covenant.
Hebrews 7:23 And they were many priests, because they were by death hindered from continuing <transChange>in their office;</transChange>
Hebrews 7:24 but He, because He abideth for ever, hath a priesthood that passeth not <transChange>to any other:</transChange>
Hebrews 7:25 wherefore also He is able to save to the uttermost, those that come unto God by Him, seeing He ever liveth to make intercession for them.
Hebrews 7:26 For such an high-priest was meet for us, <transChange>who was</transChange> holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and higher than the heavens;
Hebrews 7:27 who hath no need, as the <transChange>Levitical</transChange> high-priests <transChange>had,</transChange> daily to offer sacrifices first for his own sins, <transChange>and</transChange> then for those of the people: for this He did once <transChange>for all,</transChange> in offering up Himself.
Hebrews 7:28 For the law appointeth men high-priests, who have infirmity; but the oath, <transChange>recorded</transChange> since the law, <transChange>appointeth</transChange> the Son <transChange>to be priest</transChange> for ever, being <transChange>fully</transChange> perfected <transChange>for it.</transChange> <chapter eID="gen7150" osisID="Heb.7"/>
Hebrews 8:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.8" sID="gen7179"/>
Hebrews 8:1 Now the sum of the things that have been said <transChange>is this, that</transChange> we have such an high-priest, who is sat down at the right hand of the throne of the majesty in the heavens;
Hebrews 8:2 a minister of holy things, and of the true tabernacle, which the Lord hath raised, and not man.
Hebrews 8:3 For every high-priest is appointed to offer gifts and sacrifices; wherefore <transChange>it was</transChange> necessary that He also should have something to offer.
Hebrews 8:4 For if He were on earth, He could not be a priest, seeing there are priests <transChange>already</transChange> that offer gifts according to the law:
Hebrews 8:5 who worship <transChange>under</transChange> the representation and shadow of heavenly things; as Moses was ordered by God, when he was about to finish the tabernacle. For see, saith He, <transChange>that</transChange> thou make all according to the model shewn thee in the mount.
Hebrews 8:6 But now He hath obtained a more excellent ministry, inasmuch as He is also the mediator of a better covenant, which is established upon better promises.
Hebrews 8:7 For if the first <transChange>covenant</transChange> had been unexceptionable, there had been no room for a second:
Hebrews 8:8 <transChange>as we see there was,</transChange> for <transChange>after</transChange> complaining of them, He adds, "Behold the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel, and with the house of Judah:
Hebrews 8:9 not according to the covenant which I made with their fathers, in the day when I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt; for they continued not in my covenant, and I regarded them not, saith the Lord.
Hebrews 8:10 But this <transChange>is</transChange> the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, saith the Lord, I will put my laws into their mind, and I will inscribe them on their hearts; and I will be to them a God, and they shall be to me a people.
Hebrews 8:11 And they shall not teach every one his neighbour, and every one his brother, saying, Know the Lord: for they shall all know me, from the lest even to the greatest of them.
Hebrews 8:12 For I will forgive their crimes, and their sins and their iniquities I will remember no more."
Hebrews 8:13 <transChange>Now</transChange> by saying, a new <transChange>covenant,</transChange> He hath antiquated the first: and what is antiquated, and groweth old, <transChange>is</transChange> near <transChange>it's</transChange> exit. <chapter eID="gen7179" osisID="Heb.8"/>
Hebrews 9:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.9" sID="gen7193"/>
Hebrews 9:1 Therefore the first covenant had also rites of worship and a worldly sanctuary.
Hebrews 9:2 For there was a tabernacle prepared; the first <transChange>part,</transChange> wherein <transChange>was</transChange> the candlestick, and the table, and the loaves set on <transChange>it,</transChange> which is called the sanctuary.
Hebrews 9:3 And beyond the second veil, the tabernacle which is called the Holy of holies, having the golden censer,
Hebrews 9:4 and the ark of the covenant <transChange>which was</transChange> overlaid all round with gold, <transChange>and</transChange> in which <transChange>was</transChange> the golden pot with the manna in it, and Aaron's rod that budded, and the tables of the covenant;
Hebrews 9:5 and over it the cherubims of glory shadowing the mercyseat: of which it is not <transChange>necessary</transChange> now to speak particularly.
Hebrews 9:6 Now these things being thus disposed, the priests always went into the first <transChange>part of the</transChange> tabernacle to perform their <transChange>daily</transChange> services:
Hebrews 9:7 but into the second only the high-priest <transChange>went</transChange> once a year; <transChange>and that</transChange> not without blood, which he offered for himself, and <transChange>for</transChange> the sins of the people <transChange>committed</transChange> through ignorance.
Hebrews 9:8 The Holy Ghost shewing <transChange>by</transChange> this, that the way into the <transChange>Holy</transChange> of holies was not yet manifested, the first tabernacle being yet standing.
Hebrews 9:9 Which figure <transChange>remains</transChange> to the present time, wherein gifts and sacrifices are offered, that cannot perfect the worshipper as to <transChange>his</transChange> conscience,
Hebrews 9:10 <transChange>relating</transChange> only to meats and drinks, and different washings, and <transChange>such</transChange> carnal ordinances <transChange>as were</transChange> required till the time of reformation.
Hebrews 9:11 But Christ being come an high-priest of the good things to come, hath entered once for all into the holy <transChange>places,</transChange> through a greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is, not of this building,
Hebrews 9:12 nor by the blood of goats and calves, but by his own blood, having obtained eternal redemption <transChange>for us.</transChange>
Hebrews 9:13 For if the blood of bulls and goats, and the ashes of an heifer sprinkling the unclean, sanctifieth to the purification of the flesh;
Hebrews 9:14 how much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself spotless to God, purify your conscience from dead works, that ye may serve the living God?
Hebrews 9:15 And on this account He is the mediator of a new covenant, that undergoing death for the redemption of transgressions against the first covenant, they that are called might receive the promise of an eternal inheritance.
Hebrews 9:16 For where a testament <transChange>is,</transChange> there is a necessity of proving the death of the testator.
Hebrews 9:17 For a testament is valid after men are dead, but is of no force while the testator is living.
Hebrews 9:18 Whence neither was the first <transChange>covenant</transChange> entered into without blood:
Hebrews 9:19 for when every command was spoken according to the law, by Moses to all the people, he took the blood of calves and goats, with water and scarlet wool, and hyssop, and sprinkled the book and all the people,
Hebrews 9:20 saying, this is the blood of the covenant, which God hath enjoined you.
Hebrews 9:21 And the tabernacle, and all the vessels of public worship he likewise sprinkled with blood.
Hebrews 9:22 And according to the law almost all things are purified with blood; and without shedding of blood there is no remission.
Hebrews 9:23 <transChange>It was</transChange> therefore necessary that the representations of things in the heavens should be purified with these; but the heavenly things themselves with more excellent sacrifices than these.
Hebrews 9:24 For Christ is not entered into holy <transChange>places</transChange> made with hands, <transChange>which were but</transChange> types of the true <transChange>ones;</transChange> but into heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God for us:
Hebrews 9:25 nor to offer Himself often, as the high-priest entereth into the <transChange>holy of</transChange> holies every year with the blood of others;
Hebrews 9:26 (for then He must <transChange>indeed</transChange> have suffered often since the foundation of the world) but now once at the conclusion of the ages He hath been made manifest for the abolishing of sin by the sacrifice of himself.
Hebrews 9:27 And as it is appointed to men once to die, and after this the judgement;
Hebrews 9:28 so Christ, having been once offered to bear the sins of many, shall appear the second time without sin, to those who are waiting for Him, unto salvation. <chapter eID="gen7193" osisID="Heb.9"/>
Hebrews 10:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.10" sID="gen7222"/>
Hebrews 10:1 For the law having <transChange>but</transChange> a <transChange>faint</transChange> shadow of good <transChange>things</transChange> to come, <transChange>and</transChange> not the full image of the things, can never, even by the <transChange>great</transChange> annual sacrifices which they offer statedly, make the comers thereunto perfect.
Hebrews 10:2 For then they would have ceased to be offered, because the sacrificers, being once purified, would no longer retain any consciousness of sins.
Hebrews 10:3 Whereas in <transChange>these</transChange> very sacrifices there is a recalling of sins to mind every year.
Hebrews 10:4 For it is impossible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sins.
Hebrews 10:5 Wherefore upon his coming into the world He saith, "Sacrifice and offering thou didst not desire, but a body hast thou prepared me:
Hebrews 10:6 in whole burnt-offerings and <transChange>sacrifices</transChange> for sin thou hadst no pleasure:
Hebrews 10:7 then said I, Lo I come, <transChange>as</transChange> in the volume of the book it is written of me, to do thy will, O God."
Hebrews 10:8 Having said before, "Thou didst not desire, nor hadst pleasure in, sacrifice and offering, and whole burnt-offerings, and <transChange>sacrifices</transChange> for sin," (which are offered by the law) then He adds,
Hebrews 10:9 "Lo I come to do thy will, O God." (He taketh away the first, that He may establish the second.)
Hebrews 10:10 By which will we are sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
Hebrews 10:11 And indeed every priest <transChange>under the law</transChange> standeth daily ministring, and frequently offering the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins:
Hebrews 10:12 but He having offered one sacrifice for sins, is for ever sat down at the right hand of God;
Hebrews 10:13 waiting for the future, till his enemies be put under his feet.
Hebrews 10:14 For by one offering He hath perfected for ever those that are sanctified.
Hebrews 10:15 And <transChange>of this</transChange> the holy Ghost also beareth witness with us:
Hebrews 10:16 for after He had said, "This <transChange>is</transChange> the covenant that I will make with them after those days, saith the Lord, I will put my laws into their hearts, and on their minds will I inscribe them;
Hebrews 10:17 <transChange>He adds,</transChange> and their sins and their iniquities I will remember no more."
Hebrews 10:18 Now where <transChange>there is such</transChange> a remission of these, there <transChange>needs</transChange> no more offering for sin.
Hebrews 10:19 Having therefore, brethren, free admission into the holy <transChange>places</transChange> by the blood of Jesus,
Hebrews 10:20 the new and living way which He hath consecrated for us, through the veil, that is <transChange>to say,</transChange>
Hebrews 10:21 his flesh, and <transChange>having</transChange> a great <transChange>high</transChange>-priest over the house of God,
Hebrews 10:22 let us draw near with sincerity, in the full assurance of faith, having our hearts cleansed from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water.
Hebrews 10:23 Let us inflexibly retain the profession of our hope,
Hebrews 10:24 (for He is faithful who hath promised) and let us observe each other to the incitement of love and good works:
Hebrews 10:25 not forsaking our assemblies, as the custom of some <transChange>is,</transChange> but exhorting <transChange>one another;</transChange> and so much the more as ye see the day approaching.
Hebrews 10:26 For if we sin wilfully after having received the knowledge of the truth, there remaineth no more sacrifice for sins;
Hebrews 10:27 but a dreadful expectation of judgement, and a fiery indignation, which shall devour the adversaries.
Hebrews 10:28 <transChange>If</transChange> any <transChange>one</transChange> that violateth the law of Moses, dieth without mercy under two or three witnesses,
Hebrews 10:29 of how much greater punishment, think ye, shall he be counted worthy, who hath trampled under foot the Son of God, and accounted the blood of the covenant, by which he was sanctified, an unholy thing, and abused the Spirit of grace?
Hebrews 10:30 For we know who hath said, "To me <transChange>belongeth</transChange> vengeance, I will recompense, saith the Lord:" and again, "The Lord will judge his people."
Hebrews 10:31 <transChange>It is</transChange> a dreadful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
Hebrews 10:32 But call to remembrance the former days, in which <transChange>after</transChange> being enlightened, ye sustained a great conflict of sufferings;
Hebrews 10:33 partly, being made a public spectacle by reproaches and afflictions; and partly, as ye became associates of those who were so treated:
Hebrews 10:34 for ye sympathized with <transChange>me in</transChange> my bonds, and ye took joyfully the plundering of your goods, knowing in yourselves that ye have in heaven a better and an enduring substance.
Hebrews 10:35 Cast not away therefore your couragious profession, which hath a great recompence of reward.
Hebrews 10:36 For ye have need of patience, that having done the will of God ye may receive the promise.
Hebrews 10:37 For yet a little while, and He, that is coming, will come, and will not delay:
Hebrews 10:38 and the just shall live by faith, but if <transChange>any</transChange> draw back, my soul shall have no pleasure in him.
Hebrews 10:39 But we are not of those who withdraw to perdition; but of them that believe to the saving of the soul. <chapter eID="gen7222" osisID="Heb.10"/>
Hebrews 11:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.11" sID="gen7262"/>
Hebrews 11:1 Now faith is the confident expectation of <transChange>things</transChange> hoped for, and a conviction of things not seen:
Hebrews 11:2 for by it the ancients obtained an <transChange>honorable</transChange> testimony.
Hebrews 11:3 By faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the word of God, for the things which are seen were not made of things which appear.
Hebrews 11:4 By faith Abel offered unto God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, by which he obtained the testimony that he was righteous, God bearing witness to his gifts: and by it, though dead, he yet speaketh.
Hebrews 11:5 By faith Enoch was translated, that he should not see death; and was not found, because God had translated him; for before his translation he had <transChange>this</transChange> testimony that he pleased God:
Hebrews 11:6 whereas without faith <transChange>it is</transChange> impossible to please <transChange>Him;</transChange> for he that cometh to God must believe, that He is, and is the rewarder of them that diligently seek Him.
Hebrews 11:7 By faith Noah being warned by God of things <transChange>which were</transChange> not yet seen, moved with <transChange>pious</transChange> fear, prepared an ark for the safety of his family; whereby he condemned the world, and became heir of the righteousness <transChange>which is</transChange> by faith.
Hebrews 11:8 By faith Abraham <transChange>when</transChange> called to go out to a place which he was afterwards to receive for an inheritance obeyed: and went out, though he knew not whither he was going.
Hebrews 11:9 By faith he sojourned in the land promised <transChange>him,</transChange> as <transChange>in</transChange> a foreign <transChange>country,</transChange> dwelling in tents, as did Isaac and Jacob the heirs with <transChange>him</transChange> of the same promise.
Hebrews 11:10 For he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose maker and founder <transChange>is</transChange> God.
Hebrews 11:11 By faith also Sarah received strength to conceive seed, and brought forth <transChange>a son</transChange> when she was past age, because she accounted Him faithful who had promised.
Hebrews 11:12 So that there descended even from one, and him <transChange>in a manner</transChange> dead, <transChange>a posterity</transChange> like the stars of heaven for multitude, and as the sand on the sea shore, innumerable.
Hebrews 11:13 These all died in faith, not having received the promises, but seen them from afar, and been persuaded <transChange>of them,</transChange> and embraced <transChange>them,</transChange> and confessed that they were strangers and sojourners on the earth.
Hebrews 11:14 Now they that say such things shew plainly that they are seeking <transChange>their own</transChange> country:
Hebrews 11:15 and if they had been mindful of that from which they came, they might have had opportunity to have returned.
Hebrews 11:16 But they desire a better, that is, an heavenly <transChange>one;</transChange> wherefore God is not ashamed to be called their God; for He hath prepared for them a city.
Hebrews 11:17 By faith Abraham, when he was tried, offered up Isaac: and he who had received the promises, offered up his only son;
Hebrews 11:18 of whom it was told <transChange>him,</transChange> that in Isaac shall thy seed be called:
Hebrews 11:19 concluding that God was able to raise <transChange>him</transChange> even from the dead; from whence indeed he had in a manner received him.
Hebrews 11:20 By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things future.
Hebrews 11:21 By faith Jacob, <transChange>when he was</transChange> dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph; and worshipped <transChange>leaning</transChange> on the top of his staff.
Hebrews 11:22 By faith Joseph when he died, mentioned the departure of the children of Israel and gave a charge concerning his bones.
Hebrews 11:23 By faith Moses, when he was born, was hid three months by his parents, because they saw <transChange>he was</transChange> a fine child, and they were not afraid of the king's edict.
Hebrews 11:24 By faith Moses, when he was grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter;
Hebrews 11:25 chusing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, than to have the temporary enjoyment of sin:
Hebrews 11:26 esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures in Egypt, for he looked to the recompence of reward.
Hebrews 11:27 By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king: for he continued firm as seeing Him who is invisible.
Hebrews 11:28 By faith he observed the passover and sprinkling of the blood, that he, who destroyed the first-born <transChange>of the Egyptians,</transChange> might not touch them.
Hebrews 11:29 By faith they passed through the Red-sea, as by dry <transChange>land,</transChange> which the Egyptians attempting <transChange>to do</transChange> were drowned.
Hebrews 11:30 By faith the walls of Jericho fell down, after they had been encompassed seven days.
Hebrews 11:31 By faith Rahab the harlot perished not with the unbelievers, having received the spies with peace.
Hebrews 11:32 And what need I say more? for the time would fail me to tell of Gideon, and Barak, and Sampson, and Jephthah, and David, and Samuel, and of the prophets:
Hebrews 11:33 who by faith subdued kingdoms, worked righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,
Hebrews 11:34 quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, from weakness were made powerful, became strong in battle, <transChange>and</transChange> turned to flight the armies of <transChange>their</transChange> enemies.
Hebrews 11:35 Women received their dead raised to life again; and others were tortured <transChange>to death,</transChange> not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.
Hebrews 11:36 And others had the trial of mockings and scourgings, and of bonds too and imprisonment.
Hebrews 11:37 They were stoned, they were sawn asunder, were tempted, were slain by the sword: they went about in sheep-skins, and goat-skins, being destitute, afflicted,
Hebrews 11:38 distressed, (of whom the world was not worthy) wandering in deserts, and mountains, and dens, and caves of the earth.
Hebrews 11:39 And these all, though they obtained an <transChange>honorable</transChange> testimony by faith, <transChange>yet</transChange> received not the promise;
Hebrews 11:40 God having provided something better concerning us, that without us they might not be made perfect. <chapter eID="gen7262" osisID="Heb.11"/>
Hebrews 12:0 <chapter osisID="Heb.12" sID="gen7303"/>
Hebrews 12:1 Having therefore so great a cloud of witnesses surrounding us, let us lay aside every incumbrance, and the sin that easily besets <transChange>us,</transChange> and run with patience the race <transChange>that is</transChange> set before us,
Hebrews 12:2 looking unto Jesus the leader and finisher of <transChange>our</transChange> faith; who for the joy <transChange>that was</transChange> set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.
Hebrews 12:3 Wherefore consider Him who endured such contradiction of sinners against Himself, that ye may not give out, fainting in your minds:
Hebrews 12:4 <transChange>for</transChange> ye have not resisted unto blood <transChange>in</transChange> striving against sin.
Hebrews 12:5 Have ye forgotten the exhortation, which speaketh to you as to sons, <transChange>saying,</transChange> "My son, despise not the chastening of the Lord, nor saint when rebuked by Him?
Hebrews 12:6 for whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth."
Hebrews 12:7 If ye endure chastening, God treateth you as sons; for what son is there, whom the father doth not chastise?
Hebrews 12:8 But if ye be without chastisement, of which all are partakers, then are ye bastards and not sons.
Hebrews 12:9 Now if we had fathers of our flesh, who corrected <transChange>us,</transChange> and we gave them reverence; shall we not much more be in subjection to the Father of spirits, and live?
Hebrews 12:10 For they indeed corrected <transChange>us</transChange> for a while, as seemed good to them; but He for our profit, that we may be partakers of his holiness.
Hebrews 12:11 Now no chastening seems for the present to be <transChange>matter</transChange> of joy but of grief: and yet afterwards it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness to those that are exercised thereby.
Hebrews 12:12 Lift up therefore the hands that hang down, and <transChange>strengthen</transChange> the feeble knees.
Hebrews 12:13 And make strait paths for your feet, that <transChange>what is</transChange> lame may not be turned out of the way, but rather be healed.
Hebrews 12:14 Follow peace with all <transChange>men;</transChange> and holiness, without which none shall see the Lord:
Hebrews 12:15 looking to it, least <transChange>there be</transChange> any one falling short of the grace of God, least any root of bitterness springing up should be troublesome, and by it many be defiled:
Hebrews 12:16 least <transChange>there be</transChange> any fornicator, or profane <transChange>person,</transChange> as Esau, who for one repast gave away his birthright.
Hebrews 12:17 For ye know that, when he would afterwards have inherited the blessing, he was rejected: for he found no room for repentance, though he sought it earnestly <transChange>even</transChange> with tears.
Hebrews 12:18 Ye are not come to a tangible mountain, and burning fire, and a thick cloud, and darkness, and tempest,
Hebrews 12:19 and the sound of a trumpet, and the voice of words, which they that heard, intreated that the word might not any more be <transChange>thus</transChange> delivered to them:
Hebrews 12:20 (for they could not bear the <transChange>strict</transChange> command, if so much as a beast touch the mountain, it shall be stoned, or shot through with a dart;
Hebrews 12:21 and so terrible was the appearance <transChange>that</transChange> Moses said, I exceedingly fear and tremble:)
Hebrews 12:22 but ye are come to mount Sion, and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to myriads of angels,
Hebrews 12:23 to the general assembly and church of the first-born who are written in heaven, and to God the judge of all, and to the spirits of the just made perfect,
Hebrews 12:24 and to Jesus the mediator of the new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling, that speaketh better <transChange>things</transChange> than Abel.
Hebrews 12:25 See that ye reject not Him that speaketh; for if they escaped not, who rejected him that gave forth divine oracles on earth, much less <transChange>shall</transChange> we, if we turn away from Him that <transChange>speaketh</transChange> from heaven:
Hebrews 12:26 whose voice then shook the earth; but now He hath promised, saying, "Yet once <transChange>more</transChange> I shake not only the earth, but also the heaven."
Hebrews 12:27 Now this <transChange>expression</transChange> "yet once more" signifieth the removing of the things that are shaken, as of things which had been appointed <transChange>only for a season,</transChange> that those <transChange>which cannot be</transChange> shaken may remain.
Hebrews 12:28 Wherefore since we receive a kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us have grace whereby we may serve God acceptably with reverence and holy fear:
Hebrews 12:29 for our God is a consuming fire. <chapter eID="gen7303" osisID="Heb.12"/>

Hebrews 13:1 Let brotherly love continue.
Hebrews 13:2 Be not forgetful of hospitality; for thereby some have entertained angels, not knowing <transChange>it.</transChange>

Hebrews 13:4 Marriage <transChange>is</transChange> honorable in all, and the bed <transChange>is</transChange> not defiled: but whoremongers and adulterers God will judge.

Hebrews 13:7 Remember your guides, who spake the word of God to you; whose faith imitate, considering the <transChange>happy</transChange> end of <transChange>their</transChange> conversation.

Hebrews 13:12 Wherefore Jesus also, that He might sanctify the people by his own blood, suffered without the gate.

James 1:0 <chapter osisID="Jas.1" sID="gen7360"/>
James 1:1 <hi type="bold">James</hi> a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes in dispersion <transChange>sendeth</transChange> greeting.
James 1:2 Account it all joy, my brethren, when ye fall into various trials:
James 1:3 knowing <transChange>this,</transChange> that the trial of your faith worketh patience;
James 1:4 but let patience have <transChange>it's</transChange> perfect work, that ye may be entirely perfect, failing in nothing.
James 1:5 And if any of you lack wisdom, let him ask <transChange>it</transChange> of God, who giveth to all <transChange>men</transChange> liberally and upbraideth not, and it shall be given him.
James 1:6 But let him ask in faith, nothing doubting; for he that doubteth is like a wave of the sea blown about and tossed by the wind.
James 1:7 Let not that man think that he shall receive any thing from the Lord.
James 1:8 A double-minded man <transChange>is</transChange> inconstant in all his ways.
James 1:9 Let the brother <transChange>that is</transChange> low rejoice in his exaltation: but the rich in his humiliation,
James 1:10 because as the flower of the grass he shall pass away.
James 1:11 For when the sun is risen with <transChange>it's</transChange> sultry heat, it drieth up the grass, and the flower of, it falleth, and the beauty of it's appearance is lost: so shall the rich man fade away in his projects.
James 1:12 Happy <transChange>is</transChange> the man who sustaineth temptation; for being approved he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love Him.
James 1:13 Let no one that is tempted say, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted by evils, and He tempteth no one.
James 1:14 But every <transChange>man</transChange> is tempted, <transChange>when</transChange> drawn aside and insnared by his own <transChange>vehement</transChange> desire.
James 1:15 Then desire having conceived bringeth forth sin, and sin when it is finished bringeth forth death.
James 1:16 Be not <transChange>therefore</transChange> deceived, my beloved brethren: <transChange>for</transChange> every good gift,
James 1:17 and every perfect gift, <transChange>but no evil one,</transChange> is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation, nor shadow of turning:
James 1:18 who hath of his own will begotten us by the word of truth, that we might be a kind of first-fruits of his creatures.
James 1:19 Wherefore, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath:
James 1:20 for the wrath of man doth not practise the righteousness of God.
James 1:21 Laying aside therefore all filthiness, and excess of malice, receive with meekness the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.
James 1:22 But be doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving yourselves.
James 1:23 For if any be a hearer of the word, and not a doer, he is like a man beholding his natural face in a mirror,
James 1:24 who beheld himself, and went away, and immediately forgot what manner of man he was.
James 1:25 But he that looketh well into the perfect law of liberty, and continueth <transChange>therein,</transChange> being not a forgetful hearer, but a doer of the work, this <transChange>man</transChange> shall be blessed in his deed.
James 1:26 If any among you seem to be religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceiveth his heart, this man's devotion <transChange>is</transChange> vain.
James 1:27 Pure and uncorrupt religion before God and <transChange>our</transChange> Father is this, to take care of orphans and widows in their affliction, and to keep himself unspotted from the world. <chapter eID="gen7360" osisID="Jas.1"/>
James 2:0 <chapter osisID="Jas.2" sID="gen7388"/>
James 2:1 My brethren, hold not the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ, <transChange>the Lord</transChange> of glory, in a <transChange>partial</transChange> respect of persons.
James 2:2 For if there come into your synagogue a man with a gold ring in fine clothes, and there come in also a poor <transChange>man</transChange> in a mean habit;
James 2:3 and ye turn your eyes toward him that weareth the fine clothes, and say to him, Sit thou here in an honorable place; and say to the poor <transChange>man,</transChange> Stand thou there, or sit here under my footstool:
James 2:4 do ye not make a <transChange>partial</transChange> difference within yourselves, and become judges that reason wickedly?
James 2:5 Hear, my beloved brethren; hath not God chosen the poor of this world <transChange>who are</transChange> rich in faith, and heirs of the kingdom, which He hath promised to them that love Him? but ye have slighted the poor.
James 2:6 Do not the rich tyrannize over you; and drag you to <transChange>their</transChange> tribunals?
James 2:7 Do they not blaspheme the glorious name by which ye are called?
James 2:8 If ye fulfil the royal law, according to the scripture, <transChange>which saith,</transChange> Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself, ye do well.
James 2:9 But if ye <transChange>partially</transChange> respect persons, ye commit sin, being convicted by the law as transgressors.
James 2:10 For whosoever shall keep the whole law <transChange>besides,</transChange> but offend in one <transChange>point,</transChange> he is under the penalty of all:
James 2:11 for He that said, Do not commit adultery, said also, Do not kill. Now if thou do not commit adultery, but committest murder, thou art a transgressor of the law.
James 2:12 So speak, and so act, as those who are to be judged by the law of liberty.
James 2:13 For he shall have judgement without mercy, that hath not shewn mercy: but mercy triumpheth over judgement.
James 2:14 What <transChange>is</transChange> the advantage, my brethren, if any <transChange>one</transChange> say that he has faith, and he hath not works, can faith <transChange>alone</transChange> save him?
James 2:15 If a brother or sister be naked, and destitute of daily food;
James 2:16 and one of you say to them, Go in peace, be ye warmed and be ye filled: but ye give them not the necessaries of life, what profit <transChange>is it to them?</transChange>
James 2:17 so faith, if it have not works, being alone, is dead.
James 2:18 But one may say, Thou hast faith, and I have works: shew me thy faith by thy works, and I will shew thee my faith by my works.
James 2:19 Thou believest that there is one God; thou dost well: the devils also believe and tremble.
James 2:20 But desirest thou to know, O vain man, that faith without works, is dead?
James 2:21 <transChange>consider,</transChange> Was not our father Abraham justified by works, when he offered his son Isaac upon the altar?
James 2:22 Thou seest that faith co-operated with his works, and <transChange>that</transChange> by <transChange>his</transChange> works <transChange>his</transChange> faith was perfected.
James 2:23 And the scripture was fulfilled, which saith, Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him for righteousness; and he was called the friend of God.
James 2:24 Ye see then that a man is justified by works, and not by faith only.
James 2:25 And in like manner also was not the harlot Rahab justified by works, when she entertained the spies, and let them out another way?
James 2:26 For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead also. <chapter eID="gen7388" osisID="Jas.2"/>
James 3:0 <chapter osisID="Jas.3" sID="gen7415"/>
James 3:1 My brethren, be not many teachers, knowing that we <transChange>who are such</transChange> shall pass a stricter trial <transChange>than others:</transChange> for in many things we all offend;
James 3:2 <transChange>and</transChange> if any offend not in word, he is a compleat man, able to manage also the whole body.
James 3:3 Behold we put bridles into the mouths of horses, that they may obey us, and we turn their whole body <transChange>as we please.</transChange>
James 3:4 Behold also the ships which are of so great bulk, <transChange>and</transChange> even when <transChange>they are</transChange> driven by hard winds, <transChange>yet</transChange> are turned about by a very small helm which way soever the pilot pleaseth.
James 3:5 So the tongue is a small part <transChange>of the body,</transChange> yet boasteth great things. Behold how much fuel a little fire kindleth!
James 3:6 And the tongue <transChange>is</transChange> a fire, a world of iniquity: so is the tongue among our <transChange>several</transChange> parts, defiling the whole body, inflaming the course of nature, and <transChange>is</transChange> set on fire by hell.
James 3:7 For every kind of wild beasts, and birds, and reptiles, and fishes, is tamed and hath been tamed by mankind:
James 3:8 but the tongue can no man tame; <transChange>it is</transChange> an unruly evil, full of deadly poison.
James 3:9 With it we bless God even the Father; and with it we curse men, who are made after the likeness of God:
James 3:10 out of the same mouth proceedeth blessing and cursing. These things, my brethren, ought not so to be.
James 3:11 Does a fountain from the same opening send forth sweet <transChange>water</transChange> and bitter?
James 3:12 Can a fig-tree, my brethren, produce olives, or a vine figs? so <transChange>can</transChange> no fountain produce salt water and sweet.
James 3:13 <transChange>Is there</transChange> any wise and understanding <transChange>man</transChange> among you? let him shew his works by a good conversation in the meekness of wisdom:
James 3:14 but if ye have bitter envy and strife in your hearts, do not boast and lie against the truth;

James 3:16 for where envying and strife <transChange>is,</transChange> there is confusion and every evil work.

James 3:18 And the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace for those that promote peace. <chapter eID="gen7415" osisID="Jas.3"/>

James 4:1 Whence <transChange>come</transChange> wars and fightings among you? <transChange>Come they</transChange> not hence? <transChange>even</transChange> of your <transChange>carnal</transChange> appetites making war in your bodies?

James 4:3 Ye ask and receive not, because ye ask wickedly; that ye may spend <transChange>it</transChange> in your pleasures.
James 4:4 Ye adulterers and adulteresses, know ye not that the friendship of the world <transChange>is</transChange> enmity to God? whosoever therefore will be a friend of the world becomes an enemy of God.
James 4:5 Do ye think the scripture speaks in vain? <transChange>or</transChange> does the Spirit that dwelleth in us, excite to envy?
James 4:6 No, He giveth more grace: wherefore it is said, God resisteth the proud, but sheweth favor to the humble.
James 4:7 Submit yourselves therefore to God: resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
James 4:8 Draw near to God, and He will draw near to you: cleanse your hands, O sinners, and purify your hearts, ye double minded.

James 4:13 Come now, ye that say, To-day or to-morrow we will go to such a city, and spend a year there, and trade and get gain;

James 5:1 Weep now, ye rich men, and howl for your miseries which are coming upon <transChange>you.</transChange>
James 5:2 Your riches are corrupted, and your garments are moth-eaten:
James 5:3 your gold and silver is cankered, and their rust shall be a witness against you, and shall eat your flesh like fire: ye have been treasuring <transChange>them</transChange> up for the<transChange>se</transChange> last days.
James 5:4 Behold the hire of the laborers, that reaped your fields, of which they are defrauded by you, crieth out <transChange>against you:</transChange> and the complaints of the reapers are come into the ears of the Lord of hosts.
James 5:5 Ye have lived upon earth delicately and luxuriously; ye fattened your hearts as in a day of slaughter.
James 5:6 Ye have condemned, ye have murdered the just <transChange>one, who</transChange> resisted you not.
James 5:7 Wait patiently therefore, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, till the coming of the Lord: behold the husbandman expecteth the precious fruit of the earth, waiting patiently for it, till he receive the former and the latter rain.
James 5:8 Be ye also patient, establish your hearts; for the coming of the Lord is near.
James 5:9 Repine not, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, against each other, that ye be not condemned: behold, the judge is at the door.
James 5:10 Take for an example of enduring evil and of long-suffering the prophets, who spake in the name of the Lord.
James 5:11 Behold, we account those happy, that are patient. Ye have heard of the patience of Job, and have seen the end of the Lord, that the Lord is very compassionate and merciful.
James 5:12 But above all, my brethren, swear not; neither by heaven, nor by the earth, nor any other oath: but let your yea be yea, and your nay nay; that ye may not fall under condemnation.
James 5:13 Is any among you afflicted? let him pray: is any chearful? let him sing psalms.
James 5:14 Is any sick among you? let him call for the elders of the church; and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord:
James 5:15 and the prayer of faith shall save the sick, and the Lord will raise him up; and if he have committed sins, they shall be forgiven him.
James 5:16 Confess <transChange>your</transChange> faults one to another, and pray for one another, that ye may be healed: the fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much.
James 5:17 Elias was a man of like passions with us, and he prayed earnestly that it might not rain, and it rained not upon the land for three years and six months:
James 5:18 and he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth put forth its fruit.
James 5:19 Brethren, if any among you be seduced from the truth, and one convert him;
James 5:20 let him know that he, who turneth back a sinner from the error of his way, shall save a soul from death, and shall cover a multitude of sins. <chapter eID="gen7452" osisID="Jas.5"/> <div eID="gen7359" osisID="Jas" type="book"/>

I Peter 1:1 <hi type="bold">Peter</hi> an apostle of Jesus Christ to the strangers <transChange>who</transChange> <transChange>are</transChange> dispersed through Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia,
I Peter 1:2 Asia, and Bithynia, chosen according to the fore-knowledge of God, through sanctification of the Spirit, unto obedience, and <transChange>to</transChange> the sprinkling of the blood of Jesus Christ,---may grace and peace be multiplied unto you.
I Peter 1:3 Blessed <transChange>be</transChange> the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who according to his abundant mercy hath regenerated us to a lively hope, by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
I Peter 1:4 to an inheritance incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading, reserved in heaven for you,
I Peter 1:5 who are kept by the power of God through faith unto salvation ready to be revealed in the last time.
I Peter 1:6 In which ye rejoice, tho' now for a little while, if need be, ye are grieved through various trials.
I Peter 1:7 That the proof of your faith, <transChange>which is</transChange> much more precious than of gold, (that perisheth, though tried by fire) may be found unto praise, and honor, and glory, when Jesus Christ shall be revealed:
I Peter 1:8 whom having not seen ye love; in whom, though now ye see Him not, yet believing ye rejoice with joy ineffable and full of glory; receiving the end of your faith,
I Peter 1:9 <transChange>even</transChange> the salvation of your souls:
I Peter 1:10 concerning which salvation the prophets, who prophesied of the grace <transChange>to be conferred</transChange> on you, enquired and diligently sought after <transChange>it:</transChange>
I Peter 1:11 searching what, or what manner of time the Spirit of Christ in them did declare <transChange>in</transChange> testifying beforehand the sufferings <transChange>that were to come</transChange> upon Christ, and the glories following them:
I Peter 1:12 to whom it was revealed, that <transChange>it was</transChange> not to themselves, but to us they ministered these <transChange>things,</transChange> which are now declared unto you by them that have preached the gospel unto you, through the holy Spirit sent down from heaven; which things the angels desire to look into.
I Peter 1:13 Wherefore girding up the loins of your mind, be sober, and stedfastly hope for the grace to be conferred upon you at the appearing of Jesus Christ;
I Peter 1:14 as children of obedience, not conforming yourselves to the former lusts in your ignorance:
I Peter 1:15 but as He who hath called you is holy, be ye also holy in all <transChange>your</transChange> conversation: since it is written,

I Peter 1:17 And if ye call upon the Father, who without respect of persons judgeth according to every man's work, pass the time of your sojourning here in fear:
I Peter 1:18 knowing that ye were redeemed from your vain conversation <transChange>learned</transChange> by tradition from your fathers, not with corruptible things, <transChange>as</transChange> silver and gold;
I Peter 1:19 but with the precious blood of Christ as <transChange>of</transChange> a lamb without blemish and without spot:
I Peter 1:20 <transChange>who was</transChange> indeed appointed before the foundation of the world, but manifested in these last times, for your sakes,
I Peter 1:21 who through Him trust in God that raised Him from the dead, and gave Him glory, that your faith and hope might be <transChange>fixed</transChange> in God.
I Peter 1:22 Having <transChange>therefore</transChange> purified your souls by obedience to the truth, through the Spirit, to brotherly love unfeigned, love one another with a pure heart fervently:
I Peter 1:23 being regenerated not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible, by the word of God which liveth and abideth for ever.
I Peter 1:24 For all flesh <transChange>is</transChange> as grass, and all the glory of man as the flower of grass: the grass withereth, and the flower thereof falleth away;
I Peter 1:25 but the word of the Lord abideth for ever. And this is the word which is preached to you in the gospel. <chapter eID="gen7474" osisID="1Pet.1"/>

I Peter 2:1 Therefore laying aside all malice, and all deceit, and hypocrisies,
I Peter 2:2 and envies, and all evil-speakings, as new-born babes desire that rational milk <transChange>which is</transChange> without guile, that ye may grow thereby:
I Peter 2:3 for ye have tasted that the Lord <transChange>is</transChange> gracious;
I Peter 2:4 to whom coming <transChange>as to</transChange> a living stone, rejected indeed by men, but chosen of God,
I Peter 2:5 <transChange>and</transChange> precious, ye also are built up as living stones, a spiritual house, an holy priesthood to offer up spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God by Jesus Christ.
I Peter 2:6 Whence also it is said in scripture, Behold I lay in Sion a chief corner-stone, choice <transChange>and</transChange> precious: and he that confideth on it shall not be ashamed.
I Peter 2:7 To you therefore who believe <transChange>it is</transChange> precious: but to them that are disobedient, the stone which the builders rejected is become the head of the corner,
I Peter 2:8 and a stone of stumbling, and a rock of offence. These stumble at the word through unbelief, unto which also they were appointed.

I Peter 2:10 who heretofore <transChange>were</transChange> not a people, but <transChange>are</transChange> now the people of God: who had not obtained mercy, but now have obtained mercy.
I Peter 2:11 <transChange>Dearly</transChange> beloved, I exhort you as strangers and sojourners <transChange>here,</transChange> to abstain from carnal lusts, which war against the soul:
I Peter 2:12 having a good conversation among the Gentiles; that whereas they speak against you as evil-doers, they may glorify God in the day of <transChange>their</transChange> visitation, on account of the good works which they behold <transChange>in you.</transChange>
I Peter 2:13 Be subject therefore to every human form of government, for the Lord's sake: whether <transChange>it</transChange> be to a king as supreme;
I Peter 2:14 or to governors as <transChange>persons</transChange> sent by him for the punishment of evil-doers, and <transChange>the</transChange> praise of them that do well.
I Peter 2:15 For so is the will of God, that by <transChange>your</transChange> good behaviour ye may silence the ignorance of foolish <transChange>men:</transChange>
I Peter 2:16 as free, and <transChange>yet</transChange> not using <transChange>your</transChange> liberty as a cloke for wickedness, but as <transChange>the</transChange> servants of God.
I Peter 2:17 Give <transChange>due</transChange> honor to all <transChange>men.</transChange> Love the brotherhood. Fear God. Honour the king.
I Peter 2:18 Ye <transChange>who are</transChange> servants, <transChange>be</transChange> subject to <transChange>your</transChange> masters with all fear, not only to the good and mild, but also to the morose:
I Peter 2:19 for this is <transChange>an evidence of</transChange> grace, if any one for conscience towards God endure griefs, suffering unjustly.
I Peter 2:20 For what glory <transChange>is it,</transChange> if when ye sin and are punished <transChange>for it,</transChange> ye bear it patiently? but if when ye do well and suffer <transChange>for it,</transChange> ye bear it patiently, this <transChange>will gain</transChange> favor with God.
I Peter 2:21 For unto this are ye called; because Christ suffered for you, leaving you an example, that ye might follow his steps.
I Peter 2:22 Who did no sin, neither was guile found in his mouth:
I Peter 2:23 who, when He was reviled, reviled not again; when He suffered, He threatened not; but committed <transChange>Himself</transChange> to Him that judgeth righteously.
I Peter 2:24 Who Himself bare our sins in his own body on the cross, that we being dead to sins, might live unto righteousness: by whose stripes ye are healed.
I Peter 2:25 For ye were as sheep going astray; but are now turned unto the shepherd and bishop of your souls. <chapter eID="gen7500" osisID="1Pet.2"/>

I Peter 3:1 Ye women likewise, be subject to your own husbands, that if any believe not the word, they may yet without the word be gained over by the deportment of the wives,
I Peter 3:2 beholding your chaste conversation in <transChange>the</transChange> fear <transChange>of God.</transChange>
I Peter 3:3 Whose adorning, let it not be that without, of plaiting the hair, and putting on of gold, or wearing <transChange>fine</transChange> clothes;
I Peter 3:4 but the hidden man of the heart, in the incorruptible <transChange>ornament</transChange> of a meek and quiet spirit, which is in the sight of God of great price.
I Peter 3:5 For so also formerly the holy women, who hoped in God, adorned themselves, being submissive to their husbands; as Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him <transChange>her</transChange> lord:
I Peter 3:6 whose daughters ye are, if ye do well, and are not terrified with any <transChange>sinful</transChange> fear.
I Peter 3:7 Ye husbands likewise, dwell with <transChange>them</transChange> according to knowledge, yielding due respect to the wife as the weaker vessel, and as joint-heirs of the grace of life; that your prayers be not hindered.
I Peter 3:8 Finally, <transChange>my beloved, be</transChange> unanimous, <transChange>be</transChange> sympathizing, love as brethren, <transChange>be</transChange> compassionate, <transChange>be</transChange> courteous:
I Peter 3:9 not returning evil for evil, or reproach for reproach: but on the contrary blessing <transChange>even those that curse you:</transChange> knowing ye are called unto this, that ye may obtain a blessing.
I Peter 3:10 "For he that would desire life, and see good days, let him refrain his tongue from evil, and his lips that they speak no guile;
I Peter 3:11 let him turn away from evil, and do good:
I Peter 3:12 let him seek peace, and pursue it: for the eyes of the Lord <transChange>are</transChange> upon the righteous, and his ears <transChange>are open</transChange> to their prayer: but the face of the Lord <transChange>is</transChange> against them that do evil."
I Peter 3:13 And who will hurt you, if ye be imitators of Him that is good?
I Peter 3:14 But if ye should even suffer for righteousness sake, happy <transChange>are ye:</transChange> and <transChange>therefore</transChange> be not afraid of their menaces, neither be troubled; but sanctify the Lord God in your hearts:
I Peter 3:15 and be always ready to answer every one that asketh you a reason of the hope <transChange>that is</transChange> in you, with meekness and reverence:
I Peter 3:16 having a good conscience, that whereas they speak against you as evil-doers, they may be ashamed who calumniate your good conversation in Christ.
I Peter 3:17 For <transChange>it is</transChange> better (if it be the will of God) to suffer <transChange>for</transChange> doing good than <transChange>for</transChange> doing evil.
I Peter 3:18 As Christ also once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust (that He might introduce us to God) being indeed put to death in the flesh, but raised to life by the Spirit:
I Peter 3:19 by which also He went and preached to the spirits <transChange>now</transChange> in prison;
I Peter 3:20 who of old were disobedient, when the long-suffering of God waited in the days of Noah, while the ark was preparing; wherein <transChange>a</transChange> few, that is eight souls, were saved by water.
I Peter 3:21 The resemblance of which, <transChange>even</transChange> baptism, doth also now save us, (not the <transChange>outward</transChange> cleansing of filth from the flesh, but the answer of a good conscience towards God) by the resurrection of Jesus Christ,

I Peter 4:0 <chapter osisID="1Pet.4" sID="gen7549"/>
I Peter 4:1 Seeing therefore Christ hath suffered for us in the flesh, arm yourselves likewise with the same thought, that he, who hath mortified the flesh, hath ceased from sin;
I Peter 4:2 that he should no longer live the rest of <transChange>his</transChange> time in the flesh according to the lusts of men, but after the will of God.
I Peter 4:3 For the time past of <transChange>our</transChange> life <transChange>is</transChange> sufficient for us to have wrought the will of the Gentiles, walking in lasciviousness, <transChange>inordinate</transChange> desires, excess of wine, revellings, drunkenness, and abominable idolatries:
I Peter 4:4 in which they think it strange that ye run not with <transChange>them</transChange> into the same excess of riot, and <transChange>therefore</transChange> speak evil <transChange>of you:</transChange>
I Peter 4:5 who shall give an account to Him, who is ready to judge the living and the dead.
I Peter 4:6 For to this <transChange>end</transChange> was the gospel preached also to them that are dead, that they might be judged indeed according to men in the flesh, but might live according to God in the spirit.
I Peter 4:7 But the end of all <transChange>things</transChange> draws nigh: be ye therefore sober, and watch unto prayer:
I Peter 4:8 having above all things fervent love to each other; for love will cover a multitude of sins.
I Peter 4:9 <transChange>Be</transChange> hospitable one to another, without grudging;
I Peter 4:10 as every one hath received a gift, imparting it to each other, as good stewards of the manifold grace of God.
I Peter 4:11 If any one speak, <transChange>let it be</transChange> as <transChange>declaring</transChange> the oracles of God: if any one minister, <transChange>let it be</transChange> as from the power which God affordeth <transChange>him:</transChange> that in all <transChange>things</transChange> God may be glorified through Jesus Christ, to whom be the glory and dominion for ever and ever. I Peter 4:13 but rejoice in that ye are partakers in the sufferings of Christ; that, when his glory shall be revealed, ye may also rejoice with exceeding joy.
I Peter 4:14 If ye be reproached for the name of Christ, happy <transChange>are ye;</transChange> for the Spirit of glory and of God resteth upon you: <transChange>and</transChange> though as to them He is blasphemed, yet as to you He is glorified.
I Peter 4:15 But let none of you suffer as a murderer, or <transChange>as</transChange> a thief, or <transChange>as</transChange> a malefactor, or as an intermeddler with other people's affairs.
I Peter 4:16 But if <transChange>any suffer</transChange> as a Christian, let him not be ashamed; but let him glorify God herein.

I Peter 4:18 And if the righteous be saved with difficulty, where shall the ungodly and the sinner appear?
I Peter 4:19 Wherefore let them, that suffer according to the will of God, commit their souls in well-doing <transChange>to Him</transChange> as to a faithful Creator. <chapter eID="gen7549" osisID="1Pet.4"/>

I Peter 5:1 The elders that are among you I exhort, who am also an elder and a witness of the sufferings of Christ, and a partaker of the glory which shall be revealed; feed the flock of God that is among you,
I Peter 5:2 taking the episcopal charge <transChange>of it,</transChange> not by constraint, but willingly; not for shameful lucre, but with a ready mind:
I Peter 5:3 nor as lording it over the people, but being examples to the flock.
I Peter 5:4 And when the sovereign Shepherd shall appear, ye shall receive an unfading crown of glory.
I Peter 5:5 Likewise ye younger, be subject to the elder; and all <transChange>of you behaving</transChange> with <transChange>due</transChange> submission one to another, be clothed with humility: for God resisteth the proud, but sheweth favor to the humble.
I Peter 5:6 Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due time;
I Peter 5:7 casting all your care upon Him, for He careth for you.
I Peter 5:8 Be sober, be vigilant; for your adversary the devil, like a roaring lion, walketh about, seeking whom he may devour:
I Peter 5:9 whom resist, stedfast in the faith, knowing that the same sufferings are endured by your brethren in the world.
I Peter 5:10 But may the God of all grace, who hath called us to his eternal glory in Christ Jesus, after ye have suffered a little while, make you perfect, confirm, strengthen, <transChange>and</transChange> establish <transChange>you.</transChange>
I Peter 5:11 To Him <transChange>be</transChange> glory and dominion for ever and ever. Amen.

II Peter 1:1 <hi type="bold">Simon</hi> Peter, a servant and an apostle of Jesus Christ, to them that have obtained like precious faith with us, in the righteousness of our God, and <transChange>of our</transChange> saviour Jesus Christ:
II Peter 1:2 grace and peace be multiplied unto you, in the acknowledgement of God, and of Jesus our Lord;
II Peter 1:3 as his divine power hath given us all <transChange>things</transChange> that <transChange>pertain</transChange> to life and godliness, through the knowledge of Him who hath called us by <transChange>that</transChange> glory and virtue,
II Peter 1:4 by which are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises; that by these ye may become partakers of a divine nature, having escaped the corruption <transChange>that is</transChange> in the world through lust.
II Peter 1:5 And to this giving all diligence, add to your faith fortitude;
II Peter 1:6 and to fortitude knowledge; and to knowledge temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience piety;
II Peter 1:7 and to piety brotherly affection; and to brotherly affection charity.
II Peter 1:8 For if these be in you and abound, they will not suffer <transChange>you</transChange> to be idle, nor unfruitful in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.
II Peter 1:9 But he, that hath not these, is blind, <transChange>or</transChange> short-sighted, having forgot his <transChange>baptismal</transChange> purification from his former sins.
II Peter 1:10 Wherefore, <transChange>my</transChange> brethren, be the more diligent <transChange>thus</transChange> to make your calling and election sure; for if ye do these <transChange>things</transChange> ye shall never fall.
II Peter 1:11 For so an entrance shall be administered unto you abundantly into the everlasting kingdom of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.
II Peter 1:12 Wherefore I will not neglect to put you always in mind of these <transChange>things,</transChange> though ye know them, and are established in the present truth.
II Peter 1:13 And I think it my duty, while I am in this tabernacle, to stir you up by way of remembrance:
II Peter 1:14 knowing that I must soon lay down <transChange>this</transChange> my tabernacle, even as our Lord Jesus Christ hath shewed me.
II Peter 1:15 And I will endeavour that after my departure also ye may always be able to call these <transChange>things</transChange> to remembrance.
II Peter 1:16 For we did not follow artfully devised fables, when we made known unto you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ; but were eye-witnesses of his majesty.
II Peter 1:17 For He received from God the Father honor and glory when a voice came to Him from the magnificent glory, <transChange>saying</transChange>, "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."
II Peter 1:18 And this voice, from heaven we heard, when we were with Him in the holy mount.
II Peter 1:19 We have also the more sure word of the prophets, to which ye do well to attend, as to a lamp shining in a dark place, till the day dawn, and the morning-star rise in your hearts:
II Peter 1:20 knowing this first, that no prophecy of scripture is of private interpretation;
II Peter 1:21 for prophecy was not delivered of old at the will of man, but holy men of God spake as they were moved by the holy Spirit. <chapter eID="gen7585" osisID="2Pet.1"/>
II Peter 2:0 <chapter osisID="2Pet.2" sID="gen7607"/>
II Peter 2:1 But there were indeed false prophets among the people <transChange>of old,</transChange> as there will be also among you false teachers, who will privately introduce pernicious heresies, denying even the Lord that bought them, <transChange>and</transChange> bringing upon themselves swift destruction,
II Peter 2:2 And many will follow their pernicious tenets, on whose account the way of truth will be reproached:
II Peter 2:3 and by artful speeches they will make sale of you for gain. Whose judgement is long since hastening, and their destruction doth not slumber.
II Peter 2:4 For if God spared not the angels that sinned, but cast <transChange>them</transChange> down to hell, and delivered <transChange>them</transChange> into chains of darkness, <transChange>to be</transChange> reserved unto judgement; and <transChange>if</transChange> He spared not the old world,
II Peter 2:5 (but preserved Noah an eighth <transChange>person,</transChange> a preacher of righteousness,) bringing a deluge upon the world of the ungodly;
II Peter 2:6 and reducing the cities of Sodom and Gomorrha to ashes, condemned <transChange>them</transChange> to destruction, making <transChange>them</transChange> an example to those that should afterwards be impious;
II Peter 2:7 and delivered righteous Lot grieved at the lewd conversation of the wicked:
II Peter 2:8 (for that good <transChange>man</transChange> by seeing and hearing <transChange>their crimes,</transChange> when he dwelt among them, tormented his righteous soul from day to day with <transChange>their</transChange>
II Peter 2:9 iniquitous deeds) <transChange>then</transChange> the Lord knoweth how to deliver the pious from temptation, and to reserve the wicked to the day of judgement <transChange>to be</transChange> punished:
II Peter 2:10 especially those who walk after the flesh in the lust of uncleanness, and despise authority; <transChange>who, being</transChange> audacious <transChange>and</transChange> self-willed, are not afraid to speak evil of dignities:
II Peter 2:11 whereas angels, who are greater in strength and power, bring not a reviling accusation against them before the Lord.
II Peter 2:12 But these <transChange>men,</transChange> like brute beasts naturally produced to be taken and destroyed, speaking evil of things which they do not understand, shall perish by their own corruption; receiving the reward of <transChange>their</transChange> unrighteousness:
II Peter 2:13 who account it a pleasure to riot <transChange>even</transChange> in the day; spots and disgraces; revelling in their frauds, while they partake of your feasts:
II Peter 2:14 having eyes full of adultery, and which cannot be restrained from sin: ensnaring unstable souls, <transChange>and</transChange> having a heart practised in rapine; cursed people:
II Peter 2:15 who have forsaken the right way, and are gone astray, having followed the way of Balaam <transChange>the son</transChange> of Bosor, who loved the wages of iniquity;
II Peter 2:16 but was reproved for his transgression: <transChange>for</transChange> a dumb beast speaking with the voice of a man checked the madness of the prophet.
II Peter 2:17 These are wells without water, clouds driven by a storm, for whom thick darkness is reserved for ever.
II Peter 2:18 For when they speak swelling words of vanity, they ensnare in the lusts of the flesh, through <transChange>their</transChange> lasciviousness, those who had indeed withdrawn from such as deal in error;
II Peter 2:19 promising them liberty, while they themselves are the slaves of corruption: for by whom any one is vanquished, by him he is also enslaved.
II Peter 2:20 For if, after they had escaped the pollutions of the world, through the knowledge of the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, they are again entangled and vanquished by them, their last state is worse than the first;
II Peter 2:21 for it had been better for them not to have known the way of righteousness, than when they knew <transChange>it,</transChange> to turn from the holy commandment delivered to them.
II Peter 2:22 But it is happened to them according to the true proverb, The dog <transChange>is</transChange> returned to his own vomit, and, The swine that was washed to <transChange>her</transChange> wallowing in the mire. <chapter eID="gen7607" osisID="2Pet.2"/>

II Peter 3:1 This second epistle, <transChange>my</transChange> beloved, I now write unto you; in <transChange>both</transChange> which I stir up your sincere mind in remembrance,
II Peter 3:2 that ye may be mindful of the words formerly spoken by the holy prophets, and of the commandment of us the apostles of the Lord and Saviour: knowing this first,
II Peter 3:3 that there will come in the last days scoffers,
II Peter 3:4 walking after their own lusts, and saying, Where is the declaration of his coming? for except that the fathers are fallen asleep, all things remain as <transChange>they were</transChange> from the beginning of the creation.
II Peter 3:5 For they are willingly ignorant of this, that by the Word of God the heavens were <transChange>made</transChange> of old, and the earth <transChange>too</transChange> from the water, and subsisting on the water.
II Peter 3:6 Whence the old world being drowned in water perished.
II Peter 3:7 But the heavens and the earth, <transChange>that</transChange> now <transChange>are,</transChange> by the same Word are kept in store, reserved unto fire on the day of judgement and destruction of ungodly men.
II Peter 3:8 But, beloved; be not ignorant of this one <transChange>thing,</transChange> that one day <transChange>is</transChange> with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.
II Peter 3:9 The Lord is not slow as to his promise (as some count <transChange>it</transChange> slowness) but is long-suffering towards us, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance.
II Peter 3:10 But the day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night, in which the heavens shall pass away with a great noise, and the elements being set on fire shall be dissolved, and the earth and the works therein shall be burnt up.
II Peter 3:11 Seeing then that all these <transChange>things</transChange> shall be dissolved, what manner of persons ought ye to be in holy conversation and godliness,
II Peter 3:12 expecting and hastening on the coming of the day of God, whereby the heavens being set on fire shall be dissolved, and the burning elements shall be melted.
II Peter 3:13 But we, according to his promise, look for new heavens and a new earth, in which righteousness dwelleth.
II Peter 3:14 Wherefore, beloved, seeing ye expect these <transChange>things,</transChange> give diligence to be found of Him in peace, spotless and blameless;
II Peter 3:15 and account the long-suffering of our Lord salvation, as our beloved brother Paul also, according to the wisdom given to him, hath written unto you;
II Peter 3:16 as also in all <transChange>his</transChange> epistles, speaking in them of these <transChange>things:</transChange> in which are some <transChange>things</transChange> hard to be understood, which the illiterate and unstable wrest, as <transChange>they do</transChange> also the other scriptures, to their own destruction.
II Peter 3:17 Do ye therefore, beloved, as ye know <transChange>these things</transChange> before, take heed least being seduced together <transChange>with them</transChange> by the error of the wicked, ye should fall from your own stedfastness.
II Peter 3:18 But grow in grace, and in <transChange>the</transChange> knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ: to Him <transChange>be</transChange> glory both now and for ever. Amen. <chapter eID="gen7630" osisID="2Pet.3"/> <div eID="gen7584" osisID="2Pet" type="book"/>

I John 1:1 <hi type="bold">That</hi> which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes, which we have contemplated, and our <transChange>very</transChange> hands have felt concerning the Word of life,
I John 1:2 (for <transChange>this</transChange> Life was manifested, and we saw <transChange>it;</transChange> and we testify and declare unto you <transChange>that</transChange> eternal Life, which was with the Father,
I John 1:3 and was manifested unto us) what we have seen and heard we declare unto you, that ye also may have communion with us: and our communion is with the Father and with his Son Jesus Christ.
I John 1:4 And these <transChange>things</transChange> we write unto you, that your joy may be complete.
I John 1:5 Now this we have heard from Him, and declare unto you, that God is light, and in Him there is no darkness at all.
I John 1:6 If we say that we have communion with Him, and walk in darkness, we lie and do not practise the truth:
I John 1:7 but if we walk in the light, as He is in the light, we have communion with one another, and the blood of Jesus Christ his Son cleanseth us from all sin.
I John 1:8 If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us.
I John 1:9 If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness:
I John 1:10 <transChange>but</transChange> if we say that we have not sinned, we make him a liar, and his word is not in us. <chapter eID="gen7650" osisID="1John.1"/>

I John 2:1 My little children, I write these <transChange>things</transChange> unto you, that ye may not sin. And if any <transChange>man</transChange> sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous.
I John 2:2 And He is the propitiation for our sins; and not for ours only, but also for <transChange>the sins of</transChange> the whole world.
I John 2:3 And by this we know that we have known Him, if we keep his commandments.
I John 2:4 He that saith, I know Him, and keepeth not his commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him.
I John 2:5 But whosoever keepeth his word, in him verily is the love of God perfected: <transChange>and</transChange> by this we know that we are in Him.
I John 2:6 He that saith, he abideth in Him, ought himself also so to walk even as He walked.
I John 2:7 Brethren, I write not a new commandment unto you, but an old commandment which ye had from the beginning: the old commandment is the word which ye have heard from the beginning:
I John 2:8 <transChange>though</transChange> I write <transChange>it</transChange> again <transChange>as</transChange> a new commandment, which is truth in Him and in you: because the darkness is past, and the true light now shineth.

I John 2:10 <transChange>whereas,</transChange> he that loveth his brother, abideth in the light, and is in no danger of stumbling.
I John 2:11 But he, that hateth his brother, is in darkness, and walketh in darkness, and knoweth not where he goeth, because the darkness hath blinded his eyes.

I John 2:19 They went out from us, but they were not of us: for if they had been <transChange>indeed</transChange> of us, they would have continued with us; but <transChange>this was done</transChange> that they might be made manifest, because all, <transChange>that are with us,</transChange> are not <transChange>indeed</transChange> of us.

I John 2:22 Who is a liar, if not he who denieth that Jesus is the Christ? This is the antichrist, that denieth the Father as well as the Son;
I John 2:23 <transChange>for</transChange> whosoever denieth the Son, hath not the Father: <transChange>but he that confesseth the Son acknowledgeth the Father also.</transChange>
I John 2:24 Let that therefore, which ye have heard from the beginning, abide in you: <transChange>for</transChange> if that, which ye heard from the beginning, remain in you, ye also will remain in the Son and in the Father.

I John 2:27 But the unction, which ye have received from Him, abideth in you; and <transChange>therefore</transChange> ye have no need that any should teach you: since this <transChange>very</transChange> unction teacheth you concerning all things, and is truth and not falshood; even as that hath taught you, abide in Him.
I John 2:28 And now, little children, abide, <transChange>I say,</transChange> in Him; that, when He shall appear, we may have confidence, and may not be ashamed before Him at his coming.
